    Whenever a surety bond to indemnify the village is required as a prerequisite to exercising the duties of any office or position, or to the issuance of a license or permit or for the exercise of any special privilege, the surety on such bond shall be a corporation licensed and authorized to do business in the state as a surety company, in the absence of specific provision to the contrary by ordinance. Whenever in its opinion additional sureties or an additional surety may be needed on any bond to indemnify the village against any loss or liability because of the insolvency of the existing surety or sureties or for any other reason, the board of trustees may order a new surety or sureties to be secured on such bond. If such new surety or sureties are not procured within ten (10) days after the time such order is transmitted to the principal on the bond, or his or her assignee, the board shall declare the bond to be void, and such principal or assignee shall be deemed to have surrendered the privilege or position as condition of which the bond was required. 
(Prior code § 4.15) 
2.08.060 - Retirement fund. 
A.  The village shall participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund, effective January 1, 1972. 
B.  The village clerk shall file a certified copy of this section with the board of trustees of the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund. 
(Prior code § 4.16) 
2.08.070 - Access to records. 
A.  In accordance with the requirements of the Freedom of Information Act [5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.], the village president, village clerk and the village manager [5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.] shall, during normal weekday business hours when the municipal building is open, have free access to the examination of all books, papers, vouchers, warrants, entries and accounts of each and every office and position of employment in the village, and all public records of the village. 
B.  Except as otherwise provided by administrative order or ordinance, and in accordance with the requirements of the Freedom of Information Act [ILCS 140/1 et seq.], the public shall have access to examine village public records during normal weekday business hours when the municipal building is open. Copies of village public records shall be made available to the public only upon payment of fees as established in the annual fee ordinance. 
C.  The village clerk shall keep a full record of all proceedings of all meetings of the board of trustees and shall make such records available for public inspection at least forty-eight (48) hours before the next regularly scheduled meeting of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part)) 
2.08.080 - Limitations on hiring of elected officials and relatives of village employees and officials. 
A.  Statement of Purpose. The village desires to continue to maintain a transparent and merit-based employment process that attracts and retains employees who provide the highest level of professional service to village residents. The purpose of this section is to foster integrity and fairness in the village's hiring process by precluding undue influence in village hiring decisions concerning applications for employment by elected officials or relatives of village employees or elected officials. 
B.  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following terms will have the following definitions: 
    "Elected official" means any person who serves or has served at any time in the offices of mayor, trustee, or clerk of the village, whether on an elected or appointed basis. 
    "Party to a civil union" means a person who has established a civil union pursuant to the Illinois Religious Freedom Protection and Civil Union Act, Public Act 96-1513, as it may be amended from time-to-time. 
    "Relative of a village party" shall mean any father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife, father-in-law, mother-in-law, brother-in-law, sister- in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepsister, half-brother, half-sister, grandchild, or grandparent of any village employee or a currently serving elected official. A "relative of a village party" shall also include any person who is a party to a civil union with a village employee or a currently serving elected official, or any person in a co-habitational arrangement with a village employee or a currently serving elected official. 
    "Village employee" shall mean any full-time, part-time, or seasonal employee of the village and not members of any appointed board or commission. 
C.  Limitation on Employment of Elected Officials. No elected official may apply for, be considered for, or be hired for employment with the village, for a period of five years beginning on the last day that the elected official serves in office. This subsection C. shall not preclude an elected official from service as an officer, official, or member of any appointive board or commission. 
D.  Prohibition on Employment of Relatives of a Village Party. 
1.  The village shall not hire or accept any application for employment from any relative of a village party at any time for any reason. 
2.  This subsection D shall not preclude the village from continuing to employ a village employee that becomes the relative of a village party during the course of his or her employment. 
3.  An applicant for employment whose application is rejected pursuant to this subsection D and wishes to present additional factual evidence demonstrating that he or she is not a relative of a village party may submit such additional factual information to the village manager or his designee for review within fifteen (15) days after the rejection of such application. The village manager or his designee will review the additional factual information and notify the applicant by first class mail within thirty (30) days after the village's receipt of the additional information of the village's determination. If the village manager or his designee determines that the additional factual information demonstrates that the applicant is not a relative of a village party, the applicant will be notified that the application for employment may be re-submitted to the village for review. 
(Ord. No. 2011-0-20, § 2, 9-20-2011) 
Chapter 2.12 - VILLAGE MANAGER 
Sections: 

2.12.010 - Appointment-Duties. 
A.  Appointment. The president of the village with the advice and consent of the boards of trustees shall appoint the village manager. 
B.  Qualifications, Powers and Duties. The village manager qualifications, powers and duties shall be in accordance with the Pay and Classification Plan as adopted by the village board. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part): prior code § 4.015) 
Chapter 2.16 - VILLAGE CLERK 
Sections: 

2.16.010 - Election-Term of office. 
    The village clerk shall be elected and serve for a four-year term and until a successor is elected and qualified as is provided by statute. 
(Prior code § 4.02(a)) 
2.16.020 - Oath and bond-Required. 
    The clerk, before entering upon the duties of the office, shall execute a bond in the amount of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) and take the oath of office prescribed by law and conditioned upon the faithful performance of the clerk's duties. 
(Prior code § 4.02(b)) 
2.16.030 - Powers and duties. 
A.  Documents-Sealing and Attesting. The clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the village and licenses, permits and such other documents as shall require this formality. 
B.  Minutes and Notices. The clerk shall attend all meetings of the board of trustees, and shall keep in a suitable book a full and faithful record of its proceedings. The clerk shall issue and cause to be served upon all trustees notices of all special meetings of the board; also notices to the members of the different committees of the board; and to all other persons whose attendance may be required before any such committee when so directed by the chairman thereof. 
C.  Recordkeeping. In addition to the record of ordinances and other records which the clerk is required by statute to keep, the clerk shall keep a register of all licenses and permits issued, a record showing all of the officers and employees of the village, and such other records as may be required by the board of trustees. 
D.  Seal. The clerk shall be the custodian of the village seal and shall fix its impression on documents whenever this is required. 
E.  Delivery of Papers to Officers. The clerk shall, without delay, upon the adjournment of each meeting of the board of trustees, deliver to the committees of the board, and to the officers of the village, all petitions, communications, reports, resolutions, orders, claims and other papers referred to those committees or officers by the village. The clerk shall also, without delay, deliver to the president all ordinances or resolutions in the clerk's charge, which are required to be approved or otherwise acted upon by the president. 
F.  Preparation of Documents. The clerk shall prepare all commissions, licenses, permits and other official documents required to be issued by the clerk under the laws and ordinances of the village and shall attest the same with the corporate seal; and the clerk shall in like manner attest all deeds for the sale or transfer of real estate owned by the village. 
G.  Additional Duties. The village clerk shall have such other duties as may be imposed upon the clerk by law or by the board of trustees. The clerk shall not be ex officio collector. 
(Prior code § 4.02(c)-(i)) 
2.16.040 - Vacancy of office-Successor. 
    In case the office of village clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the president and board of trustees shall appoint a successor as is provided by statute. 
(Prior code § 4.02(j)) 
2.16.050 - Location of office. 
    The clerk's office shall be in the village hall or at such other place as the board of trustees may direct. 
(Prior code § 4.02(k)) 
2.16.060 - Salary. 
    The clerk shall receive such salary as shall be fixed by the board of trustees from time to time subject to the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(Prior code § 4.02(l)) 
2.16.070 - Deputy clerk-Appointment-Powers and duties. 
A.  The village clerk is authorized to appoint one deputy clerk, who (without limitation) shall have the power and duty to execute all documents, papers, receipts, orders, checks and other instruments required by law to be executed by the village clerk, to affix the corporate seal thereto whenever required, and to make such records and perform any and all duties and functions performable by the village clerk. Any such appointment may be revoked at any time and a new appointment may thereafter be made if desired. Any such appointment, however, shall run concurrently with the village clerk's term of office unless sooner terminated. An original of the instrument making an appointment of a deputy by the village clerk shall be filed and shall remain on file in the office of the village clerk. Any person accepting an appointment as deputy of the village clerk under this section shall take and subscribe the same oath or affirmation as is required of village officers and such oath or affirmation shall be filed and remain on file in the office of the village clerk. 
B.  In signing any documents, the deputy clerk shall sign his or her name and the words "deputy clerk." 
C.  The powers and duties of the deputy clerk described in this section shall be exercised only in the absence of the clerk from the place where the clerk's office is maintained, and only when either written direction has been given by the clerk to such deputy clerk to exercise such power, or the corporate authorities have determined by resolution that the clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform such function. 
D.  When duly authorized as provided in this section for the signature affixed by such deputy in the manner prescribed in this section on any document, including, but not limited to contracts, bonds, or other obligations of the village, such document shall have the same effect as if the documents so executed had been signed by the clerk in person. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 4.02(m)) 
Chapter 2.24 - VILLAGE TREASURER 
Sections: 

2.24.010 - Appointment. 
    There is created the office of village treasurer, who shall be appointed by the president and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees as is provided by statute. The treasurer shall serve for the ensuing fiscal year. 
(Prior code § 4.04(a)) 
2.24.020 - Oath and bond. 
    The treasurer, before entering upon the duties of the office, shall take the oath prescribed by law and shall give a bond in the sum required by the board of trustees, but such amount shall not be less than that required by statute. This bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance by the treasurer of his or her duties, and shall be conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty or any act of the treasurer. 
(Prior code § 4.04(b)) 
2.24.030 - General duties. 
    The treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for the office by statute or ordinance. The treasurer shall receive all moneys paid to the village either directly from the person paying the moneys or from the hands of some other officer or employee as may receive it, and shall pay out moneys only on vouchers or orders properly signed by the president and clerk or other individuals authorized by the board of trustees. 
(Prior code § 4.04(c)) 
2.24.040 - Deposit of funds. 
    The treasurer shall deposit the funds of the village in such depositories as may be selected from time to time as is provided by law. The treasurer shall keep the deposit of the village money separate and distinct from the treasurer's own money, and shall not make private or personal use of any village money. 
(Prior code § 4.04(d)) 
2.24.050 - Records. 
    The treasurer shall keep the records showing all money received by the treasurer, showing the source from which it is received and the purpose for which it is paid, and the treasurer shall keep records at all times showing the financial status of the village. 
(Prior code § 4.04(e)) 
2.24.060 - Accounting. 
    The treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance, and the treasurer shall keep them in the manner required by the board of trustees. 
(Prior code § 4.04(f)) 
2.24.070 - Special assessments-Held as special fund. 
    All money received by the treasurer as a special tax or assessment shall be held as a special fund, to be applied to the payment of the improvement for which such special tax or special assessment was made, and the money so received shall be used for no other purpose except to reimburse the village for money expended for such improvement. (ref. IMC 3-10-6.) 
(Prior code § 4.04(g)) 
2.24.080 - Separation of funds. 
A.  The treasurer shall keep all moneys belonging to the village separate and distinct at all times from personal moneys or funds, and the treasurer is prohibited from using directly or indirectly the village moneys or warrants in the treasurer's custody and keeping for personal use or benefit, or that of any other person. 
B.  Any violation of this section shall subject the treasurer to immediate removal from office by the president and board of trustees, who may declare the office vacant and appoint a successor for the unexpired portion of term in manner prescribed for regular appointment. (ref. IMC 3-10-4.) 
(Prior code § 4.04(h)) 
2.24.090 - Reports of receipts and expenditures; approval of expenditures. 
A.  The treasurer shall prepare for the president and board of trustees, as often as required, a full and detailed report of all receipts and expenditures of the corporation, as shown by the books of the treasurer's office, up to the time of the report. The treasurer shall each year prepare and file with the clerk a full and detailed report of all receipts and expenditures of all accounts of the office during the preceding fiscal year. The report shall reflect the state of the treasury at the close of the fiscal year. The clerk shall keep the report on file in his or her office for the inspection of the general public. 
B.  The approval of the president and board of trustees of the report of receipts and expenditures described in subsection A of this section at a regular or special meeting of the board of trustees shall constitute approval of each expenditure included on the report, provided, however, that the board of trustees may, in its sole discretion, except specific expenditures from such approval, in which case such expenditures shall not be made. 
C.  In the event that the regularly scheduled meeting of the board of trustees is cancelled, the treasurer may submit the report of receipts and expenditures to the president and individual members of the board of trustees for comment. The treasurer shall be authorized to make the expenditures included on such report provided that: 
1.  At least seven days have passed since the date the report was submitted to the board of trustees; 
2.  No expenditure shall be made that has been specifically excepted from approval by any one or more members of the board of trustees. 
    All expenditures made pursuant to this subsection shall be subject to the subsequent ratification at the next meeting of the board of trustees. Any expenditure that is specifically excepted from approval under this subsection shall be held for consideration until the next meeting of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. 2004-0-24 § 2: prior code § 4.04(i)) 
2.24.100 - Delinquent officers. 
    The treasurer shall report to the president and board of trustees any officer authorized to receive moneys for the use of the village who fails to make a return of the moneys received by him or her at the time required by law or ordinance. 
(Prior code § 4.04(j)) 
2.24.110 - Bookkeeping-Open to examination. 
    The treasurer shall keep the books and accounts in such manner as to show with accuracy all moneys received and disbursed by him or her for the village, stating from whom and on what account received, and to whom and what account paid out, and in such way that the books and accounts may be readily investigated and understood. Such books and accounts and all files and papers of the treasurer's office shall be at all times open to examination by the president or a trustee. 
(Prior code § 4.04(k)) 
2.24.120 - Deputy treasurer-Appointment-Powers and duties. 
A.  The village treasurer is authorized to appoint one deputy treasurer who (without limitation) shall have the power and duty to execute all documents, papers, receipts, orders, checks and other instruments required by any law to be executed by the treasurer and to make such records and perform any and all duties and functions performable by the treasurer. Any such appointment may be revoked at any time and a new appointment may thereafter be made if desired. Any such appointment, however, shall run concurrently with the treasurer's term of office unless sooner terminated. An original of the instrument making an appointment of a deputy by the treasurer shall be filed and shall remain on file in the office of the village clerk. Any person accepting an appointment as deputy of the treasurer under this section shall take and subscribe the same oath or affirmation as is required of village officers and such oath or affirmation shall be filed and remain on file in the office of the village clerk. 
B.  In signing any documents the deputy treasurer shall sign the name of the treasurer with the word "by" and the deputy treasurer's own name and the words "deputy treasurer." 
C.  The powers and duties of the deputy treasurer described in this section shall be exercised only in the absence of the treasurer from the place where the treasurer's office is maintained, and only when either written direction has been given by the treasurer to the deputy treasurer to exercise such power, or the corporate authorities have determined by resolution that the treasurer is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform such function. 
D.  When duly authorized as provided in this section for the signature affixed by any such deputy in the manner prescribed by this section on any document, including, but not limited to contracts, bonds, checks or other obligations of the village, the document shall have the same effect as if the documents so executed had been signed by the treasurer in person. 
(Prior code § 4.04(l)) 
Chapter 2.28 - SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS 
Sections: 

2.28.010 - Appointment. 
    The president of the village with the advice and consent of the board of trustees shall appoint the director of public works. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part): prior code § 4.06(a)) 
2.28.020 - Qualifications, powers and duties. 
    The superintendent qualifications, powers and duties shall be in accordance with the Pay and Classification Plan as adopted by the village board. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part): prior code § 4.06(b)-(f)) 
Chapter 2.32 - BUILDING COMMISSIONER 
Sections: 

2.32.010 - Building commissioner-Appointment-Qualifications, powers and duties. 
A.  Appointment. The president of the village with the advice and consent of the board of trustees shall appoint the building commissioner. 
B.  Qualifications, Powers and Duties. The building commissioner qualifications, powers and duties shall be in accordance with the Pay and Classification Plan as adopted by the village board. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part): prior code § 4.07) 
Chapter 2.40 - POLICE DEPARTMENT 
Sections: 

2.40.010 - Department created. 
    There is created and established an executive department of the village, to be known as the police department. 
(Prior code § 5.01) 
2.40.020 - Chief of police-Appointment. 
    The president of the village with the advice and consent of the board of trustees shall appoint the chief of police. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part): prior code § 5.02) 
2.40.030 - Chief of police-Qualifications, powers and duties. 
    The chief of police shall be the head of the police department and shall have supervision over all officers and members thereof. His or her qualifications, power and duties shall be in accordance with the Pay and Classification Plan as adopted by the village board and the rules and regulations adopted by the board of police commissioners. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part): prior code § 5.03) 
2.40.031 - Deputy chief of police-Qualifications, powers and duties. 
A.  One (1) assignment of deputy chief of police is hereby created pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-4. 
B.  The chief of police shall appoint a qualified sworn officer of the department to the assignment of deputy chief of police from time to time in his or her discretion in accordance with the standards and procedures set for in 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-4 and after consultation with the village manager. The deputy chief of police shall serve at the discretion of the chief of police. 
C.  The deputy chief of police shall, the absence of the chief of police, perform all duties usually performed by the chief of police. The deputy chief of police shall be subordinate to the chief of police and shall perform such duties as may be assigned by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2015-0-11, § 2, 6-2-2015) 
2.40.040 - Sergeant of police-Powers and duties. 
    The sergeant of police shall, in the absence of the chief of police and the deputy chief of police, perform all duties usually performed by the chief of police. The sergeant shall be subordinate to the chief of police and the deputy chief of police and shall perform such duties as may be assigned by the chief of police and deputy chief of police. Notwithstanding anything in this provision to the contrary, the chief of police may, by duty assignment, designate from time to time one (1) or more sergeants as commanders for purposes of establishing a chain of command and exercising supervisory responsibilities as determined by the chief of police. 
(Prior code § 5.04) 
(Ord. No. 2015-0-11, § 3, 6-2-2015) 
2.40.050 - Police department-Duties assigned by chief of police. 
    Other members of the police department shall perform such duties as may be assigned to them by the chief of police, in accordance with the rules and regulations of the board of police commissioners and under the supervision of the chief of police. It shall be the duty of every member to conduct himself or herself in a proper and lawful manner, at all times, and to avoid the use of unnecessary force. 
(Prior code § 5.05) 
2.40.060 - Duties of police department-Generally. 
A.  Enforcement of Laws. The police department shall be charged with the enforcement of all ordinances and laws in full force and effect in the village, and with the prevention of crimes and offenses and the apprehension of law violators. Every member of the police department is declared to be a conservator of the peace and shall have the powers granted by law to such conservators of the peace. 
B.  Warrants. All warrants for the violation of any ordinance of the village or the state criminal law, to whomever directed, may be served and executed within the limits of the village by any member of the police department. For this purpose members of the police department shall have the common-law statutory powers of constables. 
C.  Conduct of Members. It shall be the duty of members of the police department to conduct themselves in a proper and law abiding manner, and to avoid the use of any unnecessary force. 
(Prior code § 5.06) 
2.40.070 - Police officers-Residency requirements. 
A.  Findings and Determinations. It is found and determined: 
1.  In accordance with 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-6, the corporate authorities of the village are authorized and empowered to adopt ordinances which allow police officers to reside outside the corporate limits of the village, both at the time of appointment and while serving as such police officers; and 
2.  It is in the best interests of the village to allow police officers to reside outside the corporate limits of the village, but within certain defined boundaries in order to insure that an adequate force of police officers will at all times be conveniently available to fulfill their municipal responsibilities. 
B.  Boundaries Designated. Police officers of the village are authorized to reside outside of the corporate limits of the village, both at the time of appointment and while serving as such police officers provided they reside within the territorial limits of the state of Illinois, it being further determined that policemen residing within the territory described in this subsection or any collective bargaining agreements between the village and the police officers' designated union are located within sufficient proximity to the village that they are reasonably available for any official duties or emergency services which may be required of them. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 5.07) 
2.40.080 - Part-time police officers. 
A.  Employment. The Village of Grayslake may employ part-time police officers from time to time as they are deemed necessary by the board of trustees. Persons employed as part-time police officers shall be selected by the chief of police in accordance with this section; they shall not receive a certificate of appointment (as provided in 65 ILCS 5/10- 2.1-1 et seq.), but shall be sworn officers of the village. 
B.  Duties. A part-time police officer shall have all the responsibilities of a full-time police officer and such specific duties as delineated in the general orders of the Grayslake Police Department, but the number of hours a part-time officer may work within a calendar year is restricted to not more than one thousand (1,000) hours per year. Part-time police officers shall not be assigned to supervise or direct full-time police officers. Part-time police officers shall be trained in accordance with the Illinois Police Training Act (50 ILCS 705/1 et. seq.) and the requirements of 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-21 (including the applicable standards established by the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards Board). 
C.  Hiring Standards. In selecting any person to be employed as a part-time police officer, such person must be found to meet the following standards: 
1.  Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of sound health, and physically and mentally able to perform assigned duties. 
2.  Be at least twenty-one (21) years of age. 
3.  Pass a village medical examination. 
4.  Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate. 
5.  Possess a valid driver's license. 
6.  Possess no prior felony convictions. 
7.  Any individual who has served in the U.S. military must have been honorably discharged. 
D.  Discipline. Part-time officers shall be under the disciplinary jurisdiction of the chief of police. Part-time police officers serve at the discretion of the chief of police, shall not have any property rights in said employment, and may be removed by the chief of police at any time with or without cause and without prior hearing. Part-time police officers shall comply with all applicable rules and general orders issued by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2012-0-17, § 2, 6-5-2012) 
Chapter 2.44 - POLICE PENSION FUND 
Sections: 

2.44.010 - Fund-Established. 
    There is established a police pension fund in the village, as required by law. 
(Prior code § 5.10(a)) 
2.44.020 - Board of trustees-Membership-Elections-Meetings. 
A.  Membership. The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall consist of five members. The members of the board of trustees shall be selected as provided for by law, for the respective terms provided by law as follows: two of the members of the board shall be appointed by the president of the board of trustees of the village. One of the members so appointed shall serve for the period of one year beginning on the second Tuesday in May after the village came, by virtue of having obtained the necessary population, within the provisions of the law, and one of the members shall serve for a period of two years, beginning on the same date. The successors to each of the foregoing trustees shall serve for a period of two years each, or until such time as their successors are appointed and qualified. The third and fourth members of the board of trustees of the pension fund shall be elected from the regular police force by the active members of the force. The fifth member shall be elected by and from among the beneficiaries of the fund as soon as there are such beneficiaries. The members to be elected shall be elected by ballot for a term of two years, beginning on the second Tuesday of the first May after the election, at a regular election, at which election all members of the regular police force shall be entitled to vote for the police force members of the board and all beneficiaries of lawful age shall be entitled to vote for the members chosen from among the beneficiaries. 
B.  The election provided for in this section shall be held biennially on the third Monday in April, under the Australian ballot system, at such place or places in the village, under such regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed members of the board. In the event of the death, resignation or inability to act of any member of the board, elected under the provisions of this section, the successor of such member shall be elected for the unexpired term at a special election, which shall be called by the board and shall be conducted in the manner as are the regular elections provided for in this section. 
C.  Meetings. Suitable rooms for offices and meetings of the board shall be assigned by the president or board of trustees of the village. The board of trustees of the pension fund, which shall be known as the board of trustees of the police pension fund of the village of Grayslake, Lake County, Illinois, shall meet at least quarterly on the second Tuesday of July, October, January and April annually, as provided by law, and shall hold such additional meetings as may be called by the president of the board. 
(Prior code § 5.10(b)) 
2.44.030 - Board of trustees-Powers and duties. 
    The board of trustees of the pension fund shall have control of the management of all funds belonging to, or designated by law or ordinance as a part of, the police pension fund and of the administration of the fund, as provided by statute and/or ordinance. 
(Prior code § 5.10(d)) 
2.44.040 - Revenue to be deposited in the fund. 
    There shall be deposited in the pension fund the sums required by law, which presently include the appropriate percentage, to be determined annually, deducted per month from the salary of each member of the police force, the proceeds of an annual tax to be levied in such amount as is required by Section 3-125 of Article 3 of the Illinois Pension Code as amended, and such other funds as provided for by Section 3-125. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part): prior code § 5.10(c)) 
2.44.050 - Part of Illinois Pension Code controlling. 
    Reference is made to Article 3 of the Illinois Pension Code as amended (Illinois Revised Statutes, Chanter 108 1/2, Article 3) for such details and matters as are not set forth in this chapter. In case of any conflict, if any, the applicable provisions of the Code shall control, and as the Code is amended from time to time, the provisions of this chapter, insofar as any variance may develop, shall automatically be amended so as to conform with the Illinois Pension Code. 
(Prior code § 5.10(e)) 
Chapter 2.46 - ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES TO DETERMINE ELIGIBILITY UNDER THE PUBLIC SAFETY EMPLOYEE BENEFITS ACT 

2.46.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide a fair and efficient method of determining the eligibility of an employee for the benefits enumerated under the Public Safety Employee Benefits Act ("PSEBA" or the "Act") through an administrative process, including if necessary, an administrative or evidentiary hearing. All benefits provided employees pursuant to PSEBA will be consistent with PSEBA. 
(Ord. No. 2017-0-28, § 2(Exh. A), 9-5-2017) 
2.46.020 - Application procedure. 
A.  Public safety employees or family members of an injured or deceased public safety officer in the event the employee is not capable of taking this action ("applicant") must file with the village manager a full and complete PSEBA application as described in more detail in this Section 2.46.020, in writing, within thirty (30) calendar days of filing a pension claim, or within thirty (30) calendar days of the date of the adoption of this chapter in the event that an applicant has filed for a pension claim prior to the date of the adoption of this ordinance, whichever is later, if the applicant is seeking benefits under PSEBA. Failure to timely file the full and complete application with the village manager shall result in a forfeiture of the benefits under PSEBA. Upon request, the village shall furnish a Public Safety Employee Benefit Act application (the "application form") to the applicant. 
B.  Any applicant seeking benefits under the Act shall complete the application form provided by the village, and shall, pursuant to the Act, include the applicant's or family member's firsthand knowledge explaining how the disability injury/death directly resulted from the public safety employee's: 
1.  Response to fresh pursuit; 
2.  Response to what is reasonably believed to be an emergency; 
3.  Response to an unlawful act perpetrated by another; or 
4.  Participation during the investigation of a criminal act. 
C.  The application form must be sworn and notarized to certify the truthfulness of the content of the information contained in the application form and the additional information required for a completed application, including without limitation a signed PSEBA medical authorization release, and a signed PSEBA general information release. Both the PSEBA medical and PSEBA general information releases authorize the collection of information related to the incident including, but not limited to, the disability pension proceedings, worker's compensation records and medical records. A review of the application will not occur until all elements of the application are complete, including the medical releases. 
D.  The complete application must include the name of public safety employee, date of hire, detailed information regarding the incident, (including date, time, place, nature of injury, any other factual circumstances surrounding said incident giving rise to said claim), witnesses to the incident, witnesses the applicant intends to call at the PSEBA hearing, information and supporting pension documentation filed with the police pension board and any police pension board determination or ruling, information supporting the PSEBA eligibility requirements, a signed PSEBA medical authorization release, a PSEBA general information release authorizing the collection of information as set forth in Section 2.46.020.C above, and if applicable, other sources of health insurance benefits currently enrolled in or received by the employee and/or family members if the employee is deceased. 
E.  The PSEBA medical information release must specify name and address information for pertinent health care provider(s) and hospital(s), along with employee's and/or his/her authorized representative's signature and witness signature. 
F.  The PSEBA general information release must specify name and signature of employee or his/her authorized representative along with legal proof of said representation along with name and signature of witness authorizing the collection of information pertinent to the incident review process. 
G.  On the date that the village receives a complete application, which will include a completed application form, PSEBA medical release, PSEBA general information release, and all other supplemental information supporting the application, the village shall issue the applicant a receipt, and the application shall then be submitted to the village manager, as the preliminary administrative record; a copy of the same shall be date stamped and provided to the applicant. 
H.  Upon receipt of a complete application for PSEBA benefits timely filed, the village manager shall review the application and supporting documents to make a determination (subject to final approval of the board of trustees) as follows: 
1.  Grant benefits based upon the facts on the application as it stands; 
2.  Set matter for a final administrative hearing before a hearing officer to make a determination based on the result of an administrative hearing; 
3.  Set matter for an evidentiary hearing before a hearing officer to make a recommendation to the board of trustees based on the result of an evidentiary hearing. Following receipt of the recommendation of the hearing officer, the board of trustees shall render a determination rewarding the applicant's eligibility for benefits under PSEBA; 
4.  Enter such other finding as is consistent with the evidence or by agreement of the applicant and the village. 
I.  If the board of trustees grants the benefit based on the preliminary record as it stands, the applicant will be contacted by the village within thirty (30) days of the decision. The applicant will be required to contact the finance director for benefit explanation and processing. 
J.  If the board of trustees determines the matter requires a final administrative or evidentiary hearing, the applicant will be given written notice of such decision along with a date for the scheduled hearing. 
K.  If the applicant, upon receiving written notice of the date for a final administrative hearing or an evidentiary hearing, cannot attend said date as indicated in the notice of such hearing, the applicant must contact the hearing officer within seven (7) days after being served with notice of the hearing, communicating alternative hearing date(s) which are within close proximity of the original date indicated by the hearing officer. Failure to appear may result in denial of benefits. 
L.  If the board of trustees denies the benefit based on the preliminary record as it stands, the applicant will receive written notice of such denial and the applicant shall have the right to request an evidentiary hearing which must be served in writing to the village manager not later than thirty (30) calendar days after being served with written notice of the denial. Upon receipt of a timely notice from the applicant, the village manager shall schedule the evidentiary hearing and serve the applicant with notice of such hearing. 
M.  If the applicant, upon receiving written notice of denial, chooses not to request an evidentiary hearing, the applicant will be required to contact the finance director to discuss other options in which the applicant may be eligible to participate. 
(Ord. No. 2017-0-28, § 2(Exh. A), 9-5-2017) 
2.46.030 - Administrative composition. 
    A final administrative hearing or an evidentiary hearing under this Chapter 2.46 shall be scheduled, which hearing shall be comprised of a hearing officer whose power and authority and limitations are as follows: 
A.  Power of the hearing officer. The hearing officer shall have all of the powers granted to him or her under common law relative to the conduct of a final administrative hearing or an evidentiary hearing, including the power to: 
1.  Preside over all village hearings involving PSEBA; 
2.  Administer oaths; 
3.  Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the issue of eligibility under PSEBA; 
4.  Issue subpoenas to secure attendance of witnesses and the production of relevant papers or documents upon the request of the parties or their representatives; 
5.  Rule upon objections in the admissibility of evidence; 
6.  Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits in evidence introduced at the hearing; 
7.  Issue a determination (in the case of a final administrative hearing) or a recommendation (in the event of an evidentiary hearing) based on the evidence presented at the hearing, which determination or recommendation shall be in writing and shall include either a written finding of fact, decision and order or a recommended finding of fact, decision and order. 
B.  Hearing officer. The mayor with the consent of the board of trustees is hereby authorized to appoint a person to hold the position of a hearing officer for each and every individual hearing that shall come before this village. In making said selection, the mayor shall consider all pertinent information including, at a minimum: 
1.  The candidate's ability to comply with the job description as set forth herein; 
2.  Background and performance data made available to the mayor on file with the village or otherwise obtained by the village; 
3.  The candidate must be an attorney licensed to practice law in the State of Illinois for at least three (3) years and have knowledge of and experience in employment and labor law, general civil procedure, the rules of evidence, and administrative practice. 
(Ord. No. 2017-0-28, § 2(Exh. A), 9-5-2017) 
2.46.040 - Procedure. 
    An administrative or evidentiary hearing shall be initiated either by the board of trustees or by an applicant as described in more detail in Section 2.46.020, but only after the submission of a full and complete PSEBA application. 
(Ord. No. 2017-0-28, § 2(Exh. A), 9-5-2017) 
2.46.050 - Administrative and evidentiary hearings. 
    A final administrative hearing shall be held to adjudicate and determine whether the applicant is eligible for benefits under PSEBA. An evidentiary hearing shall be held to ascertain facts and formulate a recommendation whether the applicant is eligible for benefits under PSEBA. If the applicant is ultimately found eligible, the benefits shall be consistent with the Act. 
A.  Time and date. Hearings shall be held on the date, time and place as established by the village with appropriate notice served upon the applicant. 
B.  Record. The applicant, at applicant's expense, shall ensure that all hearings shall be attended by a certified court reporter and a transcript of all proceedings shall be made by said certified court reporter and a copy be provided to the village at applicant's expense within fourteen (14) days of the date of the hearing. 
C.  Procedures. The village and the applicant shall be entitled to representation by counsel at said hearing and may present witnesses, may present testimony and documents, may cross-examine opposing witnesses, and may request the issuance of subpoenas to compel the appearance of relevant witnesses or the production of relevant documents. Each party shall bear the costs of its own counsel and witnesses. 
D.  Evidence. The rules of evidence as set forth in the Illinois Code of Evidence shall apply. 
E.  Final determination; recommendation. 
1.  For each final administrative hearing, the determination by the hearing officer of whether the petitioning applicant is eligible for the benefits under the Public Safety Employee Benefits Act (820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.) shall constitute a final administrative determination for the purpose of judicial review under the common law writ of certiorari. 
2.  For each evidentiary hearing, the determination of the board of trustees (after receiving the recommendation of the hearing officer) of whether the petitioning applicant is eligible for the benefits under the Public Safety Employee Benefits Act (820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.) shall constitute a final administrative determination for the purpose of judicial review under the common law writ of certiorari. 
F.  Burden of proof. At any hearing under this Chapter 2.46, the applicant shall have the obligation and burden of proof to establish that the applicant is qualified to receive the benefits. 
G.  Administrative records. All records pertaining to the administrative process will be held in a separate file in the employee's name within the management services department of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2017-0-28, § 2(Exh. A), 9-5-2017) 
Chapter 2.48 - PLAN COMMISSION/ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- 2013-0-11, § 2, adopted Feb. 19, 2013, amended in its entirety the former Ch. 2.48, §§ 2.48.010, 2.48.020, and enacted a new Ch. 2.48 as set out herein. The former Ch. 2.48 pertained to the plan commission and derived from the prior code § 21.02, and Ord. 2009-0-03, § 2. 

2.48.010 - Plan Commission/zoning board of appeals-Created-Membership. 
A.  There is created a plan commission/zoning board of appeals. 
B.  The plan commission/zoning board of appeals shall consist of seven members. The village president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint a chairperson of the plan commission/zoning board of appeals. 
C.  The members serving on the plan commission/zoning board of appeals as of September 4, 2012 shall continue to serve until the expiration of their appointed terms and their respective successors are duly appointed. The term of each successor member (or successive term of a current member) shall be for a period of five years. The village president shall have the power to remove any member, for cause, after a public hearing. Vacancies on the commission/board shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose place became vacant in the manner provided in this section for appointment of such member. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-11, § 2, 2-19-2013) 
2.48.020 - Plan commission/zoning board of appeals-Powers and duties. 
    The plan commission/zoning board of appeals shall have the following duties: 
A.  To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees a comprehensive plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of the village. Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts each of which, when adopted, shall be the comprehensive plan, or part thereof, of the Village with reference to streets, alleys, public grounds, and other improvements hereinafter specified. The plan, as recommended by the plan commission/zoning board of appeals and adopted by the village, may be applicable, by the terms thereof, to land situated within the corporate limits and contiguous territory not more than one and one-half miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in any municipality. Such plan may be implemented by ordinances (1) establishing reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and for re-subdivisions of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment in respect to public improvements as herein defined; (2) establishing reasonable requirements governing the location, width, course and surfacing of public streets and highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, street lights, parks, playgrounds, school grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes, storm water drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers, sewage collection and treatment; and (3) may designate land suitable for annexation to the village and the recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation. 
B.  To recommend changes from time to time, in the official comprehensive plan. 
C.  To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities, from time to time, plans for specific improvements in pursuance of the comprehensive plan. 
D.  To give assistance to the village officials charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced with the official plan, to further the making of these projects, and generally promote the realization of the comprehensive plan. 
E.  To interpret the meaning of the zoning ordinance in cases of ambiguity, and to make ruling with respect to application of the zoning ordinance, including appeals from decisions of the building department. 
F.  To recommend to the board of trustees that variations be granted from the provisions of the zoning ordinance with respect to particular cases involving practical difficulties or particular hardship in carrying out the strict letter of the zoning regulations. 
G.  To hold public hearings on requests for special use permits, including for planned unit developments and amendments to the zoning ordinance, and make findings of fact and recommendations to the village board. 
H.  Study and report on all proposed amendments to the zoning ordinance; review the zoning ordinance periodically, and suggest amendments. 
I.  Any other duties or functions of the plan commission and zoning board of appeals as included in the ordinances of the village or as directed by the mayor and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-11, § 2, 2-19-2013) 
Chapter 2.52 - ELECTRICAL COMMISSION 
Sections: 

2.52.010 - Electrical commission. 
A.  Established-Membership. There is established an electrical commission which shall consist of six members as follows: The chief electrical inspector (which office is created for the village) shall be a member and the ex officio chairman of the commission; of the other five members, one shall be a registered professional engineer, one an electrical contractor, one a journeyman electrician, one a representative of an inspection bureau maintained by the fire underwriters, if such a representative resides in the village, and if no such representative resides in the village, the chief of the fire district, and one representative of an electricity supply company. If there is no such person residing in the village who is qualified under any one of the descriptions, the village president may appoint some other person to fill that position. All members of the electrical commission shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. Such members shall be appointed for one year commencing on August 1st of each year and expiring on July 31st of the following year; provided, however, that each member shall continue to serve until his or her successor is duly appointed and qualified, and provided also that the first members appointed shall only be for a period expiring on July 31st immediately following the date or dates of their appointment. In case of vacancy, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term. 
B.  Functions. The electrical commission shall recommend safe and practical standards and specifications for the installation, alteration and use of electrical equipment designed to meet the necessities and conditions that prevail in the village, shall recommend reasonable rules and regulations governing the issuance of permits by the electrical inspection department, and shall recommend reasonable fees to be paid for the inspection by the inspection department of all electrical equipment installed or altered within the village; provided that such standards and rules and regulations shall not be effective unless and until the same have been adopted by ordinance. 
C.  Permits. Upon the adoption by ordinance of such standards, specifications, rules and regulations, the same shall at once become operative, and no electrical equipment shall be installed or altered except upon a permit first being issued. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 4.10) 
Chapter 2.56 - BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS 
Sections: 

2.56.010 - Created-Terms of office. 
    There is created a board of police commissioners, consisting of three members, whose terms of office shall be three years and until their respective successors are appointed and have qualified. A vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term of a member whose place is or becomes vacant in the same manner as the original appointment. 
(Prior code § 4.20(a)) 
2.56.015 - Terms of office-Dates. 
    All terms for members of the police commission shall begin on August 1 of each calendar year. The terms for all members of each of these bodies serving on September 7, 1999 shall end on August 1 of the year in which their current term expires. 
(Ord. 99-0-30 § 1 (part)) 
2.56.020 - Appointment of members-Qualifications-Removal from office. 
A.  Appointment of Board. The members of the board of police commissioners shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
B.  Qualifications and Disqualifications. No person holding an office under a municipality shall be a member of the board of police commissioners of the village or the secretary of the board. The acceptance of any such office by a member of the board shall be treated as a resignation of his or her office as a member of the board or the secretary of the board. No person shall be appointed a member of the board of police commissioners who is related, either by blood or marriage up to the degree of first cousin, to any elected official of the village. No more than two members of the board shall belong to the same political party existing in the village at the time of such appointments and as defined in 10 ILCS 5/10-2. If only one or no political party exists in the village at the time of such appointments, then state or national political party affiliations shall be considered in making such appointments. Party affiliation shall be determined by affidavit of the person appointed as a member of the board. 
C.  Removal from Office. A member of the board shall not be subject to removal, except for cause, upon written charges, and after an opportunity to be heard within thirty (30) days in his or her own defense, before a regular meeting of the board of trustees of the village. A majority vote of the elected members of the board of trustees shall be required to remove such member from office. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 4.20(b), (d)) 
2.56.030 - Oath and bond-Required. 
    Each member of the board shall, before entering upon his or her official duties, take the oath required of other officers of the municipality by 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25, and shall give a fidelity bond as required under that section in a penal sum to be approved by the board of trustees. 
(Prior code § 4.20(c)) 
2.56.040 - Power of appointment to police department. 
    The board of police commissioners shall appoint all officers and members of the police department of the village, except the chief of police, and excepting that the board of police commissioners shall not appoint auxiliary police officers; ex officio members of the police department or special police and employees conferred with police powers nor any other personnel of any kind that are not full-time police officers of the village police department. The chief of police and all personnel not appointable by the board of police commissioners shall be appointed by the president of the village, by and with the consent of the board of trustees of the village, or otherwise as provided by ordinance. Such powers of appointment by the board of police commissioners shall be subject to the provisions of Division 2.1 of Article 10 of the Illinois Municipal Code, and the board shall have such powers of removal and other powers within its jurisdiction as are provided for under that division. 
(Prior code § 4.20(e)) 
2.56.050 - Power of appointments and removals. 
    The board shall make rules: (1) to carry out the purpose of Division 2. 1 of Article 10 of the Illinois Municipal Code, and (2) for appointments and removals in accordance with the provisions of that Division. The board, from time to time, may make changes in the rules. The rules shall be printed as provided in Section 10-2.1-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code, and the other provisions of the section applying to rules shall be followed. 
(Prior code § 4.20(f)) 
2.56.060 - Annual report and budget. 
    Annually, at any time the corporate authorities may provide, the board of police commissioners shall submit to the president of the village a report of its activities, and of the rules in force and the practical effect thereof. In this report the board may make suggestions which the board believes would result in greater efficiency in the police department. The board shall also submit an annual budget request to the municipal governing body prior to the end of each fiscal year. The president of the village shall transmit the report to the board of trustees. 
(Prior code § 4.20(g)) 
2.56.070 - Portion of the Illinois Municipal Code controlling. 
    Reference is made to Division 2. 1 of Article 10 of the Illinois Municipal Code as amended (see 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1 et seq.) for such other details and matters as are not set forth in this chapter, and the board of police commissioners shall fully consider all of those provisions in performing its functions under this chapter. In case of any conflict, the applicable provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code shall control, and as the Code is amended from time to time, the provisions of this chapter, insofar as any variance from the Code may develop, shall automatically be amended so as to conform with the Illinois Municipal code. 
(Prior code § 4.20(h)) 
Chapter 2.60 - BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS 
Sections: 

2.60.010 - Established-Powers and duties. 
    There is established the board of local improvements for the village, which shall consist of the president and all of the members of the board of trustees. The board of local improvements shall have the powers and perform the duties assigned to it by statute or ordinance. 
(Prior code § 4.17) 
Chapter 2.64 - PLAN COMMISSION/ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS 
Sections: 

2.64.010 - Established-Membership. 
    A plan commission/zoning board of appeals is established. The board shall consist of seven members appointed by the president and confirmed by the board of trustees. The original members of the board of appeals shall serve respectively for the following terms: one for one year, one for two years; one for three years; one for four years; one for five years; one for six years and one for seven years; the successor to each member so appointed to serve for a term of five years. One of the members so appointed shall be named as chairman at the time of appointment and shall hold office as chairman until a successor is appointed and qualified. The village president shall have the power to remove any member of the Board of appeals for cause, after a public hearing. Vacancies upon the board of appeals shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose place has become vacant in the manner provided in this section for the appointment of such member. 
(Prior code § 4.21(a)) 
2.64.015 - Terms of office-Dates. 
    All terms for members of the plan commission/zoning board of appeals shall begin on August 1 of each calendar year. The terms for all members of each of these bodies serving on September 7, 1999 shall end on August 1 of the year in which their current term expires. 
(Ord. 99-0-30 § 1 (part)) 
2.64.020 - Meetings. 
    All meetings of the plan commission/zoning board of appeals shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the board may determine. The chairperson, or in his or her absence the acting chairperson, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All meetings of the board of appeals shall be open to the public. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon every question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating that fact, and shall also keep records of its examinations and other official acts. Every rule, regulation, every amendment or repeal thereof and every order, requirement, decision or determination of the board shall immediately be filed in the office of the board and shall be a public record. 
(Prior code § 4.21(b)) 
2.64.030 - Jurisdiction. 
A.  The plan commission/zoning board of appeals shall hear and decide appeals from and review any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the building commissioner pursuant to this section. It shall also fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal and give due notice thereof to the parties and decide the same within a reasonable time. The board may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify or amend the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from to the extent and in the manner that the board may decide to be fitting and proper in the premises, and to that end the board shall also have the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken. 
B.  The board shall also decide all matters referred to it upon which it is required to pass under the zoning regulations of the village. 
(Prior code § 4.21(c)) 
2.64.040 - Voting. 
    The concurring vote of four members of the plan commission/zoning board of appeals is necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination of the building commissioner, or to decide in favor of the applicant any matters upon which it is required to pass under this section, or to recommend any variation or modification in the zoning regulations to the president and board of trustees. 
(Prior code § 4.21(d)) 
2.64.050 - Zoning regulation variances. 
    The plan commission/zoning board of appeals may recommend to the president and board of trustees a variance to the application of any of the provisions or regulations of the zoning regulations relating to the use, construction or alteration of buildings or structures or the use of land, but only after holding a duly advertised public hearing on the proposed variation and complying with the other provisions of the Illinois Revised Statutes relating to zoning, it being expressly provided that the power to determine and approve variances is hereby reserved to the corporate authorities of the village, that such power shall only be exercised by the adoption of ordinances and that no such variation shall be made by the corporate authorities without a hearing before the plan commission/zoning board of appeals. 
(Prior code § 4.21(e)) 
2.64.060 - Petition fees. 
    There are established in Chapter 3.08 of this code, fees for the filing of a petition or a request with the board of trustees or plan commission/zoning board of appeals of the village for a change in zoning classifications or any variances thereof. 
(Prior code § 4.21(f)) 
Chapter 2.68 - EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCY 
Sections: 

2.68.010 - Established-Purpose. 
A.  There is created the Grayslake emergency services and disaster agency (ESDA) to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or damage resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or from natural or manmade disaster, in accordance with "The Illinois Emergency Services and Disaster Act of 1975". 
B.  The ESDA shall consist of the coordinator and such additional members as may be selected by the coordinator. 
(Prior code § 4.27(a)) 
2.68.020 - Coordinator-Appointment-Responsibilities. 
A.  The coordinator of the ESDA shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees and shall serve until removed by the board of trustees. 
B.  The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training, and operation of the ESDA, subject to the direction and control of the village president as provided by state statute and any locally adopted Emergency Services Plan. 
C.  In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability to serve as the coordinator, the village president or any person designated by him or her, shall be and act as coordinator until a new appointment is made as provided in this section. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part): prior code § 4.27(b)) 
2.68.030 - Coordinator and ESDA members-Oath required. 
    The coordinator and every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the ESDA organization who is not a village employee shall, before entering upon his or her duties, subscribe to the following oath which shall be filed with the coordinator: 
 I, ____________ , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions, and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Grayslake ESDA organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence. 
(Prior code § 4.27(j)) 
2.68.040 - ESDA-Functions and duties. 
    The ESDA shall perform such functions within the village as shall be prescribed in and by the state ESDA plan and program prepared by the Governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the Governor, and in addition shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision entered into as provided in the State ESDA Act of 1975. 
(Prior code § 4.27(c)) 
2.68.050 - Exercise of emergency powers. 
    If the Governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists, it shall be the duty of the ESDA to cooperate fully with the state ESDA and with the Governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. 
(Prior code § 4.27(f)) 
2.68.060 - Mobile support team-Designation-Compensation. 
A.  All or any members of the ESDA organization may be designated as members of a mobile support team created by the State Director of ESDA as provided by state statutes. 
B.  The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the coordinator of ESDA. 
C.  Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee or officer while serving on call to duty by the Governor, or the State Director, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights, and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of the village, while so serving, shall receive from the state reasonable compensation as provided by state statutes. 
(Prior code § 4.27(d)) 
2.68.070 - Mutual aid agreements with other political subdivisions. 
    The coordinator of ESDA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the president and by the State Director of ESDA. 
(Prior code § 4.27(e)) 
2.68.080 - Event of disaster-Purchases and contracts authorized. 
A.  The village president may, on recommendation of the village coordinator of ESDA, authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the village in a position to deal effectively with any disaster resulting from the explosion of any bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and safety, protect property and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of such disaster, or from man-made or natural disaster. 
B.  In the event of enemy-caused or other disaster, the coordinator of ESDA is authorized, in accordance with instructions from the president on behalf of the village, to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to village contracts or obligations, as authorized by the State ESDA Act of 1975, provided that if the board of trustees meets at such time it shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. 
(Prior code § 4.27(i)) 
2.68.090 - Appropriations and tax levies-Authorized. 
    The board of trustees may make an appropriation for ESDA purposes in the manner provided by state statutes, and may levy in addition for ESDA purposes only, a tax not to exceed five cents per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of the assessed value of all taxable property in addition to all other taxes, as provided by the State ESDA Act of 1975; however, that amount collectable under such levy shall in no event exceed twenty-five cents per capita. 
(Prior code § 4.27(l)) 
2.68.100 - ESDA activity expenses-Reimbursement by state. 
    The village treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund, any reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training members of the ESDA as prescribed by the State Director of ESDA, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the village in response to a call by the Governor or State Director of ESDA, as provided by state statutes, and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to ESDA activities as provided by law. 
(Prior code § 4.27(h)) 
2.68.110 - ESDA members-Compensation for training. 
    To the extent permitted by law, members of the ESDA who are paid employees or officers of the village, if called for training by the State Director of ESDA, shall receive for the time spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held; members who are not village employees or officers shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established by the board of trustees. 
(Prior code § 4.27(g)) 
2.68.120 - Location of office. 
    The village president is authorized to designate space in a village building, or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the president for the village ESDA as its office. 
(Prior code § 4.27(k)) 
Chapter 2.72 - Administrative Hearing System 

2.72.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the fair and efficient enforcement of the village ordinances delineated in this chapter through an administrative adjudication process as authorized by state law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-12, § 2, 2-19-2013) 
2.72.020 - Establishment of administrative hearing system. 
A.  Adoption. The village hereby adopts Division 2.2 of Article 1 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq.; Division 31.1 of Article 11 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq.; and Sections 11-208.3 and 208.6 of Article II of Chapter 11 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq., pursuant to which authority the village establishes an administrative hearing system, including a code hearing department, to enforce and adjudicate violations of certain provisions this Code as set forth in Subsection B of this section. 
B.  Authorization to Enforce and Adjudicate. The code hearing department is authorized to enforce and adjudicate violations of the following titles of the Grayslake Municipal Code: 
1.  Title 5, Business Licenses and Regulations; 
2.  Title 6, Animals; 
3.  Title 8, Health and Safety; 
4.  Title 9, Public Peace, Morals, and Welfare; 
5.  Title 10, Vehicles and Traffic, pertaining to vehicular standing and parking violations and vehicle compliance violations carrying fines not in excess of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) or such greater amounts as authorized by State law, but not including traffic regulations governing the movement of vehicles; 
6.  Title 12, Streets, Sidewalks, and Public Places; 
7.  Title 15, Buildings and Construction; 
8.  Title 17, Zoning; and 
9.  Any other codes or ordinances as the board of trustees may designate from time to time in accordance with applicable law. 
C.  Intergovernmental Agreement. The village may operate its administrative hearing system in conjunction with, the administrative hearing system and code hearing department of another municipality or municipalities, including without limitation the joint use of hearing officers and administrative staff, pursuant to the terms of an intergovernmental agreement approved and authorized by the village president and board of trustees. 
D.  Compliance Prior to Hearing. If the village representative who issued a violation notice concerning the failure to comply with a provision of the village's municipal code, confirms, no later than three days prior to a scheduled hearing date for the violation, that the code violation has been remedied and compliance has been achieved, the village in its sole discretion may, but shall not be required to, withdraw the citation prior to hearing and elect not to impose penalties or fines or require the defendant to attend a hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-12, § 2, 2-19-2013) 
2.72.030 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
    "Building inspector." Any full-time village employee whose duties include the inspection or examination of property or structures in the village to determine if code violations exist. 
    "Code hearing department." The department under the direction of the village manager that is designed to expedite the prosecution and correction of code and ordinance violations in the manner set out in this chapter. 
    "Hearing." A hearing on an alleged violation conducted pursuant to this Chapter 2.72. 
    "Hearing officer." Each person having those responsibilities and qualifications set forth in Section 2.72.060 of this chapter. 
    "Illinois Administrative Review Law." Section 3-101 et seq. of the Illinois Code of Civil Procedure, 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq. 
    "Illinois Municipal Code." 65 ILCS 5/1-1-1.1 et seq. 
    "Owner" or "property owner." The legal or beneficial owner of a structure. 
    "Traffic education program." A traffic education program that is satisfactory under state law. 
    "Violation." A violation of a provision of those codes or ordinances designated by the president and board of trustees and set forth in Subsection 2.72.020.B of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-12, § 2, 2-19-2013) 
2.72.040 - Hearing procedures non-exclusive. 
    The provisions of this chapter do not preclude the village from using other methods or proceedings to enforce, and to adjudicate violations of, the codes or ordinances described in Subsection 2.72.020.B of this chapter or other codes or ordinances of the village, including without limitation the institution of an action in the Circuit Court of Lake County, the United States District Court, or any administrative body or proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-12, § 2, 2-19-2013) 
2.72.050 - Composition of code hearing department. 
    A. The code hearing department is comprised of one or more hearing officers, one or more code enforcement administrators, and security and other hearing room personnel, all with the power, authority, and limitations as set forth in this chapter. The code hearing department may include hearing officers, code enforcement administrators, security and other hearing room personnel provided by another municipality with whom the village jointly operates its administrative hearing system pursuant to an intergovernmental agreement as provided in Subsection 2.72.020.C of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-12, § 2, 2-19-2013) 
2.72.060 - Hearing officer. 
A.  Appointment. The village president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, may appoint one or more qualified hearing officers to perform the functions set forth in this chapter, provided that, where the village operates its administrative hearing system in conjunction with the existing administrative hearing system of another municipality, the village will not appoint a hearing officer and will use the hearing officers already designated by the municipality, unless otherwise agreed by the village and the municipality. 
B.  Qualifications. To qualify as a hearing officer, an individual must: 
1.  Be an attorney licensed to practice law in the State of Illinois for at least three years; 
2.  Be in good standing with the Illinois Supreme Court Attorney Registration and Disciplinary Commission; and 
3.  Complete a formal training program consisting of: 
a.  Instruction on the rules of procedure for administrative hearings; 
b.  Orientation to each subject area of the codes and ordinances that will be adjudicated; 
c.  Observation of hearings conducted by Illinois municipalities that have adopted the administrative hearing system; and 
d.  Participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence and issuance of final orders. 
C.  Compensation. Authorization for compensation for a hearing officer is made by the president and board of trustees through the village's annual budget process. Compensation is determined by the village manager within approved budget limitations. 
D.  Authority and Jurisdiction. Hearing officers are hereby authorized and directed to: 
1.  Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the allegation of a violation; 
2.  Issue subpoenas to direct the attendance and testimony of relevant witnesses and production of relevant documents, on the request of the parties or their representatives; 
3.  Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing, including all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; 
4.  Issue a determination, based on the evidence presented at the hearing, on whether a violation occurred or exists.
