G.  The outdoor seating area shall be accessible to the disabled, and the licensee shall at all times comply with all applicable federal, state, and village laws, ordinances, and regulations concerning accessibility and non-discrimination in the providing of services. 
H.  The outdoor seating area shall not obstruct any fire exit, fire escape, or other required ingress or egress. 
I.  All tables, chairs, and other equipment shall be constructed and set up in such a manner as to be easily removed during winter months or any other time required by the village. 
J.  An outdoor seating area must be located on an impervious surface. 
K.  Outdoor seating area will be included when figuring the restaurant's maximum occupancy to determine compliance with the State Plumbing Code public toilet facility requirements for those restaurants where outdoor seating is available for more than one hundred eighty (180) days. 
L.  Outdoor furnishing materials and finishes shall be durable, smooth, and easily cleanable and shall be kept in sound condition and good repair. All outdoor furnishings shall be designed to withstand a wind pressure of not less than thirty (30) pounds per square foot so that the furnishings will not be moved by the wind. The color and material of the furniture should be harmonious with the design of the principle structure. 
M.  Canopies that are attached to the building will be permitted for an outdoor seating area on private property only when in conformance with the regulations set forth in the village code, the zoning ordinance, and architectural standards. No additional canopy for an outdoor seating area shall be permitted. 
N.  Trash receptacles shall be located within of adjacent to the outdoor seating area in such number to ensure the ready disposal of all trash and refuse generated from the outdoor seating area, and such receptacles shall be constructed of an impervious material and be of sturdy construction equipped with a tight fitting cover. 
O.  The village manager or his or her designee may impose other reasonable restriction that ensures the health, safety and welfare of persons residing or working in the vicinity. 
(Ord. 2007-0-46 § 2 (part)) 
5.84.060 - Sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
    Notwithstanding Section 5.08.200(C) of the Grayslake Municipal Code, the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages in the outdoor seating area shall be permitted provided the licensee adheres to the requirements of the Liquor Code and provisions of this chapter, which include the following restrictions: 
A.  Primary Purpose. The outdoor seating area shall be engaged primarily in selling and serving "meals" as defined in the Liquor Code. 
B.  Enclosed Area. Any outdoor seating area, where alcoholic beverages are sold or consumed, shall be enclosed by a border. The border shall be at least three feet in height and the style shall be reviewed and approved through the application process. 
C.  Supervision. The outdoor seating area shall be supervised at all times by an employee of the restaurant who has attained the age of twenty-one (21) years or older, and who shall be present in the outdoor seating area at all times the seating area is in operation. 
D.  Removal of Alcoholic Beverages. No alcoholic beverages may be removed from the outdoor seating area, except to the interior of the restaurant. 
E.  Service. The sale and service of alcohol must be at tables where customers may be provided meals. At any time alcohol is available, customers shall have the ability to order a meal. Alcohol shall not be purchased from an interior bar area and moved to the outdoor seating area, except as permitted in provisions of this section. 
F.  Notwithstanding the restriction in this section requiring sale and service of alcoholic beverages at a table, any cafeteria-type operation, may provide alcohol for outdoor consumption, provided all other provisions of this section are met. 
G.  The village manager or his or her designee may impose any other reasonable restriction that ensures the health, safety and welfare of persons residing or working in the vicinity. 
(Ord. 2007-0-46 § 2 (part)) 
5.84.070 - Areas located on public rights-of-way. 
    In addition to the requirements set forth in Sections 5.84.050 and 5.84.060, the issuance of the outdoor restaurant seating license, where the seating will be located on a public sidewalk or right-of-way, shall be conditioned on the following: 
A.  The licensee shall submit a detailed drawing showing the placement of every item of furniture or equipment to be used as a part of the outdoor seating area. The proposed locations shall be subject to the review and approval of the village. 
B.  The licensee shall submit a plan showing the manner in which the furnishings and equipment will be stored during the hours that the outdoor seating area portion of the restaurant is closed. The plan shall be subject to the village's approval. All furnishings and equipment left outside shall be moved as close to the building wall as may be practical during the hours when not in use. 
C.  The use of public sidewalks or right-of-way for outdoor restaurant shall be permitted only when incidental to the operation of a licensed restaurant or fast-food restaurant on private contiguous property and only along the frontage of said restaurant. 
D.  The licensee shall provide the village, in a form acceptable to the village attorney, the following: 
1.  An agreement to indemnify, defend, and hold harmless the village for any and all claims for liability or damages arising from the operation of the outdoor restaurant seating area; and 
2.  A certificate of general liability insurance, workers compensation insurance, and, if applicable, dram shop insurance. The amount of required coverage shall be approved by the village's insurance carrier, but in no event shall liability coverage be in an amount less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per person. The village shall be named as an additional insured on the face of the certificate, and the insurer shall have no less than an "A" rating by the most recent AM Best Insurance Rating Guide. 
E.  In no event shall the operation of the outdoor restaurant seating area interfere with the passage of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, or reduce the open portion of the public sidewalk to less than five feet clear of all obstructions, measured from edge of the sidewalk closest to the curb (or lampposts or parking meters where such exist). 
F.  In no event shall the placement of furnishings for the outdoor restaurant seating area or the operation of the outdoor restaurant seating area obstruct access to any taxi stand, bus stop, crosswalk, mailbox, curb cut, parking space, or any other public property, or obstruct necessary access to any fire hydrant, fire escape, or fire door, or obstruct the clear view of any traffic signal, regulatory sign, or street sign. 
G.  The licensee shall be responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the public right-of-way used for the outdoor restaurant seating area and the replacement of damaged public property, including brick pavers. No furniture or furnishings may be attached by any means to the public sidewalk or any other public property. Maintenance shall include daily cleaning of the area. 
H.  When notified by the village to do so, the licensee shall promptly remove all furnishings and obstructions from the public sidewalk or right-of-way, so as to allow snow removal, to accommodate special events permitted by the village or to accommodate village repair or maintenance of the public sidewalk or right-of-way. 
I.  No electrical appliances or conductors, open flame devices, spillable petroleum products, or other flammable liquids, other than candles or lanterns of a type approved by the building department, shall be placed or kept in the outdoor seating area. 
J.  No furnishings and obstructions shall be permitted on the public sidewalk or right-of-way from November 1st each year through and including April 30th of the succeeding year. 
K.  The village manager or his or her designee may impose other reasonable restriction that ensures the health, safety and welfare of persons residing or working in the vicinity. 
(Ord. 2007-0-46 § 2 (part)) 
5.84.080 - Term of license-Renewal-Revocation-Termination. 
A.  Each outdoor restaurant seating license shall be valid for a term of one year, and may be renewed annually thereafter. A renewal application shall provide all the same information as an original application, but copies of the previous year's site plan may be used if there are no changes from the last submission. 
B.  Outdoor restaurant seating licenses may be suspended or revoked by the village manager for violations of the license requirements or any violations of any other village ordinances. 
C.  Outdoor restaurant seating licenses for use of the public sidewalk or other public property shall not constitute personal property, and the village shall retain at all times, the right to terminate any license for use of public property, or may completely eliminate this class of license, upon thirty (30) days written notice to the license holder(s). Should the village terminate any license other than for reason of a violation of the requirements of this section, the village shall refund to the licensee the pro-rated portion of the annual fee paid by the licensee. 
(Ord. 2007-0-46 § 2 (part)) 
5.84.090 - Annual license fee. 
    Annual license fee. The annual fee for an outdoor restaurant seating license shall be: 
A.  Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for seating areas not located on the public property; 
B.  Fifty dollars ($50.00) for seating area located on public property. 
(Ord. 2007-0-46 § 2 (part)) 
Chapter 5.85 - VIDEO GAMING 
Sections: 

5.85.010 - Video gaming prohibited. 
    Pursuant to the authority vested in the village by section 27 of the Illinois Video Gaming Act (230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.)(the "Act"), video gaming as defined in the Act is hereby prohibited within the corporate limits of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2010-0-04, § 2, 2-2-2010) 
Title 6 - ANIMALS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 6.04 - ANIMAL CONTROL CODE 
Sections: 

6.04.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meaning: 
    "Animal" means any animal, other than man, which may be affected by rabies. 
    "Board of health" means the county board of health or its authorized representative. 
    "Cat" includes all members of the feline family. 
    "Control" means any owned animal that is either secured by a leash or lead, or within the premises of its owner, or confined within a crate or cage, or confined within a vehicle, or on the premises of another person with the consent of that person. 
    "Dog" includes all members of the canine family. 
    "Fur-bearing mammals and wild animals" means the following specific species: arctic fox, badger, bat, beaver, bobcat, coyote, ferret, gray fox, hedgehog, mink, muskrat, opossum, prairie dog, raccoon, red fox, river otter, striped skunks, weasel, woodchuck, wolf or any animal of this type, and any wildlife cross or the offspring of a mating between a wolf or coyote and a dog. 
    "Has been bitten" means has been seized with the teeth or jaws, so that the person or animal seized has been nipped or gripped, or has been wounded or pierced and includes contact of saliva with any break or abrasion of skin, or mucous membrane. 
    "Health department" means the county health department or its authorized representative. 
    "Kennel" is any place including a pet shop, in or at which any number of dogs or other animals are kept for the purpose of sale or in connection with boarding, care, or breeding, for which a fee is charged; or any place in or at which more than four dogs, cats or other animals over the age of four months are kept for any purpose. 
    "Livestock" includes any bison, burro, cattle, donkey, emu, fowl (except back yard hens), geese, goats, horse, llama, mule, pony, sheep, or swine (except pot belly pigs) or any animal of this type. 
    "Owner" means any person having a right of property in a dog, cat or other animal, or who keeps or harbors a dog, cat or other animal, or who has it in his or her care, or acts as its custodian, or who knowingly permits it to remain on or about any premises occupied by him or her. 
    "Ownership" means any animal that is in the custody of a person for a period of seven days or more. 
    "Patient" means any person who has been bitten by an animal. 
    "Public or private nuisance" means any animal or animals which molests or attacks a person, a passing vehicle, attacks other animals, is found to be running at large, damages private or public property or barks, whines or howls in an excessive, continuous or untimely manner. 
    "Running at large" means those animals which are not under control as defined in Section 6.04.040. 
    "Vicious animal" means: (1) Any individual animal that when unprovoked inflicts a bite or bites or attacks a human being or other animal either on public or private property; (2) Any individual animal with a known propensity tendency or disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury or to otherwise endanger the safety of human beings or domestic animals; (3) Any individual animal that has a reported or verified reputation for viciousness, dangerous or unprovoked attacks upon human beings or other animals; (4) Any individual animal which has been found to be a "dangerous animal" upon three separate occasions. 
(Prior code § 14.01) 
(Ord. No. 2014-0-16, § 1, 7-1-2014) 
6.04.020 - Inoculation required. 
    Every owner of a dog or cat four months of age or older shall each year cause said dog or cat to be inoculated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian. However, if the vaccine used is one recognized by the State of Illinois Department of Agriculture, for a three-year period of immunity and the animal to be inoculated is a dog or cat over twelve (12) months of age at the time of inoculation, the interval between inoculations may be extended to three years. At such time as new rabies vaccines are recognized or revisions in recommendations are made by the State of Illinois Department of Agriculture, the administrator may issue a directive authorizing their implementation. 
(Prior code § 14.02) 
6.04.030 - Tags required. 
    The owner of a dog or cat shall keep a collar upon the animal's neck with a current county rabies tag securely fastened thereto. Any dog or cat found within the village without a tag so fastened upon its neck shall be deemed a nuisance and shall be disposed of as provided in any agreement with the county board of health and in accordance with regulations established by the village, as provided by this chapter. 
(Prior code § 14.03) 
6.04.040 - Running at large prohibited. 
A.  Running at large means a dog off the premises of its owner and not under the control of the owner (or person acting for the owner) by means of a leash, cord, chain, or like device not more than six feet in length, capable or physically restraining its movement. 
B.  No person who owns, keeps or harbors a dog, cat, domestic animal or other animal shall cause or permit such dog, cat, or other animal to run at large at any time during the year in any area in the village, other than the private premises of the owner or keeper of such dog, cat or other domestic animal. All dogs, cats or other domestic animals kept within any area of the village shall be confined within a fenced area in such a manner as to prevent the dog, cat or domestic animal from running at large. Any person walking their dog or other domestic animal on public property or private property not owned by the person walking the animal shall maintain control of the animal. Any dog, cat or other domestic animals found running at large in violation of this section, shall be declared a public nuisance and shall be apprehended and impounded in the manner as provided by any agreement with the county board of health and in accordance with any regulations established by the village as provided by this chapter. 
C.  All persons walking their dogs or other domestic animals on the public property of the village or on any private property not owned by the person walking the animal shall carry a receptacle necessary for the placing of any droppings, to-wit: feces, while the animal is on the public or property other than his own. The owner of the animal shall place the droppings in the receptacle to be disposed of in a proper garbage container or lavatory. Should any person walking a dog or other domestic animal be found without the receptacle, it shall be the duty of the law enforcement officials to issue a nontraffic complaint ticket to the person walking the animal. (Amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 14.04) 
6.04.050 - Vicious dogs, cats, or domestic animals. 
    No person shall own, keep or harbor a vicious, fierce or dangerous dog, cat or other domestic animal within the village, unless such person shall keep such dog, cat or other domestic animal safely and securely confined so as to protect from injury any person who shall come upon the premises where such dog, cat or other domestic animal, is located. All persons maintaining premises upon which a vicious, fierce or dangerous dog, cat or other domestic animal is confined, shall provide suitable and adequate warning of the presence of such dog, cat or other domestic animal by appropriate signs or other means so as to advise all persons lawfully entering upon such premises that a vicious, fierce or dangerous dog, cat or other domestic animal is confined thereon. No animal shall be deemed "vicious" if it bites, attacks or menaces a trespasser on the property of its owner or harms or menaces anyone who has tormented or abused it or is a professionally trained animal for law enforcement or guard duties. A vicious animal shall not be classified as such solely on the basis of its breed. 
(Prior code § 14.05) 
6.04.060 - Procedure when person is bitten. 
A.  It is unlawful for the owner or keeper of any dog, cat, domestic animal or other animal, when notified by the chief of police or his or her authorized agent that such dog, cat, domestic animal, or other animal has bitten any person, to sell or give away such dog, cat, domestic animal or other animal or allow such dog, cat, domestic or other animal to be taken beyond the limits of the village, except for confinement with a licensed veterinarian. It shall be the duty of such owner or keeper, upon receiving notice from the chief of police or his or her authorizing agent of the circumstance aforesaid, to deliver such dog, cat, domestic or other animal within twenty-four (24) hours to a licensed veterinarian for examination, confinement, and observation, at the expense of the owner. Where there is a failure to comply within twenty-four (24) hours with the order from the chief of police, or his authorized agent to have such dog, cat, domestic or other animal examined, confined and observed as provided in this section, the chief of police or his or her authorized agent, upon a showing of reasonable evidence that such dog, cat, domestic or other animal has bitten a person, may seek a court order to have such dog, cat, domestic or other animal confined and observed. Within twenty-four (24) hours after the dog, cat, domestic or other animal is examined and confined, the veterinarian shall report (as required by 510 ILCS 5/2.13) to the chief of police the owner's name, address and the date of confinement, the breed, description, age, and sex of the dog, cat, domestic or other animal. Such dog, cat, domestic or other animal shall be confined for a period of ten (10) days. At the termination of the period of confinement, the veterinarian shall notify the chief of police in writing of the final disposition of the animal. 
B.  If, however, the dog, cat, domestic or other animal is examined by a licensed veterinarian within twenty-four (24) hours after notification by the chief of police and found to be free of signs of rabies and the police department or the licensed veterinarian is presented evidence that such dog, cat, domestic or other animal has been inoculated against rabies more than thirty (30) days prior to the biting and less than one year if a one-year immunity vaccine is used or less than three years if a three-year vaccine is used, such dog, cat, domestic or other animal shall be confined in the house of its owner or in a manner that will prohibit such dog, cat, domestic or other animal from escaping and from biting any person or animal for the ten (10) day period, unless in the judgment of the chief of police or the licensed veterinarian, circumstances are such that the dog, cat, domestic or other animal should be confined elsewhere. At the end of the ten (10) day period it shall be the duty of the owner to present the dog, cat, domestic, or other animal to a licensed veterinarian for examination. The licensed veterinarian shall then notify the police department, in writing, within twenty-four (24) hours of the results of the examination. 
C.  If the dog, cat, domestic or other animal escapes from the house of its owner, or from such other place of confinement provided by its owner, during the ten (10) day confinement period, or if the owner fails to deliver the dog, cat, domestic or other animal to a licensed veterinarian for reexamination within twenty-four (24) hours of the completion of the ten (10) day confinement period, the owner is declared to be in violation of this section and is subject to the penalties found in Section 6.04.120. In addition, the owner of an escaped dog, cat, domestic or other animal shall immediately apprehend it and deliver it to a licensed veterinarian for confinement, at the owner's expense, for the remainder of the ten (10) day period. 
D.  The owner of a dog, cat, domestic or other animal, four months of age or older, not currently inoculated against rabies, as provided in Section 6.04.020, must have the dog inoculated against rabies at the time of release from confinement. (Amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 14.06) 
6.04.070 - Noisy animals unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to own, keep, have in his or her possession or harbor any dog, cat, domestic animal or other animal in a residential district which, by frequent or habitual barking, howling, yelping or by other loud noise, shall cause annoyance of any family or person, or shall disturb the peace or quiet of any neighborhood at any time of the day. Such annoyance of any family or person or the disturbance of the peace or quiet of any residential neighborhood by any dog, cat, domestic or other animal is declared to be a public nuisance, and it is unlawful for any person to suffer or permit such nuisance to exist. 
(Prior code § 14.07) 
6.04.080 - Livestock prohibited-Exceptions. 
    Keeping livestock or fur-bearing mammals and wild animals within the village is prohibited, except at an animal hospital or clinic. The Lake County Fairgrounds, and any property zoned agriculture as shown on the current zoning map of the village, may keep or house livestock. 
(Prior code § 14.08) 
6.04.090 - Number of animals permitted. 
    Any place in which more than four dogs or cats over the age of four months are kept in a residential district is prohibited and declared a nuisance. 
(Prior code § 14.09) 
6.04.100 - Cruelty to animals prohibited. 
    No person shall be cruel to any animal in any of the following ways: 
A.  By overloading, overdriving, overworking, cruelly beating, torturing, tormenting, mutilating or cruelly killing any animals, or causing or knowingly allowing the same to be done; 
B.  By cruelly working any old, maimed, infirm, sick or disabled animal, or causing, or knowingly allowing the same to be done; 
C.  By unnecessarily failing to provide any animal in his or her charge or custody, as owner or otherwise, with proper food, drink, shelter and proper medical attention; 
D.  By abandoning any old, maimed, infirm, sick or disabled animal or by abandoning any animal on any highway or public way or in any other place where it may suffer injury, hunger or exposure or become a public charge. 
(Prior code § 14.10) 
6.04.105 - Back yard hens. 
    Back yard hens are allowed in the Village of Grayslake subject to the following regulations: 
  Hens shall be allowed in rear yards only. 
  Maximum number of hens on any individual property shall be six. 
  Coops shall provide a minimum of six square feet for each hen. 
  All coops will be enclosed. 
  Roosters are prohibited. 
  Any individual keepings hens must register with the Illinois Department of Agriculture Livestock Program. 
  Sale of eggs from back yard hens is prohibited. 
  Slaughter of back yard hens is prohibited. 
  Feed for the hens shall be kept in a rodent free container(s). 
  Hens or accompanying activity shall not violate any regulations of Village Code Chapter 8.28 entitled "Nuisances Generally". This includes but is not limited to noise, odor, pests, cleanliness or unsightliness. 
  All coops will require a building permit and if applicable, an electrical permit. 
  Setbacks for and height of coops shall be in accordance with Chapter 17.20.030 entitled "Miscellaneous Requirements" of the Grayslake Zoning Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2014-0-16, § 2, 7-1-2014) 
6.04.110 - Police and building departments-Authority to establish regulations. 
    The village police department and/or building department may establish regulations and procedures for implementation of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 14.11) 
6.04.120 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person or persons adjudged guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter, including (without limitation) a failure, neglect or refusal to comply with a notice given pursuant to the provisions of this chapter or to comply otherwise with the provisions of this chapter, shall be fined as follows: 
Charge Fine Second Third Animal running at large but not impounded $25.00 $35.00 $50.00 Noisy animals 25.00 35.00 50.00 Failure to properly dispose of feces 25.00 35.00 50.00 Cruelty to animals 25.00 35.00 50.00 Animal not wearing current county rabies tag, but registered 15.00 20.00 30.00 Number of animals 15.00 20.00 30.00  
(Prior code § 14.12) 
Title 8 - HEALTH AND SAFETY 
Chapters: 
Chapter 8.04 - ABANDONED AND INOPERATIVE VEHICLES 
Sections: 

8.04.010 - Abandoned and inoperative vehicles-Regulations. 
A.  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter: 
    "Abandoned vehicle" means any vehicle which is left at any place for such time and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle reasonably to appear to have been abandoned. 
    "Historical vehicle" means a vehicle over twenty-five (25) years of age with current registration and capable of being driven under its own motor power. 
    "Inoperable motor vehicle" means any motor vehicle from which, for a period of thirty (30) days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor power. 
    "Inoperable motor vehicle" shall not include a motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations nor to any motor vehicle that is kept within a building when not in use, or to a motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles. 
    "Property" means any real property within the village which is not a street or highway. 
    "Street or highway" means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    "Vehicle" means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power, devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks and snowmobiles as defined in the Snowmobile Registration and Safety Act (see Ill. Rev. Stat., Chap. 95 1/2, Sec. 1-217 and Secs. 601-1 to 612-1). 
B.  Abandonment of vehicles. No person shall abandon any vehicle within the village and no person shall leave any vehicle at any place within the village for such time and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle reasonably to appear to have been abandoned. 
C.  Leaving of Wrecked, Nonoperating Vehicles on Street. No person shall leave any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked or junked vehicle on any street or highway in the village. 
D.  Inoperable Vehicles a Nuisance. Inoperable motor vehicles, as defined in this chapter, whether on public or private property, are declared to be a nuisance. 
E.  Written Notice. All persons are required to dispose of inoperable motor vehicles under their control, respectively, upon written notice received from the corporate authorities or from the chief of police or any member of the police department designated by the chief commanding such disposition of the inoperable motor vehicle. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part): prior code § 12.07) 
(Ord. No. 2010-0-22, § 2, 8-3-2010) 
Chapter 8.08 - ALARM SYSTEMS 
Sections: 

8.08.010 - Alarm system established. 
A.  An alarm system shall be operated by the village police department in accordance with this section. 
B.  This section shall apply to: 
1.  All alarm services which have a connection to the console in the police department; and 
2.  Any other alarm system which is designed to or capable of directly or indirectly summoning the police department or the Grayslake fire protection district or causing the police department or Grayslake fire protection district to be summoned to a location within their jurisdictions. 
C.  Any person who wishes to obtain police alarm service by making a connection from his or her place of business or private residence to the console in the police department shall make a request therefor to the police department on a form to be provided by the police department and pay the fees provided for in subsections F and H of this section. 
D.  Any person, firm or corporation who wishes to install and maintain an alarm system in their place of business or private residence (without a connection to the console in the police department) shall notify the police department thereof on a form to be provided by the police department and pay the fee provided for in subsection H of this section. 
E.  It shall be the duty and obligation of every person, firm or corporation who occupies a place of business or private residence which has police or fire alarm service of an alarm system to install all necessary equipment and maintain it in good condition and working order at the expense of such person, firm or corporation. 
F.  The fees payable to the village by persons who have police and/or fire alarm service shall be determined by the board of trustees. 
G.  Upon the favorable recommendation of the police chief, alarms from any person, firm, corporation or private residence with or without a connection to the console in the police department may be terminated. Any alarm system user who operates an alarm system without first obtaining a permit as required by this section, or who, after having a permit revoked or suspended, shall be in violation of this section. 
H.  Each person, firm or corporation receiving police and/or fire alarm service and/or having an alarm system covered by this section shall be allowed three false alarms during any calendar year without any additional fee. 
    An additional fee shall be charged for false alarms over three per calendar year at the following rates: fourth alarm ten dollars ($10.00), fifth alarm twenty-five dollars ($25.00), each alarm over five fifty dollars ($50.00). 
    The additional fees due for false alarms shall be billed monthly and shall be paid to the village within thirty (30) days from the date of billing. 
(Prior code § 5.09) 
8.08.020 - Northern Illinois Police Alarm System. 
A.  Whereas, natural occurrences or manmade occurrences may result in situations which are beyond the ability of an individual community to deal with effectively in terms of manpower and equipment resources on hand at a given time; and 
B.  Whereas, many municipalities in Lake County and other area counties have joined to form the Northern Illinois Police Alarm System to assist its neighbor communities by assigning some of its manpower and equipment resources to an affected community as their resources allow; and 
C.  Whereas, joining the Northern Illinois Police Alarm System will permit the Grayslake police department to more fully safeguard the lives, persons and property of all Grayslake citizens, the village shall execute a mutual aid agreement for participation in the Northern Illinois Police Alarm System. 
(Prior code § 5.08) 
Chapter 8.12 - DEFACEMENT OF PROPERTY 
Sections: 

8.12.010 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings: 
    "Deface" or "defacement" means to mar the external appearance of any property by any means, including without limitation by cutting, marking, painting, writing, or drawing. 
    "Legal guardian" means a person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by any court of record, but does not include a person appointed or given custody of a minor under the Illinois Juvenile Court Act. 
    "Minor" means a person who has attained eleven (11) years of age, but who has not yet reached nineteen (19) years of age. 
    "Owner" means any person, agent, operator, firm, or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in property; or recorded in the official records of the state, county, or municipality as holding title to property, or otherwise having control of property, including the guardian of the estate of any such person, and the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of property by a court, or the person to whom the most recent real estate tax bill was sent for property located or maintained on such real estate. 
    "Parent" means the lawful mother or father of an unemancipated minor whether by birth or adoption. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    "Property" means any manmade or natural object or structure that is of valuable right or interest to an owner, including without limitation, any public or private building or structure, sidewalk, pavement, post, store, tree, sign, mailbox, or fence. (Amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 12.13.1) 
8.12.020 - Defacement of property-Nuisance. 
A.  Whoever shall deface property not his or her own or under his or her control or without permission of the owner of such property, shall be guilty of creating a nuisance, which is a misdemeanor. 
B.  Any owner who shall suffer or permit the owner's property to remain in a defaced condition after the date set forth in a notice of defacement issued pursuant to Section 8.12.030 (unless an extension of such date is obtained from the village pursuant to Section 8.12.040) shall be guilty of maintaining a nuisance, which is a misdemeanor. 
C.  The parent or legal guardian of a minor who resides with such parent or legal guardian is liable for actual damages for the wilful or malicious acts of such minor which causes injury to property. The minor shall be deemed to have committed the offense with the knowledge, consent, acquiescence and permission of the parent or legal guardian in violation of this section. The parent or legal guardian shall be liable for the fine and requirement of restitution or reparation imposed by a court upon minor defendant for violation of this section. 
(Prior code § 12.13.2) 
8.12.030 - Notice of defacement. 
A.  Whenever property is in a defaced condition, the village shall send a notice of defacement to the owner of such defaced property, which notice shall be in writing and delivered by personal service or certified mail, return receipt requested. 
B.  The notice of defacement shall: 
1.  Identify the defaced property and its location; 
2.  Describe the conditions constituting such defacement; 
3.  Direct the owner to eliminate such defaced conditions; 
4.  Establish the time within which the owner must eliminate the defaced conditions on the property provided that such time shall be not less than three days after delivery of such notice; 
5.  Advise the owner that failure to eliminate the defaced condition on the property within the prescribed time shall be a violation of this code; 
6.  Advise the owner of the procedure in Section 8.12.040 for seeking an extension of time to eliminate the defaced condition in the property; 
7.  Advise the owner that any failure to eliminate the defaced condition on the property may result in the village's abatement of the condition and the charging of the cost of abatement to owner pursuant to Section 8.12.050. 
(Prior code § 12.13.3) 
8.12.040 - Extensions of time to eliminate defacement. 
A.  Any owner who receives a notice of defacement pursuant to Section 8.12.030 may request an extension of the time to eliminate the defacement, provided that: 
1.  Such request is in writing and delivered to the village prior to the time set forth in the notice for eliminating the defaced condition; and 
2.  Such request is accompanied by a specific plan for eliminating the defaced condition, including the methods to be employed in eliminating the defaced condition and the time by which the defaced condition shall be eliminated. 
B.  The village manager or the manager's designee may grant such extensions as are reasonable in light of the defaced conditions, the estimated cost for eliminating such conditions, and other circumstances relevant to the elimination of the defaced conditions. 
(Prior code § 12.13.4) 
8.12.050 - Village abatement of defacement. 
A.  Whenever the owner of defaced property fails to eliminate the defaced conditions within the time set forth in the notice of defacement (or any extension of such time), the village may undertake its own efforts to abate and eliminate such conditions on such property. 
B.  Any cost of abatement incurred by the village under this section shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property, and the village shall deliver a bill for such costs to the owner after its abatement work is completed to recover said costs in conformance with state statute. 
C.  If any bill is not paid within twenty-one (21) days of its mailing to the owner of property, the village clerk shall file a notice of lien against the property with the recorder of deeds of the county. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
1.  A legal description of the property; 
2.  The amount of money representing the costs and expenses incurred and payable for the abatement and elimination of the defaced conditions; 
3.  The dates when such costs and expenses were incurred by the village. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 12.13.5) 
8.12.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  A person that is found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter shall be obligated to pay such restitution or reparation as a court may require in the amount of actual loss or damage to property or pecuniary loss but not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). Nothing in this section shall preclude such additional civil remedies as are available to a complaining party for any sum not recovered under this chapter. 
B.  In addition or in lieu of such restitution or reparation as provided in this section, a fine of not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Said fine may be imposed upon the parent or legal guardian, as provided. 
C.  A person found to be in violation of this chapter by failing to remove the defacement, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate and distinct offense shall be deemed committed each day upon which such person shall continue any such violation, or permit any such violation to exist after notification thereof. (Amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 12.13.6) 
Chapter 8.16 - TREE DISEASES AND INFESTATIONS 
Sections: 

8.16.010 - Infected trees declared nuisance-Duty of owners to remove. 
A.  Infected Trees a Nuisance. All diseased and pest-infested trees, including, without limitation, those trees infected with the fungus known as the "Dutch Elm Disease" (Certostomella ulmi) and trees infested with pests such as the European elm bark beetle (Scolytus multistraitus), gypsy moth, or Asian long horned beetle, are declared to be public nuisances. 
B.  Duty of Owner to Remove and Burn Trees. It is unlawful for any owner of any lot or land in the village to permit or maintain on any such lot or land, any tree which, as provided in this section, is a public nuisance, and such owner shall promptly remove and burn any such tree under the direction of the president or the president's representative. 
C.  Right of Entry of Village Officers. To carry out the purposes of this section and to implement the enforcement thereof, the president or the president's representative is empowered to enter upon any lot or land in the village at all reasonable hours to inspect any trees situated thereon and the president or such representative may remove such specimens from any such tree as are required for the purposes of the laboratory analysis referred to in this section, or to determine whether such tree, because it is dead or substantially dead, may serve as a breeding place for pests, including, without limitation, the European elm bark beetle, gyps moth, or Asian long-horned beetle. It is unlawful for any person to take any action to prevent the president or such representative from entering on any lot or land in the village for such inspection, or to interfere with the president or such representative in the performance of any of his or her duties provided for under the provisions of this section. 
D.  Notice to Owner to Comply-Action by Village-Assessment of Costs. If, on laboratory analysis of specimens removed from any tree by the president, it is determined that such tree is a public nuisance as provided by subsection A of this section, or if the village president determines that any dead or substantially dead tree is a public nuisance as provided by subsection C of this section, the president shall cause to be served upon the person who is the owner of the lot or land on which such tree or dead elmwood is located, a written notice requiring such owner to comply with the provisions of this section. If such person fails to remove and destroy by burning such tree within ten (10) days after service of such notice, the president or such representative may proceed to remove and burn such tree and assess the cost thereof against the owner of such lot or land, and the amount of such cost shall be paid by such owner to the village. 
E.  Service of Notice of Infected Tree. Service of notice provided for in subsection D of this section shall be by personal service if the owner of the lot or land on which an diseased or infested tree is located is a resident of the village. If such owner cannot be found in the village, or is a nonresident of the village, written notice shall be by registered mail, addressed to such owner at his or her last known address and by publication at least one time in a newspaper of general circulation in the village. 
F.  Assessment of Costs. The assessment of the cost of work done by the village against the owner of the lot or land under this section shall be in addition to the penalties imposed by this code for any violation or noncompliance with any provision of this section. 
G.  Trees on Village Property. Any diseased or infested tree on property owned by the village which is a public nuisance as provided by this section shall promptly be removed and burned under the supervision of the president or the president's representative at the expense of the village. 
(Ord. 2000-0-16 § 2) 
Chapter 8.20 - INTERNATIONAL FIRE CODE ADOPTED[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-0-01, §§ 1-3, adopted Jan. 15, 2013, deleted the former Ch. 8.20, §§ 8.20.010-8.20.040, and enacted a new Ch. 8.20 as set out herein. The former Ch. 8.20 pertained to the fire prevention code adopted and derived from the prior code §§ 28.02-28.04, § 34.25; Ord. No. 2005-0-20, §§ 2, 3(a)-(c), adopted 7-19-2005. 

8.20.010. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this chapter (hereinafter referred to as the "Code") is to establish regulations affecting or relating to structures, processes, premises and safeguards regarding: 
1.  The hazard of fire and explosions arising from the storage, handling or use of structures, materials or devices; 
2.  Conditions hazardous to life, property or public welfare in the occupancy of structures or premises; 
3.  Fire hazards in the structure or on the premises from occupancy or operation; 
4.  Matters related to the construction, extension, repair, alteration or removal of fire suppression or alarm systems. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-01, § 2, 1-15-2013) 
8.20.020. - Adoption of the International Fire Code-2009 Edition, with exceptions. 
    The Municipal Code of the Village of Grayslake be amended by striking and deleting Chapter 8.20 and substituting in its place the following new Chapter 8.20 adopting and amending the International Fire Code, 2009 Edition as follows: 
A.  This code shall establish regulations affecting or relating to structures, processes, premises and safeguards regarding (1) the hazard of fire and explosions arising from the storage, handling or use of structures, materials or devices; (2) conditions hazardous to life, property or public welfare in the occupancy of structures or premises; (3) fire hazards in the structure or on the premises from occupancy or operation: (4) matters relating to the construction, extension, repair, alteration or removal of fire suppression or alarm systems. 
B.  While the 2009 Edition of the International Fire Code has been adopted, the following modifications to the 2009 International Fire Code (consisting of certain deletions, changes, and/or additions) shall control wherever the said modifications are applicable or are in conflict between provisions of the International Fire Code and those chapters, the provision of this chapter shall control. 
C.  Modifications to the 2009 International Fire Code. The following sections of the International Fire Code are hereby revised as follows: 
1.  In all chapters and sections where the "name of jurisdiction" and/or "chief appointing authority of this jurisdiction" is written insert "Village of Grayslake"; 
2.  In all chapters and sections where "ICC Electrical Code" is written insert "The National Electrical Code 2011 Edition as adopted and amended by the Village of Grayslake", Chapter 15.16 of the Grayslake Municipal Code; 
3.  In all chapters or sections where "International Plumbing Code" is written insert "The State of Illinois Plumbing Code as adopted and amended by the Village of Grayslake", Chapter 15.20 of the Grayslake Municipal Code; 
4.  In all chapters or sections where "Fire Code Official" is written insert "Code Official."

For all other structures or premises, when the Code Official or his/her designee has reasonable cause to believe that a code violation exists, the Code Official or his/her designee is authorized to enter the structure or premises at reasonable times to inspect, subject to constitutional restrictions on unreasonable searches and seizures. All door locks should be keyed to a "Master Building Key" or, at a minimum the building shall be keyed to the lowest practical number of separate door keys. The operator of the building shall immediately contact the Fire District and provide the new key when lock is changed or rekeyed. The key to such lock shall be secured in the key box.

Chapter 9 FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS 
    Section 902.1 Definitions shall be amended by adding the following definitions: 
1.  Central Supervising Station. A supervising station that is listed for central station service and that also commonly provides less stringent supervising station services such as remote supervising services. 
2.  Proprietary Supervising Station. A supervising station under the same ownership as the protected premises fire alarm system(s) that it supervises (monitors) and to which alarm, supervisory, or trouble signals are received and where personnel are in attendance at all times to supervise operation and investigate signals. 
3.  Remote Supervising Station. A supervising station to which alarm, supervisory, or trouble signals or any combination of those signals emanating from protected premises fire alarm systems are received and where personnel are in attendance at all times to respond. 
4.  Protected Premises. The physical location protected by a fire alarm system.

Section 907.7.5 - Monitoring shall be amended to read as follows: 
    907.7.5 Monitoring. Fire alarm systems required by this chapter or by the International Building Code shall be monitored by an approved supervising station in accordance with the requirements of the NFPA 72 National Fire and Signaling Code (2010) - Chapter 26 (Supervising Station Alarm Systems). The following types of supervising stations are acceptable for the monitoring and retransmission of alarms: 
1.  Central Station Service. Alarm systems for central station service which consists of the following elements: Installation of fire alarm transmitters; Alarm, guard, supervisory, and trouble signal monitoring; Retransmission; Associated record keeping and reporting; Testing and maintenance; and, Runner service shall meet NFPA 72 - Section 26.3 and applicable requirements of NFPA 72 - Chapter 26 as provided by qualified organization(s) under contract. Documentation of Central Station Service, contract(s) or other required information shall be made available for inspection at the protected property, and filed with the Code Official. 
2.  Proprietary Supervising Station Systems. Property owner who operates his/her own supervising station shall operate the station in accordance with NFPA 72 - Section 26.4 and applicable requirements of NFPA 72 - Chapter 26. 
a.  Supervising facilities of proprietary alarm systems shall comply with the operating procedures of NFPA 72 - Section 26.4. The facilities, equipment, personnel, operation, testing, and maintenance of the proprietary supervising station shall comply with NFPA 72 - Section 26.4. 
3.  Remote Supervising Station Alarm Systems. Alarm systems which transmit alarm, supervisory and trouble signals to a remote supervising station shall meet NFPA 72 - Section 26.5 and applicable requirements of NFPA 72- Chapter 26. Code official approval is required. 
Exception: Monitoring by a supervising station is not required for: 
1.  Single and multiple station smoke alarms required by Section 907.2.11. 
2.  Smoke detectors in Institutional Group I-3 occupancies. 
3.  Automatic sprinkler systems in one and two family dwellings. 
a.  Remote supervising station physical facilities, equipment, operating personnel, response, retransmission, signals, reports, and testing shall comply with the minimum requirements of NFPA 72 - Section 26.5.

Section 3308.2 Permit application shall be amended to read as follows: 
    3308.2 Permit application. A permit shall be required for the possession, display or discharge of fireworks. The Code Official shall provide the permit application forms for the display and discharge of fireworks within the corporate limit of the Village of Grayslake. The application form shall include the applicant's name, address; the date and place of the proposed discharge of fireworks; the nature and quantities of fireworks to be discharged and/or displayed; if the applicant is different than the operator, the applicant shall provide the Code Official with the operator's name and address along with information on the operators experience to discharge and/or display fireworks. Such application shall be applied for a minimum thirty (30) days prior to the proposed date of display. 
(1)  The permit may be denied if in the judgment of the Fire Chief of the Grayslake Fire Protection District or his/her designee that it would be hazardous to any property or persons to allow such discharge of fireworks. 
(2)  A permit granted by the Code Official shall not be transferable, nor shall such permit be extended beyond the dates set out. 
Add the following new sub-section 3308.2.3 Bond for display: 
    3308.2.3 Bond for display. The permit holder shall furnish a bond in amount approved by the Code Official for payment of all potential damage caused either to the person or property due to the permitted display, and arising from any acts of the permit holder or agent of permit holder. In lieu of a bond, the permit holder may provide a certificate of insurance, in amount acceptable to the Village of Grayslake and the Grayslake Fire Protection District, naming the Village and the District as an additional insured and executing an agreement holding the Village and the District harmless from damage to persons or property caused by the permitted display and discharged. Amount of insurance must meet/exceed that required by applicable laws, statutes and requirements of the State of Illinois.

8.20.030 - Repeal. 
    All parts of this chapter in conflict herewith, but only to the extent of such conflict, are hereby repealed.

8.20.040 - Severance clause. 
    If any provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, subsection, or parts of this chapter, or the application thereof to any person, firm, corporation, or circumstance, shall, for any reason, be adjudged by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid, said judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder of this chapter or the application of such provision or other persons, firms, corporation, circumstances, but shall be confined in its operation to the provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, subsection, or part thereof directly involved in the controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered and/or to the person, firm, corporation, or circumstance involved. It is hereby declared to be the legislative intent of the corporate authorities that this chapter would have been adopted had such invalid provision or provisions not been included or if it had not been made applicable to such person, firm, corporation of circumstance. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-01, § 5, 1-15-2013) 
8.20.050 - Conflicts; ordinance number; effective date. 
    Any rule, regulation, or ordinance in conflict with the provisions hereof is hereby repealed, but to the extent of such conflict only. This Ordinance [Chapter 8.20] shall be designated Ordinance No. 2013-0-00 and shall be in full force and effect ten (10) days after its approval in accordance with law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-01, § 6, 1-15-2013) 
Chapter 8.24 - GARBAGE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
Sections: 

8.24.010 - Refuse collection charges. 
A.  All persons, firms, and corporations receiving service for the collection, disposal, and recycling of garbage, refuse, landscape waste, and ashes within the corporate limits of the village, are eligible to receive said services under any contracts for such service executed by the village, or for which said services are provided by the village, such persons firms, and corporations shall pay a monthly charge to the village in accordance with the fee schedule as adopted by the village board and amended from time to time. 
B.  Any person, firm, corporation, or other user failing to pay such monthly charge within said twenty-nine (29) day period shall also be assessed a penalty, billed on the thirtieth (30th) day of the month, of ten (10) percent on the amount of the balance which is deemed past due, it being determined by the corporate authorities that ten (10) percent is a reasonable and proper estimate of the costs incurred by the village in maintaining records and otherwise administering and enforcing this section in connection with such delinquencies. The past due balance and penalty will appear on the next regular bill mailed on the thirty-first (31st) day. This overdue balance and penalty must be paid by the forty-fifth (45th) day or a subsequent delinquency notice will be sent by the village manager or his or her designee to the user on the forty-fifth (45th) day, and a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) notice fee will be added to the user's bill. 
C.  If, after a written delinquency notice is sent on the forty-fifth (45th) day by the village manager or his or her designee and the user's monthly payment and penalty is still due on the fifty-ninth (59th) day, the corporate authorities may undertake such legal proceedings as are required to enforce collection, in which event such user shall also reimburse the village for all costs, sheriff's fees, attorney's fees, and other expenses by the village for collection of such charges. 
D.  Each customer benefiting from the collection, disposal, and recycling of garbage, refuse, landscape waste, and ashes within the corporate limits of the village shall be furnished a schedule evidencing the decreased service charge from fourteen dollars twenty cents ($14.20) to thirteen dollars forty-five cents ($13.45) per month for ninety (90) gallon service, and from twelve dollars seventy-five cents ($12.75) to twelve dollars ($12.00) per month for sixty-five (65) gallon service. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part): Ord. 2000-0-21 § 1; Ord. 98-0-40 § 1: prior code § 13.01) 
8.24.020 - Placement of pick-up receptacles. 
    The receptacle containing garbage and refuse to be collected at any time shall be placed by the occupant (householder) in each case at the curb of the street shortly before the time scheduled for collection by the garbage collector but no earlier than six p.m. of the day immediately preceding the day scheduled for such collection, and it shall be the duty of such occupant (householder) to remove the emptied receptacle from the curb and front of yard within twelve hours after each collection (pick-up). 
(Prior code § 13.02) 
8.24.030 - Garbage fund. 
A.  There is created a municipal fund to be known as the "garbage fund" which fund shall be and remain in the custody of the village treasurer and shall be kept separate and apart from all other village funds. 
B.  The fund shall be used solely for the purpose of paying for the administration, collection, recollection, recycling and disposition of garbage, refuse and landscape waste accumulated within the village. 
C.  No payments of any sum whatever shall be made for such fund except in pursuance of appropriations duly made therefrom in the annual appropriation bill for the current fiscal year. The village treasurer, upon the due and proper passage, approval and publication of the annual appropriation bill, shall hold the same available for payment upon warrants properly presented chargeable to the sums provided in the appropriation bill, as the same shall come into his or her hands. 
(Prior code § 13.03) 
8.24.040 
    \Haulers of solid waste and recyclable materials-Restrictions-Penalty for violation. 
A.  Definitions. For the purpose of this chapter, the following term shall apply: 
    "Contractor" means any person, firm, or corporation being in the business of collecting and disposing of garbage, refuse, or recyclable materials. 
B.  Restrictions. It is unlawful for any contractors not having a contract within the village to collect refuse or recyclable materials from residential units, multi-family dwellings, commercial, industrial, or institutional entities, within the village. The village may elect to grant one (1) or more licenses for collecting and disposing of different categories of garbage, refuse, or recyclable materials, and the village may also grant exclusive licenses for different categories of customers receiving collection and disposal services relating to garbage, refuse, and recyclable materials. 
C.  Penalty. Any person, firm, or corporation who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Prior code § 13.04) 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-39, § 2, 11-5-2013) 
8.24.050 - Licenses for collection. 
A.  License Required. It shall be unlawful for any contractor to engage in the business of collection or disposal of garbage, refuse, ashes, or other waste (collectively, "solid waste") or recyclables without first obtaining a license therefor from the village and paying the required fee. 
B.  Fee. The annual license fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
C.  Application. Applications for licenses pursuant to this section shall be filed with the village clerk. No application shall be accepted unless accompanied by payment of the fee required for such license. 
D.  License Standards. 
1.  Every contractor seeking a license shall agree to indemnify, save, and keep harmless the village from any and all loss, cost, damage, expense, or liability whatsoever related to the services provided by such contractor, and shall properly execute an agreement so providing in a form acceptable to the village. 
2.  Every contractor seeking a license shall furnish and maintain insurance for general liability, motor vehicle liability, and other coverage in amounts established by the village manager and in forms satisfactory to the village. Copies of policies and certificates of such insurance shall be provided to the village as part of the application for such license. 
3.  Every contractor seeking a license shall provide evidence satisfactory to the village that such contractor is capable of providing the services for which a license is sought in a good, workmanlike, competent, and efficient manner in compliance with all applicable statutes, laws, codes, and regulations and without any adverse impacts on the village or any of its residents. 
E.  Contactor Service Standards. 
1.  No solid waste, landscape waste, or recyclables collection services shall commence before six a.m. on any day and such services shall not commence before eight a.m. in any given day in any commercial area that is located adjacent to residential developments. 
2.  No solid waste, landscape waste, or recyclables collection services shall be made on the following holidays: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas. 
3.  Each licensed contractor shall use only vehicles and equipment that are modern, neat, clean, and in a sanitary condition. All disposal equipment shall be watertight, and all containers shall be equipped with airtight covers. 
4.  All services by all licensed contractors shall be performed in a clean and orderly fashion. No licensed contractor shall deposit, or permit to remain, any solid waste, landscape waste, or recyclables on any property except only as provided in this section or in any contract between the contractor and the village. Every licensed contractor shall replace all containers in their proper locations. 
5.  Each licensed contractor shall be solely and completely responsible for the safety of its personnel and equipment and of all persons and property affected by such contractor's services. All services shall be performed safely. All services shall be performed at the sole risk and cost of the contactor. 
6.  Each license contractor shall immediately repair all damage inflicted on any property by such contractor and shall restore such property to a condition equal to that existing before the damage was inflicted and satisfactory to the village. 
7.  No licensed contractor shall store any materials or equipment anywhere in the village except in accordance with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules, and regulations. 
F.  Recycling. 
1.  Each licensed contractor that provides solid waste collection and disposal services to single family residential dwellings and multiple family residential units shall provide recyclable collection and disposal services to such single family residential dwelling customers and multiple family residential dwelling customers. For purposes of this Chapter 8.24, "Recyclables" shall be defined to include, at a minimum, ferrous metal, aluminum, glass and rigid plastic (PET #1 and HDPE #2) food and beverage containers, corrugated paper, junk mail, magazines, office paper, and boxboard and any other recyclable items that the Village and the licensed contractor may agree to define as recyclables as part of the licensed contractor's collection and disposal services. 
2.  Each licensed contractor that provides solid waste and recyclable collection and disposal services to multiple family residential dwellings shall provide exterior recyclable storage space at the multiple family residential dwellings. The amount of required exterior recyclable storage spaces shall be determined as follows and shall not be less than the sum of the individual calculations: 
a.  Number of studio and one bedroom units (x) 7 gallons; plus 
b.  Number of two bedroom units (x) 8 gallons, plus 
c.  Number of three and four bedroom units (x) 9 gallons, equals the total recyclable storage area required. 
    A comprehensive recycling system plan shall be required of each licensed contractor, which plan shall include provisions for the exterior recyclable storage area. The exterior recyclable storage area shall be located in close proximity to the solid waste disposal area. In the event that there is insufficient area located near the solid waste disposal area, the licensed contractor shall submit to the village an alternative recycling plan for village review and approval. 
3.  Each licensed contractor shall report the amount of recyclables to the Village of Grayslake and the Solid Waste Agency of Lake County. 
G.  Penalty. Any violation of any provision of the section shall be deemed a violation of this code and shall be grounds for the immediate revocation of any license issued pursuant to this section and for the imposition of any other penalty generally provided for violations of this code. 
(Ord. 2002-0-12 § 2; Ord. 2000-0-22 § 2) 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-08, § 2, 1-15-2013) 
8.24.060 - Sorting of recyclables. 
    All persons, firms, and corporations receiving service for the collection, disposal, and recycling of garbage, refuse, landscape waste, and ashes from single-family residential dwellings or from any multi-family dwelling unit must, when placing such materials for collection, separate all recyclables from all other materials placed for collection and place those recyclables in the recyclable storage areas provided by the licensed contractor pursuant to Section 8.24.050 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-08, § 3, 1-15-2013) 
Chapter 8.28 - NUISANCES GENERALLY 
Sections: 

8.28.010 - Public nuisances prohibited. 
    No person shall erect, contrive, cause, continue, maintain or permit to exist any public nuisance within the village or within the police jurisdiction of the village. 
(Prior code § 12.01) 
8.28.020 - Public nuisances defined. 
A.  General. A public nuisance is a thing, act, occupation, condition or use of property which shall continue for such length of time as to: 
1.  Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the comfort, health, repose or safety of the public; 
2.  In any way render the public insecure in life or in the use of property; 
3.  Greatly offend the public morals or decency; or 
4.  Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or tend to obstruct or render dangerous for passage any street, alley, highway, navigable body of water or other public way. 
B.  Public Nuisances Affecting Health. The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are specifically declared to be public health nuisances, but shall not be construed to exclude other health nuisances coming within the definition of subsection A of this section: 
1.  All decayed, harmfully adulterated or unwholesome food or drink sold or offered for sale to the public; 
2.  Carcasses of animals not buried or otherwise disposed of in a sanitary manner within twenty-four (24) hours after death; 
3.  Accumulations of decayed animal or vegetable matter, trash, rubbish, rotting lumber, bedding, packing material, abandoned vehicles or machinery, scrap metal or any material in which flies, mosquitoes, disease-carrying insects, rats or other vermin may breed or which create a fire hazard; 
4.  All stagnant water in which mosquitoes, flies or other insects can multiply; 
5.  Garbage cans which are not fly-tight; 
6.  Any act or condition in violation of the Illinois Environmental Protection Act (415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.) or any regulations promulgated pursuant to such Act; 
7.  The pollution of any public well or cistern, stream, lake, canal or body of water by sewage, industrial wastes or other substances; or any act in violation of the Environmental Protection Act; 
8.  Any use of property, substances or things within the village emitting or causing any foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous, noxious, or disagreeable odors, effluvia or stenches repulsive to the physical senses of ordinary persons which annoy, discomfort, injure or inconvenience the health of persons within the village; 
9.  All abandoned wells not securely covered or secured from public use; 
10.  Any barn, stable or shed used for keeping animals; 
11.  Any obstruction in or across any watercourse, drainage ditch or ravine; 
12.  The deposit of garbage, rubbish, or any offensive substance on any street, sidewalk or public place, or on any private property, except as may be permitted by ordinance; 
13.  Any noxious weed on private property, as defined in Section 8.40.010 or as established pursuant to 505 ILCS 100/1 et seq.; 
14.  The escape of smoke, soot, cinders, noxious acids, fumes, gases, fly ash, or industrial dust within the village limits that either: 
a.  For any stationary equipment or facility involving or engaged in aggregate mixing or processing, mineral production or processing, or petroleum refining or related activities: 
i.  Exceeds particulate emissions of 0.02 grains per dry standard cubic foot; or 
ii.  Exceeds emissions of thirty (30) parts per million volume of oxides of nitrogen; 
b.  For any stationary equipment or facility, exceeds the emission rates for the following contaminants: 
i. Benzene 0.1080 lbs/hr ii. Chromium (VI) 0.00408 lbs/hr iii. Formaldehyde 0.09002 lbs/hr iv. Manganese 0.2544 lbs/hr v. Mercury 0.00408 lbs/hr vi. Toluene 31.23 lbs/hr  
    The village may periodically require any owner or operator of such equipment or facility to perform appropriate stack testing for any or all of these contaminants to determine compliance with this subsection; 
c.  For any stationary industrial processing, mixing, production, or other equipment or facility located within one thousand (1,000) feet of a residential district, exceeds ninety (90) percent of the allowable limits under subsections (B)(14)(a) or (b) of this section; or 
d.  In such quantities or of such character as to endanger the health of persons of ordinary sensibilities. 
C.  Public Nuisances Offending Morals and Decency. The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are specifically declared to be public nuisances offending public morals and decency, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances offending public morals and decency coming within the definition of subsection A of this section: 
1.  All gambling houses and buildings or structures kept or resorted to for the purpose of prostitution, promiscuous sexual intercourse or gambling, except the state authorized lottery; 
2.  All gambling devices and slot machines; 
3.  All places where intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverages are sold, possessed, stored, brewed, bottled, manufactured or rectified without a permit or license as provided for by this code; 
4.  Any place or premises within the village where ordinances or state laws relating to public health, safety, peace, morals or welfare are openly, continuously, repeatedly and intentionally violated. 
D.  Public Nuisances Affecting Peace and Safety. The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are declared to be public nuisances affecting peace and safety, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances affecting public peace or safety coming within the provisions of subsection A of this section: 
1.  All buildings erected, repaired or altered in violation of the provisions of the ordinances of the village relating to materials and manner of construction of buildings and structures; 
2.  All unauthorized signs, signals, markings or devices which purport to be or may be mistaken as official traffic control devices placed or maintained upon or in view of any public highway or railway crossing; 
3.  All trees, hedges or other obstructions which prevent persons driving vehicles on public streets, alleys or highways from obtaining a clear view of traffic when approaching an intersection or pedestrian crosswalk; 
4.  All limbs of trees which project over a public sidewalk less than eight feet above the surface thereof or less than ten (10) feet above the surface of a public street; 
5.  All use or display of fireworks except as provided by the laws of the state and ordinances of the village; 
6.  All buildings or structures so old, dilapidated or out of repair as to be dangerous, unsafe, unsanitary or otherwise unfit for human use; 
7.  All wires over streets, alleys or public grounds which are strung less than fifteen (15) feet above the surface of the street or ground; 
8.  All loud and discordant noises or vibrations of any kind; 
9.  All obstructions of streets, alleys, sidewalks or crosswalks and all excavations in or under the same, except as permitted by the ordinances of the village, or which, although made in accordance with such ordinances, are kept or maintained for an unreasonable length of time after the purpose thereof has been accomplished; 
10.  All open and unguarded pits, wells, excavations or unused basements freely accessible from any public street, alley or sidewalk; 
11.  All abandoned refrigerators or iceboxes from which the doors and other covers have not been removed or which are not equipped with a device for opening from the inside by pushing only with the strength of a small child; 
12.  Any unauthorized or unlawful use of property abutting on a public street, alley or sidewalk or of a public street, alley or sidewalk which causes large crowds of people to gather, obstructing traffic and free use of the streets or sidewalks; 
13.  Any advertisements or signs affixed to any building, wall, fence, sidewalk, street or other private or public property without permission of the owner thereof; 
14.  The operation in any building or on any premises of any radio device or mechanical musical instrument or device of any kind whereby the sound therefrom is projected or cast directly upon the public streets or public places, or such device is maintained and operated for advertising purposes or for the purpose of attracting the attention of the passing public, or such device is so placed and operated that the sounds coming therefrom can be heard to the annoyance, inconvenience or discomfort of travelers upon any street or public place or of any persons occupying or being upon neighboring premises; 
15.  Any sign or awning which is in an unsafe condition, or which overhangs any roadway, or which overhangs any sidewalk less than eight feet above the sidewalk surface; 
16.  Any barbed wire fence or barbed wire railing fronting on any street; 
17.  Any structure, material or condition which constitutes a fire hazard or will impair the extinguishing of any fire; 
18.  Any nuisance so defined by state statutes; 
19.  Any outdoor swimming pool in the village that is in a rear yard abutting a public park, pedestrian way, bike path, or other publicly owned land that is not protected by a fence or wall at least three feet six inches in height with a self-latching and self-closing gate, unless such pool is less than twenty-four (24) inches deep or has a surface area less than two hundred fifty (250) square feet. 
(Prior code § 12.02) 
8.28.030 - Abatement of public nuisances. 
A.  Inspection of Premises. Whenever a complaint is made to a village official that a public nuisance exists the notified official shall promptly notify the proper village department which shall inspect or cause to be inspected the premises and shall make a written report of the findings. Whenever possible, the inspecting officer shall cause photographs to be made of the premises. 
B.  Summary Abatement. 
1.  Notice to Owner. If the inspecting officer shall determine that a public nuisance exists on private property and that there is great and immediate danger to the public health, safety, peace, morals or decency, the president may direct the chief of police, or a deputy sheriff, to serve a notice on the owner, or, if the owner cannot be found, on the occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance and to post a copy of the notice on the premises. Such notice shall direct the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance to abate or remove such nuisance within twenty-four (24) hours or such time as is reasonable, and shall state that unless such nuisance is so abated, the village will cause the same to be abated and will charge the cost thereof to the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining the same, as the case may be. 
2.  Abatement by Village. If the nuisance is not abated within the time provided, or if the owner, occupant or person causing the nuisance cannot be found, the president, or other village official whom the president shall designate, shall cause the abatement or removal of such public nuisance. 
C.  Abatement by Court Action. If the inspecting officer shall determine that a public nuisance exists on private premises but that the nature of such nuisance is not such as to threaten great and immediate danger to the public health, safety, peace, morals or decency, the inspecting officer shall file a written report of his or her findings with the president who shall cause an action to abate such nuisance to be commenced in the name of the village. 
(Prior code § 12.03) 
8.28.040 - Cost of abatement.
