    In addition to any other penalty imposed by this chapter for the erection, contrivance, creation, continuance or maintenance of a public nuisance, the cost of abating a public nuisance by the village shall be collected as a debt from the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining the nuisance, and if notice to abate the nuisance has been given to the owner, such cost shall be assessed against the real estate as other special taxes. 
(Prior code § 12.04) 
8.28.050 - Chronic nuisance properties. 
A.  Definition. A "chronic nuisance property" means any property upon which three or more nuisance activities or conditions, as defined in this chapter or elsewhere in the Grayslake Municipal Code, have occurred during any one hundred twenty (120) day period; such chronic nuisance property status shall result either from (i) three distinct types of nuisance conditions or activities on such property (even if arising from the same factual circumstances or investigation), (ii) three separate factual events that have been separately investigated by the village or any law government agency involving the same nuisance condition or activity, or (iii) a combination of three conditions, activities, or events as described in (i) and (ii). 
B.  General. A property that is found to be a chronic nuisance property shall remain a chronic nuisance property until such time that the village manager or the manager's designee certifies that the property has remained nuisance-free for twenty-four (24) consecutive months. 
C.  Enforcement. 
1.  Notice. Upon determination by the village manager that a property is a chronic nuisance property, the village manager shall cause to be served upon the owner of such property a notice that the property has been found to be a chronic nuisance property. If the owner of such property cannot be found after reasonable efforts, the notice required by this provision may be served upon the occupant of the property or upon the person or persons causing, permitting, or maintaining any then-existing nuisances on the property. The notice shall direct the recipient of the notice to abate or remove such nuisance within twenty-four (24) hours or such time as is reasonable, and shall state that if the nuisance is not abated or removed in such time, the village may take appropriate action to abate or remove such nuisance at the sole cost and expense of the recipient of the notice. 
2.  Penalties. 
a.  After the village has given notice in accordance with subsection (C)(1) of this section, in addition to all other remedies available to the village, and upon the failure of the recipient of the notice to abate or remove nuisances on the property within the time specified by such notice, the village may initiate abatement or enforcement actions with respect to any new, recurring, or continued nuisance condition or activity on such chronic nuisance property without further notice. 
b.  The village may record on the chain of title for such property in the Lake County recorder's office a notice that such property is a chronic nuisance, provided that a further notice shall later be recorded at such time that the property ceases to be a chronic nuisance property. 
c.  In addition to or in lieu of the actions authorized under Section 8.28.030 of this chapter, under this section, or under any other provision of this code, the village may request a court of competent jurisdiction for injunctive relief, a cease and desist order, or any other necessary or convenient relief to abate all nuisances on a chronic nuisance property. 
d.  In addition to any fines authorized by this chapter, by the Grayslake Municipal Code, or by statute, whoever suffers or permits any public nuisance or nuisance as specified in this code to exist or continue upon such chronic nuisance property in violation of this section shall be subject to a separate fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation of this section exists or continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2006-0-07 § 2) 
Chapter 8.32 - NUISANCE VEHICLES AND JUNK 
Sections: 

8.32.010 - Definitions. 
    Terms used in this chapter mean as follows: 
    "Abandoned vehicle" means a vehicle located on public or private property which is allowed to remain on public property, or on private property without the consent of the owner, for a period of more than twenty-four (24) hours. 
    "Inoperable vehicle" means a vehicle which in its present state is incapable of being operated on a public highway and has remained in such state for a period of thirty (30) days. 
    "Junk" means and includes, but is not limited to, discarded paper, cartons, boxes, barrels, wood, plastics, metals, pieces of glass, crockery and other discarded manufactured items. 
    "Major recreational equipment" means and includes travel trailers, pickup campers or coaches, motorized dwellings, tent trailers, jet skis, snow mobiles, boats and boat trailers, and the like, cases or boxes used for transporting recreational equipment, whether occupied or not, and any other vehicle whose primary purpose is recreational or any trailer whose primary purpose is used for transporting recreational equipment. 
    "Vehicle" means and includes automobile, truck, bus and similar vehicle designed for operation on public highways. 
(Ord. 2007-0-44 § 2 (part): prior code § 12.08(a)) 
8.32.020 - Nuisances declared. 
    The following are declared to be public nuisances when they exist upon property within the corporate limits of Grayslake: 
A.  The storage outside of an enclosed building of one or more abandoned or inoperable vehicles or parts thereof, or of any junk or debris, machinery or equipment not in operable condition, except on property in a zone in which a junk yard is permitted under the zoning ordinance of Grayslake, and which meets the standards for a junk yard set forth in the zoning ordinance. 
B.  Storage or use of major recreational equipment in residential districts. No major recreational equipment shall be parked or stored on any lot in a residential district except in a garage or carport or behind the nearest portion of a building to a street; provided, however, that motorized dwellings, campers or coaches, with the exception of boats, may be parked anywhere on residential premises for not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours during loading or unloading and not more than forty-eight (48) hours in a seven-day period. No such equipment shall be used for living, sleeping, or housekeeping purposes when parked or stored on a residential lot, or in any location not approved for such use. 
C.  Storage of major recreational equipment in nonresidential zones. No major recreational equipment shall be parked or stored outside of an enclosed building, in a nonresidential zone, unless the property's "principal use," as defined by the village's zoning ordinance is selling or storing major recreational equipment. 
(Ord. 2007-0-44 § 2 (part): prior code § 12.08(b)) 
8.32.030 - Enforcement. 
    The building commissioner is designated as the enforcing officer of this chapter with the assistance of the police department. Any authorized employees of such department shall have the authority to issue nontraffic complaint tickets to any person violating the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 12.08(c)) 
8.32.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    The owner of any vehicle, junk, or major recreational vehicle declared to be a nuisance under this chapter or any person owning, leasing, occupying or having control of property on which a nuisance exists shall be issued a nontraffic complaint ticket by an authorized official and be given a reasonable time, but no less than forty-eight (48) hours, to correct the violation. If the owner, lessee, occupant, or person having control of the property fails to correct the violation within the prescribed time, he or she shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined a sum not less than five dollars and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day upon which a violation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. Further, if the owner fails to correct the violation within the prescribed time, the village, through its properly designated officers, shall have the right to secure a court order to enter upon the property and correct the violation, and shall have a lien against the property for the reasonable cost of correction. 
(Prior code § 12.08(d)) 
Chapter 8.36 - OPEN BURNING 
Sections: 

8.36.010 - Open burning regulations. 
A.  Burning upon Public Pavements. It is unlawful to burn anything upon the paved part of any public street, sidewalk or alley within the corporate limits of Grayslake. 
B.  Certain Open Burning Prohibited. The open burning of garbage, of automobile tires, or of trash other than that excepted in this subsection, within the corporate limits of the village, is defined and prohibited as a nuisance; provided and excepting, however, this shall not be construed to include or to prohibit the open burning upon private property, or upon the shoulders, ditches, edges of parkways, or upon the other unpaved parts of public thoroughfares, of well-dried leaves, foliage clippings, brush, trees, grass clippings or other natural vegetation, or of other dry materials productive of no annoying smoke, fumes or odors. 
C.  Open Burning Creating Smoke or Other Annoyance or Fire Hazard. In case any open burning within the village creates smoke, fumes or odor annoyance over neighboring property, either public or private, including (without limitation) over any public street or alley, or creates a fire hazard, then upon direction of any police officer, it shall be the duty of the person creating the open burning, or of the person in possession of the premises where such open burning occurs, to take prompt steps to abate the fire, and in case of a failure so to do, such open burning shall be deemed a nuisance under this section and a violation of the provisions of this section. 
    In case the person in possession of any such premises cannot be found, or in case it proves impractical for any such police officer to give any such direction, then the village may abate the fire, and the reasonable expense of such abatement shall be paid to the village by the person or persons in possession of the property promptly on demand. Fires accidentally caused shall not be considered a violation of this section if reported promptly to the village or agency providing fire services to the village, for assistance in abatement. 
D.  Burning Contrary to Law. Nothing set forth in this section shall be construed as any authorization to conduct any burning otherwise prohibited by law. 
(Prior code § 12.11) 
8.36.020 - Burning of leaves and yard waste prohibited. 
    Except as authorized in this section, the burning or deposit by any person of leaves or yard wastes, or both, upon any street, sidewalk, or public place, or upon any private property is declared to be and prohibited as a nuisance. Exceptions to said prohibition are limited to the following: 
A.  Nothing in this section shall prevent burning of branches, wood, or logs where the primary purpose thereof is for cooking food or heating liquids for human consumption; 
B.  Nothing in this section shall prevent the placement of leaves into piles between the edge of pavement and the sidewalk or within fifteen (15) feet from the edge of pavement in areas without sidewalks when leaves are being collected by a vacuum or other mechanical process in accordance with a leaf disposal program provided by village contract; 
C.  Nothing in this section shall prevent the placement of leaves or yard waste used for composting upon private property in conformance with village ordinance; 
D.  Nothing in this section shall prevent the placement of leaves or yard waste in approved bags or garbage containers in accordance with a yard waste disposal service provided by village contract; 
E.  Upon proper application where particular hardship or unique circumstances are demonstrated, the village may grant a special use permit varying the requirements of this section. 
(Prior code § 12.12) 
Chapter 8.40 - WEEDS 
Sections: 

8.40.010 - Weed regulations generally. 
A.  Excessive Growth. It is unlawful for any owner, lessee or occupant having control of any lot or parcel of land including the parkway situated in the village, and within two hundred (200) feet of any building occupied as a residence, to allow or maintain on any lot or parcel of land including the parkway any growth of noxious weeds or grasses to a height in excess of eight (8) inches. Noxious weeds or grasses shall not include cultivated flowers or gardens. 
B.  Noxious Weeds. For the purpose of this section, the term "noxious weeds" shall include the following: Canada thistle and all its varieties, perennial show thistle, common ragweed, giant ragweed, common burdock, cocklebur, poison ivy, wild carrot, lambsquater [lambsquarter], carlock, wild mustard, common milkweed, jimson, rough pigweed, wild hemp, curled dock, poison hemlock, cocklebur or any weed designated as a noxious by the State Department of Agriculture (Illinois Noxious Weed Law, 505 ILCS 100/1 et seq.). 
C.  Duty to Destroy. It shall be the duty of all owners of land on which noxious weeds are growing to destroy the same before they reach a seed-bearing stage and to prevent such weeds from perpetuating themselves. 
D.  Notice to Owner-Destruction by Village. The village shall notify, in writing, the owner, agent or occupant of any lands on which noxious weeds or grasses are permitted to grow in violation of this chapter. Such notice shall contain a statement of the methods of treating and eradicating such noxious weeds or grasses as a summary of the provisions of this section. Failure of the village to give such written notice shall not constitute a defense to any action to enforce payment of any penalty provided for violation of this section. In any case such owner, agent or occupant shall refuse or neglect to destroy any such noxious weeds or grasses after written notice transmitted to such owner, agent or occupant by the village, it shall be the duty of the village to enter upon such lands and to destroy such noxious weeds or grasses or cause the same to be destroyed. 
E.  Control Fund. Any fine collected for the violation of this section shall become a part of the general fund of the village. 
F.  Removal by Village-Ownership Unknown. In the case of property such as abandoned subdivisions and all other lands where definite ownership is not known to the village and cannot be established, it shall be the duty of the village to cause the destruction of noxious weeds found upon such property in accordance with provisions of this section. 
G.  Recovery of Costs by Village. Any expense incurred by the village in destroying any noxious weeds or grasses pursuant to this section shall be paid by the owner of such land, and the village shall have a lien against such land for such expense, which lien may be enforced pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7. Any owner who shall refuse or neglect to destroy such noxious weeds or grasses as provided for in this section shall be subject to the penalties provided for violation of this code. 
(Amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 12.05) 
(Ord. No. 2010-0-21, § 2, 8-3-2010) 
Title 9 - PUBLIC PEACE, MORALS AND WELFARE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 9.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

9.04.010 - Purpose. 
A.  The provisions of this chapter shall be construed in accordance with the general purposes of this code, to: 
1.  Forbid and prevent the commission of offenses; 
2.  Define adequately the act and mental state which constitute each offense, and limit the condemnation of conduct as criminal when it is without fault; 
3.  Prescribe penalties which are proportionate to the seriousness of offenses and which permit recognition of differences in rehabilitation possibilities among individual offenders; 
4.  Prevent arbitrary or oppressive treatment of persons accused or convicted of offenses. 
B.  The commission of any of the acts described in this chapter is unlawful and is prohibited. 
(Prior code § 42.01) 
9.04.020 - Definitions. 
    Terms used in this chapter mean as follows: 
    "Act" means and includes a failure or omission to take action. 
    "Conduct" means an act or a series of acts, and the accompanying mental state. 
    "Dwelling", except as otherwise provided in this chapter, means a building or portion thereof, a tent, a vehicle, or other enclosed space which is used or intended for use as a human habitation, home or residence. 
    For the purposes of this code, "dwelling" means a house, apartment, mobile home, trailer, or other living quarters in which at the time of the alleged offense the owners or occupants actually reside or in their absence intend within a reasonable period of time to reside. 
    "Misdemeanor ordinance violation" means any offense for which the fine shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and for which no term of imprisonment is sought or provided. 
    "Offense" means a violation of any penal statute of the state. 
    "Peace officer" means any person who by virtue of his or her office or public employment is vested by law with a duty to maintain public order or to make arrests for offenses, whether that duty extends to all offenses or is limited to specific offenses. 
    "Person" means an individual, public or private corporation, government, partnership, or unincorporated association. 
    "Public employee" means a person who is elected to office pursuant to statute, or who is appointed to any office which is established, and the qualifications and duties of which are prescribed, by statute, to discharge a public duty for the state or any of its political subdivisions. 
    "Reasonable belief" or "reasonably believes" means that the person concerned, acting as a reasonable person, believes that the described facts exist. 
(Prior code § 42.02) 
9.04.030 - Rights of defendant. 
A.  General Limitations. All prosecutions under any section of this chapter must be commenced within eighteen (18) months after the commission. 
B.  Limitations upon Concurrent Prosecution. Any local prosecution commenced by the village may be terminated by the village prosecutor upon proper notice and an order of a court of competent jurisdiction prior to jeopardy attaching without prejudice to the People of the State of Illinois to commence a similar prosecution under the same or similar state statute. 
(Prior code § 42.03) 
Chapter 9.08 - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND DECENCY 
Sections: 

9.08.010 - Disorderly conduct. 
A.  A person commits disorderly conduct when he or she knowingly: 
1.  Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the peace; or 
2.  Enters upon the property of another and for the lewd or unlawful purpose deliberately looks into a dwelling on the property through any window or other opening in it. 
B.  Any person violating subsection (a)(1) of this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first offense, and not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a second offense or subsequent offenses for each offense. Any person violating subsection (a)(2) shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. (Amended during 2001 codification: prior code § 42.18) 
9.08.020 - Assault. 
A.  A person commits an assault when, without lawful authority, he or she engages in conduct which places another in reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery. 
B.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.04) 
9.08.030 - Battery. 
A.  A person commits battery if he or she intentionally or knowingly without legal justification and by any means, (1) causes bodily harm to an individual; or (2) makes physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with an individual. 
B.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.05) 
9.08.040 - Reckless conduct. 
A.  A person who causes bodily harm to or endangers the bodily safety of an individual by any means, commits reckless conduct if he or she performs recklessly the acts which cause the harm or endanger safety, whether they otherwise are lawful or unlawful. 
B.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.06) 
9.08.050 - Possession of cannabis-Violations-Penalty. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person knowingly to possess cannabis within the village limits. 
B.  Any person who violates this section with respect to: 
1.  Up to ten (10) grams of any substance containing cannabis is guilty and shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. 
2.  More than ten (10) grams but not more than thirty (30) grams of any substance containing cannabis is guilty and shall be fined two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each offense. 
C.  No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. (Amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 42.20) 
(Ord. No. 2017-0-01, § 2, 1-3-2017) 
9.08.055 - Sale and possession of drug paraphernalia. 
A.  Definitions. Whenever the following words or terms are used in this section they shall have the meanings ascribed to them below: 
    "Cannabis" means marijuana, hashish, and other substances which are identified as including any parts of the plant Cannabis sativa, whether growing or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such plant; and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of such plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinal (THC) and all other cannabinal derivatives, including its naturally occurring or synthetically produced ingredients, whether produced directly or indirectly by extraction, or independently by means of chemical synthesis; but shall not include the mature stalks of such plant, fiber produced from such stalks, oil or cake made fro the seeds of such plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of such mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil or cake, or the sterilized seed of such plant which is incapable of germination. 
    "Controlled substance" means a drug, substance, or immediate precursor as defined in Article II of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act, 720 ILCS 570/100 et seq. 
    "Deliver" means the actual constructive, or attempted transfer of possession, with or without consideration, whether or not there is an agency relationship. 
    "Drug paraphernalia" means all equipment, products, and materials of any kind which are peculiar to and marketed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body cannabis or a controlled substance. This includes, but is not limited to: 
1.  Kits peculiar to and marketed for use in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, or preparing cannabis or a controlled substance; 
2.  Isomerization devices peculiar to and marketed for use in increasing the potency of any species of plant which is cannabis or a controlled substance; 
3.  Testing equipment peculiar to and marketed for private home use in identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness, or purity of cannabis or a controlled substance; 
4.  Diluents and adulterants peculiar to and marketed for cutting cannabis or a controlled substance by private persons; 
5.  Objects peculiar to and marketed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil into the human body including, where applicable, the following items: 
a.  Water pipes; 
b.  Carburetion tubes and devices; 
c.  Smoking and carburetion masks; 
d.  Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials; 
e.  Carburetor pipes; 
f.  Electric pipes; 
g.  Air-driven pipes; 
h.  Chillums; 
i.  Bongs; 
j.  Ice pipes or chillers; 
6.  Any item whose purpose, as announced or described by the seller, is for use in violation of this section. 
B.  Sale or Delivery. 
1.  Any person who keeps for sale, offers for sale, sells, or delivers for any commercial consideration any item of drug paraphernalia may be fined up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such item. 
2.  Any store, place, or premises where any item of drug paraphernalia is kept for sale, offered for sale, sold, or delivered for any commercial consideration is declared to be a public nuisance, subject to the abatement procedures contained in Title 8 of this code. 
C.  Possession. 
1.  A fine not exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) may be imposed on a person who knowingly possesses an item of drug paraphernalia with the intent to use it in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis or a controlled substance into the human body, or in preparing cannabis or a controlled substance for that use. 
2.  In determining intent under subsection 1, the proximity of the cannabis or controlled substances to drug paraphernalia, or the presence of cannabis or drug paraphernalia, may be considered. 
D.  Exempt Items. 
1.  This section shall not apply to: 
a.  Items marketed for use in the preparation, compounding, packaging, labeling, or other use of cannabis or a controlled substance as an incident to lawful research, teaching, or chemical analysis and not for sale; or 
b.  Items marketed for, or historically and customarily used in connection with the planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, or inhaling of tobacco or any other lawful substance, including, but not limited to, garden hoses, rakes, sickles, baggies, tobacco pipes, and cigarette-rolling paper; or 
c.  Items listed in subsection 9.08.055(D)(1)(b) above that are marketed for decorative purposes, when such items have been rendered completely inoperable or incapable of being used for any illicit purpose prohibited by this section. 
2.  In determining whether or not a particular item is exempted under this subsection, the following factors may be considered: 
a.  The general, usual, customary, and historical use to which the item involved has been put; 
b.  Expert evidence concerning the ordinary or customary use of the item and the effect of any peculiarity in the design or engineering of the device upon its functioning; 
c.  Any written instructions accompanying the delivery of the item concerning the purposes or uses to which the item can or may be put; 
d.  Any oral instructions provided by the seller of the item at the usual time and place of sale or commercial delivery; 
e.  Any national or local advertising concerning the design, purpose, or use of the item involved and the entire context in which such advertising occurs; 
f.  The manner, place, and circumstances in which the item was displayed for sale, as well as any item or items displayed for sale or otherwise exhibited upon the premises where the sale was made; 
g.  Whether the owner or anyone in control of the object is a legitimate supplier of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed distributor or dealer of tobacco products; and 
h.  The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community. 
E.  Forfeiture and Seizure of Property. 
1.  All drug paraphernalia is subject to forfeiture by the local law enforcement agency. 
2.  Property subject to forfeiture under this section may be seized by any peace officer upon process issued by any court having jurisdiction over the property. Pursuant to 720 ILCS 600/5, judgments in favor of the village in a forfeiture proceeding based upon this section against a person's specific property shall serve as process authorizing a police officer to seize such property without further process. 
3.  Pursuant to 720 ILCS 600/5, seizure may be made without process if there is probable cause to believe that the property is directly dangerous to health or safety and existing circumstances do not allow reasonable time for the officer to obtain lawful process. 
4.  The presence of items which are deemed to violate this section or are otherwise subject to its forfeiture provisions in an inventory shall not subject the entire inventory to seizure or forfeiture. 
5.  Property taken or detained under this section shall not be subject to replevin, but is deemed to be in the custody of the law enforcement department, subject only to the order and judgments of the circuit court having jurisdiction over the forfeiture proceedings. Property seized under this section may be placed under seal. 
6.  No disposition may be made of the property under seal until the validity of the seizure has been determined in the circuit court, unless such court upon application therefor, orders the sale of perishable substances and the deposit of the proceeds of the sale with the clerk of the court. The circuit court shall rule on the validity of the seizure within thirty (30) days after the seizure, unless a continuance is obtained by a person from whom the items were seized or a person who otherwise has standing to complain, or by the village for good cause shown. In no event shall a continuance be granted to the village pursuant to the section extend beyond thirty (30) days. If judgment is entered in favor of the person from whom the property is seized, all seized property shall be returned immediately. Pursuant to 720 ILCS 66/5, appeals from orders of the circuit court shall be heard within sixty (60) days from the date judgment is entered. Judgments in favor of the person entitled to possession of the subject property shall serve as a mandate to the agency holding said property to return the same forthwith. 
7.  When property is forfeited under this section, the chief administrative officer of the seizing department or agency may retain it for official use, or forward it to the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs, United States Department of Justice, or its successor agency, for disposition. 
F.  Intent. It is the intent of the village that the provisions of this section shall be substantially in accordance with the requirements of the State Drug Paraphernalia Control Act, 720 ILCS 600/1 et seq. 
(Ord. 99-0-40 § 2) 
9.08.060 - Resisting or obstructing a peace officer. 
A.  A person who knowingly resists or obstructs the performance by one known to the person to be a peace officer of any jurisdiction within the village limits of any authorized act within his or her official capacity commits the offense of resisting or obstructing a peace officer. 
B.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.19) 
9.08.070 - Curfew regulations. 
A.  Curfew. It is unlawful for any person under the age of seventeen (17) to be present at or upon any public assembly, building, place, street, or highway at the following times, unless one of the exceptions listed in subsection B of this section applies: 
1.  Between 12:01 a.m. and six a.m. Saturday; 
2.  Between 12:01 a.m. and six a.m. Sunday; and 
3.  Between eleven p.m. on Sunday to Thursday, inclusive, and six a.m. on the following day. 
B.  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to any person under seventeen (17) years of age who is: 
1.  Accompanied and supervised by a parent, legal guardian, or other responsible companion approved by a parent or legal guardian and at least eighteen (18) years of age; 
2.  Engaged in a business or occupation which the laws of Illinois authorize a person under seventeen (17) years of age to perform; 
3.  Attending or traveling to or from an official school, religious or civic activity; 
4.  Attending or traveling to or from any assembly activity for which a permit has been lawfully issued; 
5.  Involved in an emergency involving the protection of a person or property from an imminent threat of serious bodily injury or substantial damage; or 
6.  Traveling between states or internationally from a location outside of Illinois to another location outside of Illinois. 
C.  Enforcement. A police officer shall not take any enforcement action under this section unless he or she reasonably believes that a violation of this section has occurred and that no exception listed in subsection B of this section is applicable. 
D.  Parental Responsibility. The parental responsibility regulations contained in this code shall apply to any parent, legal guardian, or other person that knowingly permits a person in his or her custody or control to violate subsection A of this section. 
E.  Penalty. Any person found guilty of violating subsection A of this section shall be fined not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. 2004-0-11 § 2: Ord. 99-0-41 § 2) 
9.08.080 - Firearm security. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to store or leave, within premises under his or her control, a firearm if the person knows or has reason to believe that a minor who does not have a firearm owner identification card is likely to gain access to the firearm without the lawful permission of the minor's parent, guardian, or person having charge of the minor, unless the firearm is: 
1.  Secured by a device or mechanism, other than the firearm safety, designed to render a firearm temporarily inoperable; 
2.  Placed in a securely locked box or container; or 
3.  Placed in some other location that a reasonable person would believe to be secured from a minor. 
B.  Subsection A does not apply if the minor: 
1.  Gains access to a firearm and uses it in a lawful act of self-defense or defense of another; or 
2.  Obtains the firearm by unlawful entry of the premises by the minor or another person. 
C.  For the purposes of the section, "firearm" shall have the same meaning as that contained in the Illinois Firearm Owners Identification Card Act, 430 ILCS 65/0.01 et seq. "Trigger lock" shall be defined as any operable device, other than the firearm's safety, that must be unlocked or disengaged in order to fire a firearm. 
(Ord. 2000-0-15 § 2) 
9.08.090 - Social host regulations. 
A.  For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall have the following stated meanings: 
    "Alcohol" means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, whiskey, rum, brandy, gin, or any other distilled spirits, including dilutions and mixtures thereof from whatever source or by whatever process produced. 
    "Alcoholic beverage" means alcohol, spirits, liquor, wine, beer, and every liquid or solid containing alcohol, spirits, wine, beer, and which contains one-half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume and which is fit for beverage purposes either alone or when diluted, mixed, or combined with other substances. 
    "Conveyance" means any vehicle, trailer, watercraft or container operated for the transportation of persons or property. 
    "Event" or "gathering" means any group of three or more persons who have assembled or gathered together for a social occasion or other activity. 
    "Host" means to aid, conduct, allow, entertain, organize, supervise, control, or permit a gathering or event. 
    "Illicit drugs" means any drug, substance or compound prohibited by law, including drugs prescribed by a physician which are in the possession of or used by someone other than the person to whom the drug was prescribed. 
    "Parent" means any person having legal custody of a juvenile: 
1.  As a natural, adoptive parent, or step-parent; 
2.  As a legal guardian; or 
3.  As a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of the court. 
    "Public place" means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office building, transport facilities, parks, businesses or parking lots. 
    "Reasonable steps" means controlling access to alcoholic beverages at the event or gathering; controlling the quantity of alcoholic beverages present at the event or gathering; verifying the age of persons attending the event or gathering by inspecting drivers licenses or other government-issued identification cards to ensure that minors do not consume alcoholic beverages while at the event or gathering; and supervising the activities of minors at the event or gathering, calling for police assistance in the event people under twenty-one (21) are in possession of alcohol at the event or gathering or advising law enforcement in advance of departing one's residence that the owner will be away and no underage person is authorized to be present and consume alcohol at the owner's residence. 
    "Religious ceremony" means the possession, consumption and dispensation of alcohol or an alcoholic beverage for the purpose of conducting any bone fide rite or religious ceremony. 
    "Residence" or "premises" means any home, yard, farm, field, land, apartment, condominium, hotel or motel room, or other dwelling unit, or a hall or meeting room, park, or any other place of assembly, public or private, whether occupied on a temporary or permanent basis whether occupied as a dwelling or specifically for a party or other social function, and whether owned, leased, rented, or used with or without permission or compensation. 
    "Underage person" means any individual under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, allow, host, or fail to take reasonable steps to prevent an event or gathering at his or her place of residence or other private property, public place, any other premises under his or her control, or in any conveyance where illicit drugs or alcoholic beverages have been consumed by an underage person, if such person either knows or reasonably should know that an underage person has consumed any illicit drugs or alcoholic beverages. 
1.  A person who permits, allows or hosts an event or gathering shall be deemed to have known or should have known that an underage person has consumed illicit drugs or alcoholic beverages if the person has not taken all reasonable steps to prevent the consumption of illicit drugs or alcoholic beverages by underage persons. 
2.  A person who permits, allows, or hosts an event or gathering shall be rebuttable presumed to have known or should have known that underage persons have consumed illicit drugs or alcoholic beverages if the person is present at the premises of the event or gathering at the time any underage person consumes illicit drugs or an alcoholic beverage. 
3.  This section shall not apply to conduct involving the use of alcoholic beverages that occurs at a religious ceremony or exclusively between an underage person and his or her parent or legal guardian, as permitted by Illinois state law. 
4.  It is the duty of any person who permits, allows or hosts an event or gathering at his or her place of residence or other private property, public place, any other premises under his or her control, or in any conveyance, where underage persons will be present, to take all reasonable steps to prevent the consumption of illicit drugs or alcoholic beverages by any underage person at the event or gathering. 
5.  A person who hosts an event or gathering does not have to be present at the event or gathering to be liable under this section. 
6.  A person who hosts an event or gathering shall not be in violation of this section if that person has requested assistance from the police department or other law enforcement agency to remove any person who refuses to abide by the host's performance of the duties imposed by this section or terminates the event or gathering because the host has been unable to prevent underage persons from consuming illicit drugs or alcoholic beverages despite having taken all reasonable steps to do so, provided such action is taken before any other person makes a complaint about the event or gathering. 
C.  Any person who violates or assists in the violation of any provision of this section 9.08.090 shall be deemed to have committed a petty offense and shall be fined not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each such violation. Each day on which, or during which, a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
1.  The first violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of no less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
2.  A second violation of this section by the same responsible person, within a twelve-month period shall be punishable by a fine of no less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
3.  A third or subsequent violation of this section by the same responsible person, within a twelve-month period shall be punishable by a fine of no less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or the maximum fine permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 2016-0-04, § 2, 3-1-2016) 
Chapter 9.12 - THEFT AND RELATED OFFENSES 
Sections: 

9.12.010 - Theft. 
A.  A person commits theft when he or she knowingly: 
1.  Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner; or 
2.  Obtains by deception control over property of the owner; or 
3.  Obtains by threat control over property of the owner; or 
4.  Obtains control over stolen property knowing the property to have been stolen or under such circumstances as would reasonably induce him or her to believe that the property was stolen; and 
a.  Intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of the property; 
b.  Knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the property in such manner as to deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit; or 
c.  Uses, conceals, or abandons the property knowing such use, concealment or abandonment probably will deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit. 
B.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.07) 
9.12.020 - False report of theft and other losses. 
A.  A person commits the offense of making a false report of theft and other losses when he or she knowingly makes a false report of a theft, destruction, damage or conversion of any property to a law enforcement agency or other governmental agency with the intent to defraud an insurer and is guilty of a Class A misdemeanor. 
B.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.08) 
9.12.030 - Theft from coin-operated machines. 
A.  A person commits theft from a coin-operated machine when he or she knowingly and without authority and with intent to commit a theft from such machine, opens, breaks into, tampers with, or damages a coin-operated machine. 
B.  As used in this section, the term "coin-operated machine" includes any automatic vending machine or any part thereof, parking meter, coin telephone, coin laundry machine, coin dry cleaning machine, amusement machine, music machine, vending machine dispensing goods or services, or money changer. 
C.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.09) 
9.12.040 - Retail theft. 
A.  A person commits the offense of retail theft when he or she knowingly: 
1.  Takes possession of, carries away, transfers or causes to be carried away or transferred, any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of retaining such merchandise or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full retail value of such merchandise; or 
2.  Alters, transfers, or removes any label, price tag, marking, indicia of value or any other markings which aid in determining value affixed to any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale, in a retail mercantile establishment and attempts to purchase such merchandise personally or in consort with another at less than the full retail value with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or 
3.  Transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale, in a retail mercantile establishment from the container in or on which such merchandise is displayed to any other container with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise; or 
4.  Under-rings with the intention of depriving the merchant of the full retail value of the merchandise; or 
5.  Removes a shopping cart from the premises of a retail mercantile establishment without the consent of the merchant given at the time of such removal with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such cart; or 
6.  Represents to a merchant that he or another is the lawful owner of property, knowing that such representation is false, and conveys or attempts to convey that property to a merchant who is the owner of the property in exchange for money, merchandise credit or other property of the merchant; or 
7.  Uses or possesses any theft detection shielding device or theft detection device remover with the intention of using such device to deprive the merchant permanently of the possession, use or benefit of any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail merchandise establishment without paying the full retail value of such merchandise. 
B.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.10) 
9.12.050 - Deceptive practices. 
A.  Definitions. As used in this section: 
    "Account holder" is any person having a checking account or savings account in a financial institution. 
    "Financial institution" means any bank, savings and loan association, credit union, or other depository of money, or medium of savings and collective investment. 
    "Intent to defraud" means to act wilfully, and with the specific intent to deceive or cheat, for the purpose of causing financial loss to another, or to bring some financial gain to oneself. It is not necessary to establish that any person was actually defrauded or deceived. 
B.  General Description. A person commits a deceptive practice when, with intent to defraud: 
1.  He or she causes another, by deception or threat to execute a document disposing of property or a document by which a pecuniary obligation is incurred; or 
2.  He or she knowingly makes or directs another to make a false or deceptive statement addressed to the public for the purpose of promoting the sale of property or services; or 
3.  With intent to obtain control over property or to pay for property, labor or services of another, he or she issues or delivers a check or other order upon a real or fictitious depository for the payment of money, knowing that it will not be paid by the depository. Failure to have sufficient funds or credit with the depository when the check or other order is issued or delivered, or when such check or other order is presented for payment and dishonored on each of two occasions at least seven days apart, is prima facie evidence that the offender knows that it will not be paid by the depository, and that he or she has the intent to defraud; 
4.  He or she issues or delivers a check or other order upon a real or fictitious depository in the amount exceeding seventy-five dollars ($75.00) in payment of an amount owed on any credit transaction for property, labor or services, or in payment of the entire amount owed on any credit transaction for property, labor or services, knowing that it will not be paid by the depository, and thereafter fails to provide funds or credit with the depository in the face amount of the check or order within seven days of receiving actual notice from the depository or payee of the dishonor of the check or order. 
C.  Violation-Penalty. A person convicted of deceptive practice under this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.11) 
9.12.060 - Civil liability for deceptive practices. 
A.  A person who issues a check or order to a payee in violation of Section 9.12.050(B)(3) and who fails to pay the amount of the check or order to the payee within thirty (30) days following a written demand delivered by certified mail to the person's last known address, shall be liable to the payee or a person subrogated to the rights of the payee for, in addition to the amount owing upon such check or order, damages of treble the amount so owing, but in no case less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus attorney fees and court costs. 
B.  A cause of action under this section may be brought in small claims court or in any other appropriate court. Prior to the hearing of any action under this section, the defendant may tender to the plaintiff and the plaintiff shall accept as satisfaction of the claim, an amount of money equal to the sum of the amount of the check and the incurred court costs, and service and attorney fees. 
(Prior code § 42.12) 
Chapter 9.16 - PROPERTY OFFENSES 
Sections: 

9.16.010 - Criminal damage to property. 
A.  Any of the following acts is a Class A misdemeanor and any such act when the damage to property exceeds three hundred dollars ($300.00) is a Class 4 felony: 
1.  Knowingly damages any property of another without his or her consent; or 
2.  Recklessly by means of fire or explosive damages property of another; or 
3.  Knowingly starts a fire on the land of another without his or her consent; or 
4.  Knowingly injures a domestic animal of another without his or her consent; or 
5.  Knowingly deposits on the land or in the building of another, without his or her consent, any stink bomb or any offensive smelling compound and thereby intends to interfere with the use by another of the land or building; 
6.  Knowingly damages the property of another without his or her consent by defacing, deforming or otherwise damaging such property by the use of paint or any other similar substance. 
B.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.14) 
9.16.020 - Trespass upon private property. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to commit a trespass upon private property within the village as defined in this section. 
B.  Any of the following shall constitute a trespass in violation of this section: 
1.  The entering upon the land, or any part thereof, of another, after receiving prior to such entry timely notice from the owner or occupant that such entry is forbidden, or the remaining upon the land of another after receiving notice from the owner or occupant to depart. 
2.  The throwing or placing of sticks, stones, rubbish, debris or any obnoxious or objectionable thing or material upon the land, or any part thereof, of another without the express consent of the owner or occupant of such land. 
3.  The throwing or placing of any article, vehicle or material upon the land of another with intent to annoy, or in violation of the express wishes of the owner or occupant of the land duly communicated in advance to the person, firm or corporation so throwing or placing same. 
    A person shall have received notice or communicated wishes from the owner or occupant of land within the meaning of any of the foregoing subsections if such person is notified personally, either orally or in writing, or if a printed or written notice forbidding such entry or prohibited action is conspicuously posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such land or the forbidden part thereof. 
4.  The entering upon or use of the land, or any part thereof, of a private property owner while wearing or using rollerblades, in-line skates, rollerskates, skateboards, or any other coasting device in a manner that is inconsistent with the terms of entry or use established by the owner or occupant of the land; provided, however, that the owner or occupant has provided written notice to the person entering upon or using the land, that this manner of entry or use is forbidden, in the form of a written or printed sign conspicuously posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such land. 
C.  Any person adjudged guilty of violating this section shall be fined not less than four dollars ($4.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Prior code § 42.17) 
9.16.030 - Criminal trespass to residence. 
A.  A person commits the offense of criminal trespass to a residence when, without authority, he or she knowingly enters or remains within any residence, including a house trailer. For purposes of this section, in the case of a multi-unit residential building or complex, "residence" shall only include the portion of the building or complex which is the actual dwelling place of any person and shall not include such places as common recreational areas or lobbies. 
B.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.13) 
9.16.040 - Criminal trespass to land. 
A.  Whoever enters upon the land or a building, other than a residence, or any part thereof of another, after receiving, prior to such entry, notice from the owner or occupant that such entry is forbidden, or remains upon the land or in a building, other than a residence, of another after receiving notice from the owner or occupant to depart, commits the offense of criminal trespass to land. 
B.  A person has received notice from the owner or occupant within the meaning of subsection A of this section if he or she has been notified personally, either orally or in writing, or if a printed or written notice forbidding such entry has been conspicuously posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such land or the forbidden part thereof. 
C.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.16) 
9.16.050 - Criminal damage of firefighting apparatus, hydrants or equipment. 
A.  A person who wilfully and maliciously cuts, injures, damages, tampers with or destroys or defaces any fire hydrant or any hose or any fire engine, or other public or private firefighting equipment, or any apparatus appertaining to such equipment, or intentionally opens any fire hydrant without proper authorization within the village limits is guilty of said offense. 
B.  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. No period of imprisonment shall be sought or imposed for violating this section. 
(Prior code § 42.15) 
9.16.060 - Unlawful sale or possession of spray paint or wide tipped markers. 
A.  Sales Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person or corporation operating a business in the village to sell either paint in spray cans or wide-tipped markers to any person under the age of eighteen (18). For the purpose of this section a "wide-tipped marker" shall be any marker containing a fluid which is not water soluble and has a point, brush or applicator or other writing surface of three-eighths inch or greater. 
B.  Possession Illegal; Exceptions. No person under the age of eighteen (18) shall possess within the village paint in a spray can or wide-tipped markers. This prohibition shall not apply to: 
1.  A child using paint or a marker while under the immediate supervision of his or her parent or legal guardian; 
2.  A student using paint or a marker while under the immediate supervision of his or her teacher; 
3.  An employee using paint or a marker at the direction and under the supervision of his or her employer. 
C.  Obtaining for Another. No person shall aid, assist, or abet a person under the age of eighteen (18) in obtaining possession of paint in a spray can or a wide-tipped marker. This prohibition shall not apply to: 
1.  A parent or legal guardian assisting and supervising his or her own child or ward in the use of paint or a marker; 
2.  A teacher assisting and supervising his or her students in the use of paint or a marker; 
3.  An employer assisting and supervising his or her employees in the use of paint or a marker. 
D.  Adult Responsibility. No person shall sell or otherwise transfer spray paint to a minor unless the minor is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian at the time of purchase or transfer. 
E.  False Identification. No minor shall at the time of purchase of a spray paint container, furnish fraudulent evidence of age in order to purchase same nor use the same. 
F.  Warning Displayed. Every place in the village where spray paint in cans or wide-tipped markers are sold shall display at all times, in a prominent location, a printed card which shall be issued by the village clerk and which shall read substantially as follows: 
1.  Minors, you are subject to a fine up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) under the ordinances of the Village of Grayslake, Illinois if you purchase spray paint in cans or wide-tipped markers, or misrepresent your age for the purpose of purchasing spray paint in cans or wide-tipped markers. Official photo identification will be required to prove age before purchase. 
G.  Any person who violates or assists in the violation of any provision of this chapter shall be deemed to have committed a petty offense and shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such violation. 
(Ord. No. 2011-0-24, § 1, 12-6-2011) 
Title 10 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 
Chapters: 
Chapter 10.04 - ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED 
Sections: 

10.04.010 - Illinois Vehicle Code-Adopted by reference. 
A.  Finding of Fact. Whereas, three copies of The Illinois Vehicle Code as amended, current edition, and published by the Secretary of State of the State of Illinois, have been placed on file in the office of the village clerk for public use, inspection and examination continuously for more than thirty (30) days prior to the date hereof, and said copies thereof will hereafter be so kept on file in said office for such public use, inspection and examination; and, whereas prior to the aforesaid thirty (30) day period, public notice was given in The Grayslake Times, a weekly newspaper published in the village and having a general circulation therein, that three copies of said Illinois Vehicle Code would be so on file during the thirty (30) day period, as well as subsequent thereto, and that the corporate authorities of the village would give consideration to and might adopt all or any portion of the Illinois Vehicle Code by reference, at any time after the lapse of the thirty (30) day period, without setting forth the provisions of said Code or the portion thereof so adopted in full, all as shown by the certificate of publication of said public notice on file in the office of the village clerk, the corporate authorities of the village find as facts the statement aforesaid. 
B.  Adoption by Reference of The Illinois Vehicle Code. All of the Illinois Vehicle Code as amended, current edition, of the State of Illinois, with the exception of the penalty clauses thereof, is adopted by reference, and the provisions thereof are expressly incorporated by such reference as ordinance regulations of the village. Accordingly, when proceedings are instituted hereunder, or when the provisions of this chapter are in any way invoked or become pertinent, the numbering and lettering of the articles, sections, paragraphs, and subparagraphs as employed in the Illinois Vehicle Code as amended, and as adopted and incorporated by reference herein, shall be cited and referred to by the same numbering and lettering hereunder, as articles, sections, paragraphs and subparagraphs of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 41.01) 
Chapter 10.08 - SUPPLEMENTAL TRAFFIC REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

10.08.010 - Amendments to speed limits. 
    Section 10.04.010 which adopts the Illinois Vehicle Code which designates maximum speed limits on all streets in residentially zoned areas is amended as follows: 
A.  All streets in residentially zoned areas shall have a maximum speed limit of twenty-five (25) mph except for the streets listed in subsection B of this section which are designated thirty (30) mph. 
B.  Streets designated 30 mph: 
The full length of: 1. Lake Street; 2. Brae Loch Road; 3. Drury Lane; 4. Harris Road; 5. Atkinson Road.  
C.  Center Street, between Route 83 and Lake Street in the downtown business district, shall have a maximum speed limit of twenty-five (25) mph. 
(Prior code § 41.01A) 
(Ord. 2008-0-21, § 1, 9-2-2008; Ord. No. 2009-0-21, § 1, 9-15-2009) 
10.08.020 - Through streets and stop intersections. 
    The board of trustees may designate through streets and stop intersections in the village. When appropriate signs and signals are erected in accordance with such designations, no person shall operate a vehicle in violation of the instructions of any such sign or signal. 
(Prior code § 41.06) 
10.08.030 - Right-of-way at crosswalks. 
A.  When traffic-control signals are not in place or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger. 
B.  Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(Prior code § 41.07) 
10.08.040 - Taxicabs. 
    No taxicab driver shall park his or her cab or solicit passengers on the streets of the village within the area described and bounded, except in areas set aside by the board of trustees with the approval of the chief of police. 
(Prior code § 41.08) 
10.08.050 - Deliveries from trucks prohibited in business zone. 
    Center Street between Slusser Street and Seymour Avenue is designated as a business zone. No deliveries shall be made from any truck in such business zone between the hours of seven a. m. and eight p.m. 
(Prior code § 41.09) 
10.08.060 - Reckless driving. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle in a reckless or wanton manner, or in a careless manner, or in a negligent manner, or so as to unnecessarily endanger life or property. 
(Prior code § 41.03) 
10.08.070 - Crossing roadway centerlines. 
A.  Crossing Certain Roadways Prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle across the centerline of the following roadways within the village to turn into a parking space or for any other purpose, unless said motor vehicle is crossing the centerline at an intersection or driveway to a business or residence: 
1.  Center Street, between Lake Street and Seymour Street; 
2.  Whitney Street; 
3.  Slusser Street, between Hawley Street and Park Avenue. 
B.  Penalty for Noncompliance. Any person who violates, neglects, or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed to have committed a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such violation. 
(Prior code § 41.03A) 
10.08.080 - Authority to designate one-way streets and alleys. 
    The board of trustees may designate one-way streets and alleys within the corporate limits of the village and it is unlawful for traffic to be driven thereon in violation of such designation. Signs shall be installed and maintained to indicate and carry out the provisions of this section and to regulate, warn or guide traffic; and no such designation shall become or remain in effect unless and until appropriate signs are posted to show such one-way streets or alleys. The foregoing shall be subject to the limitations of 625 ILCS 5/11-301-5/11-304. (Amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 41.05) 
10.08.090 - Minibikes and trail bikes. 
A.  For the purpose of this chapter every motor vehicle which is self-propelled by power obtained by the combustion of gasoline which is designed with a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and is designed to travel on not more than three wheels, but excluding a tractor, and which is not subject to license under the statutes of the state of Illinois shall be a minibike or trail bike. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to operate any minibike or trail bike within the corporate limits of the village. 
(Prior code § 41.04) 
10.08.100 - Motorized vehicles in greenbelt area. 
A.  Findings and Determinations. It is found and determined that the operation of motorized vehicles on village bicycle trails and in greenbelt areas is disruptive to the use and enjoyment of these public facilities by the community, promotes destruction of natural areas within the greenbelt areas, and exposes the citizenry to unnecessary danger and injury. 
B.  Motorized Vehicles Prohibited. No person shall operate a motorized vehicle or cause a motorized vehicle to be upon any greenbelt area of the village. For purposes of this section, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    "Greenbelt areas" means any right-of-way or land owned or maintained by the village on which is located any bicycle trail, path, or walking trail having an impervious or improved surface of a width not less than four feet nor greater than ten (10) feet. 
    "Motorized vehicle" means every vehicle which is self-propelled (including snowmobiles) except for vehicles moved solely by human power and motorized wheelchairs. 
    "Vehicle" means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn. 
C.  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. 
(Prior code § 41.31) 
10.08.110 - Excessive use of engine braking systems prohibited. 
A.  Purpose. The village recognizes that the use of engine braking systems that employ internal mechanisms within a vehicle engine or similar equipment as part of a system that provides supplemental stopping power for vehicles ("engine braking systems") produces excessive noise when employed, but the use of engine braking systems is necessary and appropriate when needed for immediate and emergency stops. The use of engine braking systems at times or under circumstances when not necessary or desirable for stopping a vehicle in compliance with applicable traffic signals and regulations constitutes a public nuisance. 
B.  Excessive Use of Engine Braking Systems Prohibited. The operation or actuation by drivers of commercial vehicles of engine braking systems that emit excessive noise shall be prohibited in the village except when necessary to effect an immediate stop to avoid a collision with a person or another vehicle. 
C.  Signage. The village may post signs stating "Excessive Engine Braking Noise Prohibited" pursuant to the rules adopted by the Illinois Department of Transportation for the erection and placement of those signs. 
D.  Penalty. Any person violating the prohibition in Subsection B. of this section shall be subject to a fine of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(Ord. No. 2012-0-25, § 2, 7-3-2012) 
Chapter 10.12 - TRUCK ROUTES AND WEIGHT LIMITS 
Sections: 

10.12.010 - Definitions. 
    Terms used in this chapter mean as follows: 
    "Tandem axle" means any two or more consecutive axles whose centers are more than forty (40) inches and not more than ninety (90) inches apart, measured to the nearest inch between any two adjacent axles in the series. 
    "Truck" means every motor vehicle designed, used, or maintained primarily for transportation of property. 
(Prior code § 41.10(a)) 
10.12.020 - Trucks restricted to certain posted routes. 
A.  No person shall operate or cause to be operated, any truck upon any street within the village, unless permitted under Section 10.12.040. 
B.  An operator of any truck stopped on a street which is not posted "Truck Route" shall furnish documentation showing point of origin and destination for said truck. 
C.  All signs posted as required by this section shall be done so at the direction of the chief of police. 
(Prior code § 41.10(b)) 
10.12.030 - Police officers to weigh vehicles and require removal of excess loads. 
A.  Any police officer having reason to believe that the weight of a vehicle and load is unlawful shall require the driver to stop and submit to a weighing of the same either by means of a portable or stationary scales. If such scales are not available at the place where such vehicle is stopped, the police officer shall require that such vehicle be driven to the nearest available scale that has been tested and approved by the Illinois Department of Agriculture. 
B.  Whenever an officer, upon weighing a vehicle and the load, determines that the weight is unlawful, such officer shall require the driver to stop the vehicle in a suitable place and remain standing until such portion of the load is removed as may be necessary to reduce the weight of the vehicle to the limit permitted in this chapter, and shall forthwith arrest the driver or owner. All material so unloaded shall be cared for by the owner or operator of the vehicle at the risk of such owner or operator. 
C.  Whenever any axle load of a vehicle exceeds the axle or tandem axle weight limits permitted by this chapter by two thousand (2,000) pounds or less, the owner or operator of the vehicle must shift or remove the excess so as to comply with this chapter. No overweight arrest ticket shall be issued to the owner or operator of the vehicle by any officer if the excess weight is shifted or removed as required by this chapter. 
(Prior code § 41.10(c)) 
10.12.040 - Truck routes designated. 
A.  The following streets shall be designated as through truck routes within the village, with no weight restrictions imposed other than those specified in 625 ILCS Ch. 5/15: 
1.  Illinois Route 45; 
2.  Illinois Route 83; 
3.  Illinois Route 120; 
4.  Illinois Route 137; 
5.  Alleghany Road - South of Route 120; 
6.  Washington Street; 
7.  Center Street - East of Route 83; 
8.  Ivanhoe Road. 
B.  The following streets shall be designated as local truck routes and restricted to trucks with a gross weight, including load, not to exceed seventy-three thousand two hundred eighty (73,280) pounds gross weight or sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds per axle: 
1.  Lake Street - From Washington Street to Center Street; 
2.  Ziegler Drive - From Center Street to Oriole Court; 
3.  Center Street - Route 83 to Lake Street; 
4.  Lake Street - South of Route 120; 
5.  Seymour - From Center Street to Hawley Street; 
6.  Hawley Street - From Seymour to Lake Street; 
7.  Wicks Street. 
C.  All other streets not posted "Through Truck Route" or "Local Truck Route" shall be restricted to trucks meeting the following requirements: 
1.  Gross weight, including load, not to exceed eight thousand (8,000) pounds; 
2.  Registered gross weight not to exceed eight thousand (8,000) pounds. 
D.  Local Deliveries. All trucks entering, passing through, or operating within the village for the purpose of delivering or picking up materials or merchandise shall use only the streets or roadways as set forth in subsection A of this section for trucks exceeding sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds per axle, and only on the streets or roadways set forth in subsections A or B of this section for trucks not in excess of sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds per axle or seventy-three thousand two hundred eighty (73,280) pounds gross weight, except said trucks may use other village streets for the purposes only of arriving or departing from a destination, for loading or unloading, which is not located or on one of said through truck routes or local routes, and such travel is permitted. When vehicles in excess of sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds per axle but not exceeding eighteen thousand (18,000) pounds per axle, thirty-two thousand (32,000) pounds per tandem axle, nor a gross weight of seventy-three thousand two hundred eighty (73,280) pounds, must deviate from through truck routes, they will follow those routes' posted limits until such time as they are nearest to their destination before traveling on streets or roadways where the limit is eight thousand (8,000) pounds gross weight. This same route is to be followed on departure as nearly as possible. 
E.  The provisions of this section governing weight and load do not apply to fire apparatus or equipment for snow and ice removal operations owned or operated by any governmental body, or to implements of husbandry temporarily operated or towed in a combination upon a street provided such combination does not consist of more than three vehicles or, in the case of hauling fresh, perishable fruits or vegetables from farm to the point of first processing, not more than three wagons being towed by an implement of husbandry, or to a truck operated under the terms of a special permit issued by the village in accordance with the procedures established by the village. 
F.  Whenever any truck is operated in violation of the provisions of this section, the owner or driver, or both, of such truck shall be deemed guilty of such violation, and either or both the owner and the driver, may be prosecuted for such violation. 
G.  Any person, firm or corporation convicted of any violation of subsections A through D of this section, including but not limited to a maximum axle or gross limit specified on a regulatory sign shall be fined according to the following schedule: 
1.  Up to and including two thousand (2,000) pounds overweight, the fine is fifty dollars ($50.00) unless the weight can be shifted or removed to conform to all legal weights; 
2.  From two thousand one (2,001) through two thousand five hundred (2,500) pounds overweight, the fine is one hundred thirty-five dollars ($135.00); 
3.  From two thousand five hundred one (2,501) through three thousand (3,000) pounds overweight, the fine is one hundred sixty-five dollars ($165.00); 
4.  From three thousand one (3,001) through three thousand five hundred (3,500) pounds overweight, the fine is two hundred sixty dollars ($260.00); 
5.  From three thousand five hundred one (3,501) through four thousand (4,000) pounds overweight, the fine is three hundred dollars ($300.00); 
6.  From four thousand one (4,001) through four thousand five hundred (4,500) pounds overweight, the fine is four hundred twenty-five dollars ($425.00); 
7.  From four thousand five hundred one (4,501) through five thousand (5,000) pounds overweight, the fine is four hundred seventy-five dollars ($475.00); 
8.  From five thousand one (5,001) or more pounds overweight, the fine shall be computed at the rate of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each increment of four hundred (400) pounds overweight or fractions thereof. 
H.  Any owner or operator, or both, charged with a violation of subsections A, B, (C)(1) or D of this section shall post a cash bail in the amount equal to the amount of the fine fixed by subsection G of this section plus costs and penalties. 
I.  Any owner or operator, or both, found guilty of a violation of subsections A, B, (C)(1) or D of this section shall be fined the amount fixed by subsection G of this section plus costs and penalties. 
J.  Any owner or operator, or both, found guilty of a violation of subsections (C)(2) or K of this section shall post bail as required by the Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 110A, Art. V, Par. 526. 
K.  No vehicle weighing more than eight thousand (8,000) pounds gross weight, including the weight of the vehicle and its load, shall be driven or moved up onto, off, or over the edge of the pavement, street, or roadway within the village unless the operator thereof shall protect such edge by putting down solid planks or other suitable device to prevent such vehicles from breaking off the edges or corners of such pavement. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); Amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 41.10(d)) 
Chapter 10.16 - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 
Sections: 

10.16.010 - Parking at curb prohibited-Exceptions.
