    No vehicle shall be parked with the left side of such vehicle at the curb, and it is unlawful to stand or park any vehicle in a street other than parallel with the curb and with the two right wheels of the vehicle within twelve (12) inches of the regularly established curb line, except upon those streets which have been marked for angle parking, in which case vehicles shall be parked at the curb at the angle indicated by such marks. 
(Prior code § 41.11) 
10.16.020 - Lights on parked vehicles-Required when. 
    Whenever a vehicle is parked or stopped on a street during the times between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise or at any other time when there is not sufficient light to render clearly discernible any vehicle on the street from a distance of two hundred (200) feet, there shall be displayed upon such vehicle one or more lamps projecting a white light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the front of such vehicle and projecting a red light visible under like conditions from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the rear, except that such parking light or lights need not be displayed upon any vehicle stopped or parked in accordance with other provisions of this chapter upon any street designated by the chief of police where there is sufficient light to reveal any person within a distance of two hundred (200) feet upon such street. 
(Prior code § 41.12) 
10.16.030 - No parking areas designated. 
    It is unlawful to permit any vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other vehicles or in compliance with the direction of traffic policemen or traffic signals, to stand in any of the following places: 
A.  In any intersection; 
B.  In a crosswalk; 
C.  Upon any bridge or viaduct, or in any subway or the approach thereto; 
D.  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within twenty (20) feet of a point on the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone; 
E.  Within thirty (30) feet of a traffic signal or a through street sign on the approaching side; 
F.  Within twenty (20) feet of any intersection; 
G.  At any place where the standing of a vehicle reduces the usable width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than eighteen (18) feet; 
H.  At any curb within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant; 
I.  At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a driveway; 
J.  Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; 
K.  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire department station and on the side of the street opposite the entrance to such station within seventy-five (75) feet of the entrance; 
L.  At any place where official signs prohibit parking; 
M.  On a sidewalk or parkway; 
N.  In front of a public or private driveway; 
O.  Within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic-control signal located at the side of a roadway; 
P.  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless the village on streets under its jurisdiction indicates a different length by signs or markings; 
Q.  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such parking would obstruct traffic; 
R.  On the roadway side of any vehicle parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
S.  Alongside any curb designated as a no parking area by means of yellow paint. 
(Prior code § 41.13) 
10.16.040 - Parking on parkway prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to park any vehicle in the space between the curb line and the adjacent sidewalk line. 
(Prior code § 41.14) 
10.16.050 - Parking vehicle for sale or repair prohibited. 
    No person shall park any vehicle upon any street, parkway or sidewalk for the purpose of displaying it for sale, or park any vehicle upon any business street from which vehicle merchandise is peddled, or park any vehicle on any street, parkway, alley or sidewalk to repair the vehicle, except for emergency repairs. 
(Prior code § 41.15) 
10.16.060 - Abandoned vehicles-Removal by police. 
    It is unlawful to leave any vehicle unattended on the streets of the village for more than twenty-four (24) consecutive hours. Any such vehicle shall be considered an abandoned vehicle and shall be removed at the direction of the police department and held as an abandoned car. If the chief of police or shift supervisor has reason to believe that such vehicle was stolen, he shall take the necessary steps in regard to stolen cars. 
(Prior code § 41.16) 
10.16.070 - Loading zones designated. 
    During the times specified in this section it is unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for longer than is necessary to load or unload passengers, not to exceed three minutes, and for the driver to stand any freight-carrying vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials not to exceed thirty (30) minutes at any of the following places: 
A.  In a public alley, during any hour of the day or night. 
B.  At any place not to exceed seventy-five (75) feet along the curb before the entrance to any hospital or hotel at any time. 
C.  At any place not to exceed seventy-five (75) feet along the curb before the entrance to a public building between eight a. m. and six p.m. except on a Sunday. 
D.  Directly in front of the entrance to any theater at any time the theater is open for business. 
(Prior code § 41.17) 
10.16.080 - Parking Prohibited. 
A.  Overnight Parking. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any public street of the village between the hours of three a.m. and five a.m. 
B.  At All Times on Specific Streets. When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets or part of streets where such signs are erected. 
C.  Limited Parking. When signs are erected giving notice of time limitation, no person shall park a vehicle on the streets or parts thereof for longer than the time indicated or during the hours or time indicated. 
D.  Designation. The board of trustees may designate by resolution the parking limits described in this section. 
E.  Penalties. Any person violating any provisions of this section shall be assessed a fine in the amount of not less than four dollars ($4.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Violations of any two hour parking restriction shall be assessed a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
F.  Towing Rights Reserved. Any vehicle parked on any public street of the village in violation of this section may be removed by the order of the Grayslake police department to any other place as may best suit the convenience of the Grayslake police department. The owner of each vehicle so removed shall pay to the designated towing and impounding agency the amount of the reasonable cost of such removal and the further cost of storage pending the redemption of the vehicle; said agency shall have the right to retain the vehicle until such payment is made. 
(Ord. 99-0-23 § 1: prior code § 41.18) 
10.16.090 - Parking restricted in certain downtown areas. 
    No person shall park a vehicle for longer than two hours on the streets described as follows: 
A.  Both north and south sides of Center Street between Slusser Street on the west and Seymour Street on the east. 
B.  Both sides of Whitney Street from the first alley south of Center Street to Hawley Street. 
C.  Both sides of Slusser Street from the first alley south of Center Street to Hawley Street. 
D.  Both north and south sides of Hawley Street from Lake Street on the west to Seymour Street on the east. 
    The village shall have the authority to enact a placard system to allow permitted parking to businesses adjacent to certain restricted parking areas. The village shall distribute placards to certain businesses in a number determined solely by the village. Vehicles that have official placards displayed in the lower corner of the front windshield on the passenger side shall not be in violation of this section. 
(Ord. 99-0-23 § 2: prior code § 41.19) 
10.16.100 - Parking prohibited at bus stops. 
A.  The chief of police may establish bus stops on such streets and in such places as he or she shall determine to be of greatest convenience to the public. Every bus stop shall be designated by appropriate sign. The term "bus" as used in this section applies to any motor- or electrically-driven vehicle operating over a regularly designated course on schedule and carrying passengers. 
B.  No person shall park any other vehicle in an officially designated bus stop, except that in an emergency, the driver of any passenger vehicle or truck may temporarily stop. 
(Prior code § 41.20) 
10.16.110 - Parking prohibited that constitutes trespass. 
    It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on private property within the village (regardless of whether the property is open to customer or public parking under limited circumstances or not), in violation of any rule, regulation or prohibition of the owner or other person having possessory control of such private property, when such rule, regulation or prohibition is conspicuously posted upon such premises, or when it otherwise constitutes a trespass as herein defined. Proof of ownership of any vehicle found parking in violation of the provisions of this section shall constitute prima facie evidence of a violation of this section by such owner, which, however, shall be rebuttable by competent evidence. 
(Prior code § 41.21) 
10.16.120 - Authority to designate parking restrictions. 
    When the corporate authorities of the village find that the width of a street, normal traffic conditions or other physical conditions connected with or affecting any street are such as to require it for public safety purposes to avoid impeding the free flow of traffic, they may by resolution, or other action duly entered upon the minutes of their proceedings, designate either side, or both sides, or any part of any public street, as an area or areas where the parking of vehicles shall be prohibited, either at all times, on certain days or between certain hours of certain days or of every day, as they may stipulate, and shall cause appropriate signs to be erected and maintained giving notice thereof. No person shall park a vehicle in violation of any such prohibition when public notice thereof shall be duly indicated by an official sign or signs erected as aforesaid. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit a vehicle from standing in an area restricted pursuant to the provisions of this section for such period of time as is necessary for the reasonably expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, provided such loading or unloading shall not consume more than three minutes, nor to prohibit any commercial vehicle from standing in any such area for such period of time as is necessary for reasonably expeditious loading, unloading and delivery or pick-up of goods, merchandise, articles or materials, provided such loading, unloading and delivery or pick-up shall not consume more than thirty (30) minutes. Neither shall any such prohibition be construed to apply to any ambulance, police, utility or emergency vehicle while the operator thereof is engaged in the necessary performance of emergency or police duties; nor shall it be construed to prevent any vehicle from being brought to a stop to avoid collision, or standing in compliance with the orders of any public officer or the direction of any traffic control signal. 
(Prior code § 41.22) 
10.16.140 - Handicapped parking. 
A.  Limitations on Parking in Areas Designated "Handicapped Parking." 
1.  It is unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to park a vehicle or to leave a vehicle unattended in any area designated by the owner thereof or the board of trustees as "Handicapped Parking" unless either the driver or a passenger in the vehicle is a handicapped person. Any property owner reserving a portion of a parking area for handicapped parking is deemed to have granted to the board of trustees the right to enforce this parking restriction. A "handicapped person" for the purposes of this section shall be any person whose vehicle possesses handicapped license plates issued by the state of Illinois, or who has obtained a sticker for display on the vehicle from the police department to be issued to handicapped persons. 
2.  Any person violating any provisions of this section shall be assessed a fine in the amount of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each offense and any such person may have his or her vehicle towed from any parking area designated as a handicapped parking area and, thereafter, such vehicle shall be towed and impounded at the owner's expense. 
B.  Posting of Designated "Handicapped Parking." The village shall post or cause to be posted an appropriate sign or signs indicating that parking is limited to handicapped parking at all times in the area designated, and describing the penalties for violation of these provisions. 
(Ord. 2005-0-42 § 1; prior code § 41.24) 
10.16.150 - Parking on streets after snowfall prohibited. 
A.  It is unlawful to park any vehicle upon any public street of the village when snow has fallen to a depth of two inches or more on any village street during snow removal operations. 
B.  Any vehicle parked in any public street of the village in violation of this section may be removed by the order of the police department to any other place in the village as may best suit the convenience of the police department. The owner of each vehicle so removed shall pay to the designated towing and impounding agency the amount of the reasonable cost of such removal and the further cost of storage pending the redemption of the vehicle; such agency shall have the right to retain the vehicle until such payment is made. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 41.25) 
Chapter 10.20 - PARKING REGULATIONS FOR DESIGNATED PUBLIC PARKING FACILITIES 
Sections: 

10.20.010 - Overnight parking and other parking regulations in certain designated public parking facilities. 
A.  Definitions. Terms to be used in this chapter mean as follows: 
    "Designated overnight parking spaces" means spaces where overnight parking is permitted in a designated public parking facility. Said designated overnight parking spaces shall be limited to the following: 
1.  Spaces along the south parking lot property line of the Seymour Avenue parking lot; 
2.  Spaces along the north parking lot property line of the United Protestant Church parking lot; 
3.  Spaces along the west side of the 151 Hawley Street building; 
4.  Spaces along the east parking lot property line of the Hawley/Whitney Street parking lot; 
5.  Five (5) spaces along the southwest corner parking lot property line of the 30 S. Whitney Street parking lot; 
6.  Nine (9) spaces along the north parking lot property line of the 33 S. Whitney Street parking lot; 
7.  Ten (10) spaces along the northwest corner parking lot property line of the Washington Street Metra Station parking lot. 
    "Designated public parking facility" means any property that is owned, operated, leased, or maintained by the village, excluding property owned by any commuter rail line, where the intended use of the property is for the purpose of public parking of vehicles, including the: 
1.  Seymour Avenue parking lot; 
2.  10 S. Seymour Avenue parking lot; 
3.  United Protestant Church parking lot; 
4.  151 Hawley Street building parking lot; 
5.  Hawley/Whitney Street parking lot; 
6.  30 S. Whitney Street parking lot; 
7.  33 S. Whitney Street parking lot; 
8.  45 S. Whitney Street parking lot; 
9.  Washington Street Metra Station parking lot. 
    "Overnight parking" means the parking of a vehicle between the hours of 3:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m., Monday through Sunday, of each week in any designated public parking facility. 
    "Person" means any individual with a valid driver's license issued by the state of Illinois, organization, corporation, or any combination of the foregoing. 
    "Vehicle" means any operable passenger vehicle less than eight thousand (8,000) pounds with a valid and current vehicle registration issued by the State of Illinois or other state. This excludes all boats, campers, snowmobiles, and any vehicles deemed inoperable or nonpassenger in nature by the village manager or his or her designee. 
B.  Overnight Parking. 
1.  Overnight Parking Restrictions. 
a.  Overnight parking is allowed only in designated overnight parking spaces. 
b.  Vehicles must be parked with the front of the vehicle facing away from the driving lane. 
c.  At any time the village may restrict parking in designated overnight parking spaces, with at least twenty-four (24) hours' notice prior to closure via posted signage at the spaces to be closed, for necessary maintenance and/or special functions, upon which the village may remove any vehicle found to be parked in a closed space at the owner of said vehicle's expense. 
C.  Other Parking Regulations. 
1.  Parking Prohibited. 
a.  Parking of vehicles in excess of eight thousand (8,000) pounds (class B registration) in designated public parking facilities. 
b.  Parking of any vehicles in designated public parking facilities without a valid registration issued by the state of Illinois or another state. 
c.  Parking of any boats, campers, snowmobiles, off-road vehicles, trailers or any vehicles deemed inoperable, unsafe or nonpassenger vehicles by the village manager or his or her designee are prohibited. 
2.  Parking in the United Protestant Church parking lot shall be in accordance with restrictions as posted. 
3.  At any time the village may close designated public parking facilities or impose additional parking restrictions, with at least twenty-four (24) hours' notice prior to closure via posted signage at the parking facility to be closed, for necessary maintenance and/or special functions, upon which the village may remove any vehicle found to be parked in a closed parking facility at the owner of said vehicle's expense. 
4.  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, the village may remove any vehicle from any designated public parking facility without notification in case of emergency at the owner of said vehicle's expense. 
(Ord. 2007-0-31 § 2; Ord. 2006-0-31 § 2; Ord. 99-0-42 § 1: Ord. 98-0-43 § 1: prior code § 41.32) 
(Ord. No. 2010-0-27, § 2, 10-19-2010) 
Chapter 10.24 - TOWING OF VEHICLES 
Sections: 

10.24.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings stated in this section. Any term not defined herein shall have the meaning ascribed to it in other sections of this code or ordinances of the village, and if not defined in any other section or ordinance, it shall have the meaning ascribed in the Illinois Vehicle Code, Chapter 95 1/2 of the Illinois Revised Statutes. 
    "Abandoned vehicle" means: 
1.  A vehicle, other than a "hazardous" or "unlawful" vehicle on the public way or in a public parking lot in such a state of disrepair that it is incapable of being driven; or 
2.  A vehicle, other than a "hazardous" or "unlawful" vehicle on the public way or in a public parking lot that has been unmoved for a period of at least seven days and appears to have been abandoned by its owner based on (i) its condition, (ii) the period during which it has not been moved, or (iii) other circumstances indicating abandonment; or 
3.  A vehicle in a private parking lot without the consent of the lot owner, proprietor or agent, which person has requested that the vehicle be towed; or 
4.  A vehicle, other than a "hazardous" or "unlawful" vehicle, defined as abandoned, or subject to being towed, by any other code sections or ordinances of the village. 
    "Hazardous vehicle" means: 
1.  A vehicle that has been involved in an accident and is disabled or cannot be immediately moved by the owner or operator of the vehicle; or 
2.  A vehicle that presents an immediate danger to the health or welfare of members of the public; or 
3.  A vehicle on a public street, way or alley that is impeding the orderly flow of traffic or poses a potential danger to pedestrians and operators of other vehicles; or 
4.  A vehicle that is parked in such a way as to block access to a fire hydrant. 
    "Owner" means a person who holds legal title to a vehicle, or the right to possession of a vehicle. 
    "Unlawful vehicle" means: 
1.  A vehicle that has been reported stolen or is the subject of a search and seizure by the police department; or 
2.  A vehicle parked in violation of any statute or ordinance that authorizes the vehicle to be towed, but only when signs posted at the location in question indicate that vehicles may be subject to towing. 
3.  A vehicle driven by the subject of a custodial arrest that has been parked on any village street for more than twenty-four (24) hours after the arrestee has been given express notice that such vehicle will be towed if not moved within twenty-four (24) hours thereafter. 
    "Vehicle" means any device or part thereof including trailers and other devices designed to be pulled by a propelled device, in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported upon a street, highway or any public way. (Added during 2001 codification) 
10.24.020 - Authorization for towing. 
A.  Abandoned vehicles may be towed after prior notice and the affording of an opportunity for a hearing as provided in Sections 10.24.030 and 10.24.040 of this chapter. 
B.  Hazardous and unlawful vehicles may be towed without notice. Within twenty-four (24) hours after towing a vehicle pursuant to this section, a notice shall be sent to the owner of the vehicle affording the opportunity for a hearing as provided in Sections 10.24.050 and 10.24.070 of this chapter. 
C.  The towing of vehicles by the village or its approved towing service operators pursuant to this section shall be authorized only by the police department and only under the circumstances herein provided. 
D.  Towed vehicles shall be impounded only at facilities designated by the police department until lawfully claimed or disposed of pursuant to provisions of this chapter or the laws of the state. (Added during 2001 codification) 
10.24.030 - Pre-tow notice for abandoned vehicles. 
A.  Not less than seven days prior to towing any abandoned vehicle pursuant to Section 10.24.020(A) of this chapter, the village shall forward written notice of its intent to tow by certified or registered mall, return receipt requested, to the address of the owner of the vehicle as indicated in the most current registration list of the Secretary of State of the state in which such vehicle is registered. The notice shall be in the form provided in subsection B of this section. 
B.  The following form shall be utilized for the purposes of giving pre-tow notice to owners pursuant to subsection A of this section: 

C.  On or before the day of mailing of the aforesaid written notice, a notice of intent to tow sticker with the earliest date upon which the tow may take place and the address and phone number of the police department shall be placed on the vehicle. (Added during 2001 codification) 
10.24.040 - Pre-tow hearing procedures. 
A.  The owner of a vehicle to be towed as an abandoned vehicle pursuant to Section 10.24.020(A) shall have seven days after the date of mailing of notice pursuant to Section 10.24.030 to request, in writing, a pre-tow hearing. Said written request shall be delivered to the police department within said seven-day period. Unless such a request is received within said seven-day period, the vehicle may be towed and any hearing rights under the provisions of this section shall be deemed waived. 
B.  In the event that a pre-tow hearing is not requested as provided herein, a post-tow hearing shall, upon written request of the owner of a vehicle towed as an abandoned vehicle, be provided pursuant to Section 10.24.070 of this chapter. 
C.  Upon any request for a pre-tow hearing being made, the village shall schedule a date and time, not later than fifteen (15) days following receipt of such request, for such hearing. Upon receipt of such request, but not less than forty-eight (48) hours before such hearing, the village shall notify the owner of the date and time for such hearing by telephone, by mail, or in person as the circumstances require. Pending a final disposition of such hearing, the vehicle shall not be towed except pursuant to the procedures of this chapter applicable to hazardous or unlawful vehicles. 
D.  Upon any request for a pre-tow hearing being made, the village shall choose an officer or employee of the village to serve as hearing officer. In no case shall that hearing officer be an individual who was involved in the initial decision to tow the vehicle. The hearing officer shall have the authority to require the presence of the enforcement officer who initiated the proposed tow or any other village personnel and to request the presence of other witnesses at the hearing. 
E.  After receiving all relevant evidence, the hearing officer shall make a written decision based upon a preponderance of the evidence as to whether towing of the vehicle is authorized by the laws of the state of Illinois or the ordinances of the village; with a specific statutory or ordinance section cited in the decision. The owner shall be provided a copy of such pre-tow hearing decision. 
F.  If the preponderance of the evidence supports towing as authorized in this chapter, the hearing officer shall direct that the vehicle be towed, with any towing and storage costs to be imposed upon the owner thereof. The fees to be charged for towing and storage services shall be at the rates established in Sections 10.24.050 and 10.24.060 of this chapter. The owner of said vehicle having had such a hearing may avoid the towing by immediately removing the vehicle from the improper location to a proper, lawful location and correcting any unlawful condition of the vehicle. 
G.  If the preponderance of the evidence falls to support towing of the vehicle, the hearing officer shall direct that the vehicle shall not be towed. The village shall furnish a copy of such decision to the owner, who may display it inside the vehicle. No vehicle about which such a decision has been rendered shall be towed by the village unless (1) the circumstances under which the decision was rendered have changed and (2) the procedures for towing similarly-situated vehicles under this chapter are followed. 
H.  All pre-tow hearing decisions, towing reports, and any associated police reports or documents shall be retained by the police department for a period of at least five years after each hearing, or after each tow if no hearing was requested or held. 
I.  Any such hearing will not be determinative of or adjudicate any citation issued relative to the vehicle. (Added during 2001 codification) 
10.24.050 - Post-tow notice for hazardous and unlawful vehicles. 
A.  Not more than seven days after towing any hazardous or unlawful vehicle pursuant to Section 10.24.020(B) of this chapter, the village shall forward written notice of the towing by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the owner of the vehicle as indicated in the most current registration list of the Secretary of State of the state in which such vehicle is registered. The notice shall be in the forms provided in subsections C and D of this section. 
B.  All approved towing service operators shall prominently post two large signs, with dimensions of at least twelve (12) inches by eighteen (18) inches, indicating the opportunity and procedures for a hearing to contest the validity of any vehicle tow. These signs, the form for which is set out in subsection C of this section, shall be placed in locations readily visible to the public transacting business at any towing facility. 
C.  The following form shall be utilized for the purpose of giving post-tow notice to owners pursuant to subsections A and B of this section by posting in towing establishments and mailing to owners: 
NOTICE OF VEHICLE RELEASE 
REQUIREMENTS AND HEARING RIGHTS 
 BEFORE THE OWNER OF ANY IMPOUNDED VEHICLE SHALL BE PERMITTED TO REMOVE THE SAME FROM CUSTODY OF THE GRAYSLAKE POLICE DEPARTMENT OR ITS AUTHORIZED TOWING SERVICE OPERATOR, SUCH OWNER SHALL FURNISH EVIDENCE OF HIS OR HER IDENTITY AND OWNERSHIP OF THE VEHICLE AND RIGHT OF POSSESSION THERETO, SHALL SIGN A RECEIPT FOR THE VILLAGE, AND SHALL PAY A FEE OF $ ____________ FOR A PASSENGER VEHICLE OF NOT MORE THAN 7 PASSENGERS, AND $ ____________ FOR ANY OTHER VEHICLE TO COVER THE COST OF TOWING OR REMOVAL TO A VEHICLE POUND OR AUTHORIZED GARAGE, AND IN ADDITION THEREOF, THE COST OF STORAGE OF $ ____________ PER DAY FOR A PASSENGER VEHICLE OF NOT MORE THAN 7 PASSENGERS, AND $ ____________ PER DAY FOR ANY OTHER VEHICLE. 
 FAILURE TO CLAIM A TOWED VEHICLE WILL RESULT IN ITS SALE AT PUBLIC AUCTION PURSUANT TO THE PROVISIONS OF THE VILLAGE OF GRAYSLAKE MUNICIPAL CODE. 
 ANY OWNER WISHING TO CONTEST THE VALIDITY OF THE TOW MAY OBTAIN A HEARING UNDER THE CONDITIONS OF EITHER PARAGRAPH (A) OR (B) BELOW: 
TO OBTAIN A HEARING 
 (A) IF THE VEHICLE HAS BEEN RELEASED, THE OWNER MAY, WITHIN 15 DAYS OF THE RELEASE OF THE VEHICLE OR THE MAILING OF THE NOTIFICATION OF THE TOW, WHICHEVER OCCURS FIRST, REQUEST A HEARING BY DELIVERING A REQUEST FOR HEARING IN WRITING TO THE GRAYSLAKE POLICE DEPARTMENT, 33 SOUTH WHITNEY STREET, GRAYSLAKE, ILLINOIS 60030. THE RIGHT TO ANY HEARING SHALL BE DEEMED WAIVED AFTER SUCH 15 DAY PERIOD. 
 (B) IF THE VEHICLE IS STILL IMPOUNDED, THE OWNER MAY SUBMIT A WRITTEN REQUEST TO THE ABOVE OFFICE AND OBTAIN A HEARING WITHIN 24 HOURS AFTER THE REQUEST, EXCLUDING WEEKENDS AND HOLIDAYS, UNLESS THE REQUEST IS MADE AFTER 3:00 P.M. IF A REQUEST FOR A HEARING IS MADE AFTER 3:00 P.M., THE HEARING WILL TAKE PLACE ON THE SECOND WORKING DAY THEREAFTER, EXCLUDING WEEKENDS AND HOLIDAYS. 
NATURE OF HEARING 
THE HEARING SHALL BE CONDUCTED ACCORDING TO VILLAGE ORDINANCE PROVISIONS AND SHALL DETERMINE THE VALIDITY OF THE TOWING AND IMPOUNDING OF THE VEHICLE AND THE IMPOSITION OR REFUND OF ANY TOWING OR STORAGE CHARGES, BUT THE HEARING WILL NOT DETERMINE OR ADJUDICATE ANY CITATIONS ISSUED. IF THE HEARING OFFICER SUSTAINS THE VALIDITY OF THE TOW AND IMPOUNDING. THE OWNER SHALL PAY ALL UNPAID TOWING AND STORAGE FEES BEFORE OBTAINING THE RELEASE OF THE VEHICLE. 
D.  The following form, along with the form in subsection C of this section, shall be utilized for the purpose of giving post-tow notice to owners pursuant to subsection A of this section: 

(Added during 2001 codification) 
10.24.060 - Procedures for releasing towed vehicles. 
A.  Before the owner of any towed vehicle shall be permitted to remove said vehicle from a vehicle pound or authorized garage, the owner shall furnish evidence of his or her identity and ownership and right to possession of the vehicle, sign a receipt for the vehicle, and pay an amount as set forth in subsection B of this section. The police department is authorized to promulgate regulations as to the documents or other proof necessary to establish these facts. 
B.  The owner shall pay fees set by the village to cover the cost of towing or removal of the vehicle, and in addition thereto, a fee for storage, and thereupon must take possession of the vehicle within twenty-four (24) hours of payment. The owner may pay the full amount of fees and subsequently request a hearing pursuant to Section 10.24.070 of this chapter. 
C.  Upon release of a towed vehicle as provided in this section, towing service personnel shall direct the owner's attention to the signs concerning notice and hearings posted pursuant to Section 10.24.050(B) of this chapter. 
D.  Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter to the contrary, an owner may remove a towed vehicle without paying towing or storage fees upon presentation of an order for release issued pursuant to Section 10.24.070(G)(2)(b) of this chapter. 
E.  Notwithstanding any other ordinance or statutory provisions to the contrary, any towing service operator authorized to perform tows on behalf of the village must perform its services subject to the provisions of this chapter. However, the towing company shall have the right to recover the reasonable value of its services, not paid by the vehicle owner, from the village. (Added during 2001 codification) 
10.24.070 - Post-tow hearings. 
A.  The owner of a vehicle towed as a hazardous or unlawful vehicle pursuant to Section 10.24.020(B) of this chapter shall have fifteen (15) days after the date of mailing of notice or release of the vehicle, whichever occurs first, to request in writing a post-tow hearing to determine the validity of such tow and any towing or storage charges. Said written request shall be delivered to the police department within said fifteen (15) day period, or the right to a post-tow hearing under the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed waived. The hearing will not be determinative of, or adjudicative, any citation issued relative to any towed vehicle. 
B.  Upon any request for a post-tow hearing being made, the village shall schedule a date and time for such hearing as follows: 
1.  In those instances where the vehicle has been released upon the full payment of towing and storage charges, the hearing shall take place within fifteen (15) days after the receipt of such request for such hearing. Upon receipt of such request, but not less than forty-eight (48) hours before such hearing, the village shall notify the owner of the date and time for such hearing by telephone, by mail, or in person as the circumstances require. 
2.  In those instances where the vehicle has not been released, the hearing shall take place at the option of the owner: 
a.  Within twenty-four (24) hours after such request for such hearing, excluding weekends and holidays; except that if such request is made after three p.m., then a hearing shall be held on the second working day following the request. Upon receipt of such request, the village shall notify the owner of the daze and time of such hearing by telephone or in person. 
b.  If acceptable to the owner, within fifteen (15) days of such request on a date convenient to all parties. Upon receipt of such request, but not less than forty-eight (48) hours before such hearing, the village shall notify the owner of the date and time for such hearing by telephone, by mail, or in person as the circumstances require. 
C.  Upon any request for a post-tow hearing being made, the village shall choose an officer or employee of the village to serve as hearing officer. In no case shall the hearing officer be an individual who was involved in the initial decision to tow the vehicle. The hearing officer may be the same person designated for pre-tow hearings pursuant to Section 10.24.040 of this chapter. The hearing officer shall have the authority to require the presence of the enforcement officer who ordered the tow; or any other village personnel, and to request the presence of other witnesses at such hearing. 
D.  The hearing officer shall review all evidence presented by the vehicle owner and the police department and make a finding based on the evidence presented as to the lawful authority for the towing and storage of the vehicle. The village must establish such authority by a preponderance of the evidence. 
E.  For each hearing, the hearing officer shall complete a vehicle tow hearing decision and attach such decision to the original vehicle towing report of the police department, and supply a copy of the vehicle tow hearing decision to the owner by personal delivery if the owner is present, otherwise by mail. 
F.  After receiving all relevant evidence, the hearing officer shall make one or more of the following written findings, which must be incorporated into the vehicle tow hearing decision: 
1.  The towing and storage of the vehicle was authorized by the laws of the state of Illinois or any village ordinance. One or more specific statutory or ordinance sections and the amount owed for towing and storage shall be stated in such a finding; 
2.  There was no authority in law for the towing and storage of the vehicle, or the municipal employee causing the vehicle to be towed did not comply with the requirements of the statute or ordinance authorizing the tow; 
3.  The towing of the vehicle was authorized by law, but the owner was caused to incur additional storage charges because of late notification of towing or other reasons not the fault of the owner. The specific amount owed by the owner, and the specific amount excused, shall be stated in the decision; 
4.  The request for hearing was not made within fifteen (15) days of the mailing of notice of towing or the date the vehicle was released from the vehicle pound or authorized garage, whichever was earlier; 
5.  A hearing was requested but the person requesting the hearing failed to appear and failed to request a continuance. 
G.  The hearing officer shall advise the owner of his or her findings at the conclusion of the hearing to-wit: 
1.  If the towing and storage was authorized by law, and is not otherwise reimbursable, the owner shall be so informed and further advised as to the amount due. 
2.  Should the towing and/or storage be found to be unauthorized or reimbursable, the hearing officer shall: 
a.  If the vehicle has been released to the owner: 
i.  Note the amount of the cash deposit or towing and storage fees prepaid by the owner on the vehicle tow hearing decision, 
ii.  Complete a printed voucher form for the amount to be reimbursed, 
iii.  Transmit said decision and voucher form to the police department for authorization for payment, 
iv.  Advise the owner that a refund of said cash deposit or fees will be transmitted to the village treasurer for payment, 
v.  Transmit a copy of said hearing decision, along with the original voucher and original payment receipt to the village treasurer within forty-eight (48) hours of the hearing, 
vi.  Unless the village files a lawsuit to contest the decision of the hearing officer, the owner shall be paid the money due within twenty-eight (28) days after the decision of the hearing officer; 
b.  If the vehicle is still impounded at the time of the hearing, the following procedure shall be followed: 
i.  An order for the release of the vehicle shall be prepared in duplicate; the owner shall be provided with the original, and a copy shall be attached to the vehicle tow hearing decision, 
ii.  Upon presentation by the owner to the towing service operator of the order for release, said vehicle shall immediately be released to the owner upon payment of the towing and storage fees, if any, found to be due. 
H.  All vehicle tow hearing decisions, towing reports, and any associated police reports or documents shall be retained by the police department for a period of at least five years after each hearing, or after each tow if no hearing was requested or held. 
I.  The village or the owner may contest the decision of the hearing officer in any manner provided by law. (Added during 2001 codification) 
10.24.080 - Sale of towed vehicle. 
A.  Any vehicle towed pursuant to this chapter may be sold by the police department to the highest bidder at either a private or public sale. 
B.  No vehicle shall be sold under this section until at least thirty (30) days after the latter of: 
1.  If a hearing is requested, the date of a vehicle tow hearing decision; or 
2.  If no hearing is requested, the expiration of the period for requesting a vehicle tow hearing. 
C.  Notice of any sale pursuant to this section shall be forwarded by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the owner of the vehicle as indicated in the most current registration list of the Secretary of State of the state in which the vehicle is registered. Notice of sales under this section shall be given to the owner as described herein at least thirty (30) days in advance of a sale and shall be published at least twenty (20) days in advance in a newspaper of general circulation in the village. (Added during 2001 codification) 
Chapter 10.28 - SKATEBOARDS AND ROLLERSKATES 
Sections: 

10.28.010 - Skateboards, rollerblades, rollerskates, and other coaster devices. 
A.  No person shall operate or ride upon a skateboard, rollerblades, rollerskates, or any means of any coaster device on any publicly used ancillary structure, which is defined as benches, gazebos, bike racks, hand rails, and curb bumpers. 
B.  No person shall operate or ride upon a skateboard, rollerblades, rollerskates, or any means of any coaster device within the confines of Centennial Park, located downtown along Center Street. 
C.  Any parent, guardian, custodian, or person in control of, or responsible for any child under the age of sixteen (16) who knowingly allows said child to violate the provisions of this section and who has previously been advised of a prior violation or violations of this section by the same child, shall be subject to prosecution under this section and the penalties prescribed for violation of this section. 
(Ord. 97-0-35 § 2: prior code § 7.23) 
Chapter 10.32 - ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES AND PENALTIES 
Sections: 

10.32.010 - Liability of registered owner. 
    Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of any provision of this title prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be prima facie responsible for such violation and subject to the penalty thereof. 
(Prior code § 41.26) 
10.32.020 - Ticketing parking violations-Duties of police officer. 
A.  In case any vehicle is parked in violation of any section of this title it shall be the duty of any police officer of the village discovering such violation to make out a report, acting in accordance with instructions issued by the president of the village setting forth the following: 
1.  The location where such a violation shall have occurred; 
2.  The state license number of such vehicle; 
3.  The details of such violation, including the time such vehicle is parked in violation of any of the provisions of this title and the time the notice is attached to the vehicle; 
4.  Any other facts or knowledge which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. 
B.  Such police officer shall also attach to such vehicle a notice to the owner or operator thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of a provision of this title and instructing such owner or operator to report to the police station of the village in regard to such violation. Each such owner or operator may, within the time specified below when the notice is attached to such vehicle, pay as a penalty for and in full satisfaction of all the following violations either by placing same in an envelope properly addressed and deposited in the U. S. mail, or by delivering same to the police officer in charge at the desk at the police station or to the village clerk within said time periods. 
C.  If not so paid within a fourteen (14) day period, the charge for each such violation shall be increased by one hundred (100) percent after fourteen (14) days and another one hundred (100) percent after twenty-eight (28) days, provided said latter sum is paid prior to a complaint being filed in the court for such violation (see Schedule of Parking Violations, Section 10.32.050). The failure of such owner or operator to make such payment within said time period specified shall render such owner or operator subject also to the penalties hereinafter provided for the violation of the provisions of this title. 
(Prior code § 41.27) 
10.32.030 - Penalties. 
A.  Penalties for Violation of Wheel and Axle Loads and Gross Weights. Whenever any vehicle or combinations of vehicles is operated upon any street or highway within the corporate limits of the village in violation of Section 15-111 of the Illinois Vehicle Code adopted under this title, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such violation and either the owner or driver may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person convicted of any violation of Section 15-111 shall be fined according to the following schedule: 
Up to and including 2,000 pounds overweight = The fine is $50.00 From 2,001 through 2,500 pounds overweight = The fine is $135.00 From 2,501 through 3,000 pounds overweight = The fine is $165.00 From 3,001 through 3,500 pounds overweight = The fine is $260.00 From 3,501 through 4,000 pounds overweight = The fine is $300.00 From 4,001 through 4,500 pounds overweight = The fine is $425.00 From 4,501 through 5,000 pounds overweight = The fine is $475.00 From 5,001 or more pounds overweight = The fine is $750.00  
B.  Penalties for Violation of Illinois Vehicle Code Sections 15-102, 15-103 or 15-107. Whenever any vehicle is operated upon any street or highway within the corporate limits of the village in violation of Sections 15-102, 15-103 or 15-107 of the Illinois Vehicle Code adopted under this title, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such violation, and either may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person convicted of any violation of Sections 15-102, 15-103 or 15-107 shall be fined for the first or second conviction an amount equal to not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and for the third and subsequent convictions by the same person within a period of one year after the date of the first offense, the sum of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
C.  Penalties Not Covered. Any person adjudged guilty of a violation of any of the provisions adopted under this title when the penalty for such violation is not covered under any of the foregoing sections of this chapter, shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and each day during which any violation of this title occurs, continues or is permitted shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. (Amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 41.28) 
10.32.040 - Bail. 
    Any person arrested for a violation of any provision adopted under this chapter shall be released on proper bail being furnished as authorized by law. 
(Prior code § 41.29)

Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 12.04 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS GENERALLY 
Sections: 

12.04.010 - Supervision. 
    All public streets, alleys, sidewalks, and other public ways shall be under the supervision of the superintendent of public works. He or she shall have supervision over all work thereon, and the cleaning thereof, and shall be charged with the enforcement of all ordinance provisions relating to such public places (except traffic ordinances) and is authorized to enforce such ordinances. 
(Prior code § 7.01) 
12.04.020 - Repairs. 
    All public streets, alley and sidewalk pavement shall be in good repair. Such repair work, whether done by the village or the abutting owner, shall be under the supervision of the superintendent of public works. 
(Prior code § 7.04) 
12.04.030 - Construction. 
A.  Permit. It is unlawful to construct or lay any pavement on any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public way, or to repair the same, without having first secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the building commissioner and shall state the location of the intended pavement or repair, the extent thereof, and the person or firm who is to do the actual construction work. 
B.  Specifications. All street and sidewalk pavement shall be made in conformity with the specifications laid down from time to time by the village. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 7.02) 
12.04.040 - Injury to streets. 
    It is unlawful to walk upon or drive upon, or injure any newly laid street or sidewalk or alley pavement while the same is guarded by a warning sign or barricade; or to injure any street, sidewalk or alley pavement or any post, sign, light, vegetation or any other appurtenance thereon, except as authorized by the village. 
(Prior code § 7.03) 
12.04.050 - Obstructions. 
    It is unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain any obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public way, except as may be specifically authorized by ordinance or by the building commissioner. 
(Prior code § 7.05) 
12.04.060 - Barricades. 
A.  Any person laying or repairing any pavement or doing any work in a street, sidewalk, or other public place or making an excavation in the same, shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury of any person or vehicle by reason of the work. Lights or some other form of illumination at nighttime shall protect such barricades. 
B.  Any defect in any such pavement shall be barricaded to prevent injury. 
C.  It is unlawful to disturb or interfere with any barricade or light lawfully placed in any public street, alley, or sidewalk to protect the public. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 7.06) 
12.04.070 - Merchandise and signs. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use any street, sidewalk, alley or other public property as space for the display of goods or merchandise for sale; or to write or mark any sign or advertisement on any such pavement or street appurtenance. 
(Prior code § 7.07) 
12.04.080 - Encroachments. 
    It is unlawful to erect or maintain any building or structure which encroaches upon any street, sidewalk, alley or public property. 
(Prior code § 7.08) 
12.04.090 - Drains. 
    It is unlawful to obstruct any drain in any public street or alley or village drain on a right-of-way or easement. 
(Prior code § 7.09) 
12.04.100 - Poles and wires. 
    It is unlawful to erect any poles or wires or maintain any poles or wires over any public place, street, alley or other public way without having first secured permission from the board of trustees. 
(Prior code § 7.10) 
12.04.110 - Snow on streets and sidewalks. 
A.  No person shall deposit snow or ice upon any street from any parking lot, commercial or institutional service area, or public or private driveway or service area. 
B.  The person occupying the ground floor of any building, the user of any lot without a structure thereon, and the owner of any vacant building or other premises shall remove the snow and ice accumulating on the abutting sidewalks within twenty-four (24) hours after any snowfall has ceased. If snow or ice cannot be removed, the surface shall be sanded or otherwise treated to lessen the hazard for pedestrians until the climate permits removal. 
(Prior code § 7.11) 
12.04.120 - Rainwater drains. 
    It is unlawful to construct or permit the maintenance of any stormwater drain which discharges water onto any sidewalk, street or alley in the village. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part): prior code § 7.12) 
12.04.130 - Games. 
    It is unlawful to play any games upon any street, alley or sidewalk or other public place, where such games cause unnecessary noise, or interfere with traffic or pedestrians. 
(Prior code § 7.13) 
12.04.140 - Openings. 
    It is unlawful to construct or maintain any opening or stairway in any public street or sidewalk or alley without a permit from the building commissioner. All such lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitably strong cover or railing, to the approval of the building commissioner. 
(Prior code § 7.14) 
12.04.150 - Barbed wire fences. 
    It is unlawful to maintain or construct any fence composed in whole or part of barbed wire, or with any similar material designed to cause injury to persons, or any wire charged with electric current, anywhere within three feet of any public street, alley, sidewalk, park or other public way or place. 
(Prior code § 7.15) 
12.04.160 - Deposits on streets. 
A.  It is unlawful to deposit on any street or sidewalk any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, refuse, chemical or glass, or other articles which may do injury to any person or property. 
B.  Materials may be deposited in streets preparatory to delivery or use provided that such deposit does not reduce the usable width of the roadway at that point to less than eighteen (18) feet, and provided that such material, other than material to be used in actual building construction, shall not be permitted to remain in such street for more than three hours. 
C.  Any such material shall be guarded by lights if the same remains upon any street after dark. 
D.  Merchandise or other articles may be deposited on sidewalks preparatory to delivery provided that the usable width of the sidewalk is not thereby reduced to less than four feet, and provided that no such article shall remain on such walk for more than one-half hour. 
(Prior code § 7.16) 
12.04.170 - Burning leaves and rubbish. 
    It is unlawful for any person to burn any leaves, paper, rubbish or other substances upon any of the public streets, sidewalks or alleys in the village. 
(Prior code § 7.17) 
12.04.180 - Driving on parkways. 
A.  No person (except the village in the improvement, maintenance or care of public property) shall drive, or cause to be propelled, any automobile, truck, trailer or similar vehicle across any public parkway in the village, except upon a driveway temporarily or permanently improved or upon a parking area temporarily improved so as to meet the requirements provided in Section 12.08.060. 
B.  The term "public parkway" as used in this section refers to the area between the curb or regularly traveled part of a public street and the edge of the public sidewalk, if one exists, which is adjacent to or nearest to the property line of the property bordering on the street, or the adjoining property line if there is no public sidewalk. 
C.  A driveway or parking area to be temporarily improved within the requirements of this section shall meet the minimum requirements provided in Section 12.08.060 for a "temporary driveway or parking area" and a driveway to be permanently improved shall meet the minimum requirements provided in Section 12.08.040 for a "permanent driveway." 
(Prior code § 7.18) 
12.04.190 - Curb, gutter and sidewalk construction-Adjoining property owners to pay costs. 
    No curb, gutter or sidewalk shall be installed hereafter by the village upon any public street within the village without the adjoining property owners, respectively, paying the current costs of the installation apportionable to that part or those parts installed in the area or areas of the street or streets, upon which their respective properties front or adjoin. 
(Prior code § 7.20) 
12.04.200 - Cul-de-sac clear zones. 
    In each cul-de-sac at least one clear zone in the parkways shall be provided that is sixteen and one-half (16.5) feet long as measured along the back of curb, and within twenty (20) feet of the center line extended to the end of the cul-de-sac, all as indicated in the sketch following this chapter detailing said cul-de-sac clear zones. The clear zone shall be devoid of any obstructions, including but not limited to, driveways and driveway pavements, mail boxes, fire hydrants and trees. All clear zones shall be delineated and established on any plans submitted for any cul-de-sac within the village. 
(Prior code § 7.24) 
;oh5; 12.04.210\Private rail spurs and storage of rail cars. 
A.  From and after May 17, 2017, no private property abutting or having direct or indirect access to any public street within the corporate limits of the village may construct: 
1.  Any new railroad track, spur, or similar railway facility (a "rail facility"); or 
2.  Any extension of an existing rail facility 
    on such property, unless such rail facility is directly engaged in interstate commerce and under the exclusive control of the Federal Railroad Administration. 
B.  No private property located within the corporate limits of the village shall be permitted to store on such property more than two rail cars or similar vehicles intended for use on a rail facility unless such rail car or similar vehicle is within a fully enclosed building that satisfied all regulations of the village's building and zoning codes. For purposes of this section, "store" shall mean to maintain upon a property (whether or not in the same location upon the property) for a period of more than eighteen (18) hours. 
C.  Nothing in this section shall apply to a rail facility from which the village is pre-empted from regulating as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 2017-0-19, § 2, 5-16-2017) 
Chapter 12.08 - DRIVEWAYS 
Sections: 

12.08.010 - Construction-Permit required. 
    A permit is required for the construction of any permanent street access facility (driveway) within the village right-of-way or when a change in intensity or expansion of an existing use or development, except on an individual single family lot, is proposed. 
(Prior code § 7.19(a)) 
12.08.020 - Permit application. 
A.  The application for a permanent access permit will be available on a form provided by the building department. The application must include the name, address, and telephone number of the applicant and/or owner of the property to be served by the access facility. In addition, the application shall detail the intended land use the proposed access will serve. Depending on the intended use, the building department will require a sketch or detailed plan for the access. This information may vary from a simple sketch for a residential driveway to a site plan and/or survey plat for commercial development. 
B.  The application must be accompanied by the fee as established in Table 1 following this chapter and will not be refunded, irrespective of the outcome of the application. A nonrefundable ten dollar ($10.00) fee will be charged for each application attempt. This fee will be in addition to any required permit fee. Any excess out-of-pocket expenses incurred by the village for such things as engineering review will be reimbursed to the village prior to issuance of the permit. 
(Prior code § 7.19(b)) 
12.08.030 - Permit issuance. 
    A permit for permanent street access shall be issued upon building department approval of the sketches, drawings, etc. Said permit may, as a condition of the permit, require the completion of street improvements, driveway access improvements and/or enhancing specific interior on-site traffic controls, or traffic patterns designed to allow village streets to accommodate the additional traffic that would result from the new access or proposed change in this intensity or expansion of an existing use or development. The permit is not approved until the building department seal is affixed. For nonresidential use, the permit will not be approved by the village unless a cash deposit is submitted to the building department. The cash deposit will be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per access point. The deposit will be refundable when the village approves the access point construction. No work on the access may be performed until an approved permit is posted on the job site. The permit must be posted at the site for the duration of the project. 
(Prior code § 7.19(c)) 
12.08.040 - Permanent access construction. 
A.  The permanent access will be constructed in conformance with the geometric requirements and materials detailed in Table 1 following this chapter. The assignment to each of the three categories of land use type will be made by the building department for each application for a driveway permit. 
B.  During construction, a copy of the permit must be maintained at the job site. The driveway shall be constructed with the geometric requirements and materials as detailed in Table 1. 
C.  All village-required standard traffic control devices and methods will be applicable to the permitted work. (Consult the Illinois MUTCD for details). 
D.  The requirements of the county watershed development ordinance will be followed in regards to soil erosion control and mud deposits on streets. 
E.  When required for safety considerations, proper roadside treatment (i.e. guardrail) shall be provided by the applicant to safeguard both vehicular and pedestrian traffic. 
F.  No residential access permit will be granted where curb drains exist. 
G.  No commercial access permit will be granted where curb drains exist. If, in the opinion of the village, special circumstances exist in which there are no other alternatives, the village may issue a permit where curb drains exist. 
H.  Driveways constructed between the street and property line shall have a surface comparable to that of the street that they have access to. 
(Prior code § 7.19(d)) 
12.08.050 - Maintenance of the permanent access. 
A.  The total permanent access facility installation, including any safety device and/or culvert, is the maintenance responsibility of the owner of the parcel or the successors or assigns. 
B.  In the case of an existing permanent driveway that meets the minimum requirements provided in Section 12.08.040 except for the culvert requirement, the owner, tenant, or occupant shall have ninety (90) days from after date due notice is given to install a culvert if required. If an emergency exists, the village will give the owner twenty-four (24) hours to install the culvert, If the culvert is not installed within twenty-four (24) hours, the village will install the culvert at owner's expense. If the owner fails to pay the village for such expense, the village shall have the right to place and enforce a lien on the property. 
(Prior code § 7.19(e)) 
12.08.060 - Temporary driveway or parking area. 
A.  If deliveries for construction or special purposes are to be made upon premises where there is no existing or contemplated garage or parking area and/or where there otherwise will be no need or use for a permanent driveway, then a temporary driveway or parking area shall be installed for use during the period of construction under a building permit or during such temporary period as may reasonably be required for such special purpose, of wood, planks, or other material approved by the building department, between the curb or roadway and property line, and provisions approved by the building department shall be made to protect any existing curb. The village requirements for erosion control measures shall be implemented where applicable. A right-of-way bond must be posted for restoration of the right-of-way. 
B.  A permit for a temporary driveway or parking area shall not be considered a matter of right and shall only be issued when the building department finds that special conditions warrant same and no appreciable harm to the public welfare is likely to result therefrom. A permit for a temporary driveway or parking area shall be limited in time as specified by the building department. The permit shall be subject to any special conditions which the building department shall have power to terminate the right to the continued maintenance of a temporary driveway or parking area at any time that the building department finds that it conflicts with the public welfare. The building department may extend or renew a permit for a temporary driveway or parking area if the building department finds that the conditions required for the original issuance thereof still exist. All applicable processes, bonds, and fees shall be in effect as spelled out for a permanent driveway except that a verbal approval may be made by the building department when the proper fee and required cash deposit has been received by the department, and conditions warrant expedition of the process. Under these circumstances, the documents will follow as required. 
(Prior code § 7.19(f)) 
12.08.070 - Driveway improvement. 
A.  On streets with curbs, the curb must be broken, the broken faces repaired as approved by the village and a driveway shall be constructed between curb and property line. 
B.  On streets with no curb, a culvert shall be installed which shall be no less than twelve (12) inches in diameter, no less than eighteen (18) feet in length and shall be of asbestos cement, galvanized corrugated steel, or other material approved by the superintendent of public works. The culvert shall be set at the bottom of the flow line of ditch, pitched in direction of flow, all as approved by the superintendent of public works. The driveway shall be constructed over the culvert between the edge of the roadway and the property line. 
C.  If deliveries for construction purposes are to be made upon premises or a part of premises where there is no existing or contemplated garage or parking area and/or where there otherwise will be no need or use for a permanent driveway, then a temporary driveway shall be installed for use during the period of construction or other work under the building permit, of wood planks or other material approved by the superintendent of public works between the curb or roadway and property line, and provisions approved by the superintendent of public works shall be made to protect any existing curb. 
D.  In all cases, driveways must be at least eight (8) feet wide; ingress and egress to the property shall be only over driveway and no material, machinery or debris may be placed between property line and curb or roadway; existing sidewalks and/or curbs must be protected with wood planks or other approved means and all damage that may be done to existing sidewalks and/or curbs due to construction operations shall be repaired as approved by the superintendent of public works. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 24.04) 
12.08.080 - Violations-Penalty. 
    Any party who constructs any permanent or temporary access facility in violation of this chapter, will stand in breach of this chapter. The village will pursue all proper legal remedies to ensure removal of the improper access. The village will give the violating party a reasonable period of time to bring the illegal access into conformance with this chapter. If the illegal access is not brought into conformance within a reasonable period of time, the village will cause the removal of the access at owner's expense. The village may place a lien and enforce the lien on the property owner for the costs associated with the removal of the illegal access. If the village deems the illegal access facility an immediate danger, it will direct the owner to immediately remove the access; if the owner does not immediately remove the access the village will remove at owner's expense. 
(Prior code § 7.19(g))
