**  Undisturbed length of curb between driveway edge and intersecting street flare. 
General Notes 
1. Driveways shall be constructed to the right-of-way line. 
2. Culverts shall be provided where no curb and gutter is present. The minimum size shall be twelve (12) inches diameter or size as directed by the village engineer. Culverts shall contain end sections and shall extend three feet beyond the edge of the driveway flare. Pipe shall be RCP Class III, or CMP 0.064? thick. 
Chapter 12.12 - TREES AND SHRUBS 
Sections: 

12.12.010 - Trees and shrubs generally. 
A.  Planting. It is unlawful to plant any tree or shrub bush in any public street or parkway or other public place without having first secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the building commissioner and superintendent of public works. All trees and shrubs so planted shall be placed subject to the directions and approval of the village. 
B.  Removal. It is unlawful to remove or cut down any tree or shrub in any street, parkway or other public place without having first secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the building commissioner and superintendent of public works, and shall be referred by them to the board of trustees before permission shall be granted. 
C.  Injury. It is unlawful to injure any tree or shrub planted in any public place. 
D.  Advertisements or Notices. It is unlawful to attach any sign, advertisement or notice to any tree or shrub in any street, parkway or other public place. 
E.  Dangerous Trees. Any tree or shrub which overhangs any sidewalk, street or other public place in the village in such a way as to impede or interfere with traffic or travel in such public place shall be trimmed by the owner of the abutting premises or of the premises on which such trees or shrub grows so that the obstruction shall cease. 
    Any limb of a tree which has become likely to fall on or across any public way or place shall be removed by the owner of the premises on which such tree grows or stands. 
F.  Wires. It is unlawful to attach any wire or other rope to any tree or shrub in any public street, parkway or other public place without permission of the board of trustees. 
    Any person or company given the right to maintain poles and wires in the streets, alleys or other public places in the village shall, in the absence of provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such wires and poles free from and away from any trees or shrubs in such places so far as may be possible and shall keep all such trees and shrubs properly trimmed subject to the supervision of the superintendent of public works, so that no injury shall be done to the poles or wires or shrubs and trees by contact. 
G.  Gas Pipes. Any person maintaining any gas pipe in the village shall, in the absence of provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such pipes free from leaks so that no injury shall be done to any trees or shrubs. 
H.  Excavations. In making excavations in streets or other public places proper care shall be taken to avoid injury to the roots of any tree or shrub wherever possible. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 7.21) 
Chapter 12.16 - TREE PRESERVATION 
Sections: 

12.16.010 - Findings and determinations. 
    It is found and determined: 
A.  It is the public policy of the village to maintain and preserve, to the greatest extent possible, existing trees within the village. Trees contribute to the scenic beauty of the village and increase property values while enhancing the quality of life within the village. Trees also tend to soften the rough edges of developments and reduce the visual effects of suburbanization by creating a natural setting. 
B.  The preservation of individual trees and wooded areas provides desired environmental effects such as: acting as a barrier to noise, helping in the prevention of soil erosion and the absorption of water; providing nesting areas for birds and other wildlife; reducing the effects of sun, cold and wind, and filtering the air of pollutants. 
C.  The preservation of trees within the village is necessary in order to safeguard persons, protect property, prevent damage to the environment, and promote the public welfare; to promote the foregoing, it is necessary to guide, regulate, and control any development or construction activity which disturbs or disrupts trees or vegetative cover in the village. 
D.  In order to promote the health, safety, welfare and preserve the type and quality of life enjoyed by the residents of this village, it is necessary and desirable to enact an ordinance preserving trees within the village. 
(Prior code § 16.01) 
12.16.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter certain terms are defined as set forth below: 
    "Buildable area" means the area on a lot within the building setback line or required yards where a permitted structure may be erected. 
    "Building permit" means a permit issued by the village for the construction, erection, or alteration of a structure or building. 
    "Caliper" means thickness or diameter of trees. 
    "DBH" means diameter at breast height or four feet above the ground. 
    "Mature tree" means any tree with a DBH of twelve (12) inches or greater. 
    "Mature woodland" means any grove consisting of eight or more individual trees having a DBH of at least twelve (12) inches whose combined canopies cover at least fifty (50) percent of the area encompassed by the grove; provided, however, that no trees kept or grown for commercial purposes shall be considered a mature woodland. Trees that the village determines are detrimental to the area shall not be counted in determining a mature woodland. 
    "Parcel" means all contiguous land in one ownership. 
    "Significant tree" means any tree at least twenty-four (24) inches in diameter breast height or any individual tree which is of such size, species, condition, and structure that it dominates an area. 
    "Site development" means altering terrain, trees, and/or vegetation and constructing improvements thereon. 
    "Sketch plan" means a general map or drawing on which the design for the subdivision or planned unit development of land is presented for discussion purposes prior to the preparation of a preliminary plat. 
    "Tree expert" means an individual designated by the village to review a tree survey and perform any other tasks, regarding trees, as assigned. 
    "Tree survey" means a site plan indicating the location, size, condition, and common name of all trees located on the parcel with a DBH of twelve (12) inches or greater. The tree survey also outlines the proposed structures and impervious areas and identifies those trees which are proposed to be removed. 
    "Village" means the village of Grayslake, Lake County, Illinois. 
    "Village engineer" means the individual engineering consultant retained by the village. 
    "Woodland" means an area or stand of trees whose total combined canopy covers an area of one acre or more and at least fifty (50) percent of which is composed of canopies of trees having a DBH of at least six inches; provided, however, that no trees kept or grown for commercial purposes shall be considered a woodland. 
(Ord. 98-0-05 § 2; prior code § 16.02) 
12.16.030 - Tree preservation standards. 
    The objective of this chapter is to control tree removal caused by any construction activity in the village. Measures taken to protect trees shall assure that existing trees shall be saved to the greatest extent possible. However, it is not the purpose of this chapter to prohibit development within allowed building setback; rather, the intent is to minimize tree loss through careful planning and tree replacement where necessary. The following standards shall apply to all development or construction activities within the village and to the preparation of the submissions required under the subdivision control ordinance and zoning ordinance and building department permit process. 
A.  Development Proposals. 
1.  A tree survey shall be submitted with the sketch plan or other initial submittal related to development or redevelopment of a parcel and it shall be reviewed and verified by the tree expert. Said survey shall include a site plan indicating the location, size, common name, and condition of all trees located on the parcel with a DBH of twelve (12) inches or greater, and shall delineate all mature woodlands and woodlands. The tree survey will also outline the proposed structures and impervious areas and identify those trees which are proposed to be removed. The developer shall demonstrate through the tree survey, the proposed development design, and other information, that the proposed development minimizes tree loss to the greatest extent feasible and practical. Further, the developer shall demonstrate that the proposed lot configuration minimizes tree loss to the greatest extent feasible and possible by placing the maximum amount of trees feasible in the nonbuildable areas of proposed lots. 
2.  In areas considered woodlands under Section 12.16.020, no more than thirty (30) percent of the mature trees shall be cleared for development and the remaining seventy (70) percent shall be designated for preservation. Tree removal for required public improvements shall not constitute clearing of trees and shall not be included in calculating the thirty (30) percent of trees allowed to be removed. However, the developer shall demonstrate through the tree survey and other information that the proposed location of required public improvements minimizes tree loss to the greatest extent feasible and practical. Trees that the village determines are detrimental to the area shall not be counted in determining the removal percentage. 
3.  In areas considered woodlands under Section 12.16.020, the village board may specifically authorize more than thirty (30) percent removal as part of the final plat approval where particular hardship or impracticality is clearly demonstrated. Trees that the village determines are detrimental to the area shall not be counted in determining the removal percentage. 
4.  All final plats of subdivision or of planned unit developments approved by the village board shall include the location and size of all mature trees that will remain after development is completed. All included mature trees shall be designated for preservation. 
B.  Tree Preservation. The following shall apply to all buildable lots in the village: 
1.  All applications for building construction shall include a tree survey which identifies the size, location, and health of all significant trees and all mature trees on the parcel. 
2.  Tree preservation areas (as defined in subsection (B)(2)(a) of this section) shall be established for all new residences on subdivided lots where one or more mature or significant trees exist at the time of application for a building permit. 
a.  The tree preservation area is that area of a lot which is not needed for the house and driveway construction and where all mature trees and significant trees shall be preserved. The building activity area shall be the area on the lot where building activity may take place and shall be as small as possible, including the entire area affected by building and grading activities related to the approved construction. No construction activity, movement and placement of equipment or material storage shall be permitted outside the building activity area, in the tree preservation area. All buildings and driveways shall be located to minimize tree damage and/or removal but consistent with minimum building setback requirements of the zoning ordinance. The building activity area shall be temporarily fenced by the developer during all construction so that all trees in the tree preservation area shall be preserved. 
b.  The building commissioner shall prescribe and publish procedures to be implemented by building permit applicants in order to ensure that mature trees and significant trees required to be preserved under the terms of this chapter are not damaged or destroyed as a result of construction. Any person finding such procedure to be unreasonable or overly burdensome may appeal the enforcement of such procedure to the zoning board of appeals which such board may confirm such procedure, modify such procedure or establish such other procedure as the zoning board of appeals shall determine. 
3.  The building department shall verify the preservation of all mature trees and significant trees in the tree preservation area prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. Trees removed or destroyed in the tree preservation area shall be replaced in accordance with Section 12.16.040. 
4.  Any entity intending to perform underground utility construction that may involve removal of trees or work within drip lines of trees must first provide the village with a tree survey of the work area designating all woodlands, mature woodlands, mature trees or significant trees. The survey must also show drip lines of trees. After review of the survey, the village can issue a removal permit if the tree is dead or diseased, or the entity has no other option but to construct in the area. Open trenching shall be prohibited within the drip lines of trees unless it can be demonstrated that there is no other alternative location of utilities or method of installation. 
5.  If the entity does remove woodlands, mature woodlands, mature trees or significant trees or parts thereof, all options for replacement or relocation of the tree(s) must be considered. 
C.  Replacement Trees. Replacement trees shall not include the following: 
1.  Soft maple; 
2.  Poplar; 
3.  Willow; 
4.  Box elder; 
5.  Catalpa; 
6.  Tree of heaven; 
7.  Mountain ash; 
8.  Mulberry; 
9.  Ash trees; 
10.  As determined by the village board upon recommendation of the building department. 
D.  Removal and Destruction of Trees. Any one or more of the following conditions shall be sufficient to authorize the removal and destruction of a mature tree: 
1.  Necessary to alleviate a safety hazard to pedestrian or vehicle traffic or which threatens public safety; 
2.  Necessary to remove a tree which poses a safety hazard to structures or utilities; 
3.  Necessary to remove a diseased tree or one which has been weakened by age, storm, fire, or other injury; 
4.  Necessary to observe good forestry practice such as the number of healthy trees a given parcel shall support; 
5.  The tree(s) to be removed is included on the list in subsection C of this section; provided, however, that any such tree that has a DBH greater than twelve (12) inches is replaced with an acceptable replacement having minimum caliper of two and one-half inches. 
E.  Violation-Penalty. Any person removing or destroying any woodland, mature woodland or significant tree required to be preserved under the terms of this chapter, or any person removing or destroying any mature tree(s) or significant tree(s) prior to the approval of a building permit application and for the purpose of avoiding the preservation of mature tree(s) or significant tree(s) herein shall be subject to a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per mature tree or significant tree removed or destroyed. A stop work order may be placed on the site if, in the opinion of the building department, it is necessary. In addition, each mature tree or significant tree so destroyed or removed, shall be replaced with a new tree of at least five inches in caliper measured one foot from the ground. The total sum of the calipers of replacement trees must be equal to the total sum of the calipers of the trees being removed. In the event of a fraction of an inch, if a fraction is less than one-half inch or greater, the higher full number shall be used. (Ord. 2006-0-30 § 2(A); Ord. 98-0-05 §§ 3-5; prior code § 16.03) 
12.16.040 - Planting of trees on village parkways and village-owned property. 
    The following shall apply to all trees planted on village parkways or village-owned property: 
A.  Newly planted trees shall be free of infectious diseases and insect infestation. 
B.  Newly planted parkway trees shall be a minimum of fifty (50) feet from any adjoining tree. 
C.  Newly planted trees on village parkways and village owned property shall be at least two and one-half inches in caliper, measured one foot from the ground. 
D.  Planting of the following varieties shall be prohibited on village parkways and village-owned property: 
1.  Soft maple; 
2.  Poplar; 
3.  Willow; 
4.  Box elder; 
5.  Catalpa; 
6.  Tree of heaven; 
7.  Mountain ash; 
8.  Mulberry; 
9.  Ash trees. 
(Ord. 2006-0-30 § 2(B); prior code § 16.04) 
12.16.050 - Maintenance of trees on village parkways and village-owned property. 
A.  Pruning. Systemic pruning and trimming shall be carried out to accomplish the following: 
1.  Removal of dead branches, seriously damaged branches, and unbalanced branches and limbs which are a nuisance or safety hazard to the general public. 
2.  Gradual removal of lower branches to provide a minimum overhead clearance of twelve (12) feet over sidewalks and eighteen (18) feet over streets. 
3.  Shaping of young trees so that they will develop a single tall straight trunk, a strong central framework or branch structure, and a symmetrically balanced crown. 
4.  Reasonable removal of limbs that seriously interfere with or hinder proper development of adjacent trees. 
B.  Trimming. 
1.  No person shall, unless receiving approval from the village, remove, destroy, break, cut, deface, injure, or interfere with any tree growing in a village parkway or village-owned property. 
2.  All contractors, utilities, or contractors working for utilities shall not use climbing irons in trees on village parkways for any purpose other than removal of that tree or in an emergency. 
3.  Any tree or limb of a tree which has become dead, decaying, or broken and likely to fall on or across any public way shall be removed by the owner of the property on which the tree grows. The village will notify the owner of such hazard. If the owner fails to remove such hazard within thirty (30) days of such notification, the village will complete the work and bill the property owner for the cost of removing the tree or branch. If the property owner fails to pay the cost, the village may place a lien on the property to recover the cost. 
C.  Miscellaneous Tree Regulations. 
1.  No person shall permanently attach any rope or connect any electric or other wire antenna, etc. to any tree on a village parkway or other village-owned property. 
2.  No person shall attach any house number, sign, placard, or poster to any tree on village-owned property. 
3.  No person shall place around a tree on village-owned property any surfacing or material which will impede free passage of water and air to the roots without leaving a space of not less than eight inches in radius around the tree. 
4.  Wherever possible, the planting of native species shall be encouraged on village-owned property. 
(Prior code § 16.05) 
12.16.060 - Tree removal in non-newly subdivided areas. 
    It is not the intent of this chapter to prohibit removal of trees in areas not newly subdivided. However, it is strongly urged that homeowners contact the village prior to removal of significant trees in these areas. 
(Ord. 98-0-05 § 6: prior code § 16.04) 
Chapter 12.20 - GRAY'S LAKE USE REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

12.20.010 - Motor crafts on Gray's Lake. 
A.  Jurisdiction. This section shall apply to Gray's Lake only. 
B.  Permitted Groups. Only the following entities will be allowed to operate motorized craft on Gray's Lake: 
1.  Lakes management unit of the county health department; 
2.  Illinois Department of Natural Resources; 
3.  Gray's Lake management committee; 
4.  Grayslake community park district for weed harvesting purposes only; 
5.  Grayslake fire department. 
    No other person, organization or entity is allowed to operate a motorized craft on Gray's Lake. 
C.  Horsepower Limit. No motor operating on Gray's Lake shall exceed twenty-five (25) horsepower. The Grayslake fire department may exceed this limit for emergency purposes. 
D.  Violation-Penalty. Any person, organization or entity who is convicted of violating any provision of this section shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such violation and shall pay all court costs and village attorney fees incurred in prosecuting each such violation. 
(Prior code § 42.21) 
Chapter 12.24 - CEMETERY 
Sections: 

12.24.010 - Grayslake Cemetery. 
    Pursuant to Section 11-52-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code, control of the public graveyard commonly known as the Grayslake Cemetery, situated in the northerly part of the block bounded by Belvidere Road, Lake Street, Slusser Street and Junior Avenue, within the corporate limits of the village, being all that part of the aforesaid block lying north of the grade school and being in the North West quarter of Section 35, Township 45 North, Range 10 East of the 3rd P.M., in Lake County, Illinois, is taken over by the village, and the cemetery hereafter shall be managed, cared for and controlled as shall be provided for from time to time by action of the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Prior code § 4.26) 
Chapter 12.28 - NEWSRACKS 

12.28.010 - Definitions. 
A.  "Newsrack" The term "newsrack" shall mean, for the purposes of this chapter, any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit, or other dispenser designed, intended, used, placed, installed, or maintained for the display and sale or distribution of newspapers, periodicals, or other publications. 
B.  "Multiple newsrack" shall mean a single box, container, storage unit, or other dispenser that is owned, placed, and maintained by the village and that consists of multiple compartments, each of which serve as a separate newsrack. 
C.  "Multiple newsrack areas" are those areas designated by the village pursuant to Section 12.28.030 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2012-0-33, § 2, 9-18-2012) 
12.28.020 - Reserved. 
12.28.030 - Multiple newsrack areas. 
A.  Multiple Newsrack Areas. The following areas of the village are multiple newsrack areas: 
1.  That passenger railway station located in that certain area of the village bounded by Lake Street, St. Paul Street, Slusser Street, and commonly known as the Lake Street Metra Station. 
B.  Limitation of Newsracks within Multiple Newsrack Areas. No person shall place or maintain any newsrack within a multiple newsrack area except multiple newsracks placed and maintained by the village. Such multiple newsracks shall be maintained for publications on request. Such multiple newsracks shall be subject to the following standards: 
1.  The number of multiple newsracks in the multiple newsrack area shall be established by the building commissioner shall be sufficient in number to accommodate all publications located in existing newsracks within the multiple newsrack area as of September 1, 2012, and shall be reasonably sufficient to accommodate general demand. 
2.  A publication shall be assigned a compartment upon application therefor by the publisher, which application shall include information as required by the Village including, without limitation, the name, address, and contact information for the publisher. 
3.  All publications with at least five different daily editions each week shall be assigned a compartment in each multiple newsrack. If the number of additional publications seeking placement exceeds available compartments, then a random selection process shall be used to determine which publications shall be eligible for compartments. 
4.  Compartments shall be assigned randomly. For publications distributed on a paid basis, the assignments shall begin with the first available top left compartment, proceeding left to right and downward. For publications not distributed on a paid basis, the assignments shall begin with the bottom right compartment, proceeding right to left and upward. 
5.  Any compartment that remains empty for thirty (30) days or longer shall be deemed vacant and may be assigned to another publication pursuant to this chapter. 
6.  No person shall place or maintain any newsrack in the multiple newsrack area except those multiple newsracks placed and maintained by the village. 
(Ord. No. 2012-0-33, § 2, 9-18-2012) 
12.28.040 - Reserved. 
12.28.050 - Nonconforming newsracks. 
    Within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this chapter, any newsrack that does not comply with any regulation of this chapter shall be brought immediately into compliance, and thereafter all newsracks shall at all times be maintained in compliance, with all of the regulations of this chapter or shall be removed. Any newsrack not so brought into, or maintained in, compliance or removed shall be removed by the building commissioner, subject to the provisions of Section 12.28.070 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2012-0-33, § 2, 9-18-2012) 
12.28.060 - Nuisance declared. 
    Any newsrack that is placed, affixed, erected, constructed, installed, or maintained within a multiple newsrack area in violation of any provision of this chapter is hereby declared a public nuisance and may be removed at any time by the building commissioner, subject to the provisions of section 12.28.070 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2012-0-33, § 2, 9-18-2012) 
12.28.070 - Notice; removal for noncompliance. 
    If any newsrack is installed, used or maintained in violation of the provisions of this section, the building commissioner shall provide written notice to the owner of the newsrack. if known, and if the newsrack is not removed or placed so as to be in conformance with this section, within five days from the date of such notice, the newsrack may be removed. If the owner of the newsrack is unknown, or if the placement of the newsrack creates a danger to the public, the village may summarily remove it and store it in any convenient place as provided herein. The village shall then take reasonable steps to notify the owner of the newsrack. Upon failure of any owner to claim a newsrack which has been removed and stored by the village, and to pay the village's expenses for such removal and storage, such newsrack shall be deemed to be unclaimed property in possession of the village and may be disposed of pursuant to state law and village ordinances governing the disposition of unclaimed property. 
(Ord. No. 2012-0-33, § 2, 9-18-2012) 
12.28.080 - Reserved. 
12.28.090 - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates this [chapter] shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2012-0-33, § 2, 9-18-2012)

Chapter 13.04 - STANDARDS FOR PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS 
Sections: 

13.04.010 - Public improvements. 
A.  Findings and Determinations. It is found and determined that, in order to provide for the uniform and safe construction of public improvements within the village, it is necessary to establish standards applicable to all public improvements constructed within the village, as detailed in subsection B of this section. 
B.  Public Improvement Standards Established. Whenever public improvements are constructed or required to be constructed as part of any development or otherwise within the village, all such public improvements shall be constructed in accordance with the standards and requirements as set forth in the subdivision control ordinance of the village, as amended, being Title 16 (Subdivisions) of this code, inclusive of such plan review and approval, and posting of letters of credit or other security, as is required by the terms of the subdivision control ordinance as amended. Upon completion and approval of such public improvements, they shall be conveyed or transferred to the village by bill of sale in form acceptable to the village, accompanied by proof of authority to so transfer from the grantor or issuer of the bill of sale. The proof of authority shall be in such form as may be required by the village to establish ownership of the improvements in the village. 
(Prior code § 21.05) 
Chapter 13.08 - WATER SERVICE SYSTEM 
Sections: 

13.08.010 - Water service-Turn-on. 
A.  Authorization. No water from the village water supply shall be turned on for services into any premises by any person other than the superintendent of public works or some other person authorized by the superintendent to perform this service. 
B.  Application-Fee. Application to have water turned on shall be made in writing to the building commissioner, and shall contain an agreement by the applicant to abide by and accept all of the provisions of this chapter as conditions governing the use of the village water supply by the applicant. 
C.  Guarantees and Deposits. When premises (or part or parts thereof) are occupied by a tenant or tenants, a guarantee of account to guarantee the prompt payment of every billing by the village for all water, sewer and garbage furnished to the premises shall be executed by the owner or owners of the premises, upon such form and embracing such terms and conditions as may be approved by the corporate authorities, and shall accompany each such application; and in case any residential or commercial unit is being occupied or is to be occupied by a tenant and such unit has an individual water meter, regardless of whether such unit has a separate water service or whether there is just one water service for the building, the tenant shall, as additional security make a deposit of forty-five dollars ($45.00) for sewer, water and garbage in the case of a residential unit and one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for sewer and water in case of a commercial unit. When service to any tenant is discontinued permanently, the deposit less any amount still due to the village for residential sewer, water and garbage, and sewer and water service for commercial units, if any, shall be refunded without interest. 
D.  Compliance with Plumbing Code. No water shall be turned on for service in premises in which the plumbing does not comply with the ordinances of the village; provided that water may be turned on for construction work in unfinished buildings, subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 8.01) 
13.08.020 - Service connections-Inspections-Street openings-Basic charges-Recapture costs. 
A.  The provisions of this code and of all other ordinance provisions of the village relative thereto, shall be complied with in making excavations in streets or other public places, if any, for water connections. No connection with a village water main shall be made without a connection permit being issued under this chapter and without the fees and charges required by this chapter, and/or in other ordinances required, being paid. An application in writing for such a connection shall be made to the building commissioner or his or her authorized representative, together with a deposit of all amounts and security required by ordinance in connection therewith. At least twenty-four (24) hours' notice shall be given to the department of public works of the village when such a connection is desired to be made pursuant to such a permit. All materials for each connection, including materials for backfilling, shall be furnished by the permit holder. Each connection shall be made by the permit holder, his or her employee or contractor, and payment of all charges and expenses connected therewith shall be made promptly by the permit holder. Each connection shall be made under the supervision of the department of public works. Each excavation shall promptly be backfilled and road surface shall be satisfactorily repaired as required by ordinance; provided, however, that no such connection shall be covered until the work shall have been duly inspected by and approved by the department of public works. In case of any failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter, or of any ordinance provision or law, the village shall have the right to sever the connection, and the connection shall not again be made without a full compliance with such provisions. The basic applicable connection charge provided for is to provide a reasonable contribution toward a proportionate part of the overall cost of the existing village systems heretofore funded by the patrons of the system, and is to be deposited with the village as such reimbursement upon the proportionate part of such overall cost prior to the connection being made, it being expressly understood and stipulated that the recapture charge provided is to apply toward a proportionate part of the cost of the area water line installation is in addition to the aforesaid basic charge. It is expressly found and determined that the applicable basic connection charge provided for does not exceed the reasonable pro rata part of the overall cost properly chargeable to the premises for which the applicable permit may be issued. Also, it is expressly found and determined that the applicable recapture charge provided for does not exceed the reasonable pro rata part of the overall cost, properly chargeable to the premises for which the applicable permit may be issued, of the area water line extension to which the connection is to be made. 
B.  For each water connection made to a residential, commercial or industrial building or other type of structure, the basic connection charge shall be based on the size of the water meter as set forth in Section 3.08.040 of this code. 
C.  In addition to the water connection charges in Section 3.08.040, any applicable recapture cost, as provided by any village ordinance, shall be paid as reimbursement toward the cost of the water main extension to which the connection is to be made, or if no recapture ordinance applies and a main extension has been installed (to which the connection can be made) at the expense of the village through the funding provided by the existing users of the system, then a recapture charge of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per front foot of the premises to be served, is made, and shall be paid by the applicant for a connection permit, as the reasonable pro rata part of the cost of the installation of such extension. 
D.  Enjoyment of the actual water service of the system shall at all times be subject to the payment of the service rates or charges applicable, and to a compliance with the rules and regulations of the system, as established by the corporate authorities of the village from time to time and in force at any given time. 
E.  Equalization contribution charges shall be as set forth in Section 3.08.040 of this code. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 8.02) 
13.08.030 - Resale of water. 
    No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the village supply to any premises other than that for which application has been made and the meter installed, except in case of emergency. 
(Prior code § 8.03) 
13.08.040 - Tampering with system. 
    It is unlawful for any person not authorized by the village to tamper with, alter or injure any part of the village water works or supply system or sewer system or break seal on any meter. 
(Prior code § 8.04) 
13.08.050 - Water service pipes; shut-off boxes; service boxes. 
A.  Installation. All water service pipes from the mains to the premises served shall be installed by, and at the cost of, the owner of the property to be served or the applicant for the service. Such installation shall be under the inspection of the building commissioner or his or her designee. 
B.  Pipes. No water service shall be installed unless it conforms to specifications outlined in the most recently adopted plumbing code of the village, a copy of which shall be kept on file by the clerk and shall be open to inspection by any person interested. 
C.  Repairs. All repairs on water service pipes, exclusive of the saddle or corporation cock connected to the Village water main and starting with the water pipe connected to the saddle or the corporation cock, and plumbing systems of buildings shall be made by, and at the expense of, the owners of the premises served. 
In the event an owner fails to repair a water service pipe, water shut-off box, or service box within ten (10) days from the date the village notifies the owner that such repairs are necessary, the village may perform such repair work and charge the owner of the premises served for the costs expended. In addition, in the event of an emergency, the village may repair any service pipes and charge the owner of the premises served for the costs expended. 
In the sole discretion of the village, the costs expended for all repairs performed by the village may billed in up to twelve (12) equal installments as part of the regular utility bill. 
Payment of the above costs are subject to the penalty, delinquency notice, and service disconnection provisions in Sections 13.16.020 and 13.16.030 of this title, and a lien against the premises for nonpayment of such costs shall be served to the same extent and with the same effect as for delinquencies pursuant to Section 13.16.040 of this title. 
The village shall not be responsible for any damage or necessary repairs that may result from the village's attempts to locate, inspect or utilize a water service pipe or water shut-off box. 
D.  Location. It is unlawful to place any service pipe in the same excavation with, or directly over, any drain or sewer pipe. 
E.  Shut-Off Boxes. Shut-off boxes or service boxes shall be placed on every water service pipe, and shall be located between the curb line and the sidewalk line where this is practicable. Such boxes shall be so located that they are easily accessible and shall be protected from frost. 
F.  Service Boxes-Inspection Required. Before any water is turned on to any such premises, the service box must be inspected by the building commissioner or his or her designee and must be approved by him or her. If the building commissioner or his or her designee approves the service, the water will be turned on to such premises. Such fees shall be paid to the village clerk who shall give a certificate of approval to the applicant. 
(Ord. 2006-0-11 § 2: Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 8.05) 
(Ord. No. 2012-0-02, § 2, 1-17-2012; Ord. No. 2012-0-03, § 2, 1-17-2012) 
13.08.060 - Meters. 
A.  All premises using the village water supply must be equipped with an adequate water meter furnished by the village at cost plus ten (10) percent thereof, payable in cash in advance; provided that such water service may be supplied by the village at a flat rate of charge until such meter may be installed. 
B.  Before any premises are occupied, a water meter shall be installed therein as required by this section or application made for such water service at the flat rate of charge until such meter can be installed or no water shall be furnished to such premises. 
C.  Meters shall be installed in a location that will be easy to access and shall be sealed at the time of installation, and it is unlawful for anyone to break such seal of any such water meter except as authorized by the corporate authorities of the village. 
D.  The public works department and village manager or his or her designee shall read or cause to be read every water meter used in the village at such times as are necessary that the bills may be sent out at the proper time; provided, however, that nothing in this subsection shall preclude the village from issuing water bills from time to time based on estimated usage in lieu of such meter readings. 
E.  No person shall in any manner obstruct or cause to be obstructed the free access of any village personnel to any water meter or other reading device, shut-off box, service box, service line, fixture, or connection with any water main or service pipe, or refuse or prevent full access thereto by such personnel whenever such personnel shall reasonably desire access thereto. The refusal of any person to allow village personnel access to water meters or other reading device, shut-off box, service box, service line, fixture, or connection with any water main or service pipe, or to cooperate in any inspection or survey of the water system, shall constitute a sufficient basis for termination of water service, after notice in the same manner as provided for delinquencies pursuant to Section 13.16.030 of this title. 
(Ord. 2006-0-11 § 3: Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 8.06) 
13.08.070 - Emergency water use plan. 
A.  Procedures. During a water shortage crisis declared by federal, state or local governmental officials, the village may take any of the following necessary measures to reduce water demand to the minimum level necessary to maintain the health, safety and welfare of Grayslake's residents as follows: 
1.  Restrict or prohibit hydrant and water system flushing; 
2.  Restrict or place a ban on all external water uses such as watering lawns, gardens, etc.; 
3.  Restrict water available for industrial use; 
4.  Restrict use of water at commercial car washes, public swimming pools and water-cooled air conditioning systems; 
5.  Reduce water pressure in the potable water system; 
6.  Impose reasonable daily, per capita consumption limits on all residents; 
7.  Restrict water use except for residential uses and essential services. 
B.  Emergency Water Use Plan. The village shall establish an emergency water use plan which shall be on file in the office of the village clerk for imposition during such declared water shortage crises and adopted by reference. 
(Prior code § 8.07) 
13.08.080 - Landscape water use restrictions. 
A.  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    "Irrigation" means the dispersion of water to prevent arid soil conditions and/or promote landscape growth or preservation. 
    "Landscape" means and includes sodded and seeded lawns, gardens, trees, shrubs and other living plants. 
B.  Use Restrictions. The use of water from the village water system for the use in landscape irrigation from May 15th through September 15th of each year is prohibited between the hours of ten a.m. and five p.m. each day, except that newly sodded or seeded areas of lawns may be watered at any time for a two-week period following installation of such sod or planting of such seed. 
C.  Violation-Penalty. Any person violating the terms of this section shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such violation. Each day that any such violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2001-0-10 § 2: prior code § 8.08) 
Chapter 13.12 - SEWER SERVICE SYSTEM 
Sections: 

13.12.010 - Construction of definitions and statutes-Conformance with sewer permit applications. 
A.  The definitions contained in Section 13.12.020 shall apply wherever the words and phrases therein defined are employed in this chapter. 
B.  Subject to the provisions of subsection A of this section, unless the context otherwise requires, any word or phrase employed in this chapter which is defined in some other ordinance of the village, shall receive the construction so defined. 
C.  Subject to the provisions of subsections A and B of this section, unless the context otherwise requires, the rules for the construction of statutes provided for in Sections 1 to 4, both inclusive, of "An Act to revise the law in relation to the construction of the statutes," approved March 5, 1874, as amended (see Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 131, Sections 1 to 4), insofar as they may be applicable. 
D.  Applications for sewer permits under this chapter shall conform substantially with the forms on file in the office of the village clerk. 
(Prior code § 9.17) 
13.12.020 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this chapter and Chapter 13.16 shall be as follows: 
    "Administrator" means the Administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
    "Approving authority" means the village or any representative designated by the president and board of trustees. 
    "BOD (biochemical oxygen demand)" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at twenty (20) degrees C, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    "Basic user charge" means the basic assessment levied on all users of the public sewer system. 
    "Building drain" means that part of the lowest piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer or other approved point of discharge, beginning five feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    "Building sewer" means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    "Combined sewer" means a sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater, storm, surface and groundwater drainage. 
    "Control manhole" means a structure located on a site from which industrial wastes are discharged. Where feasible, the manhole shall have an interior drop. The purpose of a "control manhole" is to provide access for the village representative to sample and/or measure discharges. 
    "Debt service charge" means the amount to be paid each billing period for payment of interest, principal and coverage of (loan, bond, etc.) outstanding and shall be computed by dividing the annual debt service by the number of users connected to the wastewater facilities. 
    "Director" means the Director of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
    "Easement" means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
    "Effluent criteria" are defined in any applicable "NPDES Permit". 
    "Federal act" means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U. S. C. 1251 et seq.) as amended by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of Amendments of 1972 (Pub. L. 92-500) and (Pub. L. 93-243). 
    "Federal grant" means the U.S. government participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as provided for by Title II-Grants for Construction of Treatment Works of the Act and implementing regulations. 
    "Floatable oil" means oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. Wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
    "Garbage" means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    "Industrial user" means any nongovernmental user of publicly owned treatment works identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, Office of Management and Budget, as amended and supplemented under the following divisions: 
1.  Division A - Agriculture, Forestry, and Fishing. 
2.  Division B - Mining. 
3.  Division D - Manufacturing. 
4.  Division E - Transportation, Communications, Electric, Gas and Sanitary Services. 
5.  Division I - Services. 
    A user in the divisions listed may be excluded if it is determined by the village that it will introduce primarily segregated domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences. 
    "Industrial waste" means any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged, permitted to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business establishment or process or from the development, recovery or processing of any natural resource as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    "Major contributing industry" means an industrial user of the publicly owned treatment works that: (1) has a flow of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons or more per average work day; or (2) has a flow greater than ten (10) percent of the flow carried by the municipal system receiving the waste; or (3) has in its waste a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in standards issued under Section 307(a) of the Federal Act; or (4) is found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the issuance of the NPDES permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works. 
    "Milligrams per liter" means a unit of the concentration of water or wastewater constituent. It is 0.001 g of the constituent in one thousand (1,000) ml of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of water and wastewater analysis. 
    "Natural outlet" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface or groundwater. 
    "NPDES permit" means any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the Administrator, or, where appropriated by the Director, after enactment of the Federal Water Pollution Control Amendments of 1972, to regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant to Section 402 of the Federal Act. 
    "Person" means any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual, firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association, society, institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity. 
    "pH" means the logarithm (base ten (10)) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen-ion concentration expressed by one of the procedures outlined in "Standard Methods". 
    "Population equivalent" is a term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or other waste on a treatment works or stream. One population equivalent is one hundred (100) gallons of sewage per day, containing .17 pounds of BOD and .22 pounds of suspended solids. 
    "ppm" means parts per million by weight. 
    "Pretreatment" means the treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction into the wastewater treatment works. 
    "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    "Public sewer" means a sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the village. It shall also include sewers within or outside the village boundaries that serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the village sanitary (or combined) sewer system, even though those sewers may not have been constructed with village funds. 
    "Replacement" means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement. 
    "Residential or commercial" or "Nonindustrial" user means any user of the treatment works not classified as an industrial user or excluded as an industrial user as provided for in this section. 
    "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and into which storm, surface, and groundwaters or unpolluted industrial wastes are not intentionally admitted. 
    "Sewage" is used interchangeably with "wastewater". 
    "Sewer" means a pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or any other waste liquids, including storm, surface and groundwater drainage. 
    "Sewerage" means the system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection, transportation and pumping of sewage. 
    "Sewerage fund" is the principal accounting designation for all revenues received in the operation of the sewerage system. 
    "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive. 
    "Slug" means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five times the average twenty-four (24) hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    "Standard Methods" means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the most recent edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
    "State Act" means the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act of 1970. 
    "State grant" shall mean the state of Illinois participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as provided for by the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act and for making such grants as filed with the Secretary of State of the State of Illinois. 
    "Storm sewer" means a sewer that carries storm, surface and groundwater drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    "Stormwater runoff" means that portion of the precipitation that is drained into the sewers. 
    "Surcharge" means the assessment in addition to the basic user charge and debt service charge which is levied on those persons whose wastes are greater in strength than the concentration values established in Chapter 13.20. 
    "Suspended solids" means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage, or industrial waste, and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in "Standard Methods". 
    "Unpolluted water" means water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
    "Useful life" means the estimated period during which the collection system and/or treatment works will be operated and shall be thirty (30) years from the date of start-up of any wastewater facilities constructed with a state grant. 
    "User charge" means a charge levied on users of treatment works for the cost of operation and maintenance. 
    "User class" means the type of user either "residential or commercial" (nonindustrial) or "industrial" as defined in this section. 
    "Village" means the village of Grayslake. 
    "Wastewater" means the spent water of a community. From this standpoint, of course, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present. 
    "Wastewater facilities" means the structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and transport effluent to a watercourse. 
    "Wastewater service charge" means the charge per quarter or month levied on all users of the wastewater facilities. The service charge shall be computed as outlined in Chapter 13.20 and shall consist of the total or the basic user charge, the debt service charge and a surcharge, if applicable. 
    "Wastewater treatment works" means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or "pollution control plant". 
    "Water quality standards" are defined in the Water Pollution Regulations of Illinois. 
    "Watercourse" means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Prior code Ch. 9, Appx. 1) 
13.12.030 - Inspectors-Powers and duties. 
A.  The village engineer and other duly authorized employees of the village, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The village or its representative shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper, or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterway or facilities for waste treatment. 
B.  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in subsection A of this section, the village engineer or duly authorized employees of the village, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the village employees and the village shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by village employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required in Section 13.12.140. 
C.  The village engineer and other duly authorized employees of the village bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the village holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Prior code § 9.14) 
13.12.040 - Use of public sewers required. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the village or in any area under the jurisdiction of the village, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
B.  It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the village, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this chapter. 
C.  Except as provided in this chapter, it is unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
D.  The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes, situated within the village and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located any public sanitary (or combined) sewer of the village, is required at the owner's expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within ninety (90) days after date of official notice to do so, provided that the public sewer is within two hundred (200) feet (sixty-one (61) meters) of the property line. 
(Prior code § 9.01) 
13.12.050 - Private sewage disposal. 
A.  Where a public sanitary (or combined) sewer is not available under the provisions of Section 13.12.040(D), the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this section. 
B.  Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the county health department. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the county health department which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the county health department and/or the village building commissioner or his or her designee. 
C.  A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the county health department and the village building commissioner or his or her designee. 
    They shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the county health department and the village when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within forty-eight (48) hours of the receipt of written notice by the building commissioner or his or her designee. 
D.  The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the State of Illinois Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act and Code and with the State of Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than forty thousand (40,000) square feet (three thousand seven hundred sixteen (3,716) square meters). No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
E.  At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in Section 13.12.040(D), a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this chapter, and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. 
F.  The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, and at no expense to the village. 
G.  No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the county health department. 
H.  When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to said sewer within sixty (60) days and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bank-run gravel or dirt. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 9.02) 
13.12.060 - Building sewers and connections. 
A.  It is unlawful to make any connection with or opening into, or alter or disturb the village sanitary sewer system or storm sewer system without having first secured a permit therefor. An application for such a permit shall be made in writing to the building commissioner of this village, or the building commissioner's duly authorized representative, and shall be accompanied by a statement of the purpose of the connection to premises to be served, and the specifications of the pipe to be connected and of the drain from the building or premises to be served, to the municipal sewer main. No such permit shall be issued unless the building commissioner or the building commissioner's duly authorized representative shall have found that the ordinances of the village will be complied with in the making of such connection. 
B.  All disposal by any person into the sewer system is unlawful except those discharges in compliance with federal standards promulgated pursuant to the Federal Act and more stringent state and local standards. 
C.  There shall be three classes of building sewer permits: (1) for residential; (2) for commercial service; and (3) for service to establishments producing industrial wastes. In either case, the owner or the owner's agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the village. 
D.  A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage facilities including sewers, pump stations and waste-water treatment facilities have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load. 
E.  All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the village from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
F.  A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except that where one building stands at the rear of another on the interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
G.  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the building commissioner or his or her designee to meet all requirements of this chapter. 
H.  The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the village. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials, Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois shall apply. 
I.  Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by a means which is approved in accordance with this section and discharged to the building sewer. 
J.  No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, pumps, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
K.  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code, or other applicable rules and regulations of the village, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials, Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the village before installation. 
L.  The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the building commissioner when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the building commissioner or the commissioner's representative. 
M.  All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the village. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 9.03) 
13.12.070 - Use of the public sewers. 
A.  No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
B.  Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the village. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the village to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet. 
(Prior code § 9.04) 
13.12.080 - Wastes prohibited. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewers: 
A.  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid, or gas. 
B.  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant. 
C.  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works. 
D.  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(Prior code § 9.05) 
13.12.090 - Deleterious wastes-Defined-Prohibited. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the county public works department that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment; have an adverse effect on the receiving stream; or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. In forming an opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the county public works department will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and maximum limits established by regulatory agencies. The substances prohibited are: 
A.  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (sixty-five (65) degrees C). 
B.  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous materials; or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred (100) mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) degrees and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (0 and sixty-five (65) degrees C). 
C.  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the building commissioner or his or her designee. 
D.  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not. 
E.  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, or similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the North Shore Sanitary District for such materials. 
F.  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor-producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the North Shore Sanitary District as necessary after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters. 
G.  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the North Shore Sanitary District in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
H.  Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of 9.5. 
I.  Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005 mg/l as Hg at any time except as permitted by the North Shore Sanitary District in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. 
J.  Any cyanide in excess of 0.025 mg/l at any time except as permitted by the North Shore Sanitary District in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations. 
K.  Materials which exert or cause: 
1.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fullers earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate); 
2.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions); 
3.  Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment works; 
4.  Unusual volume of flow or concentrations of wastes constituting "slugs" as defined in Section 13.12.020. 
L.  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(Ord. 2002-0-04 § 2 (part); prior code § 9.06) 
13.12.100 - Disposition of deleterious wastes. 
A.  If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in Section 13.12.090 or Chapter 13.16, and/or which are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in Chapter 1, EPA Rules and Regulations, subchapter D, Water Programs Part 128-Pretreatment Standards, Federal Register Volume 38, No. 215, Thursday, November 8, 1973 and any amendments thereto, and which in the judgment of the North Shore Sanitary District may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the North Shore Sanitary District may: 
1.  Reject the wastes; 
2.  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
3.  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
4.  Require payment to cover the added costs of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges, under the provisions of Section 13.12.150. 
B.  If the North Shore Sanitary District permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the village, and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances, and laws. 
(Prior code § 9.07) 
13.12.110 - Interceptors-Required when. 
    Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the village, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the village and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(Prior code § 9.08) 
13.12.120 - Maintenance of preliminary treatment facilities. 
    Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at the owner's expense. 
(Prior code § 9.09) 
13.12.130 - Control manholes. 
    Each industry shall be required to install a control manhole and, when required by the village, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the village. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at the owner's expense, and shall be maintained by the owner so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Prior code § 9.10) 
13.12.140 - Tests and measurements. 
A.  The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, tests, and analyses of waters and wastes to illustrate compliance with this chapter and any special conditions for discharge established by the village or regulatory agencies having jurisdiction over the discharge. The number, type, and frequency of laboratory analyses to be performed by the owner shall be as stipulated by the village, but no less than once per year the industry must supply a complete analysis of the constituents of the wastewater discharge to assure that compliance with the federal, state, and local standards are being met. The owner shall report the results of measure-ments and laboratory analyses to the village at such times and in such manner as prescribed by the village. The owner shall bear the expense of all measurements, analyses, and reporting required by the village. At such times as deemed necessary, the village reserves the right to take measurements and samples for analysis by an outside laboratory service. 
B.  All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty-four (24) hour composite of all outfalls of a premise is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken.
