Add the following new appendix: 
Appendix L SPACE ALLOCATION FOR STORAGE OF RECYCLED MATERIALS 
    This section contains requirements for the issuance of permits for new construction, additions and alterations of multi-family and nonresidential structures for the space allocation for storage of recycled materials. 
    L101 General. The purpose of this code is to establish minimum standards for the issuance of permits for new construction, additions and alterations of multi-family and nonresidential structures for the space allocation for the storage of recycled materials. 
    L101.2 Scope. This code applies to reasonable design standards and procedures for the collection and storage of recyclables. 
    L102 Definitions. 
    L102.1 General. The following words and terms shall, for the purpose of this Appendix have the meanings shown herein: 
    Commercial Recycling Program. A recycling program that collects waste that originates from non-residential uses. 
    Cubic Yard. Unit of measurement equivalent to 200 gallons. 
    Curbside Collection. A method of collecting source-separated recyclable materials from the curb or alleyway. 
    Exterior Recyclable Storage Area. Final collection area for all recyclable materials. Exterior recyclable storage areas shall be external to the occupied area of the building unit(s) but may exist within the structural shell (i.e. loading docks, parking garages, refuse rooms, etc.). 
    Internal Recovery System. The procedures and containers utilized to isolate and remove recyclables from the occupied areas of a building. 
    Recyclable Materials (Recyclables). Waste materials that are collected separated or processed and used in raw form of raw materials. 
    Recycling Program. Any program focused on the recovery or materials for use as raw materials. Includes materials captured prior to entering the waste stream or recovered from the waste stream. 
    Recycling System. A system which addresses the needs created by the act of recycling. System components include, but may not be limited to, recycling materials storage containers at the point of generation; equipment and labor for preparing recyclable materials to exterior recyclable storage area(s). 
    Space Allocation. The area required storing or holding recyclable materials prior to final collection. 
    Space Planning. The act of identifying components of a recycling system and the specific requirements of each system element. 
    System Plan. Detailed abstract of the individual components of a recycling system and the specific requirements of each system element. 
L103 Construction Documents and Permits. 
    L103.1 Application. The application for a permit shall be accompanied by construction documents in sufficient detail and indicating the location of interior and exterior recyclable storage areas and a list of recyclable materials generated. 
L104 Use Groups I-1, R-2 and R-3. 
    L104.1 A minimum of three (3) cubic feet shall be allocated per dwelling unit, except Use Group I-1 for an internal recovery system. This area shall be located so as to facilitate storage of recyclable materials within the structure and facilitate ease of removal to the exterior recyclable storage area. 
    104.2 Exterior recyclable storage area allocation. The amount of exterior recyclable storage area allocation per dwelling shall be determined as follows and shall not be less than the sum of individual computations. 
  Number of studio and one bedroom units x 7 gallons + 
  Number of two bedroom units x 8 gallons + 
  Number of three and four bedroom units x 9 gallons = 
    The Exterior Recyclable Storage Area allocation required. 
    L104.3 Recycling system plan. A comprehensive recycling system plan shall be required which includes provisions for an exterior recyclable storage area and a collection system for recyclable materials generated by the building(s) occupants. 
    L104.4 Refuse and recycling enclosures shall be required for Use Groups I-1, R-2 and Mix-use Buildings containing Use Groups I-1 and R-2 where refuse and recycling containers are not stored wholly within the building. 
    L104.4.1 Refuse enclosure and/or recycling enclosure shall be screened from view on at least three sides by masonry wall not less than six (6) feet and not more than eight (8) feet in height. Each refuse enclosure and recycling enclosure shall have a decorative solid heavy duty metal gate or decorative heavy duty wood gates. 
    L104.4.2 Exterior design of the refuse enclosure and/or recycling enclosure shall comply with the requirements of Chapter 15.48 - Industrial and Office Design Standards. 
    L104.4.3 Refuse and recycling enclosure shall be sized to provide for both refuse and recycling receptacles without one blocking the other for proper access. 
    L104.4.4 Gate stops are required to hold back gate doors during servicing of refuse and/or recycling receptacles. 
    L104.4.5 Refuse and/or recycling enclosure shall be identified on the site plan. 
    L104.5 Refuse chutes and recycling chutes shall be provided in Use Groups I-1, R-2, or Mix-Use Buildings containing Use Groups I-1 or R-2 for the collection of garbage and the collection of recyclables in buildings two (2) stories or more where the refuse and recycling containers are stored wholly within the building. The chutes shall be constructed in accordance with 708.13 of this code. Each chute shall be clearly identified by the use of signage installed in accordance with the State of Illinois Accessibility Code. The recyclable materials shall be identified. 
    Exception: A recycling chute is not required if a room is provided on each floor that Use Group I-1 or R-2 exist for the collection of recyclables. The room shall be a minimum 100 square feet and completely separated from the reminder of the building by construction that has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 2-hour and openings into the recycling shall be protected by opening protectives that have a fire protection rating of not less than 2-hours. The room shall be fully sprinkled and the doors shall be self-closing. The room shall be identified by signage installed in accordance with the Illinois Accessibility Code. 
    L104.5.1 Termination room shall be sized to handle containers for both refuse and recyclables. This shall be demonstrated in the construction documents. The termination room shall be construction in accordance with Section 708.13.4 of this code. 
L105 Commercial, Industrial and Institutional Uses 
    L105.1 A comprehensive recycling plan shall be filed as part of the construction documents. The recycling plan shall provide provisions for exterior recycling storage, the flow of materials through the facility, identify centralized areas of consolidation of refuse and recyclables and a collection system for the recycling materials generated by the building occupants. 
    L105.2 Interior space allocation. The amount of interior space necessary to comply with the requirements of this Section is dependent on the generation of recyclable materials resultant form activities associated with commercial recycling programs. 
    L105.3 Exterior recyclable storage area allocation. The amount of exterior storage area necessary to comply with the requirements of the requirements of this Section is dependent on the volume generation of recyclable materials derived from commercial recycling programs. Exterior recyclable storage area options in shall be addressed in a recyclable system plan. 
    L105.4 Refuse and/or recycling enclosures shall be provided for Use Groups A, B, E, F, H, I, M, R-1 and R-4 where refuse and recycling receptacles are not wholly within the building. 
    L105.4.1 Refuse enclosure and/or recycling enclosure shall be screened from view on at least three sides by a masonry wall not les than six (6) feet and not more than eight (8) feet in height. Each refuse enclosure and/or recycling enclosure shall have a decorative solid heavy duty gates or duty wood gates. 
    L105.4.2 Exterior design of all refuse enclosure and/or recycling enclosure shall comply with the requirements of Chapter 15.28 - Building Facade Architectural Design Standards. 
    L105.4.3 Refuse and recycling enclosure shall be sized to provide for both refuse and recycling receptacles without blocking the other for proper access. For restaurants and/or bars the enclosure shall be sized for the storage of refuse and recycling receptacles along with the receptacles for the storage of grease and oils. 
    L105.4.4 Gate stops are required to hold gate doors during servicing of the refuse receptacles and/or recycling receptacle. 
    L105.4.5 Refuse enclosure and/or recycling enclosure shall be identified on the site plan. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-04, § 3, 1-15-2013; Ord. No. 2014-0-12, § 2, 4-15-2014; Ord. No. 2017-0-22, § 2, 6-20-2017)

(Ord. No. 2013-0-04, § 4, 1-15-2013) 
15.04.040 - Severance clause. 
    If any provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, subsection, or parts of this chapter, or the application thereof to any person, firm, corporation, or circumstance, shall, for any reason, be adjudge by a court of competent jurisdiction to unconstitutional or invalid, said judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder of this chapter or the application of such provision or other persons, firms, corporation, or circumstances, but shall be confined in its operation to the provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, subsection, or part thereof directly involved in the controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered and/or to the person, firm, corporation, or circumstance involved. It is hereby declared to be the legislative intent of the corporate authorities that this chapter would have been adopted had such invalid provision or provisions not been included or if it had not been made applicable to such person, firm, corporation, or circumstance. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-04, § 5, 1-15-2013) 
15.04.050 - Conflicts; ordinance number; effective date. 
    Any rule, regulation, or ordinance in conflict with the provisions hereof is hereby repealed, but to the extent of such conflict only. This ordinance [Chapter 15.04] shall be designated Ordinance No. 2013-0-04 and shall be in full force and effect ten (10) days after its passage and approval in accordance with law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-04, § 6, 1-15-2013) 
Chapter 15.08 - CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY 
Sections: 

15.08.010 - Required-Issuance procedure. 
A.  Condition to Issuance of a Certificate of Occupancy-Procedure. A condition is imposed upon the issuance of each certificate of occupancy for each newly improved property within the village, as follows: 
1.  An unexecuted certificate of occupancy for such property shall be filed with the assessor, and the owner of such property shall obtain from the assessor, in the form prescribed by such official, a receipt showing that the unexecuted certificate of occupancy has been filed and that the property is subject to increased assessment, from the date of issue of the certificate on a proportionate basis for the year in which the improvement was completed. 
2.  The owner of such property shall file such receipt with the village and a certified copy of the certificate, when issued, shall on behalf of the village be filed by the building commissioner of the village with the assessor. 
B.  Unlawful to Occupy Property Without Certificate. It is unlawful for any property within the village that is newly improved to be occupied without a full compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Prior code § 24.05)

15.12.020 - Chapter 1. General Administration-Amended. 
A.  Section 106 Violations and Penalties. 
1.  Section 106.4 Penalty. Delete the existing subsection and add the following: 
Any person, persons, firm or corporation adjudged guilty of violating any of the provisions of this code, including (without limitation) a failure, neglect, or refusal to comply with a notice given pursuant to the provisions hereof or to comply otherwise with the provisions hereof, shall be fined not more than seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Proceedings may be commenced by warrant, arrest, or summons, whether by ticketing or other means. Each day the violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
B.  Section 111 Permit. 
1.  Section 111.1 Permit Required. Delete the existing subsection and add the following: 
A permit shall be obtained before beginning construction, alteration or repairs, using application forms furnished by the Building Department. 
C.  Section 112 Plans. 1. Change Section 112 to read as follows: "Plans and Surveys." 
2.  Add the following new subsections: 
Section 112.3 Survey Required. A spot survey shall be filed with the Building Official for approval prior to framing. The spot survey shall be prepared by a State of Illinois Registered Land Surveyor. The information required on the survey shall be in accordance with Appendix G of this Code. 
Section 112.4 As-Built Drainage Plan. An As-Built Drainage Plan prepared by a registered State of Illinois Land Surveyor or a registered State of Illinois Civil Engineer shall be filed with the Building Official for approval prior to the issuance of a Certificate of Occupancy. The information required on the survey shall be in accordance with Appendix G of this Code. 
D.  Section 118 Stop Work Orders. 
1.  Section 118.1 General. Delete electrical and plumbing systems from first sentence. 
(Ord. 98-0-10 § 2 (part)) 
15.12.030 - Chapter 2. Building Definitions-Amended. 
A.  Section 202 General Building Definitions. 
1.  Family. Delete existing definition and add the following new definition: 
Family. Two (2) or more persons related by blood, marriage, legal adoption or guardianship or not more than five (5) persons not so related together with domestic servants and temporary gratuitous guests living together as a single housekeeping unit. 
2.  Townhouse. Delete existing definition and add the following new definition: 
Townhouse is a single-family dwelling unit constructed in a row of attached units separated by property lines and with open space on at least two sides. Units with floor-ceiling assemblies shall be defined as apartments. 
3.  Add the following new definitions: 
Curbside Collection: A method of collecting source-separated recyclable materials from the curb or alleyway. 
Internal Recovery System: The procedures and containers utilized to isolate and remove recycles from the occupied areas of a building. 
Municipally Sponsored Recycling Program: A recyclable collection program which is regulated by contract or franchise and which defines levels and frequency of recyclable collection service to be provided to the resident. 
Recyclable Materials (Recyclable): Waste materials that are collected, separated or processed and used as raw materials or products. 
Recycling: The series of activities by which materials, that would otherwise remain wastes, are collected, separated, processed and used in the form of raw materials. 
(Ord. 98-0-10 § 2 (part)) 
15.12.040 - Chapter 3. Building Planning-Amended. 
A.  Section 303 Light, Ventilation and Heating. 
1.  Section 303.1 Habitable Rooms. Add new exceptions 3 and 4: 
3.  Provide light and ventilation by windows or doors in exterior walls with both glazed and ventilating area of not less than two (2%) percent of the basement floor area. 
4.  When the floor of a recreation room is below grade level, provide light and ventilation by windows or glazed doors in the exterior walls of not less than four (4%) percent of the floor area. 
B.  Section 309 Garages. 
1.  Section 309.2 Separation Required. Change 1/2 inch (12.7mm) in Line 2 and 3 to 5/8 inch Type X. 
2.  Section 309.3 Floor Space. Delete existing subsection and add the following: 
Garage and carport floor surfaces shall be of an approved noncombustible material. If a door opening occurs between the garage or carport and the dwelling, provide a 6 inch (153mm) curb at the door or construct the floor 6 inches (153mm) lower than the adjacent residential floor. This also applies to stairwells leading to the basement from the garage. That area of floor used for parking vehicles shall be sloped to facilitate the movement of liquids toward the main vehicle entry door. Floor drains shall be prohibited. 
3.  Add the following new subsections: 
Section 309.4 Detached Garage 
This shall comply with the requirements of one-story dwellings with the following exceptions: 2 × 4 studs, maximum spacing 24 inches on center, double studs are not required at jambs of openings of less than 3'5? in width. Sheathing and building paper may be omitted on walls. Corner posts may be two (2) 2 × 4's or a 4 × 4. Top plate may be single, provided rafters occur over studs and walls are tied to the top plate in a manner satisfactory to the Building Official. Rafter ties shall be not less than the size of the rafter and installed in the lower 1/3 of same with a maximum spacing of 4 feet (1219mm) on center. Corner bracing is required except where wood sheathing or another approved rigid sheathing material is used. 
Section 309.5 Separation 
Detached garages and all other accessory structures shall maintain a ten (10) foot (3048mm) fire separation from all other structures. 
C.  Section 310 Exits. 
1.  Add the following new subsection: 
310.5 Basement Emergency Egress. 
Either a door providing exit directly to the outside or an escape type window located in an exterior wall approximately 26? × 32? (660.4mm × 812.8mm) in size with adequate area-way well with a removable steel grate is to be provided in each basement. The sill of the escape opening shall be a maximum of 44? (1118mm) above adjacent floor level. 
D.  Section 311 Doors and Hallways. 
1.  Section 311.1 General. Delete the existing subsection and add the following: 
A dwelling shall be provided with two means of egress. The main entrance door shall be a minimum of 3 feet (914mm) in width and 6'8? (2032mm) in height. The secondary entrance door must be a minimum of 2'8? (812.8mm) in width and 6'8? (2032mm) in height. A sliding glass door is acceptable as a secondary entrance provided that it is an approved exterior frame and door. 
E.  Section 314. Stairways. 
1.  Section 314.2 Treads and Risers. Change 7 3/4 inches (197mm) in line 2 to 8 1/4 inches (210mm) and 10 inches (254mm) in line 3 to 9 inches (229mm). 
F.  Section 320 Dwelling Unit Separation. 
1.  Section 320.1 Two Family Dwellings. Delete existing subsection and add the following: 
Dwelling units in two-family dwellings shall be separated from each other by a wall assembly of not less than 1-hour fire-resistive rating when tested in accordance with ASTM E 119. Fire-resistive rated wall assembly shall extend to the underside of the roof sheathing. 
2.  Section 320.1.1 Supporting Construction. Delete subsection. 
3.  Section 320.2 Townhouses. Delete existing subsection and add the following: 
Each townhouse shall be considered a separate building and shall be separated from the adjacent dwelling unit(s) by a two hour rated fire separation wall meeting the requirements of Section 302. Such wall shall not contain plumbing or mechanical equipment, ducts or vents in the cavity of the common wall. Electrical installations are limited to electrical wire, installed in raceways and electrical outlet boxes. 
Metallic electrical outlet boxes shall not exceed 16 square inches (10,320mm 2 ) in surface area. The aggregate surface area of the boxes shall not exceed 100 square inches (0.645m 2 ) for any square feet (9.29m 2 ) of wall area. Metallic outlet boxes on opposite sides of walls shall be separated by a minimum distance of 24 inches (610mm). 
Metallic electrical outlet boxes shall be installed in accordance with their listings and with the current Grayslake Electrical Code. 
4.  Section 320.2.3 Structural Independence. Delete exception 4 from subsection. 
5.  Section 320.3 Sound Transmission. Delete existing subsection and add the following: 
Wall assemblies separating dwelling units shall provide sound insulation. 
6.  Section 320.3.2 Structural-borne Noise. Delete subsection. 
7.  Add new Section 325 Recycling: 
Section 325.1 Space Allocation. A minimum of three (3) cubic feet shall be allocated (reserved) for an internal recovery system. This area shall be located so as to facilitate storage of recyclable materials within the dwelling and facilitate ease of removal to an external collection point. The internal recovery system may be located in the attached garage or basement area. Building plans for the construction of new dwellings, and the addition or alteration of existing dwellings shall identify the location of the Internal Recovery System. 
(Ord. 98-0-10 § 2 (part))

(c)  An approved automatic sprinkler system designed per current NFPA 13

15.12.120 - Appendix G-Added. 
A. Add the following as Appendix G entitled "Survey": 
Section G101 Scope. This appendix contains the requirements for surveys for new construction for one and two family dwellings and one family townhouses. 
Section G102 Permit Applications. Applications shall include the following Building Permit Grading Plan requirements: 
1.  Scale of Plan: 1? = 20' or larger (Shown on Plan) 
2.  North Arrow 
3.  Property lines with dimensions 
4.  Easement lines 
5.  Building setback lines 
6.  Proposed foundation with outside dimensions 
7.  Top of foundation elevations along with location of changes in elevation at steps in foundation 
8.  Driveway, sidewalks, and patios (curb catch basins shall not be located in driveway aprons). 
9.  Finished garage floor elevation at garage door. 
10.  Top of curb elevation at side property lines extended, curb returns for corner lots, and centerline of driveway. 
11.  Back of sidewalk elevations at side yard lot lines, sidewalk intersections on corner lots, and at centerline of driveway. 
12.  Finished grade elevations at foundation corners. 
13.  Finished grade elevations of patios. 
14.  Top of frame elevations of catch basins and/or inlets in yards and curb lines. 
15.  Existing and proposed elevations at grade break points on side and rear lot lines. 
16.  Arrows showing direction of overland flow within the lot, along side and rear lot lines and a driveway along with the proposed slope expressed in percent. 
17.  Existing or proposed tops of foundation on all adjacent lots. 
18.  Proposed foundation ties to front, all side yards and rear yards. This distance shall be the shortest distance between the proposed foundation and the property line. 
19.  Existing contour lines within the lot and to a distance of at least 25 feet outside the lot. This information should reflect current conditions and not necessarily preconstruction conditions. 
20.  A legend of contour and spot elevation symbols. The casual reviewer should be able to differentiate between existing and proposed elevations. 
21.  This document shall be titled "Proposed Grading Plan" and shall become part of the building permit records for the subject lot. 
Section G103 Spot Survey. Survey shall be done after the foundation has been completed and prior to framing. The following is the information required on the survey: 
1.  Scale of Plan: 1? = 20' 
2.  North Arrow 
3.  Property lines with dimensions 
4.  Easement lines 
5.  Building setback lines 
6.  Foundation with outside dimensions 
7.  Distances from all property lines 
8.  Top of foundation along with changes in elevation at steps in the foundation 
Section G104 Record Grading Plan. The following information is required on a "Record Grading Plan": 
1.  Plat of Survey with foundation ties and dimensions. 
2.  Finished garage floor elevation at edges of driveway. 
3.  Finished back of sidewalk at property lines, sidewalk corner on corner lots, and at driveway edges. 
4.  Ground elevations at foundation corners. 
5.  Elevation at patio corners. 
6.  Spot elevations at rear property corners and at all grade breaks on side and rear lot lines. 
7.  Top of frame elevations at inlets and/or catch basins in rear yards and curb lines. 
8.  As constructed ground slopes expressed in percent along with arrows showing direction of surface runoff. 
9.  Certification by a Registered State of Illinois Land Surveyor or Civil Engineer. 
10.  This document shall be titled "Record Grading Plan" and become part of the building permit records for the subject lot. 
(Ord. 98-0-10 § 2 (part)) 
Chapter 15.16 - NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE ADOPTED[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-0-06, §§ 1-15, adopted Jan. 15, 2013, repealed the former Ch. 15.16, §§ 15.16.010-15.16.090, and enacted a new Ch. 15.16 as set out herein. The former Ch. 15.16 pertained to the electrical code adopted and derived from Ord. 2005-0-22 §§ 2-10. 

15.16.010 - Adoption of the National Electrical Code - 2011 Edition, with exceptions and modifications. 
    The Municipal Code of the Village of Grayslake be amended by striking and deleting Chapter 15.16 of the Municipal Code and substituting in its place the following new Chapter 15.16 adopting and amending the National Electrical Code, 2011 Edition. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 1, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.020 - Electrical code. 
1.  Rules Adopted. The rules and regulations of the National Fire Protection Association, Inc. for electrical wiring and apparatus, contained in the Code known as the National Electrical Code 2011, published in book form as above adopted by the National Fire Protection Association, Inc. at its annual meeting held August 10, 2010, except as modified herein below, are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. This chapter shall be known and cited as the Grayslake Electrical Code 2011. 
2.  Additional Special Rules. Said National Electrical Code 2011 herein above referred to, is hereby made subject to additional rules and modifications as follows: 
Article 90 Introduction 
Article 90.8 Wiring Planning add the following new articles: 
    90.8 (A)(1) New Construction. In new construction, for future expansion, a minimum of ten (10) percent of the available space in a panel shall be provided as spaces or blanks. 
    90.8 (A)(2) Dwelling Units. An unused 11/4; inches (35mm) raceway shall be provided from the basement to the attic. 
Article 100 Definitions add the following definitions: 
    Chief Electrical Inspector: The chief electrical inspector shall be appointed by the Village President, by and with the consent of the Village Board, at the same time and in the same manner as other village officials. 
    Electrical Contractor: The term "electrical contractor" as used in this code means any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of installing, altering or modifying, by contract, any electrical equipment for the utilization of supply of electricity for light, heat or power, signal and communications, but excluding radio apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sounds and signals, and excluding common carries which are under the jurisdiction of the Illinois Commerce Commission, in their use or operation as public utilities. The term "electrical contractor" does not include employees of such contractor who perform or supervise such work. 
    Electrical Equipment: The term "electrical equipment" as used in this code means any conductor or equipment installed for the utilization of electricity for light, heat or power, signal and communications systems, but does not include radio apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sound and signals, and does not include conductors, apparatus and other equipment installed for and by public utilities, including common carries, which are under the jurisdiction of the Illinois Commerce Commission, for use in their operation of public utilities. 
    Electrical Vehicle (EV): Electrical Vehicles (EV) are propelled by an electrical motor (or motors) powered by rechargeable battery packets. 
    Plug-in Hybrid Electrical Vehicle (PHEV), Plug-in Hybrid Vehicle (PHV) or Plug-in Electrical Vehicle (PEV): are hybrid vehicles which utilizes rechargeable batteries, or another storage device, that can be restored to full charge by connecting a plug to an external power source. 
    Screen Room: All structures that only use screens to separate the interior from the outside environment. It will be considered a wet location and shall follow the applicable codes of this [chapter]. 
    Three Season Room: Any structure attached or detached to a residential dwelling that has windows or barriers installed, with no heat, and the use is for something other than storage, shall follow Section 210.52-Dwelling Units Receptacle Outlets; and Section 210.70-Lighting Outlets Required; and other applicable codes of this [chapter]. 
Article 110 Requirements for Electrical Installations 
110.5 Conductors delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    110.5 Conductors. All conductors used to carry current shall be copper. 
110.8 Wiring Methods add the following sentence to the end of this Article: 
    Where there is a question as to methods or material to be used, the ruling of the Chief Electrical Inspector shall govern. 
110.12 Mechanical Execution of Work at the end of this sub-section add the following sub-sections: 
(C)  All abandoned conduit, wire, and other electrical equipment and material shall be removed. This shall include low-voltage wiring, fire alarm wiring, data, processing cable, etc. 
(D)  Free standing electrical distribution centers and motor control centers designed for the floor installation must be mounted on a minimum four (4) inch (102 mm) thick concrete pad. 
(E)  All transformers where subject to physical damage, or where washing the floor with water is frequent shall be installed on a minimum four (4) inch (102 mm) thick concrete pad. 
Article 210 Branch Circuits 
Table 210.2 Specific-Purpose Branch Circuits add the following: 
    EV and PHEV Charging Stations, Section 625.4.1. 
Article 210.8(A) Dwelling Units delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
(A)  Dwelling Units. All 125-volt, single-phase, 15- and 20-ampere receptacles installed in locations specified in (1) through (8) shall have ground-fault circuit-interrupter protection for personnel. 
(1)  Bathrooms 
(a)  Receptacles installed in bathrooms shall not be permitted to fed by travelers from GFI from another room, nor shall travelers be permitted to supply other room receptacles or lighting outside the bathroom. 
(b)  All lights and exhaust fans installed inside shower stalls or over bathtubs shall be GFI protected. 
(2)  Garages, and accessory buildings that have a floor located at or below grade level not intended as habitable rooms and limited to storage areas and areas of similar use. 
    Exception to (2): A single receptacle outlet for refrigerators, freezers, garage door openers, and sump pumps located within dedicated spaces for each appliance that in normal use, are not easily moved form one place to another and that are cord and plug connected in accordance with 400.7(A)(6), 400.7 (A)(7) or 400.7 (A)(8). 
(3)  Outdoors 
    Exception to (3): Receptacles that are not readily accessible and are supplied by a dedicated branch circuit for electric snow-melting or deicing equipment shall be permitted to be installed in accordance with 426.28 or 427.22 as applicable. 
(4)  Crawl Spaces - at or below grade 
(5)  Unfinished Basements-for the purpose of this section, unfinished basements are defined as portions or areas of the basement not intended as habitable rooms and limited to storage areas, work areas or similar uses. 
    Exception 1 to (5): Receptacles that are dedicated for sump pumps and ejector pumps. 
    Exception 2 to (5): A receptacle supplying only a permanently installed fire or burglar alarm system shall not be required to be ground-fault circuit-interrupter protected. 
    Informational Note: See 760.41 (B) and 760.121(B) for power supply requirements for fire alarm systems. 
    Receptacles installed under the exception to 210.8(A)(5) shall not be considered as meeting the requirements of Article 210.52(G). 
    Exception 3 to (5): Refrigerators, freezers and similar appliances located within dedicated spaces for each appliance that in normal use, are not easily moved from one place to another and that are cord and plug connected in accordance with 400.7(A)(6), 400.7(A)(7) or 400.1(A)(8). 
(6)  Kitchens-where receptacles are installed to serve the countertop surfaces. 
(7)  Laundry, utility and wet bar sinks or other sinks-where the receptacles are installed within 6 feet (1.6m) of the outside edge of the sink. 
(8)  Boathouses 
    Exceptions to (1) to (8): A non-GFCI protected, single-type receptacle may be installed for sanitary sewer ejector pumps, sump pumps, garage door openers, or life support equipment. 
(9)  Screen Rooms, 3-Season Rooms, Screen Porches and the like. 
Article 210 (B) Other Than Dwelling Units delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
(B)  Other than Dwelling Units. All 125-volt, single phase, 15-20-ampere receptacles installed in the locations specified in (1) through (5) shall have ground-fault circuit- interrupter protection for personnel: 
(1)  Bathrooms 
(2)  Kitchens 
(3)  Rooftops 
(4)  Outdoors 
    Exception No. 1 to (3) and (4): Receptacles that are not readily accessible and are supplied from a dedicated branch circuit for electric snow-melting or deicing equipment shall be permitted to be installed without GFI protection. 
    Exception No. 2 to (4): In industrial establishments only, where the conditions of maintenance and supervision ensure that only qualified personnel are involved, an assured equipment grounding conductor program as specified in 590.6(B)(2) shall be permitted for those receptacle outlets used to supply equipment that would create a greater hazard if power is interrupted or having a design that is not compatible with GFI protection. 
(5)  Sinks-where receptacles are installed within 6 feet (1.8m) of the outside edge of the sink. 
    Exception No. 1 to (5): In industrial laboratories, receptacles used to supply equipment where removal of power would introduce a greater hazard shall be permitted to be installed without GFI protection 
    Exception No. 2 to (5): For receptacles located in patient care areas of health care facilities other than those covered under 210.8(A)(1), GFI protection shall not be required. 
    Exception to (1) through (5): A non-GFI protected, single type receptacle may be installed for sanitary sewer ejector pump, sump pumps, garage door openers or life support equipment. 
(6)  Wet bars- under bar lighting, bar area receptacles 
(7)  Locker Rooms with associated showering facilities. 
(8)  Garages, service bays, and similar areas where electrical diagnostic equipment, electrical hand tools, or portable lighting equipment are to be used. 
(9)  Outdoors, where installed to comply with Article 210.63 
210.19 (A)(1) General add Informational Note No. 5: 
    Informational Note No. 5: Where the major portion of the load consists of nonlinear loads, harmonics systems may increase the resistivity of the conductor leading to higher voltage. 
210.23 (A) 15- and 20-Ampere Branch Circuits delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    210.23 (A) 15- and 20-Ampere Branch Circuits: 
1.  Independent circuits, being a minimum of 15-ampere, shall be provided for each of the following loads: dishwasher, furnace, sump or ejector pumps (less than 2" discharge), refrigerator, motors rated at 1/2 horse power or less, permanently installed heating appliances rated at less than 1200 watts, garage lighting circuit, whole house vacuum rated at 1/2 horse power or less, built-in ironing, family room, living room, smoke detectors and whirlpool tubs. (Switch for the dishwasher shall be located under the kitchen counter. Plug in cords for the dishwasher is prohibited. The disconnect switch for the whirlpool tub shall be located in the motor access panel.) 
2.  Independent circuits, being a minimum of 20-ampere, shall be provided for each of the following loads: microwave ovens, food freezer, gas range/microwave combinations, electrical ovens (in addition to Article 210.19(B)), clothes washer, clothes dryer, compactor, whole house vacuum rated at more than 1/2 horse power, sump or ejector pumps (2" discharge or larger), dining room, permanently installed heating appliances rated 1200 watts or greater (see Article 210.8 (A)(2)). 
3.  Sump pumps and sanitary ejector pumps shall be served by an individual branch circuit. The circuit and its single receptacle outlet shall be in addition to any outlets required by 210.52.

    210.52(G) Basements, Garages and Accessory Building. For a one-family dwelling, the following provisions shall apply: 
(1)  At least one 20-amp receptacle outlet, in addition to those for specific equipment, shall be installed in each basement, in each attached garage, and in each detached garage or accessory structure with electric power. 
(2)  Where a portion of the basement is finished into one or more habitable rooms, each separate unfinished portion shall have a 20-amp receptacle outlet installed in accordance with this section. 
(3)  A separate circuit shall be provided for overhead garage door(s).

Article 225 Outside Branch Circuits and Feeders 
225.10 Wiring on Buildings delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    225.10 Wiring on Buildings. The installation of outside wiring on surfaces of buildings, signs or poles shall be permitted for circuits of not over 600 volts, nominal, in rigid galvanized metal conduit, galvanized intermediate conduit, liquidtight flexible metal conduit, rigid aluminum conduit and in busways. When rigid aluminum conduit is used, it shall be installed in a manner as not to be exposed to mechanical damage. At no time shall rigid aluminum conduit be installed between grade level and 6 feet (2 m) above grade level where vehicular traffic is present or where vehicular traffic could be present (rear of buildings in alleyways, delivery areas etc.). In these areas the use of rigid metal conduit shall be approved. Circuits over 600 volts, nominal, shall be installed as provided in Article 300.37. Circuits for signs and outside lighting shall be installed in accordance with Article 600. 
225.12 Open-Conductor Supports add the following sentence to the end of this Article: 
    All straps and hangers used that are exposed to the weather or to a corrosive atmosphere shall be required to be of malleable metal with back straps where required. 
225.32 Location add the following sentence to the end of this Article: 
    A disconnecting means shall be located inside of the occupant's space and disconnect all the power inside said unit. 
225.35 Access to Occupants deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    225.35 Access to Occupants. In a multiple-occupancy building, each occupant shall have a main disconnecting means installed within the tenant space. 
    Exception: 
1.  In single-family dwelling units, it is permissible to have two (2) disconnecting means for 400-amp and larger single-phase service. 
2.  In use group F-1, F-2, S-1, S-2 and U (i.e. factory, industrial, storage, utility and miscellaneous) as per International Building Code/2009. The main disconnect means may be located on the outside of the occupant's space. 
3.  When an office complex of Use Group B per the International Building Code/2009 not over 200 square feet (18.60 m 2 ), fed from a common tenant panel in an accessible area, and under one management meter plan, all circuits in the office space shall be able to be disconnected by one switch (i.e. lighting and power), excepted house controlled exit lighting and the switch shall be located by the front door of the tenant space. 
Article 230 Services 
230.41 Insulation of Service-Entrance Conductors delete exceptions in its entirety. 
230.42 (A) General delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    230.42(A) General. Service entrance conductors shall be of sufficient size to carry the loads as computed in accordance with Article 220. But shall not be less than the ampacity required by 230.79, herein. 
230.42(C) Ground Conductors delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    230.42(C) Ground Conductors. The ground conductor must be at least the same size as the underground conductor. 
230.43 Wiring Methods for 600 Volts, Nominal, or Less delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    230.43 Wiring Methods for 600 Volts, nominal, or less: Service entrance conductors shall be installed in accordance with the applicable re- 
quirements of this code covering the type of wiring methods used and limited to the following methods: (1) Rigid Metal Conduit and (2) Intermediate Metal Conduit. Where subjected to possible damage or corrosion, said service shall be installed in heavy wall type. 
    Exception: 
1.  Rigid commercial conduit or industrial services maybe installed by means designed for the purpose intended with the prior approval of the Chief Electrical Inspector. 
2.  Exterior parking lot lighting may be installed in PVC with prior approval of the Chief Electrical Inspector. 
230.50 Protection of Open Conductors and Cables against Damage-Above Ground delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    230.50 Protection of Open Conductors and Cables against Damage-Above Ground. Service entrance conductors installed above ground shall be protected against physical damage as specified in Article 230.43 above. This protection shall extend to not less than ten (10) feet (3048 mm) above final grade level. 
230.70(A)(1) Readily Accessible Locations delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    230.70(A)(1) Ready Accessible Locations. The service disconnecting means shall be installed at a readily accessible location outside of the residential, commercial or other buildings or structure near the utility metering, or other approved location. A switch, fuse circuit breaker, shunt-trip control, or other approved means 
    If an over-current type disconnect is not used, the service entrance conductors shall not be more than 5 feet (1.5m) in length from where they enter the building. 
    If a shunt-trip control is used, see Chief Electrical Inspector for approval. 
230.79 Rating of Service Disconnect Means delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    230.79 Rating of Service Disconnect Means. The service disconnect shall have a rating not less than the load to be carried as determined in accordance with NEC Article 220. In no case shall the rating be less than specified in (a), (b), (c), (d), (e) or (f) below: 
a.  One-Circuit Installations. For installations to supply only limited loads of a single branch circuit, the service disconnecting means shall have a rating of not less than 15 amperes. 
b.  Two-Circuit Installations. For installations consisting of not more than two 2- wire branch circuits, the service disconnecting means shall have a rating of not less than 30 amperes. 
c.  One and Two Family Dwelling Services. New one and two family dwellings, including attached townhomes shall have a minimum 200 ampere, with 40 circuit branch circuit openings. The conductors shall not be less than #3/0 wire, installed in a minimum 2 inch (53mm) conduit (See 230.43 amendment), and shall comply with disconnect requirements in accordance with 230.70(A)(1) amendment. 
d.  Multi-Family Dwelling Services. The service size shall be determined according to NEC Article 220. Each unit in a multi-family dwelling shall have a minimum 100 ampere main disconnect, with 20 circuit branch circuit openings. The conductors shall not be less then #3/0 wire, installed in a minimum 1-1/4 inch (35mm) conduit (see Article 230.43 amendment) and shall comply with disconnect requirements in accordance with 230.70(A)(1) amendment. 
e.  Residential Service Revision. All residential service revisions shall have a minimum 100 ampere main disconnect, with 20 circuit. The conductors shall not be less than #3/0 wire installed in a minimum 1-1/4 inch (35mm) conduit (see Article 230.43 amendment), and shall comply with disconnect requirements in accordance with 230.70(A)(1) amendment. 
f.  All Others. For all other installations, the service disconnecting means shall have a rating or not less than 60 amperes. The conductors shall be sized in accordance with 310.16 and shall be installed in conduit (See 230.43 amendments), and shall comply with disconnect requirements in accordance with 230.70(A)(1) amendments.

Article 300 Wiring Methods 
300.1(A) All Wiring Installations delete subsection in entirely and replace with the following: 
(A)  All wiring installations. All new wiring installations or any changes or additions to electrical systems previously constructed shall be within Rigid Metal Conduit (RMC), Intermediate Metal Conduit (IMC) or Electrical Metallic Tubing (EMT). 
    Exception: Where necessary to fish through existing [partitions], flexible metal conduit (Greenfield) may be used. 
(1)  Where flexible metal conduit (Greenfield) type method are used as provided in (A) above, for concealed spaces, the system shall adapt back to approved conduit within thirty-six (36) inches (914 mm) after leaving the concealed space.

    Table 300.5(A) Minimum Cover Requirements, 0-600 Volts, Nominal, Burial in Millimeters for installations on below grade without final landscaping (turf), the minimum cover for Rigid Metal Conduit (RMC) and Intermediate Metal Conduit (IMC) shall be a minimum of twelve (12) inches (305 mm) below the propose final grade, unless otherwise stated in the NEC to be greater.

    300.24 Abandoned Raceways, Cables and Wiring. All abandoned conduit, low voltage wiring, fire alarm wiring and electrical equipment shall be removed from all ceilings, walls and floor areas.
