Article 440 Air-Conditioning and Refrigerating Equipment 
    Article 440.14(A) In addition to that set forth in Article 440.14, the local disconnect for the air conditioning condenser(s) shall be installed as follows: 
a.  The local disconnect shall be installed a minimum of twenty-four (24) inches (610 mm) to a maximum of thirty (30) inches (762 mm) from the finish grade to the bottom of the disconnect. 
b.  Air conditioner rough-ins shall be wired to the requirements of the code to the weather proof disconnect. 
Article 553 Floating Buildings delete in its entirety. 
Article 555 Marinas and Boat Yards delete in its entirety. 
Article 600 Electrical Signs and Outline Lighting 
Article 600.8 Enclosures add a new sub-section to read as follows: 
(E)  Permanently installed exterior signs shall have a weatherproof G.F.I. receptacle installed within three (3) feet (914 mm) of the sign, for the purpose of maintenance of the sign. The G.F.I. receptacle may be installed as a part of the sign to be accessed from the exterior or installed as a part of the sign to be accessed from the exterior or interior of the sign. 
Article 625 Electric Vehicle Charging Systems 
Add the following section: 
    625.4.1 Dedicated Branch Circuit. Receptacles used for EV or PHEV charging stations shall be dedicated branch circuits. 
Article 680.71 Protection shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced with the following: 
    680.71 Protection. Hydromassage bathtubs and their associated electrical components shall be protected by a ground-fault circuit interrupter installed in the main electrical panel. In addition, an insulated green equipment grounding conductor shall be installed from the motor outlet to the panel grounding bus sized per Table 250.122. All 125-volt, single-phase receptacles not exceeding 30 amperes and located within 5 feet (1.52 m) measured horizontally of the inside walls of a hydromassage tub shall be protected by a ground-fault circuit interrupter(s). 
Article 720 Circuits and Equipment Operating at Less Than 50 Volts 
720.11 Mechanical Execution of Work delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    720.11 Mechanical Execution of Work. Circuits operating at less than 50 volts shall be installed in a neat and workmanlike manner. All low voltage wire shall be properly secured with insulated staples. Low voltage furnace control wire shall be taped or secured at the furnace location. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 2, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.030 - Office established. 
1.  Office Established. It is hereby established within the building department of the Village of Grayslake, the office of chief electrical inspector. 
2.  Chief Electrical Inspector Appointment. The chief electrical inspector as provided for above, shall be appointed by the village president, by and with consent of the village board of trustees, at the same time and in the same manner as other village officials. 
3.  Duties and Powers of Chief Electrical Inspector. The chief electrical inspector shall be charged with the duties of enforcing the provisions, rules and regulations, fixing standards and specifications for the regulation and use of electrical equipment as defined in this chapter and prescribed in any other ordinances of the Village of Grayslake. 
a.  The chief electrical inspector shall be and is hereby authorized to control, supervise, inspect and approve all electrical installations. If any equipment or wiring is found unsafe to life or property, the inspector shall notify the person, firm or corporation owning, using, installing or operating said equipment or wiring to place in a safe condition within a reasonable time, not to exceed five days thereafter. It shall be the duty of such person, firm or corporation to make necessary corrections to put the same in safe condition. 
b.  The provisions for inspection of work authorized by permits issued by the village shall not be construed as prohibiting the inspection of any electrical wiring or apparatus now or whenever installed as such time as the electrical inspector shall determine that public safety requires it. No inspection fee shall be charged for this inspection, however, if it is determined necessary to replace, repair or correct any wrong or defective wiring or apparatus as a result of such inspection, a permit in like manner as the original permit shall be obtained. 
c.  Whenever the chief electrical inspector shall find any electrical installation, equipment or wiring not conforming to the rules and regulations, as set forth in this or any other governing electrical ordinances, said chief electrical inspector is hereby empowered to stop work on any installation being made by any person, firm or corporation to whom or for which a registration or permit has been issued or granted, or who or which does not otherwise comply with the terms of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 3, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.040 - Electrical contractors. 
1.  License Required. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to engage in the business of electrical contractor, as herein defined, without being licensed as an electrical contractor, in a manner hereinafter set forth; provided however, that if such person, firm or corporation is already licensed for the current year in another city or village within the State of Illinois, such electrical contractor shall not be required to be licensed or pay a license fee for such year in this village. However, the electrical inspector shall require a sufficient display of mechanical experience of a practical and elementary character so as to test the electrical contractor's knowledge and qualifications of electrical work to be done, in the interest of safeguarding life and property. 
2.  Application for License. Application for an electrical contractor's license shall be made in writing to the chief electrical inspector, ex-officio of the electrical commission, stating the name and place of business of the applicant and the name and representative of the applicant who will act as supervisor of the work to be done under the license. Such applicant shall be accompanied by satisfactory affidavit that the applicant or his/her or their representative has had at least four years practical experience as a journeyman installing and altering "electrical equipment" as set forth in Section 15.16.020(2) of this chapter. 
3.  Revocation of License. License issued by the electrical commission shall not be loaned, rented, assigned or transferred. Each and every license may, after hearing, be suspended or revoked by the electrical commission upon failure or refusal of the electrical contractor to comply with the rules and requirements of the commission, or the provision of this chapter. 
4.  Personal Work. A homeowner may install electrical wiring, only in a residence or accessory structure that he/she owns and occupies or will occupy as his/her home, subject to the following: 
a.  All electrical wiring installed pursuant to this section shall be installed only by the owner, without compensation or pay to any other person for such labor or installation. Such installation shall comply with the requirements of the code. The homeowner shall file plans, demonstrate to the satisfaction of the chief electrical inspector that he/she possesses sufficient knowledge of the code requirements and the ability to make such installation properly, apply for and secure a permit, pay the required permit fees and call for all inspections in the manner provided in this code. Homeowner permits shall be valid for a period of six months from the date of the last inspection. 
b.  No portion of the wiring installed under a permit issued pursuant to this section shall be energized until final approval is issued by the chief electrical inspector. 
5.  Liability of Village. The inspector and control of the installation of electrical equipment or the granting of license by the village shall not make the village liable on account of such control of or granting of such license, or lessen the liability of persons, firms or corporations owning or installing such electrical equipment. 
6.  Licensing. In order to obtain an electrical contractor's license, an electrical contractor shall submit to a written examination to be administered by the chief electrical inspector upon payment of a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), which such fee shall be paid prior to each examination. Upon successful completion of said written examination, the applicant shall pay a license fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) and shall receive an electrical contractor's license. Renewal of said license shall be required annually thereafter. License renewal request shall be made on forms to be furnished by the electrical inspector. A renewal fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall accompany all renewal applications. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 4, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.050 - Permits. 
1.  Permit Required. All persons, firms or corporations shall, before beginning any installation, alteration or change of electrical wiring or equipment in the village, obtain a permit for such work. Permits for electrical work shall be issued upon receipt of a proper application made out on a printed form provided by the building department. The application for each work shall contain the following: 
a.  The name of the owner of user of the electrical equipment to be installed, altered or changed; 
b.  The location of such work by the correct address, street and number; 
c.  A description of the work to be performed; 
d.  The name and address of the person, firm or corporation making the installation or doing the work. 
2.  Issuance of Permits. Permits for electrical work to be performed under this code shall be issued only to electrical contractors as herein defined. Permits shall be issued only after payment of the required fees. Permit fees shall be paid in advance to the village. Permits for electrical work shall be valid for a period of six months from the date of issuance and no refunds shall be made for any such permit. 
a.  Permit cards shall be posted in plain view. 
b.  Any contractor or owner doing work in the village without an electrical permit shall pay up to ten (10) times the amount of the standard permit fee as a penalty for doing such work without a permit. 
3.  Time Limitation of Permit. A permit for any proposed work shall be deemed to have been abandoned six months after the date of filing, unless such permit has been diligently prosecuted. The building official shall be permitted to grant an extension of an additional six months if there is reasonable cause. In no case a permit becomes null and void after eighteen (18) months. 
4.  Previous Approvals. Except for unsafe electrical systems or installations, this code shall not require changes in the electrical system of a building for which a lawful permit has been heretofore issued or otherwise lawfully authorized, and the installation of which shall have been actively prosecuted after the effective date of this chapter. 
5.  Work Exempt from Electrical Permit. An electrical permit shall not be required for the following work: 
a.  Portable motors or other portable appliances energized by means of a cord or cable having an attachment plug end to be connected to an approved receptacle when that cord or cable is permitted by the National Electrical Code. 
b.  Repair or replacement of fixed motors, transformers or fixed approved appliances or devices rated fifty (50) amperes or less with the same type and rating in the same location. 
c.  Temporary decorative lighting. 
d.  Repair or replacement or current-carrying parts of any switch, conductor or control device of up to one hundred (100) amperes capacity. 
e.  Reinstallation of attachment plug receptacles, but not outlets therefore. 
f.  Repair or replacement of any over current device of the required capacity in the same location. 
g.  Repair or replacement of electrodes or transformers of the same size and capacity for signs or gas tube systems. 
h.  Removal of electrical wiring. 
i.  Temporary wiring for experimental purposes in suitable experimental laboratories. 
j.  Replacing flush or snap switches, fuses, lamp sockets, receptacles or ballast. 
6.  Violations Prohibited. Exemption from the permit requirements of 5.5 above shall not be deemed to grant authorization for work to be done in violation of the provisions of The National Electrical Code or other laws or ordinances of the Village of Grayslake. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 5, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.060 - Permit and inspection fees. 
1.  Fees. Fees for electrical work shall be those fees as provided for in the current fee schedule as adopted by the Village of Grayslake in Chapter 3.08 of the Grayslake Village Code. 
2.  Work Without a Permit. For work that has been started without first obtaining a permit, the permit fees shall then be up to ten times the normal fee and the person, firm or corporation doing the work may be cited for violation of this chapter as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 6, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.070 - Remodeling or reconstruction. 
1.  Remodeling or Reconstruction. If forty (40) percent of any structure is being remodeled, reconstructed, added to, and said remodeling, reconstruction, or addition requires the issuance of a permit, said structure shall be brought up to the current code. Disputes regarding what percentage of the structure is being remodeled or reconstructed shall be resolved as any other appeal to the electrical commission. 
2.  Additions, Alterations or Repairs. Additions, alterations or repairs to any building, structure or premises may be made to any electrical system or equipment without requiring the existing electrical system with all the requirements of this code, provided the addition, alteration or repair conforms to that requirement for a new electrical system or equipment. Additions, alterations, installations or repairs shall not cause an existing system to become unsafe, create unhealthy or overload conditions, or shall not adversely affect the performance of the building as determined by the chief electrical inspector. Electrical wiring added to an existing service, feeder or branch circuit shall not result in an installation that violates the provisions of the code in effect at the time of the additions are made. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 7, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.080 - Unsafe electrical systems, apparatus, wiring or equipment. 
1.  Unsafe electrical systems, apparatus, wiring or equipment regulated by this code, which is unsafe or which constitutes a fire or health hazard or is otherwise dangerous to human life is for the purpose of this section, unsafe. Use of unsafe electrical systems, apparatus, wiring or equipment regulated by this code constituting a hazard to safety, health or public welfare by reason of inadequate maintenance, improper operating condition, improper location, dilapidation, obsolescence, fire hazard, disaster, damage or abandonment is for the purpose of this section, an unsafe use. Unsafe equipment is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be abated by repair, rehabilitation, demolition or removal. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 8, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.090 - Maintenance. 
1.  All electrical systems, equipment, materials and appurtenances, both existing and new, and all parts thereof shall be maintained in proper operating condition in accordance with the original design and in a safe and hazard-free condition. All devices and safeguards that are required by this code, shall be maintained in conformance with the code edition under which installed. The owner or the owner's designated agent shall be responsible for the maintenance of the electrical systems and equipment. To determine compliance with this section, the chief electrical inspector may cause an electrical system or equipment to be re-inspected. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 9, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.100. - Inspections. 
1.  Any installation, alteration or change of electrical equipment or wiring shall be inspected before any of the work is covered or hidden from view. The person, firm or corporation responsible for such work shall notify the building department, at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance, requesting the required inspection before any work is concealed. 
2.  Upon completion of any installation, alteration or change of electrical equipment or wiring, it shall be the duty of the person, firm or corporation performing such work to notify the building department, at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance, requesting an inspection of the work. The chief electrical inspector shall inspect the work within twenty-four (24) hours and, if the work meets all standards, will issue a certificate of inspection. No certificate of inspection shall be issued unless the electrical installation and equipment is in strict conformance with the provisions of this chapter. 
3.  The inspection and control of the installation of electrical equipment or wiring, and the granting of certificates by the village shall not make the village liable on account of such control or granting certificates, nor shall it lessen the liability of persons, firms or corporations installing, owning or operating such electrical equipment. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 10, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.110 - Stop work order. 
1.  Notice. Upon notice from the chief electrical inspector or building official that the work on any building or structure is being prosecuted contrary to the provisions of this chapter or in an unsafe and dangerous manner, or without a permit, such work shall be immediately stopped upon issuance of a stop work order. The stop work order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property involved, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work. It shall state the conditions under which the work will be permitted to resume. The work shall not resume until approval is granted and the stop work order is lifted by the chief electrical inspector of the building official. 
2.  Unlawful Continuance. Any person, firm or corporation who shall continue any electrical work in or about the structure after having been served a stop work order, except such work as that person, firm or corporation is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe conditions, shall be subject to immediate arrest and, if convicted, be subject to the penalty provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 11, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.120 - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, or who shall fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made hereunder within the time duly fixed for compliance shall for each and every violation and act of noncompliance respectively, shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00), and the permit or registration of the contractor may be suspended for not more than one year. Each day during which the violation or noncompliance continues shall constitute a separate offense. Furthermore, the chief electrical inspector or building official may issue a order to stop any further work upon the building or structure where such nonconformance or violation is occurring, order the closure of the building or structure where such noncompliance or violation is occurring, until said noncompliance or violation is mitigated to the satisfaction of the chief electrical inspector or building official. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 12, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.130 - Repeal. 
    All parts of this chapter in conflict herein, but only to the extent of such conflict, is hereby repeal. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 13, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.140 - Severance clause. 
    If any provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section or part of this chapter, or the application thereof to any person, firm or corporation or circumstance, shall for any reason, be adjudged by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid, said judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder of this chapter or the application of such provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, or part thereof directly involved in the controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered and/or to the person, firm, corporation or circumstance involved. It is hereby declared to be the legislative intent of the corporate authorities that this chapter would have been adopted had such invalid provision or provisions not been included or if it had not been made applicable to such person, firm, corporation or circumstance. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 14, 1-15-2013) 
15.16.150 - Conflicts; ordinance number; effective date. 
    Any rule, regulation, or ordinance in conflict with the provisions hereof is hereby repealed, but to the extent of such conflict only. This ordinance [Chapter 15.16] shall be designated Ordinance No. [2013-0-06] and shall be in full force and effect ten (10) days after its passage and approval in accordance with law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-06, § 15, 1-15-2013) 
Chapter 15.20 - PLUMBING CODE ADOPTED* 
Sections: 

15.20.010 - General provisions. 
    The Plumbing Code is intended to be remedial and to be construed liberally and justly to secure the proper installation of a permanent, efficient system for furnishing a potable water supply and sanitary disposal system for each and every habitable building. Its purpose is to obtain a serviceable plumbing system for the comfort, convenience, health, and safety of the occupants or users of the property. 
A.  Plumbing and Drainage Generally. 
1.  Plumbing and drainage of all buildings, public and private, shall be constructed in accordance with the provisions of this code. All repairs and alterations in the plumbing and drainage of existing buildings shall comply with the provisions of this code. 
B.  Remodeling. 
1.  Whenever plumbing is remodeled or replaced, or additional plumbing fixtures are installed, the remodeled plumbing system shall conform to the provisions of this code. 
C.  Moved Building. 
1.  If any building is moved from one location to another, the plumbing thereof shall conform to the provisions of this code. 
D.  Infrequently Used Fixtures. 
1.  If in the judgment of the plumbing inspector, a plumbing fixture is used so infrequently that there is a danger that the seal of the trap will evaporate, the inspector may order the fixture removed and the outlet securely closed. 
E.  Property Lines. 
1.  All appurtenances to the building drains and building sewers, including catch basins, manholes, cleanouts, backwater valves, and fittings shall be located within the property lines of the premises served by such drains and sewers. 
F.  Care of Plumbing Fixtures. 
1.  Plumbing fixtures shall be used for the purpose for which they are intended; and such fixtures shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
G.  Abating a Nuisance. 
1.  Whenever it shall come to the knowledge of the plumbing inspector that the plumbing or drainage in any building has become a nuisance, or is of faulty construction and liable to endanger the health of the occupants, the owner, agent or occupant shall be notified of the changes necessary to bring such plumbing or drainage system into compliance with the regulations of this code. The changes shall be made within the time fixed in such notification. Should the owner, agent or occupant fail to correct the defects called to his or hers attention within such time as the plumbing inspector shall deem to be adequate, the plumbing inspector shall institute proceedings in a court having jurisdiction over such matters, seeking to compel compliance with the regulations and to secure such fine or other punishment as the court may decree. 
H.  Water Supply. 
1.  Turning On. No water from the village water supply shall be turned on for service into a premise by any person but the superintendent of public works or some other person authorized by him or her, the plumbing inspector or the building commissioner to perform this service. 
2.  Plumbing. No water shall be turned on for service to a premise in which the plumbing does not comply with the code; provided that the water may be turned on for construction work in unfinished buildings, subjected to the provisions of this code. 
3.  Service Connection, Tap-in and Inspection Street Openings. The provisions of this code and of any other ordinance of the village of Grayslake, relative thereto shall be complied with in making excavations in streets or other public places, if any, for water connections. No connection with the village water main shall be made without a permit to connect being issued, and appropriate fees and charges required being paid. 
a.  Application for such connection shall be made on forms provided by the building department with the connection fees and deposits of all monies required by village ordinance. At least forty-eight (48) hours notice shall be given to the village for such connection. The connection fee shall be established by the corporate authorities and shall be paid by the applicant for each connection together with a tap-on fee and inspection fee as specified. All materials for each connection, including materials for backfilling shall be furnished by the applicant. All connections of the service pipe shall be made under the supervision of the plumbing inspector or his or her designee. Each excavation shall be promptly backfilled and the road surface satisfactory repaired as required by village ordinance, provided, however, that no water connection whatsoever shall be covered until the work shall have been duly inspected and approved for backfill by the plumbing inspector or his or her designee. 
b.  Tampering. It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation not authorized by the village to tamper with, alter, or injure any part of the village water supply system or break a seal, tamper or alter any water meter. 
I.  Service Pipes. 
1.  Installation. All service pipes from the water main to the premises served shall be installed by and at the cost of the owner or owner's agent to the property served. Such installation shall be under the plumbing inspector or his or her designee. 
2.  Pipes. No service shall be installed unless it conforms to the provisions and specifications of this code. 
3.  Repairs. All repairs on the service pipes, exclusive of the saddle or corporation cock connected to the village water main and starting with the water pipe connected to the saddle or the corporation cock, the plumbing systems of the building shall be made by and at the expense of the owner of the premises served. The village may, in case of emergency, repair or cause others to repair any service pipe, the cost of such repair to be paid or reimbursed to the village by the owner of the premises served. In the event the village notifies any owner of water discharging between the village water main and the water meter for the owner's premises, the owner shall cause such water discharges to be repaired in seventy-two (72) hours of such notification and failing same the village may repair or cause others to repair the water discharge, whereupon the owner of the premises shall, immediately upon demand, reimburse the village for all cost incurred for such repair. The village shall maintain and repair all mains, saddles, and corporation cocks on village water mains. 
4.  Whenever a building sewer or drain is obstructed, or found to be broken or defective so that sewage or drainage escapes into the surrounding soil or into adjacent premises, repair or replacement may be ordered by the plumbing inspector or code official. Such repairs shall be made at the expense of the property owner or person in control of the property. 
5.  Excavations. Excavations for installing service pipes or repairing shall be made in compliance with ordinance provisions relating to excavations in streets. 
J.  Water Meter. 
1.  Meters Required. All premises using village water supply shall be equipped with a water meter furnished by the village. 
2.  Before any premises is occupied, the water meter shall be installed and sealed by the water department. 
3.  Installation and Sealing. Water meters shall be installed within one foot of the front building wall in a location that will be easy to access and shall be sealed at the time of installation. Permission may be granted by written approval of the building commissioner to install the meter in a different location. It is unlawful for anyone to break the seal of any such water meter or alter such water meter except as authorized by the village. 
a.  Meter vaults shall be permitted only by written approval by the building commissioner or village engineer. 
4.  Construction. During construction of any building, the contractor constructing such building is permitted to use the village water supply with proper backflow protection. A fee established by the corporate authorities will be charged at the time of the issuance of the building permit. Water used for watering landscaping shall be metered. 
5.  Fire Hydrant Use. The use of a fire hydrant for construction water is prohibited. 
K.  Plumbing. 
1.  Permit Required. Before any plumbing installation commences, the plumbing contractor shall make a permit application on forms available at the building department. 
2.  Permits Required. Permits are required and shall be obtained for any of the following: all new installations; remodeling; fixture relocation; and alterations to any part of the plumbing system (included are, pumping systems; irrigation systems; all backflow preventers; and sewer and water services-new, repair or replacement). 
3.  Fees. The corporate authorities shall establish the fees for permits. 
4.  Connection. No connection to a village sanitary sewer main shall be made without a permit being issued and at least forty-eight (48) hour notice having been given to the plumbing inspector. All such connection shall be made and all such work done by the applicant, but no work covered until approved by the plumbing inspector or his or her designee has inspected and approved the work. 
a.  If the connection requires an excavation in the village right-of-way, including the roadway, any other ordinance of the village relative thereto shall be complied with. 
5.  Specifications. All plumbing fixtures installed must conform to the requirements of this code. 
a.  All pipes used in the plumbing shall conform to the requirements of this code. 
6.  Separate Drainage for Buildings. No building shall be connected to a drain passing through premises in ownership separate from that of such building. Every building shall be separate from that of such building. Every building shall be separately and independently connected with a public or private sewer, where there is such, in a street abutting on the lot occupied by such building, and no building shall be connected with the sanitary sewer system of the village of Grayslake by a drain passing through premises in an ownership different from that of the real estate to which the building is appurtenant and constitutes a part. In case any building at the time hereafter is connected with the sanitary sewer system of the village in violation of this section, the village shall be authorized to disconnect forthwith (see Section 890.170(a)). 
a.  The entire plumbing and drainage system of every building shall be entirely separate and independent of any other building, except where there are two buildings on one lot, one in the rear of the other. Then, if there is no sewer in the alley to which the rear building can be connected, the sewer in the front building may be extended to serve the rear building. 
L.  Sewer and Drains. 
1.  Permits. It is unlawful to make any connection with the village sanitary sewer system or storm sewer system without having first securing a permit. Applications for such work are available on forms provided by the building department. 
2.  Fees. The fees for any permit for each connection with the sanitary sewer or storm sewer shall be established by the village board of trustees. 
3.  Responsibility for Repairs and Maintenance. The owner of the property having a building connected to the public sewer system is responsible for all repairs and maintenance of that portion of the sewer system which runs from the to its connection with the sewer main, including the connection to the sewer main. 
4.  Street Openings. The provisions of this code and any other ordinances of the village relative thereto shall be complied with in making excavations in the street or other public places in connection with making sewer connections. All openings made in sidewalks, parkways and roadways shall be protected by barricades. 
5.  Connection. The actual connection with the sanitary sewer or storm sewer system shall be made under the supervision of an authorized village employee. No stormwater shall be introduced into the sanitary sewer system at any time. All materials for the connections and pipes from the drains from the house to the sewers shall conform to the requirements of this code. The applicant for such service shall pay the cost for such connection where no stub exists. 
6.  Garage Drainage. Floor drains in private residential garages shall be prohibited. 
7.  Prohibited Substances. It is unlawful to permit any gasoline, benzene, or other volatile liquids to flow into any public sanitary or storm sewer in the village, or to permit any material that might injure any part of the sanitary or storm sewer system in the village. 
8.  Stormwater Drains. It is unlawful to construct or permit the maintenance of any stormwater drain which discharges water onto any sidewalk, or to construct or permit the maintenance of any such drain to discharge into any public street or alley. 
M.  Penalty. 
1.  Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this section shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. 2005-0-23 § 2) 
15.20.020 - Storm drainage. 
    The provision of this section is to govern the materials, design, construction and installation of storm drainage. 
A.  General. 
1.  Where Required. All roofs, paved areas, yards, courts and courtyards shall drain into a separate storm sewer system or to an approved place of disposal. For single-family residences, where approved, stormwater is permitted to discharge onto flat areas, such as lawns, provided that the stormwater flows away from the building. 
2.  Prohibited Drainage. Stormwater shall not be allowed to drain into the sanitary sewer system. 
3.  Continuous Flow. The size of a drainage pipe shall not be reduced in the direction of flow unless required by the village engineer. 
4.  Fittings and Connections. All connections and changes in direction of storm drainage system shall be made with approved drainage type fittings in accordance with Table 15.20.020(A)(4) Fittings for Change in Direction. The fittings shall not obstruct or retard flow in the system. 
5.  Roof Design. Roofs shall be designed for the maximum possible depth of water that will pond thereon as determined by the relative levels of roof deck and overflow weirs, scuppers, edges or serviceable drains in combination with the deflected structural elements. In determining the maximum possible depth of water, all primary roof drainage means shall be assumed to be blocked. 
6.  Cleanouts Required. Cleanouts shall be installed in the storm drainage system and shall comply with Section 890.420. 
Table 15.20.020(A)(4) 
Fittings for Change in Direction

B.  Conventional Roof Downspouts. 
1.  No downspout shall be of a smaller size than shown in Table 15.20.020(B)(1) Size of Downspouts, based on the maximum horizontal projected roof area drained. Twenty-five (25) percent of side wall areas of any building that drains onto a roof shall be added to the horizontal storm drain and shall be full size to the storm drain or sewer. The sizes of downspouts are on the diameter of circular downspouts, and other shapes shall have equivalent cross section area. All downspouts from gravel roofs shall be fitted with gravel basins or equally serviceable devices to screen out loose gravel.

C.  Roof Drain Heads. 
1.  Roof drain heads shall have strainers extending not less than four inches (one hundred two (102) mm) above the surface of the roof immediately adjacent to the roof drain. Strainers shall have an available inlet area, above roof level, of not less than one and one-half times the area the conductor or leader to which the drain is connected. 
2.  Flat Decks. Roof drains strainers for use on sun decks, parking decks, and similar areas that are nominally serviced and maintained shall comply with subsection (C)(1) of this section or shall be of the flat surface type, installed level with the deck, with an available inlet area not less than two times the area of the conductor or leader to which the drain is connected. 
3.  Roof Drain Flashings. The connection between roofs and roof drains which pass through the roof and into the interior of the building shall be made watertight by the use of approved flashing materials. 
D.  Secondary (Emergency) Roof Drains. 
1.  Secondary Drainage Required. Secondary (emergency) roof drains or scuppers shall be provided where the roof perimeter construction extends above the roof in such a manner that water will be entrapped if the primary drains allow buildup for any reason. 
2.  Separate Systems Required. Secondary roof drain systems shall have the end point of discharge separate from the primary system. Discharge shall be above grade, in a location which would normally be observed by the building occupants or maintenance personnel. 
3.  Sizing of Secondary Drains. Secondary (emergency) roof drains systems shall be sized in accordance with Tables 15.20.020(B)(1), (B)(2) and (B)(3). Scuppers shall be sized to prevent the depth of ponding water from exceeding that for which the roof was designed as determined by subsection A of this section. Scuppers shall not have an opening dimension of less than four inches (one hundred two (102) mm). The flow through the primary system shall not be considered when sizing the secondary roof drain system. 
E.  Values for Continuous Flow. 
1.  Equivalent Roof Area. Where there is a continuous or semi-continuous discharge into the building storm drain or building storm sewer, such from a pump, ejector, air conditioning plant or similar device, each gallon per minute (L/m) of such discharge shall be computed as being equivalent to ninety-six (96) square feet (nine m 2 ) of roof area, based on a rainfall rate of one inch (25.40 mm) per hour. 
F.  Controlled Flow Roof Drain System. 
1.  General. The roof a structure shall be designed for the storage of water where the storm drainage system is engineered for controlled flow. The controlled flow roof drainage system shall be an engineered system in accordance with this section and design, submittal, approval, inspected and testing requirements by a design professional. The controlled flow system shall be designed based on a rainfall rate of four inches (101.60 mm) per hour. 
2.  Control Devices. The control devices shall be installed so that the rate of discharge of water shall not exceed the values for continuous flow as indicated in subsection E of this section. 
3.  Installation. Runoff control shall be by control devices. Control devices shall be protected by strainers. 
4.  Minimum Number of Drains. Not less than two roof drains shall be installed in roof areas ten thousand (10,000) square feet (nine hundred thirty (930) m 2 ) or less and not less than four roof drains shall be installed in roofs over ten thousand (10,000) square feet (nine hundred thirty (930) m 2 ) in area. 
G.  Inside Downspouts. 
1.  When placed within the walls of any building, all downspouts shall be constructed of cast iron, galvanized wrought iron, Type K, L or M "hard drawn" copper tubing, galvanized steel pipe or PVC pipe. A roof connection to a downspout shall be made gas-tight and water-tight by use of aluminum, cast iron, copper or PVC downspout head. 
H.  Prohibited Use. 
1.  No downspout or leader pipe shall discharge into any soil or waste stack of the sanitary sewer disposal system nor shall any downspout receive wastewater from any fixture. No downspout shall be used to vent a plumbing fixture. 
I.  Material. 
1.  Underground storm drains within buildings shall be of service weight cast iron soil pipe. Ductile iron extra heavy shall be used when passing through the foundation wall to undisturbed earth, and in do case less than five feet (one thousand five hundred twenty-four (1524) mm). 
2.  Building Storm Drains. Building storm drains from a point five feet (one thousand five hundred twenty-four (1524) mm) beyond the footings or bearing walls shall be in accordance with Table 15.20.020(I)(2) Building Storm Sewer Pipe. 
Table 15.20.020(I)(2)

(Ord. 2005-0-23 § 3) 
15.20.030 - Adoption of the state of Illinois Plumbing Code, February 2004 Edition. 
    The village of Grayslake adopts the state of Illinois Plumbing Code February 2004 Edition, including the regulations, conditions, definitions and stipulations concerning the construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of plumbing systems in the village of Grayslake, providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore. 
(Ord. 2005-0-23 § 4) 
15.20.040 - Modifications, supplements and exceptions. 
    Pursuant to 17 Ill. Adm. Code 3730.307 (c)(4) and subject to the Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 890) and the Lawn Irrigation Contractor and Lawn Sprinkler System Registration Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 892), be it hereby ordained that in the city/village/county, all new plumbing fixtures and irrigation controllers installed after the effective date of this chapter shall bear the WaterSense label (as designed by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency WaterSense Program), when such labeled fixtures are available. 
    That the following sections of the state of Illinois Plumbing Code, February 2004 edition, are revised as follows: 
Subpart A: Definitions and General Regulations. 
Section 890.110 General Regulations. 
Section 890.110(b) Applicability. At the end of this subsection add the following: 
(3)  Permits. Before any plumbing installation commences, the Plumbing Contractor shall make a permit application and proceed with the work after said permit has been issued. 
(4)  Permits are required and shall be obtained for any of the following: all new installations; repairs; remodeling; fixture relocation; and alterations to any part of the plumbing system (included are: pumping systems; irrigation systems, all backflow preventers; and sewer and water services-new or replacement). 
Section 890.120 Definitions. 
Change the definition for the following: 
Plumbing system. The plumbing system includes the water supply and distribution pipes, plumbing fixtures and traps; soil, waste and vent pipes; building drains, including their respective connections, devices and appurtenances within the property lines of the premises, water treating or water using devices. 
Section 890.140 Repairs and Alterations. 
Section 890.140(a)(2) Add the following new Subsection: 
d)  Reference Section 890.110(b)(4) regarding permit requirements. 
Section 890.150 Workmanship. 
Section 890.150(b) At the end of this subsection add the following new subsections: 
1)  Corrections may be required to uncover structural problems found as a result of wall and floor material removal during remodeling, and/or repair work. Corrections will be the responsibility of the owner or his/her agent. 
2)  Cutting, Drilling or Notching. No structural member shall be weakened or impaired by cutting, notching, or otherwise, except to the extent permitted by the Building Code. Joists, beams, studs, and other framing members shall be reinforced prior to the installation of any plumbing pipes. 
3)  Firestopping of annular spaces of pipe penetrations shall be as per the Building Code. The requirements apply to all types of buildings and structures; residential and nonresidential. 
Section 890.160 Used Plumbing Material, Equipment, Fixtures. 
Section 890.160(a) shall be amended to read as follows: 
Previously used plumbing material, equipment and/or fixtures may be reused for plumbing installations with this Part and the Plumbing Contractor has received written approval from the Plumbing Inspector. 
Section 890.170 Sewer and/or Water Required shall be amended to read as follows: 
(a)  Every building with an installed plumbing system intended for human habitation or occupancy on premise that falls adjacent to or abutting property with a public water system and public sanitary sewer system accessible through the right-of-way or easement, shall have a connection to that public water system and public sanitary sewer system. 
(b)  Every existing building and every existing building hereafter constructed shall be separately and independently connected to a public sanitary sewer system whenever there is any sewer in the street, alley or easement, and adjoining property on which the building is located. Where there are two (2) or more buildings on one (1) lot serving the same occupancy and under common ownership, a common building sanitary sewer may be extended from the public sanitary sewer to serve the building, provided that the capacity of such sewer line is sufficient for the combined flow and provided that the Building Department grants approval for such common line. 
(c)  No building drain, sanitary sewer, septic tank discharge, cesspool, industrial waste, or any fixture or device discharging polluting substances shall discharge to any storm sewer, storm water drain, or highway drainage ditch, or any other unacceptable point of termination. 
(d)  The connection to a public sanitary sewer system shall be made at the "Y" or stub provided for, being in place in the line along and within the property frontage. In the Absence of a "Y" or stub so located, such connection shall be made only by means of a machine trap, approved by the Village Engineer. Excavation and shoring shall be provided by the owner or his/her agent and shall comply with the requirements of the Village Ordinances. 
(e)  Every new and existing dwelling or place of employment shall be provided with a plumbing system, including water closet facilities. When any building shall be located on a street or on a site not more than 200 feet (60.96 m) from a public sanitary sewer system, connection shall be made thereto. 
(f)  When such a sewer connection is not available, a private sewage disposal system shall be provided, subject to the provisions of this Code, and subject to the Lake County Health Department regulations and approval. 
(g)  A sampling manhole shall be installed within ten (10) feet (3048 mm) from the building on the sanitary building sewer. 
Exception: Residential buildings (single family, attached single family and multifamily) 
(h)  The minimum diameter of a building sanitary sewer service shall be four (4) inches. 
Subpart C: Joints and Connections. 
Section 890.320 Types of Joints. 
Section 890.320(a) At the end of this subsection add the following sentence: 
Pipes with caulked joints shall not be allowed above grade in buildings subjected to vibrations. 
Section 890.320(c) Wiped joints shall be amended to read as follows: 
Joints in lead pipe or fittings, in water supply, or drainage systems are prohibited. Connection to existing lead water services, alterations to existing lead DWV, or commercial drainage system shall be by written permission by the Plumbing Inspector. 
Section 890.320(d) Soldered Joints at the end of this section add the following: 
Tubing shall be reamed to eliminated erosion, cavitations, friction loss, and noise to the system. Soft tubing shall be sized with appropriate sizing tool to facilitate consistent fit of tubing to fittings. Bronze fittings shall be of lead-free composition. 
Section 890.320(i) Cement Mortar Joints shall be amended to read as follows: 
Cement mortar joints are prohibited. 
Section 890.320(k) Bituminized Fiber pipe Joints shall be deleted. 
Section 890.320(l)(2) Joints and Fittings in Plastic Pipe shall be amended to read as follows: 
Plastic Pipe and Fittings Restrictions. CPVC or any polymer pipe or fittings shall not be used on potable water piping systems. This includes plastic fixture supply riser tubes. 
Section 890.320(l)(2)(a) at the end of this section add the following: 
For use on potable well water services into a building only. 
Section 890.320(l)(2)(b) at the end of this section add the following: 
1.  Expansion couplings, such as O-rings type, will be used as determined by the Plumbing Inspector and/or manufacturer's recommendations for multi-story buildings. 
2.  Defective materials and workmanship shall be connected and retested. 
3.  ABS plastic pipe and fittings are prohibited. 
Section 890.320(l)(2)(c) at the end of this section add the following: 
Use on water well services only (see Section 890.320(l)(2)(a)). 
Section 890.320(n) No-Hub Soil Pipe Joints at the end of this section add the following: 
Hangering, support, and restraint shall be per C.I.S.P.I. requirements. 
Section 890.330(a) Copper Tubing to Screwed Pipe Joints at the end of this section add the following: 
Dielectric unions shall be used at all dissimilar material connections (i.e., water heaters, copper to galvanized piping etc.). A brass valve will not be accepted as a dielectric break or converter. 
Section 890.330(c) Slip Joints shall be amended to read as follows: 
In drainage and water piping, slip joints may be used on the inlet side of the trap or in the trap seal. Slip joints shall not be used in any inaccessible piping. Push-on angle stop valves are prohibited. Compression, threaded or sweat shall be used. 
Section 890.330(e) Compression Type Couplings shall be amended to read as follows: 
(1)  Joints on any part of a water service shall be flared only. 
(2)  Compression fittings shall only be used on stops and equipment connections downstream of a stop. 
Section 890.330(g)(1) add the following subpart: 
E) For use on well water service piping only. 
Section 890.330(g)(2)(c) at the end of this subpart add the following sentence: 
Shall be used for underground installations only. 
Section 890.360 Water Closet and Pedestal Urinal at the end of this section add the following: 
The use of commercial putty or plastic is prohibited. Closet collars shall be used on all floor-mounted closets, bidets, etc. PVC or copper DWV collars shall be secured to the firm flooring with corrosion resistant screws or bolts. 
Section 890.370 Prohibited Joints and Connections in Drainage Systems add the following new subsections: 
(a)  Heel and side inlet ells are not acceptable in waste installations. Heel and side inlet ells are permitted in vent installations. 
(b)  Cottage fittings, tees, wyes, combinations, or small branch inlet shall be used in dry vent only. 
(c)  Copper waste and water extraction/extrusion tools that form branch openings in tubing shall not be used. Fittings shall be used for any branch opening. 
(d)  The use of saddles of any type is prohibited in the building interior DWV system. Drainage or vent lines shall have the necessary branch fitting placed into the line. 
(e)  The use of saddles of any type is prohibited in the building interior potable water supply. That includes self-tapping associated with humidifiers, ice makers, and other water supply appliances. A fitting and valve shall be installed for any water line branch. 
(f)  Tapping saddles for water main and service installation with approval of the Village Engineer. 
Subpart D: Traps and Cleanouts. 
Section 890.410(k)(5) shall be amended to read as follows: 
Full or partial running traps are prohibited. 
Section 890.420(a)(4) shall be amended by adding the following sentence to the end of this section: 
Buildings constructed on slabs or with crawl spaces shall have the cleanout located outside the building within five (5) feet of the foundation wall. 
Subpart E: Interceptors-Separators and Backwater Valves. 
Section 890.510(a)(2) at the end of this subsection add the following: 
A)  Approval: The size, type and location of each interceptor or separator shall be approved by the Plumbing Inspector and no waste other than those requiring treatment or separation shall be discharged into any interceptor. 
B)  Interceptors installed without approval may be ordered removed by the Plumbing Inspector. 
Section 890.510(a)(3) at the end of this subsection add the following: 
A)  Grease lines to Exterior Grease interceptor. Said lines shall convey only grease bearing waste and be separate from any sanitary discharge. 
Section 890.510(a)(5) at the end of this subsection add the following: 
A)  Maintenance of Exterior Grease Traps. The use of ladders or the removal of bulky equipment in order to service interceptors shall constitute a violation to accessibility. 
B)  Interior above or below floor interceptors/separators shall be installed with sufficient space above them for screen/baffle removal and access for interior cleaning without removal of piping/fixtures or other obstructions. 
C)  Cleaning. Interceptors shall be maintained in efficient operating condition by periodic removal of accumulated grease. 
D)  Any interceptor, separator, or grease trap found to have been modified in any manner by removal of baffles, screens, or partitions shall be restored to its original condition or completely replaced. 
Add the following new Section 850.551 Overhead Plumbing to read as follows: 
Section 890.551 Overhead Plumbing. All new buildings with basements, floors, rooms, or occupancy areas below grade level at the building site and served by a public sanitary sewer or private sewer system shall have overhead plumbing (refer to Section 890.1360). 
Subpart F: Plumbing Fixtures. 
Delete Section 890.710 (c). 
Subpart G: Hangers, Anchors and Supports. 
Section 890.920(e) Delete this section without substitution. 
Section 890.930(e) Delete this section without substitution. 
Add the following new subsection 890.930(g) 
f)  Strains and Stresses. 
1)  Buried Piping. Piping in the ground shall be laid on a firm bed for its entire length, except where support is otherwise provided, which is adequate in the judgment of the Plumbing Inspector. 
2)  Blocking under slope of bells is prohibited and shall be removed before backfilling. Glass, silica iron, and other special waste lines, as per manufacturer's instructions. 
3)  Copper water piping in metal stud partitions horizontally run shall use ridge split plastic isolators placed in stud hole made with proper size stud punch. 
4)  No copper tubing shall contact metal partitions. Pipe clamps may be secured to studs provided pipe is isolated with tape or isolating material. 
5)  Copper tubing with ends hammered flat may be used as a secondary support, (i.e., air chambers, etc.). It shall not be used as a primary support/hanger for waste, drain, vent, or water line main or branch lines. 
6)  Copper water piping passing through slabs shall be fully wrapped with closed cell pipe covering a minimum of 1/2? thick. 
7)  Attachment. Hanger and anchors shall be securely attached to the building's construction, all nuts fully tighten on mechanical supports, expansive anchors fully embedded in concrete or masonry, wire pipe driven fully home in wood structural members. The use of double nuts, lock washers, or other protection shall be used in areas of vibration or expansion stresses. Hanging from pipe to pipe, pipe to duct, or pipe to equipment is prohibited. 
Add the following new Section 890.935: 
Stack Plumbing Wall. The stack plumbing wall shall consist of not less than 2x6 framing members. 
Subpart I: Water Supply and Distribution. 
Amend Section 890.1130 (d)(2) shall be amended to read as follows: 
A reduced pressure principal backflow preventer assembly (RPZ) shall be installed at the fire safety systems point of connection to the potable water. Reduced pressure principal backflow preventer assembly (RPZ) four (4) inches or larger shall have a bypass meter. The bypass meter shall be protected by a reduced pressure principal backflow preventer (RPZ). 
Section 890.1130(d)(1) shall be amended by eliminating "B" and "C". 
Section 890.1130(d)(2) shall be amended to read as follows: 
A reduced pressure principle backflow preventer assembly (RPZ) shall be installed at the fire safety system's point of connection to the potable water supply. Reduced pressure principal backflow preventer assembly (RPZ) four (4) inches or larger shall have a bypass meter. The bypass meter shall be protected by a reduced pressure principal backflow preventer (RPZ). 
Section 890.1150(a)(3) shall be amended to read as follows: 
The service pipe shall be laid at least 5 feet 6 inches (1676 mm) below grade level. The maximum depth of the water services shall not exceed 8 feet (2438 mm) below grade. B-boxes shall be keyable with a standard length street key. 
Section 890.1150(a) add the following new subsections: 
(5)  The minimum water service size shall be 1 inch. All water services 2 inches and less shall be Type "K" copper water tubing extending from the water main to the water meter. 
(6)  Copper water tubing 1 inch in diameter shall be installed in one piece without couplings or joints from the b-box to the building. Copper water piping 1 1/2 inches and 2 inches in diameter shall have a minimum length of 20 feet (6096 mm) between couplings, couplings shall be soft tempered Type "K." 
(7)  Water Service Inspection. The water service on the house side of the b-box shall not be covered before it has been inspected and approved by the Plumbing Inspector or his/her designee. 
(8)  Water Meters. All water services being supplied from the water distribution system of the Village of Grayslake shall be provided with a water meter. All water meters shall be purchased from the Village of Grayslake and the type and size of such water meter shall be determined by the Water Department. All water meters for new construction shall be purchased at the time of the building permit. Each and every water consumer shall have an independent water service and water meter. 
(9)  The use of galvanized piping, fittings and nipples before the water meter is prohibited. 
(10)  All single family residential and attached single family shall have an approved double check valve backflow preventer the same size as the water meter installed on the house side of the water meter. In conjunction with the double check valve backflow preventer, a potable water thermal expansion tank shall be installed in accordance with Section 890.1130(g)(6). 
(11)  There shall be a full port shut-off at each side of a water meter. 
(12)  All meters shall be set plumb, level and secure to remain. They must be in an accessible location, free from obstructions, so they can be easy to read and service. They shall be protected from freezing or damage. Brass couplings, nipples, fittings, and unions shall be installed on the inlet side and outlet side of the water meter. The customer shall pay repair of damaged water meters. 
(13)  At no time shall a water meter be installed in a private bathroom or public restroom. 
(14)  Tapping and cutting on a Water Main. All applicants for permit to connect to the water service pipes with any supply pipe must be made to the Building Department. Said water service connection shall be of copper, Type "K" water tubing for 2 inch and less. Water services three (3) inches in diameter and larger shall be ductile iron Class 50. 
Add new subsection 890.1210(b)(1): 
It shall be the responsibility of the plumbing contractor, architect, or engineer to sufficiently size the water distribution system of a building, and they shall be shown on the plans. In no case shall the sizing be less than then the minimum required by Section 890. Appendix A. 
Subpart J: Drainage System. 
Amend Section 890.1320 (a) to read as follows: 
Drain-Filled Ground. A building drain installed in filled ground shall be cast iron or non-metallic Schedule 40 or heavier. Except for cast iron, such drains shall be installed on a continuous supporting system. 
1.  All underground building drains shall be cast iron soil pipe or non-metallic PVC Schedule 40 or heavier. Building drains passing through foundation walls shall be Class 52 ductile iron to a minimum five (5) feet (1524mm) outside the foundation wall or to a point of unexcavated soil, which ever is greater. 
(A)  When non-metallic PVC Schedule 40 or heavier is used for underground waste or vent piping, ground stakes shall be used to prevent floatation or moving. Ground stakes shall be equal to Sioux Chief, Tomahawk #535-9P. 
2.  When the building sewer is constructed of cast iron and the riser in the sewer service line between the main and the building sewer, the riser shall be constructed of SDR 26, Schedule 40 or heavier when the sanitary sewer main is constructed of PVC. 
3.  Liquid waste of temperatures exceeding 160° degrees Fahrenheit (71°C) shall not discharge into any drain or sewer. Waste of 160° degrees Fahrenheit (71°C) or more shall be intercepted and cooled to below 160° (71°C). Inside blow-off basins shall be of cast iron and shall be trapped and vented to the outside of the building by means of a vent pipe through the roof. 
Subpart K: Vents and Venting. 
Section 890.1420(d) Main Stack shall be amended to read as follows: 
Each building in which plumbing is installed shall have at least one main stack no smaller than three (3) inches in diameter for each building drain is installed. (See Appendix A: Table K and Appendix A: Illustration B) No more than two (2) water closets shall be installed on any three (3) inch stack. 
Section 890.1440(a) Vent Terminal Size shall be amended to read as follows: 
Each vent extension through the roof shall have a diameter at least one inch greater than that of the pipe proper; but in no case shall it be less than four (4) inches in diameter through and above the roof. Vent terminals shall not be screened. 
Section 890.1440(e) Heel or Side-Inlet Bend shall be amended to read as follows: 
On soil and waste lines, a heel or side inlet quarter bend shall not be used as a vent when the inlet is placed in the horizontal position. 
Add the following new subsection: 
890.1450(f) Basement Vent. Every new dwelling with a basement shall be provided with a two (2) inch vent pipe brought down through the basement ceiling accessible to the basement or lower level area. The vent shall be capped for future connection. 
Section 890.1580(a) shall be amended to read as follows: 
Size of Kitchen Sink and Water Closet Vents. A kitchen sink and water closet shall have at least a two (2) inch vent. 
Subpart M: Inspections, Tests, Maintenance and Administration. 
Section 890.1920 Testing of Plumbing System shall be amended to read as follows: 
Inspection. All plumbing work shall be inspected and approved by the Plumbing Inspector. It shall be the responsibility of the licensed plumber or plumbing contractor to notify the plumbing inspector twenty-four (24) hours before an inspection is necessary and the plumbing inspector shall make such inspection within forty-eight (48) hours after such notification. At each required inspection the Plumbing Inspector shall approve or disapprove the phase of the work being inspected. If the plumbing is disapproved, the disapproval must be accompanied by the Plumbing Inspector's reasons for disapproval in writing. The following inspections shall be required: 
1)  Before any underground work is backed-filled. 
2)  Rough-in. 
3)  Final Inspection-when all plumbing work is completed. 
4)  Any additional inspections deemed necessary by the Plumbing Inspector to insure compliance with this Code. 
a)  When plumbing work has been concealed prior to being tested and approved by the Plumbing Inspector, such plumbing work shall be exposed and tested. It is the responsibility of the licensed plumber or plumbing contractor to expose the plumbing for inspection purposes. 
b)  All equipment, material and labor required for the inspection and testing of the plumbing system or any part thereof is the responsibility of the licensed plumber or plumbing contractor. 
Section 890.1930 Testing Methods shall be amended as follows: 
a)  The licensed plumber or plumbing contractor in the presence of the Plumbing Inspector shall test the entire plumbing system within the building. All pipes shall remain uncovered until successfully pass the required tests and approved by the Plumbing Inspector. 
b)  Testing: 
1.  Waste and Vent-Normal Conditions: Water. 
2.  Water-Normal Conditions: Water. 
3.  Waste and Vent-Winter Conditions: Water. 
4.  Water-Winter Conditions: Water or Air. 
c)  Special Requirements: 
1.  Underground W & V: minimum five (5) foot static head for water test and full visual inspection. 
2.  Above ground W & V: static head water test, fill to roof or a minimum ten (10) feet above the top vent bar and full visual inspection. 
3.  Water: full visual inspection of entire system. 
4.  Backflow Prevention Valves (RPZ, DCV or DDCV): the device shall be tested upon installation and test report shall be filed with the Building Department and posted on the device. 
5.  Plumbing Final: prior to occupancy the complete plumbing system and its fixtures, water heaters, appliances, etc., shall be subject to full operational performance function examination inspection. 
Exception: 
When testing of the waste, stack and vent system of a building with water becomes a risk of creating damage to occupied building contents; an air test may be substituted. A visual inspection may be required by the Plumbing Inspector prior to granting permission to authorize an air test. (The test shall be performed as required by Section 890.1930(d)) 
d)  Air Test. An air test shall be made by attaching an air compressor testing apparatus to any suitable opening and after closing all the inlets and outlets to the system, forcing air into the system until there is uniform gauge pressure of five (5) pounds per square inch (p.s.i.) or sufficient to balance a column of mercury ten (10) inches in height. This pressure shall be held without introduction of additional air for a period of fifteen (15) minutes. 
e)  Water Supply System: Upon completion of a Section, or the entire water supply system, the system shall be tested and proved tight under a water pressure at least one and one-half (1 1/2) times the system pressure, but at least 100 p.s.i., by air or water. When exceeding 100 p.s.i., the test shall be of the hydrostatic type only. Testing pressure shall be maintained for fifteen (15) minutes. The water used for this test shall be from a potable water supply. 
f)  Final Plumbing Inspection: After the plumbing fixtures have been set and their traps filled with water, their connections shall be tested and proved gas and watertight. The Plumbing Inspector may require a test for gas and water tightness of the completed drainage and vent system be made by filling the traps with water and then introducing the system with a pungent, thick smoke produced by one or more smoke machines. When the smoke appears at stack openings on the roof, the stack opening shall be closed and a pressure equivalent to a one (1) inch water column shall be maintained for a period of the inspection. The Plumbing Inspector may also elect to perform a peppermint test as a substitute. A peppermint test is performed by introducing two (2) ounces of oil of peppermint into the roof terminal of every line or stack to be tested. Immediately after the oil of peppermint is introduced into the system, ten (10) quarts of hot water a minimum of 160ºF (71ºC) shall be added, then the terminal sealed. The detection of the odor of peppermint at any trap or at any point in the plumbing system denotes a leak. Individuals whose body or clothing has come in contact with oil of peppermint shall be excluded from the area until the test has been completed. 
Section 890. Appendix A Plumbing Materials, Equipment, Use Restrictions and Applicable Standards.

15.20.050 - Right of entry. 
    The plumbing inspector or his or her designee shall have the authority to enter, at any reasonable time, any structure or premises for which a permit has been issued but that has not received a certificate of occupancy. For all other structures or premises, when the plumbing inspector has reasonable cause to believe that a code violation exists, the plumbing inspector is authorized to enter the structure or premises at reasonable times to inspect, subject to constitutional restrictions on unreasonable searches and seizures. If entry is refused or not obtained, the plumbing inspector is authorized to pursue recourse as provided by law. 
(Ord. 2005-0-23 § 6) 
15.20.060 - Penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this code or fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who installs, alters, repairs or maintains any plumbing in violation of this code shall be liable to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or no more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2005-0-23 § 7) 
Chapter 15.24 - INTERNATIONAL PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE ADOPTED[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-0-03, §§ 1-5, adopted Jan. 15, 2013, repealed the former Ch. 15.24, §§ 15.24.010-15.24.020, and enacted a new Ch. 15.24 as set out herein. The former Ch. 15.24 pertained to the property maintenance code adopted and derived from Ord. 2005-0-24 §§ 2, 3; Ord. No. 2010-0-23, § 2, adopted 8-3-2010. 

15.24.010 - International Property Maintenance Code, 2009 Edition, adopted. 
    That a certain document, three copies of which are on filed in the office of the Clerk of Grayslake, being marked and designated as the International Property Maintenance Code, 2009 edition, as published by the International Code Council, be is hereby adopted as the property maintenance code of the Village of Grayslake, in the State of Illinois for regulating and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures; by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fir for human occupation and use; and the demolition of such existing structures as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said property maintenance code on file in the office of the Village of Grayslake are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any prescribed in Section 15.24.020 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-03, § 1, 1-15-2013) 
15.24.020 - Amendments and modifications. 
    The following sections of the International Property Maintenance Code are hereby revised as follows: 
1.  In all chapters and sections where "name of jurisdiction" and/or "chief appointing authority of the jurisdiction" is written insert "Village of Grayslake"; 
2.  In all chapters and sections where "International Zoning Code" is written insert "The Grayslake Zoning Ordinance, Title 17"; 
3.  In all chapters and sections where "International Plumbing Code" is written insert the "State of Illinois Plumbing Code as adopted and amended by the Village of Grayslake", Chapter 15.20 of the Grayslake Municipal Code. 
Chapter 1 ADMINISTRATION 
Section 101 General 
Section 102 Applicability 
102.3 Application of other codes shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    Section 102.3 Application of other codes. Repairs, additions or alterations to a structure, or changes of occupancy, shall be done in accordance with the procedures and provisions or the International Building Code, Chapter 15.04; International Residential Code, Chapter 15.52; International Mechanical Code, Chapter 15.30; National Electrical Code, Chapter 15.16; the State of Illinois Plumbing Code, Chapter 15.20 and the Grayslake Zoning Ordinance, Title 17. 
Section 103.1 General shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    Section 103.1 General. The Building Department shall administer the property maintenance code and the Building Commissioner shall be known as the code official. 
Section 104 Duties And Powers of The Code Official 
104.4 Right of entry shall be amended to read as follows: 
    104.4 Right of entry. The Code Official or his/her designee shall have the authority to enter at any reasonable time, any structure or premises, where the Code Official has reasonable cause to believe a code violation exists, to inspect, subject to constitutional restrictions on unreasonable searches and seizures. If entry is refused the Code Official is authorized to pursue recourse as provided by law. 
Section 106 Violations 
106.4 Violation penalties shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    106.4 Violation penalties. Any person, firm, or corporation who shall violate any provision of this code shall upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00), nor more than seven-hundred and fifty ($750.00), and the costs of prosecution. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation who abates said violation(s) by moving said violation(s) to another property within the Village owned or controlled by said individual, firm or corporation upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00), nor more than seven-hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00), and costs of prosecution. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offence. 
Add the following new subsection: 
    Section 106.6 Repairs. Repairs associated with a violation, which normally requires permits shall not be considered abated if permits are not obtained. 
Section 107 Notices and Orders 
    107.2 (5) shall be deleted. 
Section 108 Unsafe Structures and Equipment 
108.2 Closing of vacant structures add the following new subsection as follows: 
    108.2.2 Boarded-up structures. Boarding up a structure is considered a temporary measure until a decision can be made as to what remedy the owner wants to pursue as provided in this section; but cannot exceed six (6) months unless an extension of an additional six (6) months is granted in writing by the code official. Any structure boarded up in excess of six (6) months (or in excess of twelve (12) months, if the code official has granted written approval for an extension), shall be considered abandoned, and a public nuisance, and the Village may pursue whatever action is afforded to it under this code, other appropriate ordinances and State statutes, to cause the abatement of said public nuisance. 
Section 111 Means of Appeal shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    111.0 All appeals shall be taken to the Plan Commission/Zoning Board of Appeals, and shall comply with all procedures and provisions of 17.40.010 (B) of the Village Code. 
Chapter 2 DEFINITIONS 
Section 202 General Definitions. 
Inoperable motor vehicle shall be amended to read as follows: 
    Inoperable Motor Vehicle; shall mean a vehicle which for a period of at least seven (7) consecutive days, the engine, wheels, or other parts have been altered, damaged, or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor power or that is missing wheels, tires, flat tires or broken or missing window glass. Inoperable motor vehicles shall include, but not limited to automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, snowmobiles or other similar recreational vehicles. 
Rubbish shall be amended to read as follows: 
    Includes items such as cans, bottles, wood, metal, plastic, rags, boxes, paper, tires, auto parts; dismantled machinery or appliances or parts of such machinery or appliances or other household items, lumber, scrap iron, tin and other metals not neatly piled, building material or anything whatsoever that is or may become a hazard to public health and safety, or that may harbor insects, rodents or vermin infestation. 
Add the following new definition: 
    Construction Debris. Shall mean any scrap of lumber, metal, earth, sand, brick, stone, plaster, roofing or siding material or other debris of similar nature which accumulates and is incidental to the construction, demolition or renovation of buildings, public works or other similar projects. 
Chapter 3 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS 
Section 302 Exterior Property Areas 
Add the following new subsections to read as follows: 
    301.1.1 Household Appliances. Refrigerators, regardless of type of locks, stoves, ranges microwave ovens or similar household appliances shall be prohibited from being stored outside. 
    301.1.2 Household Furniture. Desks, chairs, tables, sofas, beds or similar household furniture shall be prohibited from being stored outside. 
    Exception: Patio Furniture or other furniture design for outside use. 
    301.1.3 Construction materials. The storage outside of construction materials such as wood, concrete blocks, bricks, siding, plywood, plastic sheathing, light standards, fencing or similar construction materials shall be prohibited from being stored outside unless there is a valid construction permit and construction is progressing. 
    301.1.4 Equipment. Air conditioning units, generators, heating units, furnaces, or similar type of equipment shall not be stored outside unless properly connected to the structure. 
    301.1.5 Drums or buckets. Drums or buckets or similar type containers, weather plastic or metal shall be prohibited from being stored outside. 
    301.1.6 Vehicle parts or accessories. No vehicle parts or accessories, weather cover or uncovered shall be allowed be stored in any residential district. 
Add the following new subsection to read as follows: 
    302.2.1 Sump pumps and gutters. All sump pump discharge from all buildings shall be connected to a storm sewer, provided an existing storm sewer is adjacent to or within the boundaries of the property where the building is located. If no storm sewer exists, the sump pump and/or roof gutter shall discharge not less than five (5) feet beyond the building foundation but not more than ten (10) feet from the building foundation. Discharge shall not terminate within ten (10) feet from the property line. In no case shall the discharge cause a nuisance to adjoining properties.
