The place of discharge shall be determined at the point where the water is discharged upon the ground from hoses, pipes and other connections to the sump pump. 
Section 302.3 Sidewalks and driveways shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    302.3 Sidewalks and driveways. All sidewalks, walkways, steps, driveways and parking lots located on private property shall be maintained in a state of good repair. Parking lots or similar parking areas in nonresidential areas shall be fully improved and provided with an all weather surfacing such as asphalt or concrete. The owner and tenant of private property adjacent to all public sidewalks, walkways, and steps shall keep such sidewalks, walkways and steps free of mud, debris or other obstructions that would impair or prevent their use. 
    302.4 Weeds, insert: eight (8) inches (203 mm) 
Add the following new subsection to read as follows: 
    302.4.1 Trees, shrubs and plants. The owner shall remove trees, shrubs and plants that are dead or which, in the opinion of the Code Official to be hazardous to persons or property. 
    302.7 Accessory structures shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    302.7 Accessory structures. All accessory structures including detached garages, carports, awnings, patio covers, sheds, signs and sign structures, storage buildings, benches and similar accessory structures shall be maintained structurally sound and free from deterioration. Accessory structures shall also be free from chipped and peeling paint and metal structures shall be free from rust. 
Add the following new subsection to read as follows: 
    302.7.1 Fences and walls. All fences and walls shall be maintained in good repair, be structurally sound and plumb. Fence surfaces shall be free of rust, corrosion, deterioration, decay, missing parts, and peeling, flaking and chipped paint. Wood surfaces other than decay-resistant wood must be protected from the elements and decay by painting or other protective covering or treatment. 
302.8 Motor vehicles shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    302.8 Motor vehicles: 
A.  In residential districts: 
1.  Any type of motor vehicle that does not display a current registration or does not display a current state license plate with valid registration sticker affixed shall not be parked on any property for a period of more than seven (7) days, unless parked within an enclosed permanent building or structure. 
2.  Any type of motor vehicle on which the engine, wheels, or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven shall not be parked, kept or stored outside of an enclosed building or structure, and no vehicle shall at any time be in a state of major disassembly, repair or in the process of being stripped or dismantled, outside an enclosed building or structure. 
3.  No motor vehicle, currently registered or unregistered shall be parked or stored in any yard excepted on an approved driveway or parking surface or within a permanent building or structure. 
4.  Any type motor vehicle, currently registered or unregistered shall be parked or stored in any yard being a container for metal, glass, paper, rags or other cloth, wood, auto parts, machinery, waste or discarded materials in such quantity, quality and arrangement that a driver cannot properly be seated by any other method, unless kept within an enclosed permanent building or structure. 
B.  In nonresidential districts: 
1.  Any type of motor vehicle that does not display a current registration or state license plate with valid registration sticker affixed shall not be parked on any property for a period of more than seven (7) days unless parked in an enclosed permanent building or structure. 
    Exception: Unless the motor vehicle is for sale on the property of a licensed new and/or used automobile dealer's establishment. 
2.  Any type of motor vehicle, currently registered or unregistered, shall be parked on any property in any state of inoperability, disassembly or disrepair, nor shall any such vehicle be in the process of being stripped or dismantled, for a period greater than seven (7) days provided that such work is performed inside a structure or similar enclosed area designed and approved for such purpose, or unless the motor vehicle is waiting for repair or removal on the property of an active licensed automotive repair establishment; and no such vehicle shall remain in open air storage for a period greater than thirty (30) days. 
3.  Painting of motor vehicles is prohibited unless conducted inside an approved spray room, spray booth, or limited spaying spaces in accordance with all the applicable requirements established in Chapter 15- Flammable Finishes, of the 2009 International Fire Code. 
4.  No motor vehicle currently registered or unregistered shall be parked on any property displaying a "For Sale" signs unless the property is of a licensed new and/or used automobile dealer's establishment. 
Section 303 Swimming Pools, Spas and Hot Tubs 
Section 303.2 Enclosures shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    Private swimming pools, hot tubs and spas, containing more than twenty-four (24) inches (610 mm) of water in depth shall be completely surrounded by a minimum forty-eight (48) inch (1219 mm) high fence, measured on the side of the barrier away from the pool. Gates and doors in the fence shall be self-closing and self-latching. Where the self- latching device is less than fifty-four (54) inches (1372 mm) above the bottom of the fence, the release mechanism shall be located on the pool side of the fence. Self-closing and self-latching gates shall be maintained such that the gate will positively close and latch when released from the opening position of six (6) inches (152 mm) from the gatepost. Existing pool enclosures shall not be removed, replaced or changed in such a manner as to reduce the effectiveness as a safety device. Fences surrounding a pool, hot tub or spa shall be maintained in accordance with Section 302.7.1. 
    Exception: A spa or hot tub with a listed safety cover that complies with ASTM F 1346 as listed in Chapter 8 of this code. 
Section 304 Exterior Structure 
304.2 Protective treatment shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    All exterior surfaces, including but not limited to, doors, door and window frames, cornices, porches, trim, balconies, decks and fences shall be maintained in good condition. Exterior wood surfaces, other than decay-resistant woods, shall be protected from the elements and decay by painting or other protective covering treatment. Peeling, flaking and chipped paint shall be eliminated and the surfaces repainted. Whenever feasible, colors and materials used in maintaining exterior surfaces shall match, or be visually similar to, the original color or material being maintained unless an overall replacement or change or color or material being is taking place. Approved elevations as part of a Special Use Permit or as a condition of the issuance of a building permit shall maintained the exterior colors and materials in good condition visual similar to the approved color renderings. All siding and masonry joints as well as those between the building envelope and the perimeter of windows, doors, and skylights shall be maintained weather resistant and weather tight. All metal surfaces subject to rust or corrosion shall be coated to inhibit such rust and corrosion and all surfaces with rust or corrosion shall be stabilized and coated to inhibit future rust and corrosion. Oxidation stains shall be removed from exterior surfaces. Surfaces designed for stabilization by oxidation are exempt from this requirement. 
Add the following new subsection: 
    304.10.1 Exterior fire escapes. All exterior fire escapes and stairways shall be kept free of mud, debris, snow, ice or other obstructions. Any fire or exterior stairway found to be in a state of deterioration or determined to be unsafe by the Code Official shall be repaired immediately. 
    Section 304.14 Insect screens insert May 1 to October 31. 
Add the following new subsection: 
    304.18.1 Doors providing access. Doors providing access to a dwelling unit, unit or housekeeping unit that is rented, leased or let shall be equipped with a deadbolt lock designed to be readily openable from the side from which egress is to be made without the need for keys, special knowledge or effort. Such locks shall be installed according to manufacturer's specifications and maintained in good working order. 
Section 305 Interior Structure 
    305.3 Interior surfaces shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 305.3 Interior wall, ceiling and floor surfaces. All interior wall, ceiling and floor surfaces, including but not limited to windows and doors, shall be maintained in good repair. All surfaces shall be free from serious cracking, irregularities and peeling, flaking, chipped paint. A weatherproof and hard surface shall be provided in spaces subject to moisture. Floor surfacing shall be provide ease of maintenance and durability appropriate for use of room 
Add the following new subsection: 
    305.3.1 Toilet room compartment and bathroom flooring. Every toilet room floor surface and bathroom floor surfaces shall be properly constructed and maintained so as to be reasonably impervious to water and so as to permit such floor to easily be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
    305.4 Stairs and walking surfaces delete in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    305.4 Stairs and walking surfaces. All interior stairs and railings, ramps, balconies, porches, decks and other walking surfaces shall be maintained in a structurally sound condition, in good repair, with proper anchorage and capable of supporting the imposed loads. 
Section 308 Rubbish and Garbage 
308.3.1 Garbage facilities shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    308.3.1 Garbage facilities. The owner of a multifamily building; or the owner of a nonresidential building of more than two tenants; or the combination of residential and nonresidential building shall supply an approved leakproof outside garbage container with a close fitting cover of sufficient size to collect the garbage till the next pick-up date. If in the opinion of the Code Official the size of the garbage containment is not sufficient to handle the normal garbage between pick up dates the Code Official can require the owner to provide a larger size garbage containment or additional pick up dates. 
Section 308.3.2 Containers; add the following sentence to the end of this subsection: 
    The Code Official or his/her designee may order that a garbage container be replaced when evidence of leaking is found. 
Add the following new subsection: 
    Section 308.4 Container storage areas. Containers (garbage and/or recycling receptacles) and container storage areas shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. The container areas shall have a hard surface base of concrete, asphalt or other approved materials. Nonresidential, multi-family or mix use buildings shall have container areas enclosed by fencing or masonry walls of sufficient height to conceal the containers and storage areas. 
Chapter 4 LIGHT, VENTILATION AND OCCUPANCY LIMITS 
Section 404 Occupancy Limitations 
    404.4.1 Room area add the following sentence to the end of this section: 
    Every bedroom occupied by more than one person shall contain at least 50 square feet of floor area for each occupant. 
Section 404.5 Overcrowding shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    Section 404.5 Overcrowding. Every dwelling unit shall contain a minimum of two hundred (200) square feet of habitable floor area for the first occupant and not less than one hundred fifty (150) square feet of habitable floor area for each and every additional occupant thereafter. 
404.7 Food preparation add the following sentence to the end of this section: 
    Bedrooms shall not be used for food preparation or storage. 
Chapter 6 MECHANICAL AND ELECTRICAL REQUIREMENTS 
Section 602 Heating Facilities 
    Section 602.3 Heating supply insert October 1 st to April 30 th 
    Section 602.4 Occupiable work space insert October 1 st to April 30 th 
Section 605 Electrical Equipment 
Add the following new subsections: 
    605.1.1 Unused wiring. Exposed unused wiring, electrical equipment and devices shall be removed. 
    605.1.2 Extension cords: Extension cords or flexible cords shall not be a substitute for permanent wiring. Extension cords or flexible cords shall not be affixed to structures, extended through walls, ceilings, floors, under doors or floor coverings; nor shall the cords be subject to environmental damage or physical impact. Extension cords shall be used only with portable appliances. 
    605.2 Receptacles shall be deleted in its entirety and replace with the following: 
    605.2 Receptacles. Every habitable space in a dwelling shall contain at least two separate and remote receptacle outlets. Every laundry area shall contain at least one grounded type receptacle or a receptacle with a ground fault circuit interrupter. Contain at least one ground fault circuit interrupter receptacle. 
Add the following new subsection: 
    605.2.1 Kitchen. Every kitchen counter space twelve (12) inches and wider shall have at least one wall receptacle. All receptacles serving the counter top surfaces shall be protected by ground fault circuit interrupter receptacles. 
    605.3 Luminaires shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced with the following: 
    605.3 Luminaries. Every public hall, interior stairway, toilet room, kitchen, public bathroom, private bathroom, laundry room, boiler room, furnace room, service equipment areas, motor control areas and at electrical panels shall contain at least one electric lighting fixture 
Add the following new subsections: 
    605.3.1 Exits. Every exterior door of a dwelling unit shall be illuminated. The required light shall be switched, the switch shall be located conveniently adjacent to the door. 
    605.4 Working space and clearance. Working space clearance of not less than thirty (30) inches (762 mm) shall be provided around the electrical panel and electrical equipment. 
Section 606 Elevators, Escalators and Dumbwaiters 
Add the following new section: 
    Section 606.3 Accident reports and recorded. The owner of every building shall immediately notify the Code Official of every accent involving personal injury or damage to the apparatus on, or about or in connection with the equipment covered by this Article, and shall afford the Code Official every facility for inspecting the equipment. When the accident involves the failure, breakage, damage or destruction of any part of the apparatus or mechanism, it shall be unlawful to use such device until after an examination by the Code Official is made and approval of the equipment for continued use is granted. Record shall be open for public inspection at all reasonable hours. 
Chapter 7 FIRE SAFETY REQUIREMENTS 
Section 704 Fire Protection Systems 
Add the following new section: 
    704.5 Carbon monoxide alarms. Every dwelling unit shall be equipped with at least one approved carbon monoxide alarm in operating condition on the ceiling or wall outside each sleeping area within fifteen (15) feet of every room used for sleeping purposes. 
    Exception: As allowed by the State of Illinois Carbon Monoxide Act. 
Chapter 8 REFERENCED STANDARDS 
Add the following: 
Illinois Public Act 09-0741 IPMC 704.5  
(Ord. No. 2013-0-03, § 1, 1-15-2013) 
15.24.030 - Repeal. 
    All parts of this chapter in conflict herewith, but only to the extent of such conflict, are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-03, § 3, 1-15-2013) 
15.24.040 - Severance clause. 
    If any provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, subsection, or part of this chapter, or the application thereof to any person, firm, corporation, or circumstance, shall, for any reason, be adjudge by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid, said judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder of this chapter or the application of such provision to other persons, firms, corporations, or circumstances, but shall be confined in its operation to the provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, subsection, or part thereof directly involved in the controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered and/or to the person, firm, corporations, or circumstance involved. It is hereby declared to be the legislative intent of the corporate authorities that this chapter would have been adopted had such invalid provision or provisions not been included or if it had not been made applicable to such person, firm, corporation or circumstance. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-03, § 4, 1-15-2013) 
15.24.050 - Conflicts; ordinance number; effective date. 
    Any rule, regulation, or ordinance in conflict with the provisions hereof is hereby repealed, to the extent of such conflict only. This ordinance [Chapter 15.24] shall be designated Ordinance No. 2013-0-03 and shall be in full force and effect ten (10) days after passage and approval in accordance with law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-03, § 5, 1-15-2013) 
Chapter 15.28 - SIGN CODE 
Sections: 

15.28.010 - Sign regulations-Continued effect. 
    The sign regulations of the village set forth in the ordinance codified in this chapter, passed and approved on April 7, 1992 and all amendments and supplements thereto are continued in full force and effect. 
(Prior code § 29.01) 
15.28.020 - Scope and purpose. 
    The purpose of the sign regulations of this chapter are to protect the public welfare and safety of the community, and also to maintain and upgrade the character of the immediate respective areas in which signs are located, as measured for stabilizing and improving taxable values. To this end: (1) the size and number of signs shall be reduced as much as is practicably possible; and (2) the shape and character of signs shall be such as to protect and enhance the village's attractiveness to tourists and visitors, as well as to the local inhabitants, thereby improving the economic welfare of the community, and in this connection no proposed sign shall conflict with the reasonable visibility of other signs, nor be so grotesque, unsightly or otherwise unsuitable as to be detrimental to property values in the area or be inconsistent with any architectural theme or other general standards prevailing in the vicinity. 
(Prior code § 29.100) 
15.28.030 - Definitions. 
    When used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    "Alternate premises advertising signs" means a sign which directs attention to a business, commodity, service, activity, idea, slogan, or entertainment conducted, sold, offered, or available elsewhere than upon the premises where such sign is located or to which it is affixed. 
    "Attention attracting devices" means pennants or other similar devices that flutter, rotate, flash or move, including, but not limited to, balloons or other gas-filled figures, propellers, spinners, streamers, reflectors and strings of unshielded electric lamp bulbs of more than 7.5 watts, serving for purposes of attracting attention, promotion or advertising. 
    "Awning" means a roofed structure constructed of fabric placed so as to extend outward from the building providing a protective shield for doors, windows and other openings with supports extending back to the building, supported entirely by the building. 
    "Awning sign" means any sign painted, printed, attached or otherwise applied to any facet of an awning. 
    "Banner signs" means a temporary sign constructed of cloth, canvas or other light weight fabrics with or without a frame, intended to be displayed on a temporary basis. 
    "Canopy sign" means a sign painted on or attached to any type of overhead covering such as an awning. 
    "Changeable copy sign, manual" means a sign on which copy is changed manually. 
    "Construction sign" means a sign indicating the name of the contractors, engineers, architects, financing institutions, or products being used in a particular construction project. 
    "Development sign, temporary" means a sign erected for the purpose of selling any lot or group of lots or for the sale or rental of buildings or spaces within buildings. 
    "Directional sign" means a sign used for orientation by providing guidance to public and quasi-public buildings such as schools, churches, and hospitals, or pertaining to community events of civic, educational, or religious organizations. 
    "Flat wall sign" means a sign which is attached to the facade of a building and where no part of the sign extends more than twelve (12) inches out from the facade as measured from the face of the building wall to which it is attached. 
    "Freestanding pole sign" means a permanent sign erected in the ground supported by one or more uprights, or other structural members, which are placed in or on an approved foundation and not attached to any building. 
    "Ground sign" means a freestanding sign having a supporting structure with a size greater than or equal to twenty-five (25) percent of the total width of the sign at its widest part. 
    "Group development sign" means a freestanding sign relating to a grouping of uses rather than individual uses. 
    "Holiday decorations" means signs and decorations clearly incidental to, and customarily and commonly associated with national, local and religious holidays, and installed for a limited period of time. 
    "Home occupation sign" means a sign associated with a home occupation as defined in the Title 17 of this code. 
    "Identification sign" means a sign depicting the name and/or address of a building, establishment or individual occupying the premises where the sign is located as a means of identifying the building, establishment or individual. 
    "Indirectly illuminated sign" means a sign whose source of illumination is so arranged that light is reflected from the sign. 
    "Internally illuminated sign" means a sign whose source of illumination is a fundamental part of the sign. 
    "Light emitting diode (LED) sign" means a sign utilizing technology of diode arranged in pixels to create messages changeable by electronic means. Such signs shall include other similar signs such as liquid crystal display signs, fiber optic signs, plasma display screen signs, incandescent signs, or any such signs using similar technologies. 
    "Monument sign" means any sign constructed of brick, stone, or other masonry on a foundation separate from the building foundation. 
    "Moving sign" means any sign which revolves, rotates, swings, undulates or otherwise attracts attention by moving parts, whether operated by mechanical equipment or by natural sources, but not including flags or banners. 
    "Multiple use freestanding pole sign" means a freestanding pole sign which contains use displays of more than one business. 
    "Nonconforming sign" means any sign that: (1) on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter was lawfully maintained and had been lawfully erected in accordance with the provisions of all applicable prior sign, zoning, and other ordinances but does not conform to the limitations and standards established by the ordinance codified in this chapter in the zoning district in which the sign is located; or (2) on or after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter was lawfully erected and maintained in accordance with the provisions of the ordinance codified in this chapter, but, by reason of further amendment to the ordinance after its effective date, does not conform to the limitations as established by the ordinance in the zoning district in which the sign is located. 
    "Nonilluminated sign" means a sign having no illumination either directly or indirectly. 
    "Obscene sign" means any sign which in any manner including in writing or in picture when considered as a whole, predominantly appeals to prurient interests that are shameful, or morbid interest in nudity, sex or excretion and goes substantially beyond customary limits of candor in description or representation of such matters. 
    "Obsolete sign" means any sign pertaining to a business which is no longer operating on-site or which pertains to any event or activity that has ended or has otherwise been terminated. 
    "Operational or instructional sign" means any sign designating entrances, exits, service areas, parking areas or restrooms, or otherwise notifying or instructing the public about the functional operation of the building or premises. 
    "Permanent residential development sign" means permanent signs limited to identifying the name of a neighborhood area such as a subdivision or housing development. 
    "Political election sign" means a temporary sign announcing or supporting political candidates or issues in connection with any national, state or local election. 
    "Political message sign" means a sign other than an election sign expressing a noncommercial message regarding an issue of political or public concern. 
    "Portable sign" means a sign, usually of a temporary nature, not securely anchored to the ground or to a building or structure. 
    "Projection sign" means a sign attached to a building and extending in whole or in part more than eighteen (18) inches from the building and not more than forty-eight (48) inches. 
    "Real estate sign" means a sign advertising the sale or rental of the premises upon which it is located. 
    "Roof sign" means any sign erected, constructed, and maintained upon or over the roof of any building, with the principal support on the roof structure. 
    "Sandwich board signs" means a temporary freestanding sign constructed in an "A" type frame of wood advertising a service, product or event on the site. 
    "Sign" means any publicly displayed sign, symbol, notice or device that is used to advertise or attract public notice to any business, name of a person or firm conducting business, name of a product or service rendered, organization, person, institution, event, idea or location, whether fixed in place or portable. Any double-faced sign shall constitute a single sign. 
    "Sign area" means the surface of a sign measured to the outside of the sign structure on only one face of the sign, and including all of the display area and all the elements of the matter displayed. For wall signs composed of individual letters, figures, or symbols attached to the building, the area comprising the entire gross area of the message or display shall be measured without the deduction for space between letters or symbols. The sign area shall be measured in square feet. 
    "Sign height" means the vertical distance measured from the ground grade below the sign face to the highest point of the sign. 
    "Symbols, emblems, plaques or insignia" means symbols, insignias, commemorative plaques, or emblems of any national or political subdivision, profit or nonprofit organization, or community organization. 
    "Temporary sign" means any sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric, cardboard, wallboard, or other light materials, with or without frames, intended to be displayed on a temporary basis. 
    "Time and temperature sign" means a sign or part of a sign that indicates current time and temperature. 
    "Vehicular signs" means signs attached to or painted on any motor vehicle, whether operable or inoperable. 
    "Warning signs" means signs limited to messages of warning, caution or damage. 
    "Window signs" means signs affixed to the interior surface of a window or placed within twelve (12) inches of the interior surface of a window, so as to be seen and identified from outside by the public, or signs painted or lettered directly on a window. 
(Ord. 2007-0-29 § 1; Ord. 99-0-09 § 1; prior code § 29.200) 
15.28.040 - General standards-Structural signs. 
A.  Flat Wall Signs. No flat wall sign shall extend above the roof line nor beyond the building edge. No more than fifty (50) percent of the wall sign background area may be used for copy. Any such sign shall not exceed a total area of three square feet of copy for each lineal foot of building frontage except in no case shall such sign exceed eighty (80) square feet in sign area. 
B.  Monument Sign. Such signs shall be set back ten (10) feet from all right-of-way lines and shall not exceed eighty (80) square feet in sign area. All sight clear distances shall be preserved. 
C.  Multiple Use Freestanding Pole Sign. Such signs shall not exceed twenty (20) feet in height or two hundred fifty (250) square feet in sign area. No portion of a sign face shall be less than eight feet above grade or extend to within five feet of any right-of-way line. Such signs shall be limited to retail areas of a minimum seventy-five thousand (75,000) square feet. 
D.  Internally and Indirectly Illuminated Signs. Illumination for internally and indirectly illuminated signs shall not extend into any street right-of-way. 
E.  Roof Sign. Such signs shall not extend more than three feet above the highest portion of the roof or exceed thirty-two (32) square feet in sign area. 
F.  Ground Sign. 
1.  Such signs shall not exceed eight feet in height from grade, shall be set back a minimum of seven feet from all right-of-way lines, and adequate sight clear distances must be preserved. 
2.  Each lot or parcel of land under one ownership or use may have not more than one ground sign, with a maximum of two display surfaces, except that any lot or parcel with a frontage of three hundred fifty (350) feet or more may have two ground signs located not less than two hundred fifty (250) feet apart. The maximum sign area of each display surface shall be based upon lot frontage as follows: 
Lot Frontage Maximum Size of Each Display Surface Area 50' or less 25 square feet Over 50' but not more than 100' 25 square feet plus one additional square foot of sign area for each five feet, or major fraction thereof, of lot frontage in excess of 50' Over 100' but not more than 250' 35 square feet plus two additional square feet of sign area for each five feet, or major fraction thereof, of lot frontage in excess of 100' Over 250' 100 square feet, which is the maximum allowed  
3.  Where two ground signs are permitted on one lot or parcel, each sign may contain the maximum sign area for each display area as permitted in the foregoing table. 
4.  In the case of a corner lot, either street (but not both) may be designated for the purpose of determining frontage. 
G.  Window Signs. Such sign or signs shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the total glass area of the window or glass door on which they are located. Such signs shall be in addition to those signs permitted under the other provisions of this chapter. 
H.  All Structural Types. 
1.  All letters, figures, characters, or representations in cut-out or irregular form, maintained in conjunction with, attached to, or superimposed upon any sign shall be safely and securely built or attached to the sign structure and shall comply with all requirements of this chapter. 
2.  Except as may be required for sign illumination, no sign shall be located within eight feet of any electric power line, service drops, or line conductors, or in any location where the representative of the building department finds a reasonable danger that an electric power line would come in contact with the sign. 
3.  All signs, and the premises surrounding the same, shall be maintained by the owner thereof in a clean, sanitary and inoffensive condition, and free and clear of all obnoxious substances, rubbish, and weeds. 
I.  Changeable Copy Signs, Manual. Such signs shall only be permitted under the following as ground signs as defined by this chapter. 
J.  Light Emitting Diode (LED) Sign. Such signs may be permitted under the following conditions: 
1.  LED signs may only be permitted in the general business (GB) and shopping center business (SCB) zones. 
2.  LED signs may only be permitted as part of a multiple use free standing pole sign that complies with the applicable provisions of this chapter. 
3.  LED signs shall be a minimum five hundred (500) feet away from any residential structure. 
4.  The electronic message board component of the sign may comprise no more than thirty (30) percent of the sign or one square foot of sign area for every one thousand two hundred twenty (1,220) square feet of retail area, and in no case be greater than seventy (70) square feet of sign area. 
5.  LED colors shall be limited to three colors. Images shall be softened at dusk. 
6.  Words and images shall not be more frequently than once every eight seconds. 
7.  Messages or images displayed through an LED screen shall not blink, flicker, flash, scintillate or fast moving animate. Limited animation is allowed. The village reserves the right to restrict the use of animation. 
8.  LED message signs may only advertise businesses or activities located within the retail center and public service announcements for charitable groups or events. 
9.  LED signs being added to existing signs should be compatible and fit within the existing sign structure face. 
K.  Illuminated Wall Sign. Such signs shall have a sign face design with only individual letters internally or back illuminated, space shall be provided between letter components and letters. Letters shall not appear as one mass. 
(Ord. 2007-0-29 § 2; prior code § 29.301) 
15.28.050 - General standards-Functional signs. 
    Notwithstanding the height, area, location, setback, and number limitations described in Section 15.28.040, the following limitations shall apply to the following signs regardless of structural type: 
A.  Directional Sign. Such sign shall not exceed eight square feet in sign area. 
B.  Development Sign, Temporary. There may not be more than one such sign located on a zoning lot except as permitted below. Such sign shall not exceed sixty (60) square feet in sign area or a maximum height of ten (10) feet. On properties that have frontage on more than one street, an additional temporary development sign is permitted per street upon which the development fronts. 
C.  Operational or Instructional Sign. Such signs, except entrance and exit signs, shall not exceed eight square feet in sign area. Entrance and exit signs shall not exceed two square feet in sign area. 
D.  Real Estate Sign. In residential districts, real estate signs shall not exceed 9.25 square feet in sign area or five feet in height; provided that on lots or groups of lots of two acres or more, such signs shall not exceed twenty-five (25) square feet in sign area. No more than one sign is permitted per street frontage. In a CB or CBA District, real estate signs shall not exceed twenty-five (25) square feet in sign area. In all other nonresidential districts, real estate signs shall not exceed sixty (60) square feet in sign area or ten feet in height. All real estate signs shall be removed within fourteen (14) days after the sale or transaction has occurred. 
E.  Construction Sign. A construction sign shall not exceed twelve (12) square feet in sign area in any residential district or thirty-two (32) square feet in sign area in any nonresidential district. These signs are permitted only during the time construction is actively underway and shall be removed prior to the issuance of an occupancy permit. 
F.  Symbols, Emblems, Plaques, or Insignia. No symbol, emblem, plaque or insignia shall exceed four square feet in sign area, and all such symbols, emblems, plaques, and insignia shall be flat wall signs. 
G.  Alternative Premises Advertising in Signs. Such signs shall not exceed sixteen (16) square feet in sign area. 
H.  Temporary Sign. Such signs shall not be allowed, except as provided in Sections 15.28.060 (Prohibited signs), 15.28.070 (Permitted signs) and 15.28.092 (Political signs). No temporary sign shall be more than sixteen (16) square feet, unless stated differently in Sections 15.28.060, 15.28.070 and 15.28.092. 
I.  Identification Sign. Such signs shall not exceed fifteen (15) square feet in sign area, and all such signs shall be flat wall signs. 
J.  Group Development Sign. Such signs are permitted only in accordance with the standards below: 
1.  Commercial or Industrial Center Identification Signs. Each commercial center consisting of six or more retail business uses, and each industrial center consisting of six or more industrial uses, which uses are under separate ownership and operation and which occupy separate spaces within a multi-activity building or group of buildings comprising an integrated commercial or industrial center complex, may have one sign identifying the group of commercial or industrial uses; provided that the sign area does not exceed twenty (20) square feet for each acre of land, excluding public streets or alleys, contained in the project up to a maximum of one hundred twenty-eight (128) square feet of sign area. 
2.  Commercial or Industrial Center Directories. Where individual commercial or industrial users are located inside a grouping or complex without visible frontage facing a public street, a directory not exceeding thirty (30) square feet in sign area, stating only the name of each such use and its location within the grouping, may be installed at any pedestrian entrance to such areas. 
K.  Permanent Residential Development Signs. Such signs shall not exceed twenty-five (25) square feet in sign area and six feet in height and may be located at each entrance, provided that adequate sight clear distance is provided. Such signs may be erected within the municipal right-of-way upon village board approval. 
L.  Home Occupation Sign. Such signs shall be nonilluminated flat wall signs and shall not exceed two square feet in sign area. 
M.  Menu Boards. Menu boards shall be allowed in conjunction with a drive-through restaurant or other drive-through pick up areas with the following restrictions: 
1.  No more than two of such signs; 
2.  No more than thirty-two (32) square feet in sign area; 
3.  Maximum height of six feet; 
4.  May be freestanding or wall-mounted; 
5.  Not visible from the street right-of-way. 
(Ord. 2007-0-29 § 3; Ord. 99-0-09 § 2; prior code § 29.302) 
15.28.060 - Prohibited signs. 
A.  No sign shall be erected or maintained at any location where, by reason of its position, wording, illumination, size, shape, or color, it may obstruct, impair, obscure, interfere with the view of, or be confused with, any authorized traffic control sign, signal, or device; 
B.  No sign shall be located or use any word, phrase, symbol, shape, form, or character, in such manner as to interfere with moving traffic; 
C.  No internally or indirectly illuminated sign shall be permitted within fifty (50) feet of any residentially zoned property unless the illumination of the sign is so designed that it does not shine directly onto any adjacent property or onto any street; 
D.  No part of any sign attached to a building shall be erected to a height greater than that permitted for such building; 
E.  Signs which may be, or may hereafter become, rotted, unsafe, or unsightly shall be repaired or removed by the permittee or owner of the sign or upon notice of the building department; 
F.  No sign or part of any sign shall be erected in or over, or extended into or over, the public right-of-way except those signs established by, or by order of, any governmental agency. Any such signs not established by, or by order of, a governmental agency, may be removed by the village without notice; 
G.  No sign is permitted which includes flashing lights, mechanically moving parts, or noise emissions; 
H.  No sign over four square feet may be suspended by chains, ropes or other nonmechanical means that readily permit the sign to swing or move freely; 
I.  No obsolete sign shall be permitted; 
J.  No vehicular sign attached or painted onto an inoperable or unlicensed motor vehicle in view of the public right-of-way or attached to or painted on a licensed motor vehicle which is parked or maintained in full view of the right-of-way or on the property to which the sign thereon refers for a period of more than thirty (30) consecutive days shall be permitted; 
K.  No portable sign shall be permitted; 
L.  No attention-attracting devices, permanent or temporary, shall be permitted; provided, however, that for grand openings, special promotions, or other similar special occasions not exceeding seven (7) days in duration and not occurring more than two (2) times annually for any one zoning lot, attention-attracting devices may be considered temporary signs and allowed with a proper permit. The provisions of this subsection shall not be interpreted as prohibiting the proper display of flags of any nation or political subdivision. 
    Exception: Businesses located within festival or event areas are allowed one banner sign with the following regulations: 
1.  The sign shall not exceed thirty-two (32) square feet; 
2.  The sign shall be removed at the conclusion of the festival or event; 
3.  No permit required; 
4.  Does not count toward the maximum number of special occasions or special promotions allowed by this subsection. 
M.  No sign shall be painted directly on the wall or roof of a building, directly on a fence or other accessory structure or directly on any paved surface other than required traffic control information; 
N.  No sign shall be located at the rear of premises facing a residential property; 
O.  No sign shall be attached to a tree; 
P.  No sign shall be attached to a fence or wall constructed in accordance with the Grayslake Fence Ordinance, except for street address numbers and residents' names; 
Q.  Freestanding pole sign; 
R.  Neon or zenon type sign lighting; 
S.  Backlit box type signs with translucent sign face; 
T.  Advertising benches (public or private property); 
U.  No other sign not specifically permitted by this chapter shall be erected or maintained. 
(Ord. 2007-0-29 § 4; Ord. 99-0-09 § 3; prior code § 29.401) 
(Ord. No. 2010-0-28, § 1, 10-19-2010) 
15.28.070 - Permitted signs. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided in this section, the following signs are permitted in any zoning district without a permit. Such signs shall not be used for the purpose of calculating the total allowable signs or sign area for a zoning lot, but shall comply with all other regulations of this ordinance: 
A.  One real estate sign per zoning lot, not exceeding 9.25 square feet in sign area; 
B.  Signs established by, or by order of, any governmental agency; 
C.  Temporary signs for government, church, and nonprofit organization event signs pertaining to events of public interest such as drives, fairs or events of civic or educational events provided that the sign does not exceed sixteen (16) square feet for any zoning lot. Further signs of four square feet may be place in the public right-of-way as long as sight clear distances are preserved. Such signs shall not be erected more than twenty-one (21) days before the event and shall be removed within twenty four (24) hours after said event. Portable signs are prohibited. 
    Also, temporary directional signs, not more than four square feet in sign area showing only the directional arrow and the name of the event may be erected not more than one day before the event, and shall be removed within twenty-four (24) hours after the event. Such signs shall not be placed in the public right-of-way; 
D.  Signs not visible from the outside of a building; 
E.  Home occupation signs; 
F.  Identification signs consisting solely of house numbers and nameplates not exceeding two square feet in sign area for each residential, commercial, or industrial building; 
G.  Memorial signs or tablets, containing names of buildings and date of erection, which are cut into a masonry surface, or when constructed of bronze or other noncombustible material inlaid so as to be part of a building, provided that such signs do not exceed four square feet in sign area; 
H.  Operational or instructional signs not to exceed one and one-half square feet in sign area per sign; 
I.  Temporary nonilluminated sale signs on the interior surface of a glass show window when a sale of goods or services is being conducted by a business establishment. Such signs shall not exceed fifty (50) square feet in sign area. No promotional or sale signs shall be permitted to be affixed to the exterior of any window, wall, or other exterior surface of the structure, and in no event shall such signs obstruct or interfere with any window area required for light or ventilation under any applicable law; 
J.  Nonilluminated window signs painted or lettered directly on a window for the specific purpose of identifying the proprietor or name of the business for passersby; 
K.  Symbols, emblems, plaques, and insignia, provided such signs shall not exceed four square feet in sign area; 
L.  Vehicular signs on a motor vehicle operating in the normal course of business, which business is not primarily the display of signs; 
M.  Awning and canopy signs shall be subject to the following: 
1.  No portion of an awning or canopy shall be less than eight feet above the level of the public sidewalk. 
2.  No awning or canopy shall be permitted to extend beyond a point four feet from the curb. 
3.  Awnings and canopies shall be constructed of canvas or canvas-like material. Backlit or metal awnings or canopies are prohibited. 
4.  Awnings and canopies shall be securely attached to the building. All frames and supports shall be made of metal or other rigid material. 
5.  Only the name of the business or service offered by that business, street address number, and/or logo may be printed on the valance except as permitted by paragraph 6 of this subsection. 
6.  The name of the business or logo may be printed on the portion of the awning or canopy above the valance shall be limited to one awning or canopy only, except in the case of corner lot where on awning or canopy with printing above each valance shall be permitted on each street frontage, such name or logo printed above the valance shall be limited as follows: 
a.  Lettering shall be limited to twenty-five (25) percent of the awning or canopy, as measured from the point of attachment to the building to the bottom of the fully extended awning or canopy excluding the valance. Letters shall be limited to fifty (50) percent of the width of the awning or canopy, 
b.  A logo shall be limited to fifty (50) percent of the height of the awning or canopy, as measured from the point of the attachment to the building to the bottom of the fully extended awning or canopy; 
N.  Warning signs placed in areas of danger which are accessible to the public, utility companies or others; 
O.  Holiday decorations on private property; 
P.  Signs, accessory to the principal use of a gasoline service station, relating prices or other information required by state or federal law; 
Q.  Political message signs shall be permitted on private property without a permit in any zoning district; provided: (1) no more than two such signs shall be permitted per lot; (2) such signs are not located within fifteen (15) feet of a street intersection; (3) no such sign exceeds six square feet in sign area; 
R.  Sandwich board or message board signs shall be permitted on private property subject to the following: 
1.  Sandwich board or message board signs shall be allowed in the GB, SCB, CB and CBA zones, 
2.  No more than one shall be permitted per zoning lot or business, 
3.  Shall not be located in the right-of-way, 
4.  Shall not be greater than six square feet in sign area, 
5.  Must be nonilluminated, 
6.  Must be removed when business is not open, 
7.  Sandwich board or message board sign shall be located within twenty (20) feet of the main entrance, 
8.  Sandwich or message board signs may be located in the right-of-way in the CB or CBA zones. 
(Ord. 2007-0-29 § 5; Ord. 99-0-45 § 1; Ord. 99-0-09 § 4; prior code § 29.402) 
(Ord. No. 2010-0-28, § 2, 10-19-2010) 
15.28.080 - Nonconforming signs. 
A.  Authority to Continue. Except as provided in subsection B of this section, any nonconforming sign may be continued in its existing condition, subject to the following limitations: 
1.  If the sign is damaged or destroyed by any means to the extent of more than fifty (50) percent of its replacement cost, such sign shall not be repaired, replaced, or restored except in strict conformity with this chapter; 
2.  The sign shall not be altered, enlarged, or moved in any manner unless it thereafter is in strict conformity with this chapter; 
3.  Notwithstanding the foregoing, the owner of a nonconforming sign may: 
a.  Perform normal maintenance and incidental repair or replacement of nonbearing sign elements and electrical wiring and fixture, provided that no such repair or replacement shall increase the degree of nonconformity of such sign; and 
b.  Change the message on such sign, provided that such change does not otherwise violate the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  Termination of Nonconforming Signs. 
1.  Except as provided in subsection (B)(2) of this section, any nonconforming sign, or any nonconforming element of a sign capable of change or discontinuance separate from other elements of the sign, that has not otherwise been terminated pursuant to this chapter, shall be terminated no later than the dare provided in the following schedule: 
Original Value of Sign or Sign Element, as Shown on, or Estimated from, Building Permit Removal Required Within Stated Period After the Later of the Effective Date of this Amendment or the Date the Sign becomes Nonconforming Less than $1,000 1 Year $1,001 to $4,000 2 Years $4,001 to $7,000 3 Years $7,001 to $10,000 4 Years Over $10,000 5 Years  
    Where no original value can be established, the building department's estimate of current depreciated replacement cost shall be used. 
2.  Notwithstanding the amortization schedule in subsection (B)(1) of this section, the owner of any nonconforming sign who has not fully depreciated such sign for federal income tax purposes may, upon delivery to the village of all relevant tax returns to verify the depreciation of such sign, continue to use such nonconforming sign until the earlier of: 
a.  The time necessary to depreciate fully such sign for federal income tax purposes without altering the method of depreciation; or 
b.  Seven years after the effective date of this section (Sept. 20, 1994). 
C.  Notice and Appeal. 
1.  The village building commissioner shall give written notice of the owner(s) of any nonconforming sign of termination provisions of this section (the "N/C sign notice"). The N/C sign notice shall be sent via certified mail (return receipt requested) and, if the building commissioner so decides, by any other appropriate means. 
2.  Unless the sign owner delivers to the building commissioner satisfactory evidence of the original value of the nonconforming sign within thirty (30) days after the N/C sign notice, the building commissioner shall determine the building department's estimate of the current depreciated replacement cost of the nonconforming sign for purposes of determining when a nonconforming sign must be removed under this section. 
3.  Within thirty (30) days after the timely receipt of any evidence of the original value of a nonconforming sign, the building commissioner shall notify the owner of such sign whether such evidence is accepted, conditionally accepted, or rejected (the "valuation review notice"). The valuation review notice shall be sent via certified mail (return receipt requested) and, if the building commissioner so decides, by any other appropriate means. 
a.  If accepted, the valuation review notice shall set forth such acceptance, as well as the removal date for the nonconforming sign based on the original value and the terms of this section; 
b.  If conditionally accepted, the valuation review notice shall set forth the deficiencies in the valuation evidence, the conditions under which the owner's valuation evidence is accepted, and the removal date for the nonconforming sign based on the original value and the terms of this section. In addition, the valuation review notice shall require the owner's acceptance of the conditions within thirty (30) days, or else the evidence of original value shall be deemed rejected. 
c.  If rejected, the valuation review notice shall state that the valuation evidence has been rejected, the reasons therefor and the building department's estimate of the current depreciated replacement cost for the sign, as well as the removal date for the nonconforming sign based on such estimate; 
d.  In addition to the information required pursuant to subsection (C)(3)(a), (b), or (c) of this section, the valuation review notices shall notify the owners of nonconforming signs of their right to appeal the decision set forth in the valuation review notice to the board of trustees of the village, as well as the procedures for such appeal. 
4.  Appeals. 
a.  The owner of any nonconforming sign may appeal the decision set forth in any valuation review notice by filing a written notice of appeal with the village clerk within thirty (30) days after delivery of the valuation review notice. The notice of appeal shall state the basis for such appeal, and shall include any relevant documents, records, or other materials in support of such appeal. In addition, the building commissioner shall provide the village board with the N/C sign notice, the valuation review notice, and any other relevant information within seven days after the receipt of the notice of appeal. 
b.  Based on a review of the materials provided with the notice of appeal and the information from the building commissioner, the board of trustees shall decide within thirty (30) days after the filing of the notice of appeal whether to affirm, modify, or reverse the decision of the building commissioner. If the board of trustees does not act on the appeal within such thirty (30) day period, the decision of the building commissioner as set forth in the valuation review notice shall be deemed approved. 
c.  Any appeal of the board of trustees decision shall be in accordance with the Administrative Review Procedures of the Illinois Code of Civil Procedures, as they may be amended from time to time. 
(Prior code § 29.600) 
15.28.090 - Sign regulations by zoning ordinance classification. 
A.  Residential Districts. The following signs are permitted in all residential districts with a valid permit: 
1.  Structural Types. 
a.  Flat wall signs; 
b.  Ground signs (except in residential districts); 
c.  Window signs. 
2.  Functional Types. 
a.  Development signs, temporary; 
b.  Identification signs, but only for residential structures; 
c.  Real estate signs; 
d.  Construction signs; 
e.  Permanent residential development signs; 
f.  Flags of any nation or political subdivision; 
g.  Symbols, emblems, plaques or insignia; 
h.  Holiday decorations; 
i.  Home occupation signs; 
j.  All signs permitted without a permit. 
B.  Nonresidential Districts. The following signs are permitted in all nonresidential districts with a valid permit: 
1.  Structural Types. 
a.  Flat wall signs; 
b.  Window signs; 
c.  Multiple use freestanding pole sign (GB and SCB zoning districts only); 
d.  Canopy signs; 
e.  Roof signs; 
f.  Ground signs. 
2.  Functional Types. 
a.  Directional signs; 
b.  Development signs, temporary identification signs, but only for nonresidential structures; 
c.  Temporary signs; 
d.  Operational or instructional signs; 
e.  Real estate signs; 
f.  Time and temperature signs; 
g.  Construction signs; 
h.  Flags of any nation or political subdivision; 
i.  Symbols, emblems, plaques or insignia; 
j.  Group development signs; 
k.  All signs permitted without permit. 
C.  Shopping Center District Regulations. Notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, the following provisions shall apply in the shopping center district: 
1.  Multiple-use freestanding pole sign or ground sign may be located at each common entrance into a shopping center; provided, however, that no shopping center shall have more than two multiple-use freestanding pole signs. 
2.  Each use within a shopping center may erect or maintain one wall sign indicating only the name and nature of the occupancy. Any such sign shall not exceed a total area of three square feet of copy for each lineal foot of building frontage, except in no case shall such sign exceed two hundred fifty (250) square feet in sign area. If the occupancy is on a corner, one wall sign shall be permitted for each building face. If the building includes a canopy or marquee, each use shall be permitted one additional sign attached under such canopy or marquee, not to exceed fifteen (15) square feet in sign area. 
D.  General Business District Regulations. Notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, the following provisions shall apply in the general business district: 
1.  No more than five signs, only one may be a freestanding multiple-use pole sign, may be erected and maintained on any premise at any one time, except when the premise has frontage along two or more streets, or when a use has a front and rear entrance, one additional sign may be erected along the second frontage. 
2.  The total sign area per premises shall not exceed three square feet of sign area for each lineal foot of the main frontage of the building or space of the premises, except that no premises shall be limited to less than twenty (20) square feet of total sign area. In no case shall the size of any sign on the premises exceed the size otherwise allowed for such sign pursuant to this chapter. 
E.  Commercial Transition and Commercial Transition Limited Districts. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, the following provisions shall apply in the commercial transition (CT) and commercial transition limited (CTL) districts only: 
1.  The following signs are permitted in the commercial transition (CT) and commercial transition limited (CTL) districts with a valid permit: 
Structural Types Functional Types Flat wall signs Development signs, temporary Ground signs Identification signs, but only for residential structures Window signs Real estate signs Construction signs Permanent residential development signs Flags of any nation or political subdivision Symbols, emblems, plaques or insignia Holiday decorations Home occupation signs All signs permitted without a permit as described in Section 15.28.070  
2.  Ground signs shall be a maximum of five feet in height and not exceed thirty (30) feet in sign area; 
3.  Ground signs shall be of wood or stone base; 
4.  Only attached up or down lighting will be allowed. Nonattached or internally illuminated signs shall be prohibited; 
5.  Illuminated window signs shall be prohibited. 
6.  All signs must conform to any subarea land use plans that include the property. 
F.  Central Business (CB) and Central Business A (CBA) Districts. Notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, the following provisions shall apply in the central business (CB) and central business A (CBA) districts only: 
1.  Structural Types 
Flat Wall Signs 
Ground Signs 
Window Signs 
Canopy Signs 
2.  Functional Types 
Identification signs, but only for nonresidential structures 
Real Estate Signs 
Construction Sign 
Flag of any Nation or Political Subdivision 
Symbols, Emblems, Plaques or Insignia 
Holiday Decorations 
Home Occupation Signs 
All Signs permitted without a permit as described in Section 15.28.070 
3.  Wall Signs. Each business or use may have one wall sign. The maximum sign area shall be based upon one square foot for each front foot of building frontage; or in a building with multiple uses, one square foot of business or store frontage. In no case can the maximum sign area exceed thirty (30) square feet. 
4.  Ground signs shall be a maximum of five feet in height and not exceed a total of thirty (30) square feet. 
5.  Wall signs shall be constructed of wood. 
6.  Ground signs shall be constructed of wood with wood or stone bases. 
7.  Only attached up or down lighting will be allowed for ground signs. Nonattached or internally illuminated signs shall be prohibited. 
8.  Internally illuminated wall signs shall be prohibited. 
9.  Canopy signs shall be of cloth or canvas type of material, vinyl or synthetic type of material shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. 2007-0-29 § 6; Ord. 99-0-45 § 2; Ord. 99-0-09 § 5; Ord. 98-0-04 §§ 1, 2; prior code § 29.403) 
15.28.092 - Political signs. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions in this chapter, the following provisions shall apply to the size, placement and type of political signs. 
1.  Political election signs shall be permitted only on private property without a permit in any zoning district. 
2.  Political election signs shall not be placed within the public right-of-way. 
3.  Such signs shall not be located within fifteen (15) feet of a street intersection. 
4.  Such signs shall not exceed sixteen (16) feet in sign area. 
5.  Banner signs, portable signs, and signs attached to fences or walls, constructed in accordance with the Grayslake Fence Ordinance are prohibited. 
6.  Such signs shall not be attached to light posts, utility poles or trees. 
7.  Such signs shall not be internally illuminated. 
8.  Window signs shall not exceed two square feet per sign, not to exceed a total of sixteen (16) square feet per premises or twenty-five (25) percent window coverage. 
9.  Political election signs shall not include flashing lights, mechanically moving parts or noise emissions. 
10.  Unless political election signs include on its face the name of the person or organization responsible for such signs, the owner of the private property on which such sign is located shall be deemed responsible for said sign. 
11.  Such signs in violation of the section shall be removed by property owner within twenty-four (24) hours of notification. 
12.  Political election signs located within the right-of-way will be removed by the village without notification. 
(Ord. 99-0-09-§ 6 (part)) 
(Ord. No. 2012-0-07, § 1, 2-7-2012) 
15.28.094 - Subarea plans. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, adopted subarea plan sign stipulations for architecture treatments and architectural treatments required for signs in Chapter 15.48 Industrial and Office Design Standards shall become part of this chapter. 
(Ord. 2007-0-29 § 7; Ord. 99-0-09-§ 6 (part)) 
(Ord. No. 2017-0-22, § 2, 6-20-2017) 
15.28.100 - Enforcing officer-Powers and duties. 
A.  Appointment of the Enforcing Officer. The building department shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  Duties of the Enforcing Officer. The building department shall examine all applications for permits for the erection of new signs, shall record and file all applications for permits with any accompanying plans and documents, shall inform owners of nonconforming signs and the nature of the nonconformance and the date of removal or compliance, and shall make periodic reports to the village board of trustees. 
(Prior code §§ 29.501, 29.502) 
15.28.110 - Permits required-Applications-Limitations-Revocation. 
A.  Permits Required. Except as otherwise expressly indicated in this chapter, it is unlawful for any person to erect, alter or relocate within the village any sign without first obtaining a permit from the building department and paying the appropriate fee as set forth in Table 15.28; provided, however, that if another governmental entity with jurisdiction requires that a sign be relocated, no fee shall be charged as long as the sign is relocated on the same zoning lot. All illuminated signs shall, in addition, be subject to all the applicable electrical code provisions and the permit fees required thereunder. No permit shall be required for changing letters or the message on any sign which includes a changeable copy panel, for repainting of an existing sign, or for replacement of a sign face, by the same advertiser, due to breakage and/or deterioration of the sign face. 
B.  Applications. Any person desiring such a permit shall file application therefor upon a form provided by, or otherwise acceptable to, the building department, which shall contain or have attached thereto the following information: 
1.  Name, address, and telephone number of the applicant; 
2.  A map drawn to scale showing the location of the building, structure or lot on which the sign is to be attached or erected, and showing the position of the sign in relation to buildings and streets; 
3.  A plan drawn to scale showing the design of the sign, the materials to be used, the method of construction, and the means of attachment to the building or ground; 
4.  The cost of constructing the sign; 
5.  The name of the person, firm, corporation, or association erecting, altering, or moving the sign; 
6.  Written consent of the owner of the land or building on which the sign is to be erected, altered or relocated. 
7.  Any other information which the representative of the building department shall require in order to show full compliance with this chapter and all of the other applicable ordinances of the village. 
C.  Limitations on Temporary Sign Permits. Possession of a valid permit for a temporary sign shall entitle the owner to display one temporary sign for a period of fourteen (14) days. Such permits shall be kept on the premises where such signs are displayed and shall be shown at the request of the building department. Size, content, and location within a lot of a temporary sign may be varied at any time so long as the variations remain within the overall restrictions of this chapter. 
D.  Limitations on Temporary Development Sign Permits. Such permits shall be valid for not more than one year, but may be renewed during any time some portion of the land offered for sale remains unsold and an active sales program is underway. 
E.  Revocation or Termination of Permits. All sign permits hereafter issued by the village and all sign permits issued by the village prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, are revocable at any time by the building department if the building department finds noncompliance with this chapter or any other provisions of this code, and such noncompliance is not corrected within twenty (20) days after written notice by the building department to the permittee, with a copy to the village manager. 
(Prior code § 29.503) 
15.28.120 - Enforcement-Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Inspection of Certain Signs. The building department shall inspect, at such times as it deems necessary to protect the public health and safety, each sign which extends over a public area or which is so located as to be able to topple upon or drop upon a public area in order to ascertain whether the sign is secure and whether it is in need of removal, repair or repainting. 
B.  Unsafe and Unlawful Signs. If the building department shall find that any sign is unsafe or insecure, or is a menace to the public, or has been constructed or erected, or is being maintained in violation of the provisions of this chapter or other provisions of this code, the building department shall give written notice to the permittee thereof or to the owner of the premises as shown on the most recent tax rolls. If the permittee or owner fails to make corrections or fails to remove or alter the sign within twenty (20) days, after said notice, the sign may be removed by the building department at the expense of such permittee or owner, and such expense shall be a lien on the real property upon which such sign is located. However, the building department may cause any sign which is an immediate and imminent peril to persons or property, to be removed summarily with or without notice. 
C.  Violation and Remedies. 
1.  Violation. The violation of or failure to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter, or the erection, use, or display of any sign not in compliance with all of the provisions of this chapter, shall be and is declared to be unlawful. 
2.  Injunction. The village, through its authorized agents, may initiate injunction or abatement proceedings or other appropriate action in a court of competent jurisdiction against any person who violates or fails to comply with any provisions of this chapter or against the erector, owner, or user of any unlawful sign or owner of the property on which an unlawful sign is located, to prevent, enjoin, abate, or terminate violations of this chapter or the erection, use, or display of an unlawful sign. 
3.  Penalty. 
a.  Any person, persons, firm, or corporation adjudged guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter, including (without limitation) a failure, neglect, or refusal to comply with a notice given pursuant to the provisions of this chapter or to comply otherwise with the provisions of this chapter, shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Proceedings may be commenced by warrant, arrest, or summons, whether by ticketing or any other means. Each day the violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
b.  The owner or tenant of any building, structure, sign, premises, or part thereof, and any person, persons, firm, or corporation who commits, participates in, assists in, or maintains such violations may each be found guilty of a separate offense and subject to the above penalties. 
4.  Impound Fees. Upon determination by the village that a sign has been installed, or maintained in violation of the provisions of this chapter within the public right-of-way, the village may summarily remove the offending sign and process the sign as unclaimed property. An impound fee, which shall be measured by the village's cost and expense of impounding and storing the offending sign will be assessed against each sign summarily removed, without notice to the sign owner. The impound fee shall be assessed as follows: twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each sign impounded, assessed each day the offending sign is in the possession of the village. 
    The owner of the impounded sign shall have five days in which to reclaim his/her impounded property after which the offending sign will be disposed of by the village. Appointments to pick up confiscated property may be arranged through the building department during normal business hours. The owner of the impounded sign must submit full payment to the building department of the impound fee prior to reclaiming his/her impounded property. If after five days, the sign owner fails or refuses to reclaim his/her impounded property, the village may dispose of the sign as it so chooses and the sign owner will have no recourse against the village for the loss of its unclaimed property. 
(Ord. 99-0-09 § 7; prior code § 29.504) 
15.28.130 - Appeals and variances. 
A.  Jurisdiction. 
    The plan commission/zoning board of appeals shall be vested with the following jurisdiction and authority: 
1.  To interpret the meaning of this chapter in cases of ambiguity and to make rulings with respect to application of the ordinance, including appeals from decisions of the building department. 
2.  To recommend to the village board of trustees that variations be granted from the provisions of this chapter with respect to particular cases involving practical difficulties or particular hardship in carrying out the strict letter of the regulations contained in this chapter. 
B.  Criteria for Board Decision. 
1.  Appeals. In appeals to the plan commission/zoning board of appeals from any decision of the building department, the scope of review of the plan commission/zoning board of appeals shall be limited to determining whether or not the decision of the building department is in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. The board shall affirm or reverse the decision of the building department. If the decision of the building department is reversed, the plan commission/zoning board of appeals shall direct the building department to issue a sign permit or take whatever other action is necessary in accordance with its decision. 
2.  Variances. 
a.  An applicant for variance from the requirements of this chapter shall submit sketches, drawings, or photographs of the property and the proposed sign, and shall explain in a written petition in what manner the sign varies from the provisions of this chapter, and why a variance for the proposed sign is needed. 
b.  The plan commission/zoning board of appeals may recommend to the village board of trustees that a variance be granted from the provisions of this chapter only where: 
i.  The literal interpretation and strict application of the provisions and requirements of this chapter would cause undue and unnecessary hardship to the applicant because of unique or unusual conditions pertaining to the specific building, parcel, property, or use in question; 
ii.  The granting of the requested variance would not be materially detrimental to the property owners in the vicinity; 
iii.  The unusual conditions applying to the specific property do not apply generally to other properties in the village; 
iv.  The granting of the variance would not be contrary to the general objective of this chapter of moderating the size, number, and unobtrusive placement of signs and reduction of clutter; 
v.  The proposed sign, in the context of development on the property and development on adjacent properties and in relation to the street, would serve to enhance the property and surrounding properties and rights-of-way; 
vi.  The entire area around the sign has been or will be particularly well landscaped so as to mitigate any adverse effects of the size, shape, number, or character of such sign. 
c.  In granting a variance, the village board of trustees may attach thereto such conditions regarding the location, character, and other features of the proposed sign as it may deem necessary to carry out the spirit and purpose of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 29.505)

Chapter 15.30 - INTERNATIONAL MECHANICAL CODE ADOPTED[4]

Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-0-02, §§ 2-5, adopted Jan. 15, 2013, repealed the former Ch. 15.30, §§ 15.30.010-15.30.070, and enacted a new Ch. 15.30 as set out herein. The former Ch. 15.30 pertained to mechanical code adopted and derived from Ord. 2005-0-21 §§ 2, 3. 

15.30.010 - Adoption of the International Mechanical Code - 2009 Edition, with exceptions and modifications. 
    The Municipal Code of the Village of Grayslake be amended by striking and deleting Chapter 15.30 and substituting in its place the following new Chapter 15.30 adopting and amending the International Mechanical Code, Edition 2009 as follows: 
A.  This code shall establish restrictions and regulations and regulate the installation of mechanical systems within buildings and structures except where other provisions of this code specifically cover the subject matter in question. 
B.  While the 2009 Edition of the International Mechanical Code has been adopted, the following modifications to the 2009 Mechanical Code (consisting of certain deletions, changes, and/or additions) shall control wherever the said modifications are applicable or are in conflict between the provisions of the International Mechanical Code and those chapters, the provisions of this Chapter shall control. 
C.  Modifications to the 2009 International Mechanical Code. The following sections of the International Mechanical Code are hereby revised as follows: 
1.  In all chapters and sections where the "name of jurisdiction" and/or "chief appointing authority of this jurisdiction" is written insert "Village of Grayslake"; 
2.  In all chapters or sections where "ICC Electrical Code" is written insert "The National Electrical Code-2011 Edition as adopted and amended by the Village of Grayslake", Chapter 15.16 of the Grayslake Municipal Code; 
3.  In all chapters or sections where "International Energy Conservation Code" is written insert the "State of Illinois Energy Code" (20 ILCS 3125); 
4.  In all chapters or sections where "International Plumbing Code" is written insert "The State of Illinois Plumbing Code as adopted and amended by the Village of Grayslake", Chapter 15.20 of the Grayslake Municipal Code. 
Chapter 1 Administration 
Section 104 Duties and Powers of the Code Official 
Section 104.5 Right of entry shall be amended to read as follows: 
    The Building Official or his/her designee shall have the authority to enter, at any reasonable time, any structure or premises for which a permit has been issued but that has not received a Certificate of Occupancy in accordance with Section 110 of the International Building Code. For all other structures or premises, when the Building Official has reasonable cause to believe that a code violation exists, the Building Official or his/hers designee is authorized to enter the structure or premises at reasonable times to inspect, subject to constitutional restrictions on unreasonable searches and seizures. If entry is refused or not obtained, the Building Official is authorized to pursue recourse as provided by law.

    The fees for mechanical work shall be in accordance with The Grayslake Fee Schedule Section 3.08 of The Grayslake Municipal Code.

Each day the violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
    Section 108.5 Stop work orders. Insert Fifty ($50.00) dollars and Seven hundred and fifty ($750.00) dollars.
