12.  Walkway lighting (bollard or decorative pole type) is encouraged, if the light source is obscured and the fixture is in keeping with the proposed architectural style. 
13.  Ground-mounted building lighting shall be allowed if the light source is completely obscured, and the fixtures are screened by landscaping. 
14.  Specific landscape materials should be highlighted via landscape lighting, where possible. 
15.  All landscape lighting shall be concealed and secure from the public. 
16.  Neon and zenon type fixtures or light sources are not allowed. 
17.  Proposed L.E.D. and message board signs shall be in accordance with village ordinances. 
18.  See sign compatibility, subsection G, for addition lighting guidelines. 
I.  Building Systems. 
1.  A building's mechanical, electrical and plumbing system shall be completely concealed from view from all locations and ground level vistas. 
2.  Rooftop equipment shall be hidden by a screening device or roof structures so as not to be visible from the street, sidewalk adjacent properties or public ways. 
3.  Roof top screening shall be consistent with the shape and profile of the principal roof structure. Screening that appears "box"-shaped shall not be allowed. 
4.  Rooftop screens shall be of architectural features and materials coordinated and compatible with building architecture and color. 
5.  Screening can be fencing, architectural features and/or appropriate landscaping. 
6.  Batten seam, standing seam and corrugated metal roof systems shall be allowed as screens only if they are not a dominant architectural feature and they are complimentary to building architectural style and detail. 
7.  Ground equipment screens shall be of architectural features and materials coordinated and compatible with building architecture and color. 
8.  Solid evergreen (i.e., arborvitae) landscape screening or a combination of earth berming and evergreens shall be an acceptable method of ground equipment screening provided plantings are selected for appropriate climate and installation environment (i.e. salt tolerant) and do not create security concerns. 
9.  Enclosure of Process Equipment and Tanks. All same shall be enclosed and screened in a structure constructed of materials similar to and compatible with those materials used on the primary building elevations. 
10.  Accessory structure screening (i.e., water towers, tanks, process equipment, cooling towers, chillers, vent hoods, communication equipment, alternative power equipment, etc.) shall be compatible with primary building facade architectural style, finish and detail. 
J.  Building/Site Screening, Landscaping and Design. 
1.  The intended landscape theme for individual site design is best described as a modified restoration of the native Illinois landscape. There will be a heavy emphasis on conservation and natural treatment of the landscape with dramatic enhancement in high visibility areas. 
2.  The main goals for landscaping within the development include: 
a.  Maintaining a high level of aesthetics using quality plant materials arranged in strong, colorful plant groupings and ensuring proper and consistent maintenance. 
b.  Creating a sustainable landscape emphasizing the use of BMPs, native and noninvasive materials, using controlled irrigation and drought tolerant plantings, and encouraging natural stormwater management through utilization of grass filters and minimized catch basin/piping systems. 
c.  Incorporating key design principles (e.g. site orientation, landscape layout, site grading) to frame and enhance architecture, to create seasonal interest and to provide screening where necessary. 
3.  All plant materials shall be selected from those listed with the approved plan material palette for the village. All plant materials shall conform to the minimum plant sizes as per the approved palette and shall conform to the American Standard for Nursery Stock-most recent edition. 
4.  The following planning standards for industrial have been developed for site landscape design in the industrial area: 
a.  Foundation Landscaping. A minimum of ten (10) feet of landscaped area shall be provided around seventy-five (75) percent of all principal building foundations, excluding areas used for loading, entries and/or service areas. 
b.  Best Management Practices (BMPs). Natural storm water management will be encouraged through use of bio-swales and minimized catch basin-piping systems. LEEDs will be encouraged as part of the approach to design. 
c.  Parking and Circulation: 
i.  Parking lots shall be located to provide easy pedestrian circulation to the buildings they serve and to minimize visual impacts to adjacent properties. 
ii.  Service areas shall be located to provide easy access to adjacent streets. Public vehicular transportation should not route through service drives unless adequate provision has been made to the driveway width to insure safety. 
iii.  When major buildings are clustered around connecting parking lots, sidewalks will be provided to connect the parking modules, and when the configuration makes it difficult for pedestrians to safely access from building to building, a clearly defined pedestrian pathway will connect them. 
iv.  All parking areas that have more than ninety (90) spaces will feature: 
1.  Major circulation drives with little or no parking (usually adjacent to the structure it serves and for pickup areas). Minimum circulation drive shall be thirty (30) feet wide not including parking or pickup drive. 
2.  Parking aisles with parking access, minimum twenty-four (24) feet wide. 
3.  Passenger pick-up and drop-off areas, where incorporated, shall be designed so as to not interfere with traffic circulation and provide adequate space for safe loading or unloading of passengers. 
d.  Parking Lot Landscaping: 
i.  Wherever possible, the design of large parking lots should include landscape islands of significant size (three hundred twenty-four (324) s.f. minimum) to control traffic and break up large expanses of pavement. A minimum green area of five (5) percent shall be provided within all parking lots containing fifty (50) or more cars. 
ii.  Landscaped islands within parking lots shall contain native or adaptive trees, underplanted with native shrubs, grasses and/or perennials. All plant materials shall be selected from the approved plan material palette (see Exhibit "A" for Planting Palette for Industrial). 
iii.  Earthen berms shall be encouraged to screen parking lots from street views. 
iv.  All parking lot landscaping shall be placed to prevent any visual sight line encumbrances in accordance with village ordinances. 
e.  Shared parking is the use of parking spaces to serve two (2) or more individual land uses without conflict. The goal of a shared parking analysis is to find the balance between providing adequate parking to support a mix of uses within a development and minimizing the negative aspects of excessive land area dedicated to pavement. Shared parking may be allowed in industrial areas. 
f.  Landscape Screening: 
i.  Building mechanical systems located at ground level shall be concealed via planting, berming or other means. Mechanical equipment located on exterior walls shall be adequately screened by landscaping or trellising. 
ii.  Loading shall be located so as to minimize visibility from public or private streets. Loading areas shall be properly screened with landscaping and berming to provide for year-round screening when exposed to a public street. 
iii.  Earthen berms or other means shall be required to screen loading areas from street views. 
(Ord. 2008-0-08 § 2: Ord. 2004-0-35 § 2) 
(Ord. No. 2017-0-22, § 2, 6-20-2017) 
Chapter 15.52 - INTERNATIONAL RESIDENTIAL CODE ADOPTED[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-0-05, §§ 2-5, adopted Jan. 15, 2013, repealed the former Ch. 15.52, §§ 15.52.010-15.52.030, and enacted a new Ch. 15.52 as set out herein. The former Ch. 15.52 pertained to the international residential code adopted and derived from Ord. No. 2005-0-19, §§ 2-4, 7-19-2005. 

15.52.010 - Scope. 
    The provisions of the code shall control all matters concerning the construction, alterations, additions, repair, removal, demolition, location, occupancy and maintenance of detached one- and two-family dwellings and multiple single-family (townhouses) not more than three stories in height, their appurtenances and accessory structures, and shall apply to existing structures; except as such matters are otherwise provided for in other ordinances or statutes, or in the rules and regulations authorized for promulgation under provisions of this code. 
(a)  The regulations of this code shall apply to all existing or proposed buildings and structures in the village. 
(b)  In the event that any provision of this code is in conflict with any provision of The Village of Grayslake Zoning Ordinance or any amendment thereto, the latter shall prevail and the conflicting provision of this code shall be of no effect. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-05, § 2, 1-15-2013) 
15.52.020 - Adoption of the International Residential Code - 2009 Edition, with exceptions. 
    The Municipal Code of the Village of Grayslake be amended by striking and deleting Chapter 15.18 and Chapter 15.52 and substituting in its place the following new Chapter 15.52 adopting and amending the International Residential Code, 2009 Edition as follows: 
A.  This code shall establish restrictions and regulate the construction of all detached one- and two-family dwellings and single-family townhouses not more than three stories in height, their appurtenances and accessory structures except where other provisions of this code specifically cover the subject matter. 
B.  While the 2009 Edition of the International Residential Code has been adopted, the following modifications to the 2009 International Residential Code (consisting of certain deletions, changes, and/or additions) shall control wherever the said modifications are applicable or are in conflict with certain other provisions of the International Residential Code. In the event of a conflict between the provisions of the International Residential Code and this chapter, the provisions of this chapter shall control. 
The following sections of the International Residential Code are hereby revised as follows: 
1.  In all the chapters and sections where "name of jurisdiction" and/or "chief appointing authority of this jurisdiction" is written insert "Village of Grayslake". 
2.  In all chapters or sections where "ICC Electrical Code" is written insert "The National Electrical Code 2011 Edition as adopted and amended by the Village of Grayslake", Chapter 15.16 of the Grayslake Municipal Code. 
3.  In all chapters and sections where "International Plumbing Code" is written insert "The State of Illinois Plumbing Code as adopted and amended by the Village of Grayslake", Chapter 15.20 of the Grayslake Municipal Code. 
Chapter 1. ADMINISTRATION 
R104 Duties and Powers of the Building Official 
R104.6 Right of entry shall be amended to read as follows: 
    The Building Official or his/her designee shall have the authority, during reasonable working hours, to lawfully enter, any structure or premises for which a permit has been issued but that has not received a certificate of occupancy in accordance with this code. For all other structures or premises, when the Building Official has reasonable cause to believe that a Code violation exists, the Building Official or his/hers designee is authorized to enter the structure or premises at reasonable times to inspect, subject to constitutional restrictions on unreasonable searches and seizures. If entry is refused or obtained, the Building Official is authorized to pursue other recourse as provided by law. 
R105 Permits 
R105.2 Work exempt from permit shall be amended to read as follows: 
    Permits shall not be required for the following. Exemptions from the permit requirements of this code shall not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in violation of the provisions of this code or any other laws or ordinances of the Village of Grayslake. 
Building: 
1.  Painting, papering, tiling, carpeting, cabinets, counter tops and similar finish work. 
2.  Prefabricated swimming pools that are less than 24 inches (610 mm) deep. 
3.  Swings and other playground equipment. 
Electrical: 
1.  Listed cord-and-plug connected temporary decorative lighting 
2.  Reinstallations of attachment plug receptacles but not the outlets thereof. 
3.  Minor repair work, including the replacement of lamps or the connection or approved portable electrical equipment to approve permanently installed receptacles. 
Gas: 
1.  Portable heating, cooking or clothes drying appliances. 
2.  Replacement of any minor part that does not alter approval of equipment or make such equipment unsafe. 
3.  Portable-fuel-cell appliances that are not connected to fixed piping system and are not interconnected to a power grid. 
Mechanical: 
1.  Portable heating appliance. 
2.  Portable ventilation appliances. 
3.  Portable cooling appliances. 
4.  Steam, hot or chilled water piping within any heating or cooling equipment regulated by this code. 
5.  Replacement of any minor part that does not alter approval of equipment or make such equipment unsafe. 
6.  Portable evaporative cooler. 
7.  Self-contained refrigeration systems containing 10 pound (4.54 kg) or less of refrigerant or that are actuated by motors of 1 horsepower (746 W) or less. 
8.  Portable-fuel-cell appliances that are not connected to fixed piping system and are not interconnected to a power grid. 
    The stopping of leaks in drains, water, soil, waste or vent piping; provided, however, that if any concealed trap, drainpipe, water, soil, waste or vent pipe becomes defective and it becomes necessary to remove and replace the same with new material, such work shall be considered as new work and a permit shall be obtained and inspection made as provided in the Code. 
    The cleaning of stoppages or repairing of leaks in pipes, valves, or fixtures, and the removal and reinstallation of water closets, provided such repairs do not involve or require the replacement or rearrangement of valves, pipes or fixtures. 
R105.3.1.1 Substantially improved or substantially damaged existing buildings in areas prone to flood. Delete this section. 
R105.8 Responsibility shall be amended to read as follows: 
    R105.8 Responsibility. It shall be the duty of every person who performs work for the installation or repair of the building and accessory structures, which this code is applicable, to comply with this code. 
The following new subsection shall be added: 
    R105.9 Construction Hours. Any activity in the construction of any building or structure (including excavating, demolition, alteration or repair) or laying pavement, including and not limited to the making of an excavation, clearing or surface land, and loading and unloading material, equipment or supplies, anywhere in the village except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. on weekdays, and, except between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on Saturday is prohibited; provided that this subsection shall not be construed to apply to any person doing work on premise owned by him/her and not for compensation. It shall be unlawful to engage in any work or activity on a Sunday or Holiday or at any time other than as prescribed above, unless the Building Commissioner has first issued a special permit for such work. Application for such permit shall be made in writing, stating the proposed day(s) and time(s) of operation. No special permit shall be issued or allowed to continue that is determined to be contrary to public welfare. 
    Exception: Interior remodeling and maintenance activity is permitted within the residence where the activity will be limited to wholly within the residence and where all remodeling and maintenance activity, running of compressors, generators, saws, the delivery of materials and the dumping and storage of debris occurs wholly within the residence. 
R106 Construction Documents. 
R106.1.3 Information for the construction in areas prone to flooding shall be deleted. 
R106.2 Site plan shall be amended to read as follows: 
    The construction documents submitted with the application for a permit shall be accompanied by a site plan showing the size and location of new construction and existing structures on the site and the distances from the lot lines. In the case of new construction or an addition of eight hundred (800) square feet or more, a site plan shall be prepared by a State of Illinois Registered Land Surveyor or Civil Engineer providing the following information: 
a.  Scale of Plan: 1" = 20' or larger. 
b.  North Arrow. 
c.  Property Lines with dimensions. 
d.  Easement Lines. 
e.  Building Setback Lines. 
f.  Proposed foundation with outside dimensions. 
g.  Top of foundation elevations along with locations of changes in elevation at steps in foundation. 
h.  Driveway, sidewalks, and patios (Curb catch basins shall not be located in the driveway). 
i.  Utility service locations. 
j.  Existing utility locations. 
k.  Finish garage floor elevation at garage door. 
l.  Top of curb elevation at side property lines extended, curb returns for corner lots, and centerline of driveway. 
m.  Back of sidewalk elevation at side yard lot lines, sidewalk intersections on corner lots, and at centerline of driveway. 
n.  Finish grade elevation at foundation corners. 
o.  Finish grade elevations of patios. 
p.  Top of frame elevation of catch basins and/or inlets in yards and curbs. 
q.  Existing and proposed elevations at grade break points on side and rear lot line. 
r.  Arrows showing direction of overland flow within the lot, along the side and rear lot lines and a driveway along the proposed slope expressed in percent. 
s.  Existing or proposed tops of foundation on all adjacent lots. 
t.  Proposed foundation ties to front, all side yards and rear yards. The distance shall be the shortest distance between the proposed foundation and the property line. 
u.  Existing contour lines within the lot and to a distance of at least twenty-five (25) feet outside the lot. This information should reflect current conditions and not necessarily pre-construction conditions. 
v.  A legend of contour and spot elevation symbols. The casual reviewer should be able to differentiate between existing and proposed elevations. 
w.  This document shall be titled "Proposed Grading Plan" and shall become part of the construction documents. 
The following new subsections shall be added: 
    R-106.2.1 Spot Survey. A spot survey shall be done and filed with the Building Official after the foundation has been completed and prior to framing and shall become a part of the construction documents. The spot survey shall be done by a State of Illinois Registered Land Surveyor and shall have the following information: 
a.  Scale of plan: 1" = 20' or larger, 
b.  North arrow, 
c.  Property lines with dimensions, 
d.  Easement lines, 
e.  Building setback lines, 
f.  Foundation with outside dimensions, 
g.  Distances from all property lines, 
h.  Top of foundation along with changes in elevation at steps in the foundation, 
i.  All changes from the original permit documents submitted, should be noted. 
R106.5 Retention of construction documents shall be amended to read as follows: 
    R106.5 Retention of construction documents. Retention of documents shall be in conformance with the State of Illinois statutes. 
R108 Fees 
R108.2 Schedule of permit fees shall be amended to read as follows: 
    R108.2 Schedule of permit fees. The fees for each plan examination, building permit and inspections, and administrative costs associated with the issuance and supervision of permits shall be prescribed in Chapter 3.08 - Fee Schedules of Village Permits and Services of the Grayslake Municipal Code. 
R109 Inspections 
R109.1.1 Foundation inspection. Delete in its entirety and add the following: 
    R109.1.1 Footing inspection. All footings and pier formwork completed with all earth removed, or trench footing/wall dug out and all formwork completed, and before any concrete has been poured. 
    R109.1.1.1 Foundation wall/drain tile inspection. Upon completion of the foundation walls, stripped of all formwork, with damp proofing applied and all footing drains installed, but before backfilling has been done. 
R109.1.5 Other inspections. Add the following required inspections: 
    R109.1.5.2 Insulation inspection. This inspection is made when insulation is in place and the dwelling is weather tight but before walls and ceilings finishes are applied. 
    R109.1.5.3 Drywall inspection. Commonly made after the entire drywall is in place, but before drywall joints and fasteners are taped and finished. 
    R109.1.5.4 Sewer and water service inspection. Inspection is made prior to backfilling with piping in place and with proper bedding. 
R110 Certificate of Occupancy 
Add the following new section R110.3.1 Record Grading Plan. 
    The following survey shall be filed with the Building Official prior to a Certificate of Occupancy being issued. The survey shall be done by a State of Illinois Registered Land Surveyor or Civil Engineer and shall have the following information: 
a)  Scale of Plan: 1" = 20' or larger, 
b)  North arrow. 
c)  Property lines and dimension. 
d)  Easement lines. 
e)  Building setback lines. 
f)  Plat of survey with foundation ties and dimensions. 
g)  Finished garage floor elevation at edges of driveway. 
h)  Finished back of sidewalk at property lines, sidewalk corner on corner lots, and at driveway edges. 
i)  Ground elevations at foundation corners. 
j)  Elevation at patio corners. 
k)  Spot elevations at rear property corners and at grade breaks on the side and rear lot lines. 
l)  Top of frame elevations at inlets and/or catch basins in the rear yards and curb lines. 
m)  As constructed grade slopes expressed in percent along with arrows showing the direction of surface runoff. 
n)  Certificate by a State of Illinois Registered Land Surveyor or Civil Engineer. 
o)  The document shall be titled "Record Grading Plan" and shall become part of the construction documents for the subject lot. 
R110.4 Temporary occupancy shall be amended by deleting the last sentence of this section and add the following new sentence to the end of this section: 
    Provided further that such certificate issued for temporary occupancy shall expire forty- five (45) days from the date of issuance, or at Building Officials discretion, for safety concerns after which fines may be issued for failure to remedy, correct and/or repair any outstanding code violation or deficiencies in workmanship. Extensions of this grace period may be granted by the Building Official for weather or market conditions beyond control of the permit holder. 
Add the following new section R110.6 Penalty: 
    R110.6 Penalty. Any person firm or corporation who occupies a newly constructed structure or addition to an existing structure without first having obtained a Certificate of Occupancy or Temporary Certificate of Occupancy from the Building Official shall upon conviction of this section be liable of a fine of not less than Fifty dollars ($50.00) or not to exceed Seven Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($750.00). Each day during which any violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
R112 Board of Appeals 
R112.1 General shall be amended to read as follows: 
    The appeals shall follow the existing procedure used by the Zoning Board of Appeals as defined by the Zoning Ordinance. 
R112.2 through R112.4: Delete. 
R113 Violations. 
R113.4 Violation penalties shall be amended to read as follows: 
    R113.4 Violation penalties. Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this code or fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who erects, constructs, alters or repairs a building in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the Building Official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of the code or ordinance, shall upon conviction be liable of a fine of not less than Fifty Dollars ($50.00) or not to exceed Seven Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($750.00). Each day during which any violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
R114 Stop Work Order 
R114.2 Unlawful continuance, change "as prescribed by law" to "as prescribed by Section 114.3" in line 5. 
Add the following new Section 114.3 Penalties: 
    Any person, firm or corporation who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been ordered by the Building Official or his/hers or designee to stop work shall upon conviction of this section be liable of a fine of not less than Fifty Dollars ($50.00) or not to exceed Seven Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($750.00). Each day during which any violation continues shall constitute a separate offence. 
Chapter 2 DEFINITIONS 
R202 Definitions. Add the following definitions: 
    Family. Two (2) or more persons related by blood, marriage, legal adoption, or guardianship, or not more than five (5) persons so not related together with domestic servants and temporary gratuitous guests living together as a single housekeeping unit. 
    Curbside Collection. A method of collecting source separated recyclable materials from the curb or alleyway. 
    Internal Recovery System. The procedures and containers utilized to isolated and remove recyclables from the occupied areas of the building. 
    Municipally Sponsored Recycling Program. A recyclable collection program which is regulated by contract or franchise and which defines levels and frequency of recyclable collection service to be provided to the resident 
    Recyclable Materials (Recyclable). Waste materials that are collected, separated or processed and used as raw materials or products. 
    Recycling. The series of activities by which materials, that would otherwise remain wastes, are collected, separated, processed and used in the form of raw materials. 
    Townhouse (Townhome). Is a single-family dwelling unit constructed in a row of attached units separated by property line, with a minimum two-hour separation and with open space on two sides. Units with floor-ceiling assemblies shall be constructed to the requirements of the International Building Code as an R-2 Occupancy Classification.

Fire rated wall assemble shall contain no plumbing, mechanical equipment, ducts or vents in the cavity of the common wall. R303 Light, Ventilation and Heating 
R303.1 Habitable Rooms shall be amended by adding the following new exceptions: 
4.  Provide light and ventilation by windows or doors in exterior walls with both glazed and ventilation area of not less than two (2%) percent of the basement floor area. 
5.  When the floor of a recreation area is a full level below grade level, provide light and ventilation by windows or doors in the exterior walls of not less than four (4%) percent of the floor area. 
R307 Toilet, Bath and Shower Spaces 
Add the following new section R307.2.1 Wall Covering: 
    R307.2.1 Wall covering. Walls in shower and tub areas shall be sheeted with an approved material before the tub or shower (with or without an enclosure) is set. 
Add the following new section R307.3 Freezing: 
    R307.3 Freezing. No water piping or fixture traps shall be permitted in a wall against an unheated area. Walls or chases with plumbing in them adjacent to walls against unheated areas shall be separated from the unheated areas with an insulated wall sheeted on the inside with an approved sheathing and heating source. 
R309 Garages and Carports 
R309.1 Floor surface shall be amended by adding the following sentence to the end of second paragraph: 
    Floor drains in single family attached or detached garages or carports are prohibited. 
Add the following new section R309.1.1 Opening: 
    R309.1.1 Opening. If a door opening occurs between the garage and the dwelling, provide a minimum of a six (6) inch (153 mm) curb at the door or construct the floor a minimum six (6) inches (153 mm) lower than the adjacent residential floor. The curb requirement shall also apply to stairwells leading from the garage to the basement. 
R309.2 Carports shall be amended to read as follows: 
    R309.2 Carports. Carports shall be open on two sides. Carport floor surfaces shall be approved noncombustible material. Carports not open on at least two sides shall be considered a garage and shall comply with the provisions of this section on garages. If a door occurs between the carport and the residence, provide a minimum of six (6) inch (153 mm) curb at the door or construct the floor a minimum six (6) inches (153 mm) lower than the adjacent residence finish floor. 
    The area of floor used for parking of the vehicles shall be sloped to the main vehicle entry. Floor drains shall be prohibited. 
Add the following new sections: 
    309.5 Detached garages. Detached garages shall comply with the following requirements: 
1.  Concrete floor shall be not less than four (4) inches thick over a base of crushed stone or pea gravel of not less than four (4) inches in depth, with all sod, black dirt or other organic material removed. Thicken slab shall not be less than sixteen (16) inches wide by eighteen (18) inches deep around the entire perimeter of the slab. A minimum of four (4) inches of footing shall be above grade. 
2.  Sill plates connecting the walls to the floor shall be bolted to the foundation. Bolts shall be a minimum of one half (1/2) inch in diameter and spaced on six (6) foot on center not more than one (1) foot from each corner. Install a minimum two anchor bolts per bottom plate. 
3.  Wall studs shall be a minimum of two (2) by four (4) inches, nominal dimension, spaced not more than twenty-four (24) inches on center. Doubling of studs is not required for jambs of wall openings less than three (3) feet, cripples are required for window framing. 
4.  Corner posts shall be a minimum of (2) 2 X 4 studs or (1) 4 X 4 stud. 
5.  Top plates may be single, providing that the roof rafters occur directly over the studs at the top plate, and that all top plate splices, joints and connections at all exterior corners are tied together with framing plates and anchors, heavy gauge steel strapping methods and materials, all properly nails, to securely tie top plates together as a single acting structure unit. 
6.  Wall sheathing may be omitted, provided that each exterior corner is wind-braced with either four (4) foot by eight (8) foot by half (1/2) inch thick plywood or equivalent, one (1) inch by four (4) inch in-let bracing in the top in two directions to a minimum six (6) feet from the corner of the bottom plate. 
7.  All roof rafters must be at least two (2) inches by six (6) inches and spaced not more than twenty-four (24) inches on center. Ridge board shall be a minimum two (2) inches by eight (8) inches. Rafter ties shall be provided at the top plate, at a maximum four (4) feet on center, and shall be securely nailed into the adjoining roof rafter and top plate. No splicing is permitted. Collar ties shall a minimum two (2) inches by six (6) inches spaced four (4) feet on center. If roof trusses are used, truss designs, sealed by a State of Illinois licensed Structural Engineer or Architect shall be filed with Building Department for approval. 
8.  Roof sheathing of not less than one half (1/2) inch thick plywood shall be used with 15 pound felt paper under a minimum of 235 pound seal down asphalt shingles. Minimum 25 years warranty on shingles. 
    R309.8 Detached garage separation. Detached garages and all similar accessory structures shall maintain a ten (10) foot (3048 mm) fire separation from all other structures on the same lot. 
    Exception: See Table R302.6 - Dwelling/Garage Separation. 
R310 Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings 
Add the following new Section R310.2.2 Removable Steel Grate: 
    R310.2.2 Removable steel grate. Each window well for emergency escape and rescue opening shall have a removable steel grate capable of being removed without the use of a special tool or knowledge. 
R311 Means of Egress 
R311.7.5 Landings for stairways delete section and add the following: 
    R311.7.5 Landings. There shall be a floor or landing at the top and bottom of each stairway. 
    Exception: A floor or landing is not required in an enclosed garage, provided a door does not swing over the stairs. All other stairs, including pull down stairs for attics, shall have a landing at the top. A flight of stairs shall not have a vertical rise larger than 12 feet (3658 mm) between floor levels or landings. The width of each landing shall not be less than the width of the stairway served. Every landing shall have a minimum dimension of 36 inches (914 mm) measured in the direction of travel.

R318.1 Moisture control. Add the following sentence to the end of this section: 
    The use of plastic or [visqueen] in the exterior walls and/or the building envelope shall be prohibited. 
R322 Flood-Resistant Construction delete in its entirety. 
The following new section shall be added: 
    R324 Recycling 
    R324.1 Space allocation. A minimum of three (3) cubic feet shall be allocated for an internal recovery system. This area shall be located so as to facilitate storage of recyclable materials within the dwelling and facilitate ease of removal to an external collection point. The internal recovery system may be located in the attached garage or basement area. Building plans for new construction, addition or alterations of existing single family (attached and detached) shall identify the location of the internal recovery system. 
Chapter 4 FOUNDATIONS 
R403 Footings 
R403.1 General delete sub-section and add the following: 
    All exterior walls shall be supported on continuous concrete footings or other approved structural systems which shall be of sufficient design to accommodate all loads according to Section R301 and to transmit the resulting loads to the soil within limitations as determined from the character of the soil. Footings shall be supported on undisturbed natural soils or engineered fill. Concrete footing shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the provisions of Section R403 or in accordance with ACI 332. 
R403.1.1 Minimum size. Change the third sentence in this sub-section to read as follows: 
    Spread footings shall be at least eight (8) inches (203 mm) in thickness. 
R403.1.4.1 Frost protection shall be amended to read as follows: 
    R403.1.4.1 Frost protection. All principal structures and all structures attached to the principal structures shall require a minimum depth for footing placement of 42 inches (1067 mm) below finish grade to provide frost protection. Footings shall not bear on frozen soil.

    404.5.3.1 Wood posts. Wood posts supporting a wood deck or screen porch shall be fastened to a galvanized seat that shall be fastened to a concrete pier. The concrete piers shall be a minimum four (4) inches (102 mm) above grade.

Add the following new section: 
    R502.14 Fire protection I-joist systems and prefabricated trusses. I-joist systems and prefabricated trusses shall have a minimum one-hour rated floor/ceiling or roof/ceiling assembly or shall be protected by an approved NFPA 13R or NFPA 13D fire sprinkler system. Chapter 10 CHIMNEYS AND FIREPLACES 
Section R1004 Factory-Built Fireplaces. 
Section R1004.1 General add the following new subsections: 
    R1004.1.1 Additional combustible air. Factory-built fireplaces using wood or other solid fuels shall be provided with additional combustible air from the outdoors through the use of a UL listed outside kit. The outside kit shall be compatible with the make and model of the factory-built fireplace and shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturers' instructions. 
    R1004.1.2 Direct vent fireplaces. Listed direct vent fireplaces may be installed in all habitable rooms. Listed direct vent fireplaces shall be installed in accordance with manufacturers' instructions. 
    R1004.1.3 Vented gas fireplaces (not including direct vent) located in habitable rooms (not including bathrooms and sleeping rooms). Vented gas fireplaces maybe installed in habitable rooms (not including bathrooms and sleeping rooms) provided that: 
(a)  The fireplace is approved/listed. 
(b)  The habitable room is unconfined space. 
(c)  The fireplace is installed in accordance with the manufacturers' instructions. 
    R1004.1.4 Vented gas fireplaces (not including direct vent) located in bathrooms and sleeping rooms. Vented gas fireplaces (not including direct vent) may be installed in bathrooms and sleeping room provided that: 
(a)  The fireplace is approved/listed. 
(b)  The habitable room is unconfined space. 
(c)  The fireplace is installed in accordance with manufacturers' instructions. 
(d)  An approved/listed carbon monoxide detector is installed inside the bathroom or sleeping room and is energized by the permanent electrical wiring inside the bathroom or sleeping room. The carbon monoxide detector shall be battery backup type. 
    R1004.1.5 Unvented gas fireplaces. 
(1)  Unvented gas fireplaces may be installed in habitable rooms other than bathrooms and sleeping rooms provided: 
(a)  The appliance is approved/listed. 
(b)  The habitable room is an unconfined space. 
(c)  The fireplace is installed in accordance with manufacturers' instructions. 
(2)  Unvented gas fireplaces may be installed in sleeping rooms provided: 
(a)  The sleeping room is an unconfined space. 
(b)  The unvented gas fireplace is set in the wall. 
(c)  The appliance is equipped with an oxygen depletion safety shutoff system. 
(d)  The input rating of the appliance does not exceed 10,000 Btu/hr. 
(e)  The appliance is installed in accordance with the manufacturers' instructions. 
(f)  An approved carbon monoxide detector is installed inside the sleeping room and is energized by the permanent electrical wiring present inside the sleeping room. The carbon monoxide detector shall be battery back up type. 
(3)  Unvented gas fireplaces may be installed in bathrooms provided that: 
(a)  The bathroom is an unconfined space. 
(b)  The unvented gas fireplace is set in drywall. 
(c)  The appliance is equipped with an oxygen depletion safety shutoff system. 
(d)  The input rating of the appliance does not exceed 6,000 Btu/hr. 
(e)  The appliance is installed in accordance with manufacturers' instructions. 
(f)  An approved/listed carbon monoxide detector is installed inside the bathroom and is energized by the permanent electrical wiring present inside the bathroom. The carbon monoxide detector shall be the battery back up type. 
Add the following new section: 
    R1004.5 Decorative appliances for the installation in vented fireplaces. 
    R1004.5.1 Prohibited installations. Decorative appliances for the installation in vented fireplaces shall not be installed in bathrooms or sleeping rooms unless the appliance is listed and the bathroom or sleeping room is an unconfined space. In addition an approved carbon monoxide detector shall be installed in the bathroom or sleeping room and shall be energized by the permanent electrical wiring present in the bathroom or sleeping room. The carbon monoxide detector shall be the battery back up type. 
    R1004.5.2 Installation. A decorative appliance for installation in vented fireplace shall be installed only in a vented fireplace having a working chimney flue and constructed of noncombustible materials. These appliances shall not be thermostatically controlled. 
    R1004.5.3 A listed decorative appliance for installation in a vented fireplace shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturers' instructions. 
    R1004.5.4 Fireplace screens. A fireplace screen shall be installed with a decorative appliance for installation in a vented fireplace. 
    R1004.5.5 Approval for installation. Gas-fire log lighter shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturers' installation instructions. 
    R1004.5.6 Prohibited installations. Gas-fired log lighters shall not be installed in bathrooms or sleeping rooms. 
    R1004.5.7 Combustible and circulating air. Combustible and circulating air shall be provided in accordance with this code. 
Chapter 23 SOLAR SYSTEMS 
Section M2301 Solar Energy Systems. Add the following new sub-sections: 
    M2301.1.1 Zoning regulations involving such requirements as setbacks, height limitations, color, reflectivity or other design considerations shall comply. See Chapter 17 Zoning. 
    M2301.2.2.1 Solar panels shall be low profiled and parallel with the plane of the roof. Top of panels shall not exceed 8 inches (203 mm) above the adjacent finished roofing surfaces. Panels shall not project above the roof ridge line. 
    M2301.2.2.2 Residential buildings with hip roof layout shall have roof mounted modules located in a manner that provides one (1) three-foot (3.0') wide clear pathway from the eave to the ridge on each roof slope where modules are located. The access pathway shall be located at a structurally strong location on the building. 
    M2301.2.2.3 Residential buildings with a single ridge shall have roof mounted modules located in a manner that provides two (2) three-foot (3.0') wide access pathway from the eave to the ridge on each slope where modules are located. 
    M2301.2.2.4 Residential buildings with hip and valleys shall have roof mounted modules located no closer than one and one-half (1.5') foot to hip or valley if modules are placed on both sides of a hip or valley. If roof mounted modules are located on one side of the hip or valley that is of equal length then the modules may be placed directly adjacent to the hip or valley. 
    M2301.2.2.5 Smoke ventilation. Roof mounted modules shall be located no higher than three (3) feet below the ridge.

Add the following new Appendix: 
    Appendix R. Construction Management Regulations for Construction in Existing Residential Zones 
    AR101.1 General. These provisions shall be applicable for construction in existing residential zones. 
    AR101.1.1 Applicant. The applicant shall maintain the construction site and adjoining public ways and public property in a safe and clean condition, including but not limited to compliance with the minimum standards and requirements set forth herein for security fencing, protection of public property and landscaping, sanitation, facilities for collection and removal of debris, loading and storage, until construction of all improvements on the construction site has been completed and, if applicable, a certificate of occupancy issued. 
    AR102 Definitions. 
    AR102.1 General. For the purpose of these provisions, the terms used shall be defined as follows: 
    Applicant. Shall mean, individually and collectively, the owner of the construction site and the applicant for a building permit for the construction site. 
    Construction. Any work on a construction site that: (a) requires the issuance of a demolition permit; or (b) requires the issuance of a building permit for the work that will cause or result in grading, filling or excavation of a construction site, or the increase in the imperious surface coverage of a construction site. 
    Construction Site. A lot, block, tract or parcel of land under unified ownership within a residential zoning district in the Village of Grayslake upon which construction is to take place. 
    Critical Root Zone. Critical root zone shall mean the circular area under a tree determined by a one-foot radius for each one-inch in diameter of the trunk of the tree measured at a point 4 1/2 feet (1372 mm) above the existing grade at the base of the tree. 
    AR103 Requirements. 
    AR103.1 The applicant shall maintain the construction site and adjoining public ways and public property in a safe and clean condition, including but not limited to compliance with the minimum standards and requirements set forth herein for security fencing, protection of public property and landscaping, sanitation, facilities for the collection and removal of debris, traffic and parking control, loading and storage, until construction of all improvements on the construction site has been completed and, if applicable, a certificate of occupancy. 
    AR103.2 Upon notice by the Building Official that the construction site is not in compliance with these provisions, the applicant shall cause the construction site to be brought into compliance within twenty-four (24) hours upon notification. 
    AR103.3 As a condition of any building permit issued for a construction site, the applicant authorizes the Village and it's officers, agents and employees, in the event of any emergency, accident or violation of these provisions that affects or threatens to affect the construction site to the detriment of public health, safety and welfare to take such appropriate actions as may be reasonably necessary to respond to the emergency, accident or violation to this section. 
    AR104 Security. 
    AR104.1 Construction sites shall be enclosed by a security fence at all times from the commencement of any construction activities on the construction site, including but not limited to the delivery and/or storage of construction materials and equipment, until all the following construction activities, if applicable, have been completed on the construction site: 
(a)  demolition of the existing structure; 
(b)  excavating, backfilling and earthmoving; 
(c)  exterior storage of construction materials, equipment, vehicles, spoil or stockpiles; 
(d)  completion of building construction to the point where all buildings on the site are enclosed and secured against unauthorized entry. 
    AR104.2 Security fencing shall be chain link with a height of not less than six (6) feet (1829 mm). Fencing shall be maintained along the full perimeter of the construction site or, with the approval of the Building Official, to a smaller portion of the construction site where all the above described construction activities will be confined to that part of the construction site. 
    AR104.3 The security fence shall be provided with an access gate, which shall be securely locked at the end of each workday and at all times when work is not being done on the construction site. The applicant shall pay the Village a One Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($150.00) locking service fee for each occasion on which the gate is left unlocked and the Village locks or otherwise secures the gate against unauthorized access. Three (3) such violations shall result in a one-day stop work order. Any subsequent violations of this requirement will result in a stop work order on a one-day stop work order basis. 
    AR104.4 The applicant shall submit a site plan for approval by the Building Official depicting the location of the security fencing and the tree protection fencing; in conformance with Chapter 12.16; on the construction site at the same time as the plans are submitted for permit approval for the site. 
    AR105 Construction Debris and Portable Toilet: 
    AR105.1 The applicant shall maintain the construction site in a safe and clean condition at all times, free and clear of construction debris and refuse generated by the demolition, land development and construction activities. 
    AR105.2 Construction debris and refuse containment facilities are required for the construction sites and shall be provided on the construction site within construction dumpsters of an appropriate size for the project, or within such other structures or containers as approved by the Building Official for the project. All such dumpsters, structures or containers shall be covered or enclosed so as to be inaccessible to unauthorized persons at all times when workers are not present performing work on the construction site. 
    AR105.3 The applicant shall cause all construction debris and refuse to be picked up from the grounds of the construction site and deposited into approved construction debris and refuse containment facilities not less often than at the end of each workday. The applicant shall further cause the construction debris and refuse to be collected and removed in accordance with Chapter 15.56 - Construction and Demolition Debris Recycling from the construction site by scavengers using covered or contained vehicles for deposal in accordance with all applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations. 
    AR105.4 Unless or until construction workers will be accommodated by existing toilet facilities on the construction site, a portable toilet shall be provided by the applicant upon commencement of construction activities and maintained until the completion of construction activities. The location of the portable toilet shall be set back a minimum six (6) feet (1829 mm) from all property lines. All portable toilets shall be emptied, cleaned and restocked as needed in compliance with all local, state and federal laws and regulations. 
    AR106 Protection of Streets and Public Property. 
    AR106.1 Unless permission has been granted by the Village to defer the replacement or repair of public property damaged or destroyed during construction, the applicant shall promptly cause all public ways, utility easements, landscaping and other public property disturbed, damaged or destroyed as a result of construction activities on the construction site, including but not limited to street pavement, curbs, sidewalks, sewers, drainage systems, street lights, and other public improvements, to be repaired and restored to a condition as good and serviceable as before such damage or disturbance prior to a certificate of occupancy being issued. 
    AR106.2 Construction vehicles shall use the driveway to enter the construction site from the adjacent roadway. If there is no driveway on the construction site, the applicant shall install a temporary driveway approved by the Building Official too be used for access to the site. 
    AR106.3 The applicant shall, until the cessation of construction activity and the issuance of a certificated of occupancy, maintain that part of any public street, alley, parkway, sidewalk or other public property adjacent to the construction site, or used as a route for construction traffic, in a safe condition and clear of mud, dirt and debris deposited thereon. 
    AR106.4 If a sidewalk exists adjacent to the construction site, it shall be maintained and kept available, clean and unobstructed to provide safe pedestrian walkway at all times during construction unless otherwise directed by the Building Official. 
    AR106.5 If it is necessary to remove a sidewalk to facilitate construction, the applicant shall provide a temporary walkway approved by the Village Engineer that is readily accessible and usable by individuals with disabilities to the maximum extent feasible. The applicant shall restore and replace the permanent sidewalk as soon as possible, weather permitting. 
    AR107 Traffic and Parking 
    AR107.1 All construction activities, including deliveries, shall be preformed so as that there is minimum interference with pedestrian and vehicular traffic. 
    AR107.2 The applicant shall not perform any work with respect to a construction site, or permit any such work to be preformed, that will partially or completely block vehicular traffic on a public roadway, or access to any residence, business or institution, without prior approval from the Village. 
    AR107.3 The applicant is responsible for providing and installing warning signs, protection devices and flaggers, meeting all applicable federal, state and local requirements, when necessary for the protection of the public and the workers when any work is being performed that will partially or completely block vehicular traffic on a public road. The Village Engineer may require that additional traffic protection measures be taken where he/she determines that additional traffic protection measures are warranted because of the nature, location or time of the work to be performed. 
    AR108 Right to Enter 
    AR108.1 Every applicant seeking a construction permit from the Village shall submit a written authorization, binding on the property owner, made on a form provided by the Village, granting the Village and its officers, agents and employees permission and authority to enter upon the construction site to take remedial action as necessary to cure the applicant's failure to comply with this section. 
    AR109 Penalty 
    AR 109.1 Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this code or fails to comply with any of the requirements of these provisions shall be liable to a fine of not less than Fifty Dollars ($50.00) or more than Seven Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($750.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separated offense. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-05, § 3, 1-15-2013) 
15.52.030 - Repeal. 
    All parts of this chapter in conflict herewith, but only to the extent of such conflict, are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-05, § 4, 1-15-2013) 
15.52.040 - Severance clause. 
    If any provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, subsection, or part of this chapter, or the application thereof to any person, firm, corporation, or circumstance, shall, for any reason, be adjudged by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid, said judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder of this chapter or the application of such provision to other persons, firms, corporations, or circumstances, but shall be confined in its operation to the provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, subsection, or part thereof directly involved in the controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered and/or to the person, firm, corporation, or circumstance involved. It is hereby declared to be the legislative intent of the corporate authorities that this chapter would have been adopted had such invalid provision or provisions not been included or if it had not been made applicable to such person, firm, corporation, or circumstance. 
    Any rule, regulation, or ordinance in conflict with the provisions hereof is hereby repealed, but to the extent of such conflict only. This Ordinance [Chapter 15.52] shall be designated Ordinance No. 2013-0-05 and shall be in full force and effect ten (10) days after its passage and approval in accordance with the law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-0-05, § 5, 1-15-2013) 



Chapter 15.56 - CONSTRUCTION AND DEMOLITION DEBRIS RECYCLING 

15.56.010 - Construction and demolition debris recycling. 
A.  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    "Applicant" means a person who applies to the village for the applicable permits to undertake any construction project that is subject to this section. 
    "Code official" means the building commissioner of the Village of Grayslake. 
    "Construction" means all on-site work done in building new structures from land clearance to completion, including excavation, erection and the assembly and installation of components and equipment without limitation 
    "Construction and demolition debris" or "C&D debris" means non-hazardous, uncontaminated materials resulting from the construction, remodeling, repair, and demolition of utilities, structures, and roads, limited to the following: bricks, concrete, and other masonry materials; soil; rock; wood, including non-hazardous painted, stained, treated and coated wood and wood products; wall coverings; plaster; drywall; plumbing fixtures; non-asbestos insulation; roofing shingles and other roof coverings; reclaimed or other asphalt pavement; glass plastics that are not sealed in a manner that conceals waste; electrical wiring and components containing no hazardous substances; and corrugated cardboard, piping or other metals incidental to any of those materials. 
C&D debris does not include excavated soil or land clearing debris. This includes landscaping. 
C&D debris that is processed for use at a landfill means C&D debris that is processed for use as a municipal solid waste landfill unit as alternative daily cover road building material in accordance with the landfill's waste disposal permit issued by the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
    "Demolition" means the razing and removal of all or substantially all of a structure, including at least one exterior wall, or the removal of such portions of a principal structure or at least one exterior wall as to make the structure uninhabitable or unsafe for human occupancy. 
    "Department" means the department of building and zoning of the village. 
    "Divert and diversion" means to manage, sort and process C&D debris into recyclable C&D debris, recovered wood that is processed for use as fuel, and/or C&D debris that is processed for use at a landfill. 
    "Inert debris" means those materials which are virtually inert, such as rock, brick and concrete 
    "Permit" means any building or demolition permit as validly issued by the village. 
    "Project" means any project, unless otherwise exempt under this section for construction, renovation or demolition that meets one or more of the following thresholds: 
- Construction of new structures of two thousand (2,000) square feet or more of gross floor area. 
- Renovations of two thousand (2,000) square feet or more of gross floor area. 
- Any size of demolition. 
- Any residential or commercial construction or renovation project of four or more individual units. 
    "Renovation" means the improvement alteration, repair, or reconstruction of an existing structure 
    "Recovered wood that is processed for use as fuel" means wood that has been salvaged from C&D debris and processed for use as fuel, as authorized by any applicable state or federal environmental regulatory authority, and supplied only to intermediate processing facilities for sizing, or to combustion facilities for use as fuel, that have obtained all necessary waste management and air permits for handling and combustion of the fuel. 
    "Recyclable C&D debris" means C&D debris that has been rendered reusable and is reused or that would otherwise be disposed of or disposed of or discarded but is collected separated, or processed and returned to the economic mainstream in the form of raw materials or products. "Recyclable C&D debris" does not include C&D debris processed for use as a fuel or for use at a landfill. 
B.  Applicability. 
1.  This section applies to all projects within the Village of Grayslake except as set forth in paragraph 2 of this subsection. 
2.  This section shall not apply in any of the following circumstances: 
a.  When an immediate or emergency demolition that is required to protect the public health, safety, or welfare, as determined prior to such demolition by the code official. 
b.  When an exception is granted pursuant to subsection F of this section. 
C.  Condition of Approval for Building or Demolition Permits. Compliance with the provisions of this section is a condition of approval for all building or demolition permits issued for any project, unless the project is otherwise exempt from permitting requirements. 
D.  Diversion Requirements. At least seventy-five (75) percent of C&D debris from a site must be diverted, of that amount of C&D debris use at a landfill shall not exceed thirty-five (35) percent of the amount of C&D debris diverted for all projects subject to this section and for which a building or demolition permit has been processed. 
E.  Compliance Report. 
1.  Not less than five business days prior to the scheduled date for the final inspection of a project subject to this section, the applicant shall submit to the department a compliance report on a form provided by the department. The compliance report must include the following information, and such other information as the department may require: 
- The date(s) demolition and/or construction actually commenced; 
- The actual weight of C&D debris that was generated at the project site, divided between inert debris and other debris; 
- The actual weight of inert and other C&D debris that was diverted to achieve the seventy-five (75) percent diversion requirement with documentation on how the diversion requirement was met; 
- A specification of the method used to determine the weight and a certification that the method used was the most accurate, commercially reasonable method available; 
- Original receipts from all vendors and facilities which collected or received C&D debris, indicating actual weights received by each; 
- Certifications from the general contractor and any vendor or facility that handled C&D debris, indicating actual weights received by each; 
- Certifications from the general contractor and any vendor or facility that handled C&D debris stating the extent to which the project complies with the requirements of this section; and 
- Additional reporting requirements may be added at the discretion of the code official. 
2.  Submission of a compliance report and, if applicable, payment of any penalties set forth in this section is a condition precedent to the following: 
- Issuance of any certificate of occupancy; and 
- Determination that a property has been restored to the reasonable satisfaction of the code official. 
3.  When reporting C&D debris weights, the contractor shall calculate the weight in tons and round to the nearest hundredth (example: 49.537 tons shall be rounded up to 49.54 tons, and 49.533 tons shall be rounded down to 49.53 tons). When converting pounds to tons, the contractor shall use the conversion factor of one ton equals 2,000 pounds (example: 500 pounds divided by 2,000 equals .25 tons). If a waste hauler or recycler reports C&D debris accepted or received as a volume measurement, the contractor shall be responsible for converting the volume measurement into a weight measurement. Upon request by the department, the contractor shall provide information to justify the accuracy of the conversion. 
4.  For each project for which the contractor uses a waste hauler or recycler as defined by this section, the contractor shall submit one or more forms entitled "Construction and Demolition Debris Log and Waste Hauler/Recycler Affidavit" to the building department together with the C&D debris recycling compliance report. The hauler/recycler affidavit shall be on a form prescribed by the commissioner, and shall include a C&D debris log which accounts for the weight or volume of all C&D debris collected or accepted from the waste hauler or recycler. The hauler/recycler affidavit shall be signed by a notary public by an individual with the knowledge to certify the weight or volume of C&D debris that was accepted or collected. 
F.  Exceptions. 
1.  Exceptional Project Circumstances. Applicants seeking a partial or complete exception granting relief from the requirements of this section must file with the department an application on a form provided by the department. The application must include, in addition to such other information as the department may require, a statement from a licensed professional engineer certifying that compliance with this section is impracticable due to exceptional or extraordinary circumstances or conditions applicable to the project. The code official may grant the exception only if the code official in his or her sole determination finds all of the following: 
- There are exceptional or extraordinary circumstances or conditions applicable to the project that do not apply generally to similar projects and that make compliance with this section impracticable. 
- Granting the exception will not constitute a grant of special privilege inconsistent with limitations imposed on similar projects which are subject to this section. 
- Cost to the applicant of strict compliance with this section is not the primary reason for granting the exception. 
2.  Cost Based Exception. If a contractor receives a minimum of two quotes for a recycling option and a garbage option and the recycling option is in excess of ten percent of the garbage option the contractor will be exempted from [this section]. 
G.  Inspections, Inquiries and Audits. The code official may make any and all inspections, inquiries and audits as necessary to determine compliance with this section. 
H.  Enforcement and Penalties. Applicants who fail to satisfy the diversion requirements established in this section or otherwise comply with the requirements of this section are subject to the penalties set forth in the village code. 
I.  Appeals. Any person or entity aggrieved by any decision by the code official under the provisions of this section or to granting or denying an application for an exception from compliance with this section may file an appeal pursuant to the village code. 
(Ord. No. 2012-0-05, § 2, 2-7-2012) 
Title 16 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Chapters:
